reviews.review: Best view from the top. There are many photos from 1820 but I was especially impressed with the view from its terrace. The terrace is high enough to see whole Marrakech.
Very nice expositions. Very nice expositions and the restaurant on the rooftop is very good and the beautiful view over the medina.
Very Old Photos. Very old photos chronicle the history of the country. It is wonderful to see the expressions caught film. I was amazed how so like today so many of the faces in the photos looked.
NIce place to see sunset. The photographs were OK and it's a really small museum but it was a nice place to have tea, listen to Quran and watch sunset

Small but interesting. This is a small museum with mainly old photos of the town and its inhabitants, some dating back to the 1880s. It was very interesting, but a touch limited in scope. The rooftop terrace is pleasant enough, but overrated by guide books.

Photographic viewing. Great old private house of interest that has been turned into a museum of photography of the local area and tribes - it is set over 4/5 floors and has some wonderful old photos as well as explanations of history and tribes - a must visit if in the area

Morrocan history through the camera lens. The Photography Museum in Marrakech is a wonderful gem and definitely worth a visit. An amazing collection of photographs from the past 100 years or so record Morrocan life in a high quality range of photographs. The short video currently being shown from the 1950's of a visit into the Berber villages also provides an amazing cultural experience.

Tranquillity . After escaping from the busy, stuffy streets this is a peaceful oasis where you can relax and gather your thoughts with some fantastic examples of authentic photography showing Moroccan life. The rooftop terrace is shaded with gloriously cool drinks (or a hot mint tea) and with views over the city, will allow you to regroup and plan the next part of your adventure.
Worth having a look. It was a nice place to visit and I was really interested in watching the documentary movie playing upstairs. Good to see some old photographs.

A fascinating record of old Morocco. A large collection of stunning photographs from the 19th and 20th centuries set over three floors, with a rare 1958 film following Berber tribes. There is also a cafe on the roof.We had some trouble finding this museum as it is well hidden in the Medina and locals keep removing the signs as they would rather make money by taking people there. Be warned, you will be approached by people offering to take you, but they will demand payment. We only paid 20dh, but we were quite close by then anyway. Our "guide" was not impressed, however. If you have a smart phone app - use it. It's cheaper and less confrontational.

Wonderful photographs - well worth a visit. There are an amazing collection of photographs on display that portray Morocco's beautiful past and the portraits are just simply beautiful.
There is a wide selection of copies of the photos that you can purchase.
The lovely building and the sanctuary is provides from the maddening crowds is an added bonus.
Well worth a visit.
Lovely.... Nice way to spend an hour or two. Lovely building, beautiful pictures and atmospheric lunch on the rooftop...
ranks high for museums. the museum gave you a great history of the country and how far its come. helps with understanding to culture

Insightful glimpse into history. We found the museum with a little help from the staff at the nearby Ben Youssef Medresa. We didn't really struggle to find it but as with many places in Marrakech, some patience is needed to find where you are going. Entrance is 20dh per person. We spent our time looking through three floors of historical photos of Morocco - particularly on Marrakech and Tangier - and really enjoyed what we saw. Information is in English too. It's a quiet place and serene spot in this city. It might not be for everyone but we very much enjoyed looking at the portraits and photographs and watched a short documentary upstairs on the Berber people. We finished off with a drink on the roof terrace which has fantastic views of Marrakech! Would recommend to lovers of art and photography - it gives you some great inspiration for photos of your own!
lovely place to visit. this private museum is situated just behind the Ben Youssef Medersa and is very well sign posted. Very interesting collection of old photos and lovely roof terrace cafe

Awesome. Awesome! A nice calm spot in the middle of the hectic Medina. The photographs were typically early 20th century. On the top floor of the museum there is also a terrace to look out over the old city. Admissions was 40 dirham and if you keep the ticket you can return for free.
Excellent museum. Great to visit if you are interested in photography or the history of Morroco and Marrakech!And a nice cafe with good views on the roof
Wonderful photographs. Both the inherent quality and the historical significance of these photographs make this a place well worth visiting.

Nice collection of old moroccan photography. Beautiful building that has a nice collection of old moroccan photography. Small, but beautiful. It has a coffee shop terrase in which you could stop to have a rest.

Hidden gem and a window to the past . A small museum with an interesting range of photographs showing the history of Morocco. The quality of the pictures are amazing when you consider when they were taken and they show that many of the traditions still remain. The building is one the stars of the show and has been beautifully restored. A pleasant rooftop cafe is a great way to end a visit.

The magic of old photos.. Its amazing how silver plates from old days are able to produce such clear images.Well curated museum. Deep into Medina , difficult to find, so be informed about the location in advance .

Look at the photography, then eat a tagine on the rooftop.. This small, but fascinating photography museum is a haven out of the heat and the madness of the medina and markets. Get an insight into the first travel photography in Morocco.
Loved this place. It was beautiful because the pictures displayed showed the true face of Morocco. Pictures of Berber girls and boys, old school parties and nomads. Very interesting and beautiful.

Good but small museum, excellent cafe. This is quite easy to find on the street. On entrance there is a small area selling prints. The entrance fee is 40dhs. Which considering the relative small size of the museum (and other attractions) is relatively expensive. However the staff are friendly and knowledgable. They give a introduction to the photographs. The museum has a central courtyard and pictures in the rooms around (much like a riad). There are three floors. In one room there is a documentary about a French photographer who visited a mountain range, I think it was in the 1950s. The rest of the pictures are very good, but there really is not that many. As I noted, the space is not bigger then a riad. I do love photography but to call it a 'museum' I would expect more about the history of photography there. This is meant as constructive criticism. The space felt more like an good exhibition. Perhaps moving to a larger space would work better? However the cafe on the top floor is excellent. Staff are great, food is super and very reasonable. It's good to chill out there on a hot afternoon. Actually it made the visit. Without a cafe I don't think I would have enjoyed it. But does that make visiting the museum worthwhile? That's up to you.

Not exactly a museum. Basically a small room with some pictures, wouldn't go as far as to call it a museum. I find it difficult to understand how it is actually labeled a museum. I wouldn't waste much time trekking to see it,if youre passing maybe pop in but that'd be it.

Fascinating photography. The photography gave an interesting perspective of traditional Moroccan life. The price is slightly higher than other attractions (but still not too expensive), but more explanation of the exhibits is available. If your hotel doesn't have a rooftop terrace or you are tired from walking around, I recommend the cafe on their rooftop. It was a great place to relax.

Fascinating visit. Once we eventually found the museum we had a very interesting visit. There was lots of information in English and the range of photographs was excellent. We also enjoyed the roof top cafe with its view of the medina. Highly recommended.

Gorgeous. Visited September 2016 as a couple.We had mistakenly visited a museum nearby while trying to find the photography museum, but after finding the place (with a little help from the previous museum attendants) we were very glad to have visited! Once you pay the cheap entrance fee, you walk through long draping curtains into a courtyard area, and walk towards the stairs where your visit begins.The collection of photography in this museum is fantastic, and it is truly fascinating to see pictures of old times. With each collection is a brief about the photographer and how they came to take the photos or how they become synonymous with Moroccan photography.There was a video (15-20 minutes long) about a French mans journey (I can't remember his name) through the Moroccan mountains, and of course a few of his photos. There are some open books which describe the coloured photography techniques used in taking some pictures, and then a 'dark' room to see some examples.Truly, the pictures are wonderful and well taken. Seeing past photos of the Koutoubia Mosque to what we saw was moving.Visit this museum!

Very Enjoyable, Good Insight into History. Glad we finally found this place (it's a bit of a trek) as it was well worth the visit. The photos convey the history of the area well and copies of many are available for purchase. The restaurant on the roof is nice for a bit and a break.
Great place to visit.. Lovely pictures, interesting film. A very enjoyable experience. Good views from the rooftop cafe which offers a nice respite.

Hidden Gem. It had long been on my radar to come and see this place, but the opportunity hadn't presented itself until our recent holiday in Marrakech. The trek (and by trek I mean leisurely walk) from the old town through the Souks was a nice way to begin a day out, and despite some opportunist sellers and helpful cries of, "It's closed, come and see Tanneries...", the Museum was an oasis of calm and tranquility. The exhibitions are diligently curated and the quality of the prints are second to none. There really is a history of the Berber villages and the development of both the city and people of Morocco. Each level was filled with two to three photographers pieces, with plenty of guidance in English as to what was on display. Capping off the visit is a shaded rooftop terrace overlooking the city and Atlas Mountains. Plus, it also has a toilet that doesn't require you to dig out a couple of Dirham to the tip the attendee. Thumbs up chaps!

A hidden treasure in marrakesh. Coincidentally and while walking in the old city we discovered the Maison de la Photographie It is a nice and quite place to visit while staying in Marrakesh. In this house you can feel how people used to live in Marrakesh. The young team are helpful and they did a good job restoring this place.On the roof you can have nice view of Marrakesh from the top or over the roofs while enjoying a cup of tea.

great museum - if you can find it!. Fabulous collection of photographs - relaxed and peaceful atmosphere. When I visited there was a group being guided by a curator so I eavesdropped a little bit and gained some fascinating insights into the history of the collection and museum.Great roof bar/cafe with views over the rooftops of the city.

Very beautiful and peaceful. It was great getting out of the hustle and bustle and see photographs of marrakech in 1910-1920's. The photos are essential excellent and it's well worth the look around. There is roof top terrace with fantastic views of the medina and the atlas mountains in the distance.
Worth seeing..... Some beautiful photos on display... the rooftop terrace is the perfect place sit for a while sipping mint tea looking out over the city & towards the Atlas mountains...

Wonderful old photos. We had not planned to visit, but passed by and thought, why not? It was very much worth the time, the old photos of old Morocco were in many cases so similar of the Morocco of today.

Rewind time..... I enjoyed browsing through old but beautiful photographs. It was fascinating to see faces, streets, people and made me connect with the Marrakech of the past. I was surprised at my reaction but I enjoyed it and thought it was time well spent.
Very nice rooftop. A very interesting and detailed museum of the photography history. A variety of high quality pictures throughout the museum that keeps you engaged

Unmissable. Beautiful photography, lovingly displayed and presented. Gorgeous building and a great rooftop terrace, where we had a light and delicious lunch with drinks. Best place for culture in Marrakech!

Travel in time. The pictures are about how was Marroco in the past!! some places you will be surprise they haven´t changed but you need to go to the atlas and the desert to see that!! is worth going and it has a great restaurant in the terrace for 10 us a set menu.
Great pictures. An exposition of great historical photographies from the time of the presence of the French in Morocco. You'll be surprised how much didn't change since those times.
Cool terrace and photos. The museum itself can be viewed in an hour. On a hot day the terrace at the top is a lovely, cool place to rest your legs and sip mint tea.

Nice rooftop terrace. The rooftop terrace offered great views and the museum was presented well and offered a nice space to wander around. It didn't take long but the ticket enabled a return trip during the visit to Marrakech which was welcomed.

Worth a visit. Some fantastic photos of old Marrakech with a lot of pictorial history on the walls.
Good insite into the type of photography and developing processes used at the time.

wonderful gallery. So worth a visit, an excellent selection and history of Moroccan photography within a beautiful light filled building. Wind you way to the top for a good view and a cold fresh lemon and mint to cool you off.

Best Terasse. The little museum shows you old photographs from marrakech. It's really interesting to see the change between the now and the past. Even better is the beautiful terasse to have a mint tea.

Not so much!!. It is a walking distance from Ben youssef madrassa. Really small museum, it can be finished in less than 30 minutes. Just some old photos from old Marrakech.
They have a small terrace where you can take a break From the medina hassle.
Interesting . In my top 10 things to do in marrakesh. Lovely cafe on the roof terrace too, with a great view. The museum was bigger than I had expected too. But still small enough to feel special.
Relaxing Day. We went to this museum and we saw beautiful pictures for Morocco. We also saw the pictures of the berbers and different cultures. The roof top was an amazing view of Marrakesh.

Worth the winding walk to find this little gem!. This is a hidden gem right in the heart of the Marrakech souks. Not necessarily easy to find or well sign posted, this is a lovely little place to visit. The exhibition is nicely laid out in a beautiful Moroccan house. The space is cool and welcoming; and there are plenty of descriptions of all the photos in English and French so it's easy to understand and learn about the photographs and photographers. There is a roof terrace on the top which is a great place to stop before leaving for a cheeky mint tea. Am very glad to have found and visited this museum on our trip to Marrakech.
Great little museum with terrific terrace. This was a very pleasant and interesting museum to wander through, with a beautiful rooftop terrace to enjoy a cool drink at - well worth stopping by.

Make sure Watch documentaries . Make sure you watch the documentary upstairs. English sub Titles. From 1957 first visit to Atlas Mountains with movie camera. Captured old Morocco. Dances. Food people. Agricultural practices. Really interesting. Good roof top terrace. Mint and Citron.

not so easy to find, took us 3 goes and the third was on a tuk tuk but so worth it. calm, tranquil, informative with a wonderful rooftop pit stop/refreshing rest - wonderful photographs and art in a hectic area, great to escape and immerse yourself in the history - wpuld like to go back on my own, without my 6 year old
Interesting place !. We liked our visit at Maison de la photographie. We learned allot about maroccaine history and berberian culture. Cheap entrance too.

Highly recommended. A gorgeous Riad with a pristine collection of vintage photographs. Simply beautiful and well worth visiting ! The cafe on the rooftop is an oasis in the hustle and bustle of the Medina with very good coffee, cakes and small snacks.

Surprisingly Good. Well worth a visit, 3 main reasons - 1. its beautifully cool and calm when you want a bit of respite from the souks2. photo collection is really interesting and well presented, 3. rooftop cafe is great - cool, calm, good food and service, views over the city and out to the Atlas mountains.Really enjoyed it.

Beautiful & Informative. The museum is very well laid out over three floors with excellent information in both English and French. The photographs are beautiful capturing the history of both Marrakech and French colonism. The shop offers postcards and some trinkets not too much in the way of books, but some pamphlets.
If you're passing, go in.. This museum has some wonderful old photographs of Marrakesh and Morocco. It also has a very good café on the roof which makes for a good visit around morning tea time.
Great Photography. Whether or not you are interested in photography you will find this place of interest. A lovely calming environment in which to exhibit some great photographs through the ages

Absolute gem. We took the advice of other reviewers and visited this museum. So glad we did. The photos are so interesting and the layout is just perfect. Lovely shady rooms to soak up the images and the environment. The roof terrace at the top is the perfect reward for your walk up, and has lovely far reaching views and shady cover from flowering plants. I'd visit again at the drop of a hat.

Beautiful haunting Photographs. This museum is near to my Riad so just up an alley way so to speak,I must say before even looking at the Photographs ,the staff here are so nice and kind .The building has a nice feel about it and calming environment .Some of the Photography goes back to the 1880's and are amazing to gaze into the past ,looking more like works of Art which they are!It was so hot the day I walked in and really wanted a cold drink ( 107 degree's)That I went to the roof terrace first and had a lovely cold mint and lemon drink ,they even let me keep the fan on tables .The man serving was one of the nicest people I have ever met!The entrance ticket can be used again ,which is good as I felt too hot to concentrate on the interesting photographs and a film from 1957 also.Please visit this place.
Top photos. Lovely place to walk around and see the history of Morocco through the eyes of some great photographers. The terrace at the top of the museum gives a great view of Marrakech

A little gem. It may not be that easy to find (even though there are directions) but the Photography Museum draws an interesting perspective on Morocco and Marrakech through a vast collection of photographies. While it is not a huge place, you will easily spend 1h or more in this fascinating universe. Besides, it is on the way to the Medersa Ben Youssef so there is no excuse for not paying a visit to the Photography Museum of Marrakech
An interesting place. It s a little bit hard to find this art place but it is worth of it. The personal is gentle. And it is near the famous moskeija.
Surprisingly interesting. It's a time travel. Worth the price. Breathtaking photos. It's hard to find and a bit far, but be sure to make a stop.
Rare and fascinating archive of Moroccan life. Patrick has amassed some wonderful archive photographs. If you love photography and are visiting Marrakech, don't miss this.
Fabulous, high quality museum.. Really interesting place. Fabulous, well priced food on the top terrace. Can highly recommend anyone to visit.

Very Interesting Photographs. You get a bit of a history lesson as you view some very old photographs Take the time to view all three levels of displays then continue up to the rooftop terrace for views over the Marrakech roofs.

Best rooftop ever. Good photos collection in a sublime riyad. The rooftop is inescapable : enjoy a fresh juice, for example lemon-minth, while having one of the best view on Marrakech. We have stared at until lunch and we had a delicious tajine kefta for a nice price. Quiet place, ventilated so nice when the heat break the thermometer

Amazing view. Interesting museum and the rooftop view and bar restaurant area were really beautiful! ps: The ticket has a validity of four days so you can come back another day for a tea in the bar or something!

Good place to visit. Changing exhibitions. Great, when I was there. Old photos from Marrakech and Morocco in general.
The roof terrace is also great for a drink and the view
Must see. The vintage photographs are a must to grasp the recent history of this rich country. The rooftop terrace offers exception lunches at reasonable prices.
A place to see. Old Marrakech and Marocco by pictures. The roof terrace have beautiful views of the Medina. You will be surprised of how litle life has changed in this place.

Stunning photography. This little museum is packed full of incredible photos from the past century and beyond. They demonstrate the different ways of living win the various parts of Morocco and give great explanations of each artist and image taken. There is also an amazing cafe upstairs, which is a must! The food is gorgeous, the views are breathtaking - with 6 mosques in view, and even better it is so cheap!! A definite Marrakech must do!

Evocative. This private foundation-run museum is a must-see and really a hidden gem. In the medina close to the Museum of Marrakech and the Ben Youssef Medersa. We were impressed with the professional and highly informative displays of culture and history through photographs of the Moroccan people of the area through the years.Pearls for an even better visit:-Have lunch or coffee/tea in the museum cafe on the rooftop. Good prices and great view.-Buy a photograph reproduction in the small gift shop below. Good prices and beautiful images.-Try to see some of the other exhibits advertised by the museum. We were in Essaouira and saw one about the Gnawa that was highly memorable as well.

Interesting if you are a appreciate old photography. There are some really incredible images that tell the story of the country from the turn of the century. I enjoyed the museum and it was well worth at least 30 minutes.
Mind blowing. Spend an evening watching the shows, enjoy the freshly squeezed orange juice. Find a great restaurant and people watch.

Well Worth It. The Photography Museum is, extraordinarily, a sort of oasis and a break from the souks and a very different attraction in the heart of Marrakech. It is close to the Madrasseh Ben Youssef, so there's no reason not to combine the visit. It is relatively small, but very well done and very interesting. In addition to the remarkably good photography itself, there is a very nice little restaurant (we had only a lovely cold drink on a very hot day) and an excellent loo. Very much recommended

Interesting portrayal of Marrakesh through the years. Our visit to the museum was very interesting. The pictures and artifacts on display tell a unique and insightful story of the city, and we learnt a lot that we would have never known otherwise.The atmosphere was good - the museum was cool and quiet, and the crowd was well dispersed amongst the different levels.This is a great experience for those that wish to learn more about the history of the city, and to take a step back from the busy medina.

Very interesting piece of culture and history. I heard quite a bit of raving about the Ben Youssef Madrasa from other ladies attending the yoga retreat I was on, but for me it was the Photography Museum that resonated far more.The photography is good, but what makes it so interesting is what it captures. You can see what the Souks used to look like, there's a lot about tribal culture (whereas nowadays you don't see much skin show on the streets of Marrakech, in the museum there are photos of tribal women with their shoulders uncovered), there's a portrait of a slave (I didn't realize slavery was part of Marrakech history). All of that made this really interesting for me.It also has a lovely-looking cafe with a great view at the top. Unfortunately, I didn't have time to sit down in it, but I definitely will if I have another opportunity to visit Marrakech.
Best view. It is a small exhibition but worth a visit as the restaurant provides an escape from the madness of the market. Food was nice and the breeze very cooling.

Fascinating photographs and lovely food. Very interesting photographs showing morocco through the last hundred years or so, including some interesting photos of the main square over time. It is set in a peaceful riad, which has a nice roof terrace, serving very nice tagines at reasonable prices.
Would highly recommend to spend an hour or two.
Hidden gem. This museum has an excellent collection of historic photographs of Morocco which were high quality, well displayed and really interesting. Well worth a visit.
Good!. Nice collection of pictures mostly dating from the first half of the 20th century. There's also a rooftop terrace overlooking the medina with lunch and drinks for very reasonable prices.

Great stop. The photography museum is great for the history of Marrakesh & Morocco. It is quite small so you will great through it in probably 1-2 hours. The staff is very polite and friendly. Go around lunch and eat lunch here, they have a restaurant on the terrace with a wonderful aerial view of the city. The lunch is delicious and very reasonably priced.

Amazing food for very cheap and lovely gallery. My friend and I visited here after reading in one of our guide books about the amazing food! We were not disappointed. The service was amazing and we both had the set menu of the moroccon salad, the fresh juice (mint and lemon which was like a non-alcoholic mojito!) a tagine and fresh fruit. The salad was AMAZING! So fresh and so many amazing flavours and the rest was so tasty as well. The gallery itself was also very interesting and clean.
A quiet break from the medina.. Glad we visited this place. We loved the old photos and film. A bonus was the terrace cafe with nice salads.

Beautiful photographs. This is the best photography museum in Marrakech - lots of photographs both modern and older and is a great place to visit if you like photography. You ticket gives you lifelong membership so you can go back for another look if you like. It has a fantastic cafe on the roof with lots of shade and very reasonably priced - you might have to pop your head into the kitchen to ask for service but that is part of its charm. The cafe alone is a reason for popping back whilst you are in Marrakech and it has some fantastic photographs.
Beautiful pictures of the culture!. This was a very nice museum, great little cafe at the top. You can re enter if you save your ticket.

beautiful and fascinating. beautiful photos and a very interesting video. cool to see how europeans have been enchanted by morocco for centuries. It is a land lost to time-- it was then and in some respects still is now. It would be nice to have more information in English. There is some, but there is far more in French.

Small but excellent museum. I am passionate about photography especially in the North Africa region, and I found this small museum to be a very interesting gem in the city. The exhibits did not follow strict specialized/historical paths but highlighted very interesting photographers and early practices in the field. I have seen there one of the best photography shows in a long time.
Well worth a visit. Good photographies, interesting short movie and possibility to buy postcards of several of the photographs in the galerie.
Interesting. Loved the place. The photos are very interesting, you notice how many of Marrakech areas have not really changed in 80 years! Also nice to enjoy the view the roof terrace!
Nice museum with terrace cafe. This is a terrific little museum containing the earliest taken photos of Marrakech and a nice terrace cafe to enjoy a drink after strolling through.

Oasis in the middle of chaotic Medina . I don't normally write reviews but this place definitely deserves one. I went there on a late afternoon when they almost closed but then I got told by the friendly guy at the reception that the ticket can be used on another day. Managed to see some of the beautiful exhibition.Came back few days later (after the tiring journey into the desert), the guy still recognized me and let me in without even showing the ticket. It was really a perfect oasis after the journey and being lost sooo many times in the buzzling and chaotic medina. Beautiful building and pictures, cosy rooftop cafe with good food (and live music from street beggar down on the street), friendly staff - and european standard toilet! Literally my great escape place in the middle of hectic Marrakech.

not your average Marrakech tourist attraction. Nice surprise. This is not on an average route that I know of so needs to be hunted out a bit but when we got there the building is a lovely old and charming structure. The exhibition was of old pics of Marrakech, 1920's/30's. Well displayed. There is also a lovely roof top cafe, although I didn't get anything there.

Beautifully Curated. As a lover of photography I was keen to visit the photography museum. The selection of beautiful black and while prints were stunning and well put together to tell the story of Moroccan history and her people taken over the years by travelling photographers. I must see for those who appreciate photography and history.

Nice little museum; location chaotic. This museum is in a pretty white Riad and has a nice staff at the admissions desk. It cost about $4 to get in and the ticket can be used over again on another day. The museum is located around a center courtyard and is, unfortunately, not air conditioned so on a hot day it is not as much fun.It also has a clean restroom with a sink and plenty of toilet paper--a nice find.The building is three stories high with a cafe up a spiral staircase to the top floor. There is seating in the shade, but again since it is outdoors whatever weather there is outside it is the same inside the seating area. They have a modest selection of Moroccan tagines, salads, etc. and Moroccan tea and other beverages. The waiter has to climb up and down that spiral staircase to the kitchen for every order.Up in the cafe you can see over the low, red rooftops of medina and if you are there at the right time you can hear the calls to prayer reverberate around the city.The challenge in visiting the museum is getting through the maze of the medina and avoiding the constant shouts from the locals that you are going the wrong way, or the street is forbidden, or the museum is closed when you are actually on the right street and the museum is opened. (Also, be careful not to be run over by motor scooters--avoiding them is a constant concern.) In many cases they tried to mislead us in order to show us the right way for a price. One man hounded us all the way to the museum asking for money which we finally gave him just so he would leave us alone.When we came out the museum we turned the wrong way and found even more harassment when we tried to get back to our hotel. Fortunately a taxi driver saved us and kindly got us back to where we wanted to be. I recommend a guide from your hotel unless you are traveling in a large group--single travelers or older couples seem to attract more unwanted attention than those who are in groups or people who are younger and stronger.

Loved the photography museum. The photography museum was a highlight of Marrakech for me. A large display of beautiful black and white photos told the story of many Moroccos over time. From the fierce Berber warriors, the nomads, to the French. We bought four prints which we've framed as a lasting memory of our wonderful adventure in Morocco.
Interesting place. We had a really nice surprise to find the Photography Museum. It was a rather interesting experience and it gives you a sense of the Moroccan traditions and style.
Great museum. This was a great museum with a number of classic photos of Morocco and Tangiers of old. Well priced to enter and an excellent rooftop cafe for lunch or a coffee.
Wonderful. Wonderful food, Wonderful photos... A wonderful visit! I recommend this wonderful museum to adults especially!

GREAT old photos of the city for sale. I looked high and low for old pictures of Marrakech and found them here. The photos on the walls are for sale (not sure if all are available, but many were) in three different sizes. They were a bit pricey, but I had to have them.

great place, nice and quiet!. Right in the middle of busy Marrakech, the museum was nice and cool. Very simple to get around with a rooftop cafe that is definetely worth a look. Their homemade lemonade was amazing.
worth a visit. Very interesting stop...unexpected!! We just happened upon it but it was amazing photography of Morocco and its people, mostly from early 20th century

Yes, do go here. They have a large collection of excellent quality old black and white photographs from the 30's, giving insight into the history of the area. Especially interesting are the photos of Berber Jews.
Alright. Pretty cool to see all the old photos and nice view at the top, but not sure if it's really worth the entrance price.

Interesting but small. Very small and tucked into the winding streets of the souks in the medina. Not of any interest to my children. They were happy to access the wifi on the roof terrace. I found the photographs interesting to look at.

Excellent. When I was there, I was completely surprised. All those daily street life pictures taken in different places in Marokko from 1880 on up till about 1966, in such a good quality. Both, the extreme goed quality of the pictures self, they all look like they where taken yesterday, with the best camera's you can find; but mostly because every picture tells an amazing story. This place is one of the best things Marrakesh has to offer a tourist.
a cool place with a cool view. stop and watch the world go by with a cup of jasmine tea or spiced tea..... a very relaxing place to wile away and hour

Best part is the rooftop cafe. It's quaint and a nice courtyard but the photographs whilst good are not particularly the reason to go that I expected, that said, there were some good photos.As in my title, the best part was taking the fresh air on the roof where the view over the old town is very nice. Combined this visit with the Ben Youssef Madras nearby and it's worthwhile.

A glimpse into the past. Housed in a beautifully restored building in the medina of Marrakech, is La Maison de Photographie, which exhibits a permanent collection of beautiful black and white, sepia and hand coloured photos of Morocco from the 1870 to 1960. Framed and hung from the walls, or in display cases, the atmosphere is cool and relaxed as you wander from room to room. Take that extra time, when you reach to top floor, to sit and watch documentaries filmed during expeditions to remote villages. If you are interested in a visual history of old Morocco, the museum is definitely worth a visit.I was a little surprised at the price of the entry fee of 40dh, however your ticket can be reused for a return visit which I thought a great idea. Located within the entry you can browse through a small selection of postcards and prints from the photographic display, as well as a number of books.

Great Place!. This is a gem of a museum to see a beautiful collection of early photographs of life in Morocco. The collection is housed in a beautiful old house with the added pleasure of a rooftop cafe serving delicious and affordable meals with great views of Marrakech and the Atlas Mountains in the distance.

a must. Lots of great picture of the early part of the century well laid out space cutie cafe but was very pricey ,nice thing you can reuse your ticket so,you can check out the works again if you missed somthing .they sold prints at good prices

Beauty inside and out. This small museum is well worth the visit. The photographs are beautiful and transportive. The roof deck is an oasis with unobstructed views of Marrakech. I only grabbed a drink on top, so I cannot speak for the food. Keep your ticket though, as you can come back at a later time to view the sunset from the roof deck. It is a terrific oasis in the medina.

Favourite museum. Loved spending the morning in this small but charming museum.The photograph collection is small but interesting and beautifully presented, as is the riad the museum is in.My favourite part was the cafe on the roof terrace - some of the best views I've seen all week with beautiful tiles on the floor and reasonably priced mint tea. Entry was only 40DH which is really good and the shop had a nice variety of post cards (5DH each) and prints available.

Small museum with beautiful photos. The museum is small but beautifully displays Moroccan photography, you really get a sense of how the country and culture were in past times. Go to the rooftop cafe too, it's lovely.

Brilliant photographs . The photographs were brilliant to see, entry was cheap and the cafe and gift shop were both reasonably priced. Well worth a visit. The museum is quite small, so do not expect to spend more than an hour here.

Great short film, worth staying to watch.. Beautiful black and white photos of Marrakesh, a real historical record of the city. We loved the short film which showed an event taking place in a tribal village.
Overpriced. Although this is a nice place to visit, entry fee is 40dirham per person, which is quite expensive in comparison to other Morrocco landmarks etc.

Great photos, peaceful atmosphere. Interesting to see the genuine old photos of Marrakech, and without being hassled. Good people in this museum, who aren't trying to get money from you (for once). Well worth a visit.

Great if you're in to photography. Had some interesting photo's. If you're in to photography you will love this place. Wasn't too busy. Go up to the roof for great views of the city with a backdrop of the Atlas mountains.

Wonderful little museum with spectacular photos and beautiful rooftop restaurant. This museum is a bit tucked away, but keep asking the locals till you find it, it is worth the visit. The gallery photos are impressive, giving you historical lessons visually, captivating and beautifully presented. Film on second floor about Gerhard Muller is in French and English (subtitles) and one more on the third floor (only in French). The building itself is nicely decorated, in a clean, art deco sort of way, merging with the Marokkan flair. The rooftop restaurant is a must, food is delicious and generous (3 course meal including an amazing mint lemonade for only a 100 dirham). View is fabulous as well as the service. One of our most restful and chilled meals during our 8 day visit to Marrakech.

interesting for all sorts of reasons. It cost 40dhm to get into this small but interesting gallery. There is lots of information about photographers famous for working in Morocco and some amazing photos, mostly black and white. Beautiful portraits give a view of the culture of Berbers and other Moroccans. The colour plates on the top floor from the early 1900s are fascinating. The museum itself is beautifully decorated and gives the feel of being in a tent in the desert due to the curtains wafting in the breeze. Worth a visit in my opinion

Wonderful museum - a unique way to learn about Moroccan history. The museum is beautiful, and provides a unique and beautiful way to learn about Moroccan history. They have a vast collection of photos, spanning several decades.Make sure to have a coffee or tea at the rooftop terrace before leaving. The museum shop is also a great place to purchase some unique Moroccan souvenirs.

Amazing photos in a relaxing location. The maison de photography was just an awesome experience. At the entry we were shortly introduced to the historical background of the photos in the museum by the kind and helpful staff. We then wandered around and enjoyed a piece of original marrakech feeling.... one could definately imagine how it was back in the days. It is also quiet and fresh in there though it is perfect for hot summer days. Afterwards we drank a perfect refreshing citron mint ice tea, ate delicious tajjine and enjoyed the stunning view from the rooftop restaurant which alone is worth the visit. Definately go there even if you do not have much time in Marrakesh.

Nice little museum. We enjoyed the tour of this small museum in an interesting building. It shows the life of Berbers from the late 1800's to about the mid 1950's. Although only $4 to get in, this is more than the $1 or $2 charged by the other major museums of the city, and caused me to downgrade one star. Still cheap by Western standards, so not really an issue.

4 euro to enter per person. This little 'museum' tells in black and white pictures part of Marrakech/ Moroccan history. Although most pictures are old ( black and white) I was expecting a bit more. It must be for the real art lovers. Just wasn't exactly for me.

Just ok. Museum collection is pretty small and both the artistic and storic value are ok but have no wow effect (of course IMHO).The ticket price is a bit higher than other moroccan attractions, terrace offers a nice view on the city.Probably worth if you are passionate of photography.

Worth a visit. A very nice riad with a beautiful collection of photographs. The entrance fee is MAD 40. The rooftop terrace is comfortable, service however was too slow (only one person for 12 tables).

Interesting . Nice little museum with some very interesting photos over Marrakech and its surroundings, mostly from early 1900's to about 1950.
Amazing when you see that many do not look out of place today.
Well worth the stop. Nice little roof terrace cafe too.

A nice respite.. This is not an extensive collection of photos but the ones on display are very telling. There is also a short film that they show about Berber culture as viewed by some French explorer. Indeed, a nice cafe on the roof terrace which offers surprisingly decent food. Views over the old city are great especially if you are not staying in one of the riads in the old part of town.

Enjoyable small gallery, a window to a vanished era. If you love photography, you can't miss this. It's a cool, pleasant break from the souks, with tea, coffee and cold drinks available on the shady rooftop terrace three floors up. The entry fee was 40 dirhams. There's a small gift shop with reprints of 100-year-old photography books by the Europeans who fell in love with Morocco. The autogravure gallery (with backlighted color plates) is really something if you're into the history of photography. Walking up through the rooms of this former home is also interesting on its own.

Fascinating history and great images!. My fiancé is a photographer and was very interested in this attraction. We had a great time looking at the unique photography and enjoyed tea on the rooftop afterwards. We would definitely visit again!

Lovely terrace for a drink . Fascinating place with 100's of photos from all over Morocco. They also have a great terrace for a drink afterwards to relax before the hustle and bustle of the souk below.
Hidden gem. Stumbled across this place accidentally and so glad we did. Beautiful photography. The staff were really great and gave us an overview of the museum so we knew where to start.

Interesting but small. This gallery is hidden away down the streets of the square. Although there are some very good pictures here, there are also a lot of uninspiring ones. it doesn't take much longer then ten minutes to walk through and see everything on display. Although it is nicely kept and presented, it is a small venue and certainly not worth making a special trip for.

A Great Glimpse of Moroccan History . Nestled in a small derb relatively far from the Jemma, this museum had a wonderful collection of old photographs showcasing Marrakech and Morocco over the last 100+ years. They're are several stories of delightful images and a small cafe with a great view at the very top.

Quaint Stop. I enjoyed this private photography collection in the beautifully maintained building. Entry fee is 40dhr. The rooftop terrace is also a nice place to rest with a drink and take a few snaps of the city rooftops.

If you are even an amateur photogrpaher, this place is a MUST. Must visit place. Will take you on a long visual journey through the lens of many photographers and how they saw Morocco with their lens.

Fantastic stop for everyone. This is a great stop even for people who are not into the arts. The photos provide a view into old Marrakech. The building is beautiful as well. I also strongly recommend having a tea and / or a bite to eat on the terrace
beautiful piece of history. a great little stop to see some Moroccan history, especially if you love the art of picture taking. There's also a tasty restaurant on the terrace. Great view of the city.

Special museum in the heart of the Medina. If you have interest in photography then this is a must see museum in Marrakech. It is small and very digestible and the photography is beautifully displayed.

Interesting photos . The photographs are very interesting, mainly in black and white but some colour. It was 40 MAD to get in but was worth it. It's quite a small museum but is a welcome break from the Medina.

Beautiful Photographs!. This place has amazing photographs from the 1920's and 30's and even a film of the Berber Mountain People dancing made in 1950's!
Fascinating!

Interested. The museum is quite small but in a very nice typical Moroccan house. the collection is spread over 3 floors of a riad and is not overwhelming as some museums can be. You can see it all in an hour or less. There are photos for sale and there is an admission charge. out of the museum It's an interesting walk through the souk to get to it and there are other things worth seeing nearby.

Atmospheric Photos of Marrakech from 1920 / 1930. It hasn't changed much!! This is a lovely Riad Gallery and well worth a visit. It costs €4 euros to get in and if you keep your ticket you can re-enter any time. We found ours when we were unpacking at home so gave them to our neighbours to use for their trip to Marrakech the following week. There is a small terrace on the top floor of the Riad accessed by a spiral staircase where you can buy a thirst quenching drink and look out over the city.

Highlight of our Marrakech trip - don't miss the rooftop terrace!. Our visit to the Maison de la Photographie was a real highlight of our Marrakech trip. Three floors of beautiful black and white photos, documenting Morrocco of past and present. The riad is cool and beautiful, with white washed walls and the traditional colourful tiles throughout. But the best bit is the little rooftop terrace. Panoramic views of the city, along with fantastic food and drink. The citron a la menthe drink is cool and refreshing, and they do a three course menu for just 100 dirham per person. And it's delicious! What more could you want?

Moments in Time. The Photographic Museum is worth the effort to find. Spend about an hour studying the photos from the 19th and 20th century to gain an insight into the Morocco of bygone days. The exotic images of the people and the daily routines captured in these beautiful sepia tones are quite magical. The eyes staring back from the portraits draw you into their world.
Ok. was ok but not worth paying to get in to see the photos, theres a terrace at the top with great views over Marrakesh though

Lovely exhibit, wonderful café!. My partner and I did this along with Ben Youseff Madrasa and thoroughly enjoyed it. The entrance fee was 40 Dhr each but was worth it. The photos offered a wonderful insight into the past culture of Marrakech across three floors and it culminates with a wonderful terrace café with fair prices. Would highly recommend because the view from the terrace was gorgeous!

Excellent collection of the work. Superb collection of photographs from as long ago as the late 19th century. You will read that these are not great photos in other reviews but I can only assume that these people have not noticed the years in which the photographs were taken nor the distances these photographers would have had to travel find not only these people and places to photograph but also their trust. There is an excellent film shown as well and the walls are covered in some superb photographs of people and places. Sepia and black and white which look amazing on the white walls. Each area is dedicated to a particular photographer and of course there is an opportunity to purchase the photos in various sizes. On the roof if a terrace for drinks and lunch. An excellent couple of hours. Highly recommended.

Don't plan on lunch here. Two years ago I had a delicious lunch and enjoyed the view on the terrace, but it's too popular, so there probably won't be a table. if you are lucky enough to get one, know the staff is run off their feet so the service is slower.Have a back up plan. The food in the restaurant next door is fine and affordable, but if there's room in your budget La Fondouk is just down the road (heading back to the medersa/square). The food is fantastic, but pricey.During my last visit the show was mostly portraits, but in May 2016 there are more images of old Marrakesh so you can get a feel for what it was like before tourism and the Western influence.
Great anthropology photos !. We enjoyed the visit and it is indeed a good way to spend two hours in Marrakech to learn more about the Moroccan culture. The terrace is great.
Small but very relaxing stop in the Medina. Excellent and interesting social anthropology photographs and a great terrace to while away some time surveying the rooftops of this fascinating city.

Small but interesting Photo museum. Small but interesting museum located in the medina area. Nice for a quick stop while in the medina. Location is an old Fonduk which is interesting in its own right to see one renovated.

Nice way to spend an 1-2 hours and learn some hostory. This is a nice little photography museum in a old house. It has lots of old photos from Marrakesh and explanations of the history behind them. I would like to have seen more modern photos and while a the photos have a lot of historical significance and are used to explain the history I didn't find a lot of them that great from a photography point of view. However for 40d it's a nice way to spend a quiet hour or two and there is a roof terrace if you need some refreshments.

Outstanding. Hidden in the Medina's is this amazing museum. The collection of photographs was a delight to see. The quality of the photo's was nothing short of fine art and demonstrated how little some things have changed in the city and also, how much has changed. Well worth a visit.

Fascinating museum, with great views. A very interesting little museum with a wonderful little roof terrace. Some stunning photographs, in a lovely, compact space. And the views from the terrace are great.

great museum, excellent terrace for lunch. We visited the museum and ate lunch on the roof terrace. The food here was excellent, especially the salads. The view from the roof terrace was over the city and you could see the mountains in the background. Overall, it was stunning. The museum itself was great. There were photos from the first visitors to Morocco with cameras. Some photos were as early as late 1800s. The museum had explanations in both French and English and was well curated. It is located in a beautiful building as well. I would definitely recommend coming here for lunch and visiting the museum.
Beautiful view. I have visited the Maison de la Photographie and it's worth it. My favorite picture is the touareg one. The view on the rooftop is fantastic & they have wifi.

boff. small and expensive museum.the photos are not so interesting
it worth it just for the terrace and the coffe restaurant where you can have a view of old marrakesh
Beautiful museum, lovely roof top terrace, great lunch. Beautiful museum, lovely roof top terrace, great lunch (menu for 100drh), very calm, very friendly staff. Thank you!
Worth seeing. Good photography . Great to walk around quietly worth a visit. There are photographs to buy and gifts.
A must see!. Definitely worth a visit... the photos are amazing and well curated as were the videos... and the roof top terrace a little oasis of peace
Very, very good small museum. Great photos and exception short video about berber culture - small cafe on the roof and pleasant, friendly staff

Have a drink on the roof terrace. Lovely place showcasing amazing work by early photographers, they also have the most delightful roof top terrace for food and drinks that have a must see view over the Medina all the way to the Atlas mountains - just beautiful!

A must see on any visit to Marrakech!. This is a gem of a museum, full of social history and it gives a real flavour of old Marrakech which you won't get from the souks. Superb views from the roof terrace, I have been back again and again. Run by very professional and enthusiastic staff who are a fountain of information, if you are visiting the Ben Youssef Madersa then it's two minutes further on.
Travel back in time. Interesting place to travel back in time with all the old gelatin silver prints of "ancient" Morocco. The museum is not that big, so 30-45 minutes will suffice.

Which one?. Careful: there is a Maison de la Photographie and a photography museum. Latter is based in the Palais de Badi, but this concerns the former. Tucked away in the northern souks, this is a beautiful building with a great collection of photographs (also 3D! and movies) of the history of Marrakesh, from the 1870s onwards. Views of the now famous Jemaa el-Fnaa square show that it was famous early last century too! Great and rare shots of people and places give a great insight in the last 150 years of Marrakesh. On the rooftop is a nice terrace with cafe: tasty juices!
Favourite place in Marrakesh. We went there twice during our 3-day-stay, because the rooftop terrace has an extraordinary view over Medina and the food/drinks are awesome! Must-see when in Marrakesh!

Excellent museum and delicious lunch. I was excited to see this new addition to Marrakech. As a photography buff, I loved seeing this collection of photos from across Morocco. The gift shop sells limited edition books as well as prints. We ate lunch on the roof terrace. Do not miss the vegetable tajine or the house-made yogurt. Also, your entry ticket is good for life!

preserving the roots 1. in this nice restored riad you will be welcomed by young guys that are very proud of their job and love to explain the exposed pictures that show especially berber life scenes fron last century. the visit includes 3 floors and many rooms and one ticket is good to come again everytime you want and you can visit also the musee de marrakech, nearby. on the top they have a nice little cafe' with some seats and make wonderful fruit juices.

Nice overview of Moroccan Photography. I liked coming here a lot. If you buy a ticket once you can come back at any time and go again!Lovely building, with a terrace cafe. Good photo descriptions of the history of photography in Morocco. Friendly staff.The admission is a lot more than other attractions you'll see (but it's still just like a few dollars).

Extremely interesting photography museum. Extremely interesting museum.Located in the center of the medina in the souks which requires some knowledge of the little streets to visit.It contains many photo collections from Morocco's past.There is also a bookstore selling of photos in various sizes and some photo catalogues.On the roof there is a very pleasant little cafe which also provides some real good view of the old part of the city.The museum has also a web presence but I am not sure whether the English version is adequate as the French one.

Photos of Old Marrakech. I love this museum. It features photographs (almost all black and white, of course of Morocco from the colonial era. Those old photographs--from the 1940s back to the turn of the twentieth century and even earlier--portray another era. I especially liked the pictures of the medina of Marrakech.

Wow! Incredible!. Really enjoyed my visit here last week. The images on display are incredible. This is definitely a must see for any photography enthusiastsThe little rooftop cafe is lovely as well and very reasonableI thought the gift shop was a little pricey though. £25 for a print is a bit steep although I still indulged as I loved the image

Small and cute. I enjoyed our visit here, it is really small but lots of great photographs so really interesting. Lovely little terrace on the roof with a lovely menu and great value. We didn't eat here but if I had more time I would have liked to because it was super clean and had a great atmosphere.

Beautiful view, OK museum, VERY hard to find. I really enjoyed the view from the top of the building. Getting there was not easy at all. We got lost a few times (and got VERY lost leaving there and trying to get back to the center). Paper maps are king in Marrakesh. Don't even bother with the online ones. The exhibit itself was OK. Not my favorite thing in Marrakesh, but I enjoyed looking at some of the pictures.

Nice way to spend a couple of hours - cafe visit is a must!. We popped into the museum one morning when the weather wasn't too great. Its a really interesting look into Marrakesh's history and the development of photography Beautiful building and (most importantly!) a fantastic rooftop cafe with lovely views over the city.

A wonderful photography collection and superb views from the terrace cafe. What a pleasure to find the terrace cafe atop the fine photography museum. We whiled away the late afternoon as we sampled delicious yogurt, fresh fruit and Moroccan cookies. Yum!

Lovely exhibits in restored riad. Bite sized museum with images from the late 1800's- mid 1900's and informative descriptions. Would recommend as a place to visit as it provides a narrative for the city. Nice terrace with a lovely view of the city.
Beautiful, calm, photography museum. Lovely restored house, showing some wonderful photographs, over 3 levels. Great roof top cafe, with good views and excellent food.
a perferct paradise of calm. Great to escape the busy souk streets with the cool calm photography museum escape. Fantastic roof cafe to relax and have a drink..
Balcony highlight. Balcony was by far the highlight of the museum. Photography was also interesting, but lunch up top is a must!
Good to see. Good see this museum if you like old photographs and see how the maroccain people lived like 100 years ago. I liked it very much

View is great. The Photography museum is situated in a beautiful riad in the Medina. It has a interesting collection of photographs of Marrakech in the early 20th century. It also has a great view of Marrakech on the rooftop.

A must see in Marrakesh. A wonderful collection of stunning images from the region from the times of the dawn of photography. The images and collections are simply amazing and all set in a beautiful building. Defiantly worth the 40 DH entrance fee. Time your visit so you can take in lunch at the roof top cafe with a cool fresh breeze , traditional food and panoramic views over the Medina. A must see when visiting Marrakesh

Great experience. Really enjoyed the museum. Enjoyed seeing photos of the past and seeing what Morocco used to be like compared to now. Great cafe on the terrace. Enjoyed the citron and mint juice .compared to now.

The Beautiful World of Morocco in Photos . There are some 9000 photographs- not all on display, across 3 levels of a lovely courtyard building. There is simple cafe on the top terrace with views across the city. Plat de Jour priced at 100 DR a person. simple low seating with excellent friendly service. The photos and postcards are beautiful. They cover the period of the 1850s to 1950s and capture people; places; animals. The shop offers copies of the postcards and photographs from just 5 DR.

Wonderful insight into Moroccan history . The museum was right by our Riad so it was top on our list of things to do. The photos are really interesting and give you a sense of what life was like in Morocco in the early 20th century. It's a great space and at 40 dirhim to enter, a bargain. We also had lunch on the roof top terrace, simple and cheap but delicious.

The best museum in Marrakesh. One of the few attractions in Marrakesh that have descriptions in English, thus was the most interesting museum we saw. Great photos from the early 1900 and a roof terrace serving lovely food as well!
worth a stop. great shop for posters and beautiful images. lovely riad in itself. well curated. worth a trip for the nice roof cafe!
Amazing photos. Past and present coming together. Beautiful black and white photos. Marrakech 1880 and now. Amazing!A very pleasant terrace with a view over Marrakech.Not to be missed!

Wonderful Museum - Definitely worth a visit. We loved this museum. Although it is relatively small (3 floors), it has a wonderful collection of black and white photographs (as well as color) of people, events and places that tell a vivid tale of the country and its colonial past. Definitely worth a visit. There is a rooftop cafe which is very popular with the visitors including us. We ordered a lemon mint drink and an assortment of salads. The drink was refreshing. The salad were OK. The view was lovely.
charming museum. The walk to get here was almost as good as the museum, taking us by the fondouks. The photos are remarkable. The terrace restaurant was an added bonus.
Nice photographs, quite small collection. Some excellent historical photographs, however missed the presentation of contemporary artists. Expected more from this place.

More than meets the eye!. We were recommended this and my husband didn't really want to go but he ended up loving it! If you are a photographer this is for you as well as for people who want to see the different images of Marrakech & Morocco through the years through photos, it's just beautiful to see and so much stories behind them all! Very impressed! There is also a rooftop but it's nothing special to be honest even if they do say 'panoramic views' all you see are rooftops lol

worth a visit if...... This small museum is worth a visit if you have an interest in photography or history or better, historical photography. The collection is spread over 3 floors of a riad and is not overwhelming as some museums can be. You can see it all in an hour or less. There are photos for sale and there is an admission charge.
Great little museum. Great collection of old photographs from Marrakesh and other locations in Morroco. Fine view from the rooftop terrace and café.

See this first. Worth visiting this gallery first to see historical images of Moroccan and specifically Berber life, before you see it on the streets. Deceptively big exhibition considering the modestly sized entrance. Nice view and calm ambience in the rooftop cafe, serving yummy home cooked food. Take time to watch the old documentary video about the Berbers - really interesting!

A must for photography and history enthusiasts. I really like this place, it always has interesting themed exhibitions that are of a good size. The collection of photographs is amazing and they give a unique insight in to the countries peoples, heritage and also at time more problematically its colonial past. Many of the images are for sale in the shop, some real gems to take home. I heard some tourists grumbling in the background that it wasn't to their taste, I guess it is quite a specialised museum that is competing with more architectural marvels.

Really Great. This museum is really enjoyable, it's spaced out nicely so it doesn't feel crowded. Some of the pictures are quite powerful and it's interesting to see what has and hasn't changed in the Medina. The rooftop terrace has a great view. There is an entry fee but it's worth paying to see.

Loved it!. A nice quiet place with an extraordinary collection of antique photographs of Morroco. The pictures are placed with care according to the spaces. It has a beautiful view from the terrace! They serve food too, it smelled good although we did not try it.

Amazing Place. Highly recommended!This places depicts the daily life of the Moroccan people between the 1880 and the 1940. they also have a lovely cafe on the roof top with a panoramic view of the whole city.

Worth seeking out. While not in the top 10 attractions, this is an excellent museum near the Medersa Ben Youssef. The black and white photos cover many different periods in Marrakech, and it is a good way to see what the city was like 100 years ago. And, if you find a photo you like, a copy is available for sale.

nice but not necessary. If you like photography or want to look at some old pictures to see that the city nearly is the same since many years you should come here but in fact this is a better place to take a pause and you should have a rest on the terrace. The juices are very tasty.

Great for photography buffs.. The museum is quite small but in a very nice typical Moroccan house. It's an interesting walk through the souk to get to it and there are other things worth seeing nearby.

Wonderful museum with dramatic views of Atlas Mountains. A really interesting museum of photography displayed in a series of small rooms. Particularly interesting historical pictures of Berbers. Very friendly and helpful staff and a beautiful small roof terrace with first class food and wonderful views of thew Atlas Mountains. A haven of peace to escape from the hassle of the souks!
Worth a visit. We spent a few hours at the museum, looking at the photos and browsing the shop. The collection is very interesting and well worth a visit.

Picture Perfect. A very well curated little museum set in a Riad that has a small but exquisite collection of historic photographs presented over three floors.In addition to having a great collection of exceptional photos, the museum boasts the best roof terrace that we visited in Marrakesh. The terrace has one of the highest vantage points in town, it provides unrestricted views over the city to the Atlas mountains and provides an excellent shady spot to relax and enjoy the view with a soft drink or light bite from the kitchen.Highly recommended.

Great collection of Morrocan photos in a beautiful building.. The picture collection is very interesting for both its aesthetic and historical value, with vintage photos covering many aspects of local life from the late 1800s on. Do not miss the rooftop terrace which offers great views of the medina!

intersting. One of the more expensive attractions in Marrakech at 40 dirhams the art on show is interesting as it shows the birth of a city and the people of long ago who inhabitated it. The cafe on the roof and the view of the city rooftops and mountains in the foreground almost outdo the exhibitions

A snapshot of historical Marrakech. After seeing reviews, made sure we visited and we were not disappointed. Very quiet and restrained look back at Marrakech and its people from the 20's. Interesting video as well. A break in the rain allowed a visit to the terrace for a good coffee and biscuit but it was a shame the weather prohibited us enjoying the renowned view to the mountains. The multiple entry ticket means we may make it back if the weather improves.

Great Museum. A very good selection of historic photography from the region. A selection of prints on sale.A cafe on the top floor with great views over the roof tops to the snow capped mountains and maybe the best tangine in Marrakech. your entry ticket gives you multiple entry.
Small but interesting. This museum doesn't have a lot of exhibition space--I hope they expand in the future. Great pictures of Morocco's past. I enjoyed it. And a great view from the roof!
Great museum. I really enjoyed this exhibit of early 20th century photography. Definitely worth a visit. Cafe on the terrace is nice too.
Incredible photos and spectacular views from the roof. Well worth a visit - if only for the roof top view whilst sipping on fresh lemon and mint. Photos from Moroccos history incredibly interesting.

GREAT collection of social-documentary photos in a pleasant space.. I'm glad my husband heard about this and we went. The collection is well curated divided by artists and time. The descriptions about each room theme and the photos are succinct but thoughtful and deep. It also has a small video room with a social-documentary running that is super good, shouldn't be missed!On top of that, the restaurant @ the rooftop is not only good, but the panoramic view from there is one of the best.
Photography Museum. A beautiful airy space in the heart of the medina. Floors and galleries full of historic Moroccan photos.
Well worth seeing. Set in a lovely courtyard house, this small museum displays lovely images of Morocco through its history. Roof has tea room. Great place.

Great old pictures of Morroco. One of the better places in Marrakesh that tell the story of the country I would have liked more translation to English to help me understand great roof garden restaurant with tasty lunchtime food and views of Atlas mountains.Make sure you have the hibiscus tea or lemon and mint drinks very refreshing.
Amazing terrace. One of those places you pop into when you've run out of things to do. The photos were impressive though and the staff knowledgeable. Go to the terrace as the view is amazing.
Eye opening. Excellent catalogue of old photos of Morocco. Well worth a visit, very nice building and be sure to watch the documentary.
Beautiful museum. Lovely museum, small but with gorgeous photos. There is also a fab roof top terrace with stunning views to the Atlas Mountains.
Must see. Fascinating and haunting photography gallery in a lovely setting just outside the souk. Definitely worth a visit whilst in Marrakesh.
Beautiful cafe in terrace. It is worth going simply for the beautiful floor tiles and the calm roof terrace where they serve delicious tagines. However the museum itself of course is enchanting.

Facinating. The array of photographs in this museum cover over 130 years of history and are very informative about Marrakech through the ages. Many of the close up photographs of people are wonderful. There are lots of nooks and alcoves in this building with historical photos of many facets of Moroccan life.The roof top café offers wonderful views of the city. It is a great place to view a spectacular sunset and take your own memorable photographs of a magical city.

Excellent place. This small museum is a treasure of photography and history of Morocco. We spent about an hour there that included tea on the terrace overlooking the city. There are countless B&W photos in the galleries, plus a nice gift shop. The attendants are very friendly. They gave us a pass to another museum about a 10-minute walk away.

Escape just for the cafe!. This is a beautiful museum. It's stunning retreat from the outside streets but very hard to find. The staff are very nice and the photography is nice. However, the best part is the cafe upstairs. Not sure if it sells food but drinks they do. It's worth escaping from outside and the heat and looking out at the atlas mountains whilst you sip a cold coke or have a nice coffee. The ticket is expensive (40 dh) but you can use your ticket to come back numerous times.

Beautiful Views!. Situated close to the Marrakech Museum in a quieter area just outside of the souks. The photography exhibition isn't particularly amazing but gives you a glimpse into the past.It's worth a visit for the rooftop cafe where you can escape the chaos at street level and enjoy a nice drink with views across the roofs and to the Atlas mountains in the distance. The food also looked good though we didn't have any ourselves.
Beautiful roof terrace . I didn't think much to the exhibition but it was worth going just for the views from the terrace. Great place to escape the chaos of the streets below.

Difficult to find but worth the effort. This museum is not the easiest to find but is worth the effort for anyone interested in photography. The roof terrace offers great views over Marrakech... and all its satellite dishes!

Photography. The museum is small but contains exceptionally beautiful black and white photos of Morocco and especially Moroccan people dating from mid-1800's to early 20th Century. I was stunned by the b&w photo of a young Jewish woman circa 1900.

A must to visit. I have frequented the 'photography house' many times over the years.The staff are very helpful and informative and speak English.Set in the heart of the medina it is a calm relaxing atmosphere were you can view the photographs at your leisure.There is a terrace restaurant with a wonderful view of the High Atlas and the surrounding buildings and Riads.You can either relax with a mint tea or try one of the dishes of the day.As there is a narrow metal spiral stairway to the terrace it is not accessable to people with mobility problems.
interesting though small and pricey. We found this musuem of be informative yet not as rich as we would have liked. Enterence was quite expensive compared to other museums around Marrakesh.

A must visit. I loved this Museum which was more like a journey of Moroccan history. The photos are well positioned with information in English and other language options. One of the better museums in Marrakech, the terrace cafe is a bonus

Fabulous exhibition. This was not easy to find, but really worth a visit. It's north of Jemma el Fna on the edge of the souks and is so peaceful in the madhouse that is Marrakech. The photographs of old Morocco are stunning and they have a wonderful film taken in 1957 just after independence. The film crew spent a couple of weeks travelling around the Berber areas and Atlas Mountains with a Caid and captured life as it was then, including the local dancers, for the first time ever.Definitely go if you can.This then led us on to the Musee Douiria de Moussaine, a town house that is being restored. This two was fabulous and so peaceful. It is again just north of the main square, but ask for directions at the Maison de Photographie - there is a little signpost in the souk if you are looking for it.

Wonderful record of old Morocco. It was wonderful to see these old pictures of Morocco from the 1800's to early 1900's. Particularly enjoyed the pictures by Mueller. They do a nice job of presenting the pictures with explanations in a variety of languages. It is small in size, so an easy visit. Well worth it
Stunning views. This place is great to come for a snack and a drink and to admire the views. The museum itself is very good, and the building has a tranquil feel to it.
Beautiful place. Beautiful Arabic and Berber architecture as well as fabulous pictures. A great place to pop into whilst exploring the city.

The most beautiful view, ever .... This photographic exhibition is a very educational and pleasant way to spend a few hours out of the hustle and bustle of the medina. A modest entrance fee gets you into the building and there are many photographs and things of interest to see. The main draw of this place, though, is the view from the terrace. We ordered mint tea and sat and watched the sun go down, with cameras at the ready. I don't think I've ever seen such a beautiful sunset before, not experienced the feeling of calm that descended whilst watching.This place is a must see - time it right and the views are utterly breathtaking.

New and a bit different. Very recent addition to the tourist map. Had some difficulties getting there as it appeared someone had taken down the sign so then followed us asking for money to help us - as its a bit close to the tanneries they're a bit intimidating. Grit teeth and go as you'll be rewarded with a terrace restaurant at the top with a higher than average view of the city. Some interesting period photographs cover three levels.

Interesting small museum. Rooftop terrace cafe.. The museum is well laid out in a lovely venue in the Medina. It's a little haven from the noise and hustle & bustle of the souks. Interesting exhibition of photos of old Morocco when we visited. The roof terrace cafe has a good view of the Atlas Mountains and the roof tops of the Medina, so well worth climbing the spiral staircase.
A real gem. A real gem, defo worth a visit. Also the roof terrace allows some great vistas of the city. The photos tell a lot about the history of Morocco.
Lovely Photos. Really cool photos of Moroccan life in the early 20th century. Wish that there had been more info available on some of the photos.

Maison de la photographie. There is a museum too. So this is just to clarify that the review is for the Maison de la photographie located in the Marrakesh Medina.It is not easy to find. So get your directions well written and in detail before you leave the hotel or you will be pestered by young guys trying to "help out" and then demainding 5 EURO.The building is nice.From roof terrace you can admire Marrakesh skyline and sunset. Beautiful views.The collection is impressive. I found it very interesting.They also project a video from the 50s that is well worth seeing.

Nice and little museum with great roof terrace. It's not a must see but defenitely worth checking out when you're nearby. The museum displays a lot of old pictures of the Medina and it's citizens. Beautifully photographed and displayed in a nice mozaik building. You can refresh yourself with a cold drink on the roof terrace. The view is amazing from here! I guess we were gone in less than an hour.

Wonderful archive of diverse images of Morroco. The collection is impressive, we especially enjoyed the first film footage of Berber living from the 1950s. We also enjoyed a delicious meal on the rooftop restaurant.
A great old home with a good collection of photos. The photo collection is great of tribespeople and others etc. The house is also interesting and the view from the roof café is wonderful.

one of the many attarctions of Marrakech. One of the good attractions in Marrakech, worth seeing if you like photography. also the nearby building are nice . Difficult to find but do not give up . There is a charge of 10DAM (equal to almost 1$) entrance fee. Enjoy

A favourite place. This beautiful riad has been turned into a peaceful museum filled with breathtaking portraits and old photos of life in the medina.
