But the true star is the rooftop terrace. You get to enjoy a simple lunch, that tastes excellent, served with an abundance of charme while enjoying the view over the mountains (best view in town).

Nice place. Old photos about the history of Marrakesh in an old Riad with rooftop café hidden in a small street.
Worth to visit.
Also recomended to visit Musée Mouessine ask the receptionist.

Great space.. Would love to see current work from local photographers and artists. The museum is beautiful and the photography is exceptional however there lacked a certain amount of comparison to modern day photography.

Say cheese!. This museum is very close to the Ben Youssef Medersa.It is housed in a typical Marrakesh house. Various levels built round a central courtyard. There is information in English to help you appreciate what you are looking at. It doesn't take long to look around. You may be struck by how little some things have changed since the early photos were taken.There is a café on the roof terrace we would have used, if we hadn't already had lunch. A small shop inn the entrance sells a selection of cards.

Nice display of recent history and people. This is a small museum displaying photography from app 1850 to 1950. The imagery is fascinating and well worth a visit. The stop need not take more that half an hour plus a short break at the cafe on the terrace. Try the lemon juice! Also make sure you visit Ben Youssef Madrasa, the Koranic School around the corner.
Some amazing images. Interesting house filled with lots of old images from around Morocco, well layed out in a comfortable setting. Pop in to take a break from the fun hustle bustle of the medina

A snapshot into a culture. We visited the museum on our last full day, despite locals telling us is was closed and to go to the tannery market! I love photographs of cultures and this allowed me to get a real feel for the people of this hot and harsh land. The video that was running by (can't remember the photographer) was another opportunity to glimpse into the people of the mountains. All in all, this is a pretty cool exhibition with a rooftop cafe which offers some lovely panoramic views.

Lovely terrace with views!. Lovely little museum with black and white photographs of Marrakech and Morocco. The Terrace is beautiful with panoramic views. I ordered a lemon chicken tagine! It was super tasty! Only six Euro and it was a good portion. Friendly staff here too. It's only around the corner from Ben Yousef Maderssa too!

The pictures are worth thousands of words. This isn't a conspicuous location, on a side street in the medina. It is between two great restaurants, which is how we found it. We spent several hours absorbing the most excellent photography on display and learning about Morocco we won't be seeing anymore. The clothes, traditions, locations and customs. It is well worth the small fee, which is good for as long as you are in the city. The prints are also on sale with staff readily available to assist when you stare at that one picture so long you just have to take it home.

Great museum. The photography museum in Marrakech is a great place to get lost in the visual culture of the country and to learn more about the different people living in Morocco. We were very warmly welcomed. The terrace is a must-visit for impressive views of the High Atlas mountains.

Best roof terrace. It's worth the trip just to have a coffee on their roof terrace. We were lucky to have a fantastic street musician playing on the street while we were having a dring. The Photos are also very interesting.

Remarkable . This museum isn't large. However, what they do have is of superb quality. I spent nearly two hours here. They're most amazing feature is their terrace cafe. The views from here will make you fall in love with this city. This is a must visit on a sunny, clear day.

Don't forget to relax at the end on the roof. Stunning photographs. Copies can be bought to take home and frame. Very good value but don't forget to relax at the on the roof top cafe. One of my favourite places to visit.

Little oasis of peace in the middle of Medina. It was fun to visit the Photography Museum. The photos displayed are quite interesting, my only negative thought was about the lighting around all the frames - there is a lot of reflexion so sometimes hard to see the photo. Terrace is lovely and peaceful. There is a little cafe/bar - perfect for a cup of tea or a cold lemonade.
Great exhibition . Great selection of photos depicting Morocco in the past. Also has a roof terrace for good views, coffee and lunch. Recommend.

Interesting. Hard enough to find but so glad we kept looking! This museum is not very large but if you take the time to read all about each photographer and watch the interesting videos you could pass a few hours enjoyably here. We also had lunch in the roof top restaurant which has the best views across the city and over to the mountains

A must for lovers of art and social history. We had a guide who took us here. What a find ! Love this place. Engrossing display of large and small format sepia and black and white photos. But it is not just an ethnographic document of pics from 1870-1960s. It makes you wonder about the relationship between the subject and the photographers. Quite thought provoking. Great view from the roof. I bought 2 small light weight books of the permanent collection so I could tear myself away.

Photos and photo oppertunities. The photographs are so gorgeous in their simplicity and beauty. They are of another era, where people where more curious to be photographed. They even have a short movie about different photographers and afterwards go upstairs and enjoy the peace and quiet along with the beautifull view
Interesting place with great old Photographs . Very nice and quite place... lots of Morrocon Photographs of older times... awesome round view from the terrace.. Check it out...

Beautiful photes. The Foundouk in which the museum of Photography is based is beautiful. The collection is not very large but give a wonderful insight into the past of Marrakesh and Morroco in general. The admission was 40 dirhams per person. There is a cafe on the roof.
Very interesting. Well designed attraction, very difficult to find, took us three attempts. Worth the attempts though as we really enjoyed it. Lovely little cafe on the roof terrace.

Cute museum. Lovely little museum. Lots of interesting images from the early years through to contemporary.
Quiet cafe on the roof.

Cool. We came here to see some history of Morocco in pictures and the museum didn't let us down.It is not huge, don't expect too much, but there are photos of different international photographers in exhibition on three floors and on top there is a terrace with a small café (no high prices) and a great view over Marrakesh. The pictures are really interesting and give you an insight on what the city looked like in the last 200 years before many tourists came here. We really liked it!
Worth a visit!. A great museum! We loved our morning stroll through this library and time spent on the rooftop terrace. Definitely recommend adding it to your plans in Marrakech.

Perfect stop in your visit to the souks. Impressive collection well worth a visit but don't miss the chance to enjoy a refreshing drink in the rooftop terrace. The views of Marrakech from the top are astonishing.

Fascinating history of Marrakech. The museum holds many atmospheric photos of Morocco and Marrakesh. Some of the scenic pictures and the old films provide a wonderful historical image of the country. Take advantage of the roof top cafe. Great food at good prices.
good lunch. wonderful view and a beautiful collection of historic phofotographs, worth visiting. And some nice pieces to buy
Worth to visit. Enjoyed watching documentary from Magnum photos pioneers...original works, beautiful terace and very acceptable price prints to purchase :)

A definite must see. With outstanding views from its terrace across the medina and situated in a beautiful riad, this museum is a real treat in the heart of the city. The presentation of the photography is exquisite and entry is really cheap. A very pleasurable way to spend an hour or two

Charming museum. We stopped here for 30 minutes to view the old black and white photos of Morocco. Located in a very charming riyadh with a small roof top cafe for tea. This was an enjoyable break from the crazy, hectic Medina!

Well worth the trouble to find. Not easy to find and locals try to distract you from visiting. Persist. It's a treasure house of wonderful photographs of a bye gone era. Do watch the video on the first floor from start to finish it is amazing.

The highlight of our stay in Marrakech. Wonderful centre of photography dating from 1880's on. Your entrance ticket of 40 dirhams entitles you to return at any time during your stay and you will want to return if only to soak up the tranquil atmosphere here or buy some stunning prints!

Great hidden cafe on the roof!. We were recommended this spot by the owner of our Riad and it really is worth the trip. The set menu we had for lunch was perfect and great value for money.
We shared one tagine between us, but this was plenty!

For the Rooftop View. Love the rooftop cafe!!! Beautiful view from the rooftop cafe. Nice place to chill and see the day goes by. Lovely collection of photographs and nice interior of the building. But, the entrance is very expensive compare to other sites Dhs 40 :( Luckily the rooftop cafe makes it worth it. Tips: don't buy the postcard there. I thought their post card are special and from their collections. But it can also be found in the marker for cheaper.

Most excellent. What a brilliant way to view the Moroccan past the videos filmed in 1957 really are worth viewing, and a snack on the roof is a good thing to do as wellI expect we will have to go back there
Beautiful . We were advised to eat here for lunch and it was beautiful. You do have to pay to enter but if you keep your ticket you can get in again to eat

A good recommendation.. A local asked us several times if we had visited this museum as he considered it one of the best. It's an interesting stroll to get there but well worth it. A beautiful building with several floors of beautiful photos detailing some of the history of Marrakech. They're mainly black & white and well displayed. There's a small roof top cafe with a beautiful view over the city.

An interesting collection of old photos. There were not as many photos on display as I had expected and rooms were for the most part arranged by photographer, however they gave a fascinating flavour of Morocco many years ago and of some of the changes that have taken place. There is a very good cafe on the roof with views to the mountains.
Good exhibition in a beautiful building. We really enjoyed this gallery and it's worth visiting whilst in marrakech.The building it's housed in is beautiful and the view from the rooftop is great.

Interesting to learn about local history and artists. We were encouraged to visit this place by relatives and weren't disappointing.
The house itself is quite nice and the vibe is great, with young artists from Morocco and Europe.
Great place to learn a bit more about life in the region in the early 20th Century.
It has a decent cafe as well.

Beautiful, peaceful oasis. This is a gorgeous space filled with a wonderful collection of amazing photographs. It was well worth the time we spent there and the rooftop cafe also caps the experience nicely. This is definitely a must do for anyone interested in photography.

Great 19th-20th Centiiry photographs of Morocco/Moroccans.. Very nicely done, in a cute old riad in the center of the souks. Again extremely hard to find and would recommend a taxi if you do not wish to get lost in the souks (and buy a lot of unnecessary stuff on the way). We were given an introduction of the place and then told a bit about the history of the museum, Captivating photographs across 3 levels (all for sale as well, though pricey!) Entry was 40 MAD, and would recommend a visit! (if you like photographs)

I'd have loved to visit. I tried to visit this three times during one afternoon, over the space of an hour. Each time I was stopped by locals telling me that I couldn't go there because of local religious services. They offered to show me a longer way around, but at a cost. Sadly I gave up and walked away, unsure of what was going on.

Not really worth it. It's not a easy to find museum. When you arrive there, there are a lot of old pictures (which I don't believe are originals). But there is not much that really changed within the years. Most places look the same today, so it was rather not worth a visit.

Vintage Moroccan Photography. This photography museum can be a little tricky to find but its worth doing so - taking you on a visual journey of old Maroc. It is a beautiful space covering three floors and the collections change regularly. It also has a delightful rooftop café with views of the medina.
A glimpse into the past. A good place to start from. Beautiful photographs taken at the end of 19th and early 20th century showing life in Morocco before tourists arrived!

Very interesting photography in a lovely building. This is a great place to check out in the medina of Marrakesh. The photographs are excellent and the rooftop terrace is a lovely place to have a drink.
Really beautiful photographs. Definitely worth a visit, and the relatively expensive 40dh entry fee. A really stunning selection of black & white photography exhibited in a beautiful, tranquil riad.

Very interesting well presented display with benefit of nice roof terrace cafe.. A lovely presented building with a well sent out photographic display. Helpfull staff.Excellent cafe on the roof terrace with one of the best views over Marrakech. A little expensive at 45MOD but i think worth it just for the quality.
Quiet place, nice rooftop cafe. Small exhibition of old photos, interesting to see after having been to Jemaa el-Fnaa etc. Rooftop cafe is cheap yet very nice.
Checking out the art scene in Marrakech. Awesome exhibitions and a healthy dose of culture, outside of what you find in the medina. Excellent for museum, art and photography lovers.

Ok, but a bit experience . Compared to other attractions this was for me a bit too expensive considering. It's quite a minor exhibitipn, though in a nice and calm place. It's quite hard to find in the Medina, but watch out for the Marakech museum and this one is chose by (on the back street more or leas). You should go there only if you have a true passion for photography, otherwize there are other attractions that provides more value for money.

Art, history, culture - plus coffee on the roof terrace!. An important international collection of photographs of the Moroccan people's names a simple elegant setting. Includes some early colour photographs. I bought cheap postcards and a poster but you can also buy photographic prints. Charming staff, full of information. A fascinating, inexpensive, oasis in the Medina, close to Ben Youssef meters a! Sunset from the terrace was stunning.

Not really worth it. This was recommended in the Lonely Planet but didn't really think much of it. It has good pics but I would have rather spent that money elsewere. The restaurant view is good but the service not so much
excellent photos and view. Not only are the staff friendly, but the exhibitions are very moving. when you finally reach the roof you have the best view of Marrakesh. Definately GO

surprisingly good. We really enjoyed the photos and the staff were very helpful. great view from the roofdeck. It wasnt easy to find but worth the effort. I also bought one of the photos they had for sale.
Magical. A truly magical place - both museum and rooftop cafe which is the most wondrous place to hear the call to prayer. A late afternoon lunch here was the highlight of our stay.

Small but Intriguing. In the heart of the Medina, the Maison de la Photographie is a great place to take a break from the wild streets and learn more about the history of the city. Inside, the building is very modern, clean, and well organised. There's three floors of different photographs, ranging from the 1800s to the mid 1900s. Inside, you see images that capture the faces of citizens, local gathering places (the mosques, souks, the main roads, etc) attractions, and simply the decor around the city. Each image has a brief explanation and credit to the photographer. There's also assorted sheets of paper that talk more in depth about given subjects related to the images. (in various languages) My favourite part was seeing the old cameras that were used to capture these images, and seeing the progression in detail and quality as time went on. (I'm hoping to study photography and media in the fall at university, so this was a great experience for me.) I have nothing negative to say about the museum, I just wish that it was a bit larger. After ascending the stairs and viewing all of the levels of the museum, there's a small cafe on the rooftop where you can enjoy a glass of mint tea, and take in the captivating views of Marrakech. I believe it costs 40DH (roughly 4 Euros) to enter, but it's definitely worth it.
Great View. We enjoyed a visit here today. It was a brilliant roof terrace with great photographs throughout! Very well kept building also. Great to see if you have time in Marrakech

Interesting but quite small. This gallery was a nice respite from the hectic medina and was full of interesting photos and an insightful video into rural Moroccan life. It was quite small and only took an hour to look around.

One of our favourite places in Marrakech. We never tire of the great roof top terrace cafe and the views, the collection of photographs or the little shop where prints are available! A must visit place for us.

Small lovely space . This is a lovely little gallery with some beautiful photographs depicting Moroccan history. Once you have browsed around and watched the short documentary upstairs you can take a drink or some food at the rooftop cafe which has a lovely view over the Medina. Watch out for local scammers who will give you wrong directions and then a 'helpful stranger" will put you on the right path; for a price of course....

perfect size museum. lovely collection of photos in a charming building. great roof top view...it was crowded so we skipped having a drink there. I could live in the museum -it must have been an old house! mosaic tiled floors !
Amazing. Things unique setting takes you away from the bustle of the Medina. Amazing photographs and awesome view from the terrace.

Very interesting photos of the past. This attraction is one of the pricer ones (20Dhs, compared to 10D for all state attractions/museums etc), but it isn't much compared to European standards. There is a good range of photographs from different regions across the last century which are clear and well-presented. There is also a terrace on the roof.
Gem in the medina. Great place to see how Morocco 100 years ago. Peaceful walk in time, beautiful exhibition and relaxing terrace with great views! Souvenir shop sells nice postcards too.

An interesting collection of photographs. Once I found it we enjoyed the in the main black and white photograph collection. Set over three floors and with lots of information provided in different languages. Worth a visit.

Something to do if your near or an avid photographer. Lots of photos dating back to 1880. I think I was expecting this to be more pictures of Morocco from the past to compare to today, but it was a lot of portrait photos. It does have a quite a bit of info in English. Nice cafe on the top floor.

Wonderful gem connecting with Moroccan heritage.. Loved our little visit here. It is a privately run and funded museum with some fascinating insights and stories documented in the photographs on display. Well worth the visit. We spent almost 2 hours in the various rooms, nooks and crannies. The place also has a delightful roof top with great views over the city. Sadly it was raining hard the day we visited so the cafe was closed.
Small but interesting. Small exhibition in an interesting building. Worth the trip to see what they have and entry was very cheap. Have a drink on the roof desk.
Don't miss the vintage documentary. There is a documentary on the top floor filmed in the 1930's (??). Commentary is in french with english subtitles. This was the highlight of our visit.

fantastic. Fantastic photos (and a short film) depicting life in Marrakech and the Atlas mountains. Amazing to see how little it's changed. The rooftop terrace has the best views and serves a small but perfectly formed menu of traditional Moroccan food.

Excellent exibition. It makes you want to discover all around Morocco with a camera.
It tells you about the last 100 years of Morocco.
Nice terrace to cool down and relax after the Medina

Interesting . The exhibition has some really interesting and strong photos so you can actually see how life was at that time. I really enjoyed visiting it and contemplating how people lived in Morocco in the 19s.

Beautiful photography and definitely worth a visit. We found this place as we were exploring and getting lost in the beauty or the souks, all 3 floors were filled with stunning photography that told a story of Marrakech as well as Morroco. The roof terrace was a lovely space to relax after with a view of the city while drinking some mint tea with nice kofte tagine and bread to munch on before continuing with the adventure.

a nice collection. This is a nice collection of vintage photographs that's worth seeing. Some of it is a bit repetitious, but overall it offers an interesting look at how the city used to look (and how some parts of it remain remarkably unchanged).
Interested in photography - go!. Worth a visit. Little but interesting exhibition.Nice wiew from terrasse on top and good fresh lemon/menthe juice from bar.

Very interesting photographs.. It is a nice representation of photography from the area over the past 100+ years. The staff were friendly. The view from the roof was nice. It was very reasonably priced. I only felt that it was a little 'cold' the way the pictures were installed.

pretty, interesting, great building. 20Dhm to get in (£1.50 each) - to enter a clam cool and tranquil setting that showcases some great photos - showing the Berber history from around 1880 through the early part of 1900's. set over a couple of floors - in amazing rooms with mosaic floors - really lovely to visit. The top floor gives way to a café style restaurant - which unfortunately we couldn't eat at as it was completely full - and we could see why - the food looked lovely! Nice way to spend 1/2hr - 1hr away from the crowds and see the history through the eyes of the people of Marrakech
beautiful old black and white pictures. worth visiting it and look at all the rooms. Very nice building and garefully renovated. The pictures are beautifull and very interesting from all over Marocco

Some good pictures but the context could have been better. The photographic museum had some powerful pictures from 1880 that really took you back.
It would have been helpful if the information provided in English would have been more appealing - not only dates and names or incoherent sentences.
Overall a nice visit.

Well worth navigating your way here. Quite small, but atmospheric, selections of old photographs from the region, in a beautiful, tranquil setting. Be careful of 'helpful' individuals telling you it's closed and trying to take you elsewhere - I advise the use of Maps on a Smartphone! Cost me 40dhs for entry and to return another day if wished. Interesting building as well as the exhibitions and a wonderful terrace at the top to drink Mint Tea (or what you will) and gaze over the roof tops to the Atlas Mountains.

Wonderful staff and beautiful view from the rooftop!. But the exhibition was unfortunately not at the expected level. They showed two videos though, one about berber life filmed in the 50's, which was very interesting. I would highly recommend it though thanks the friendly and helpful staff and the fact that your ticket gave you the possibility to revisit the place on serveral occations.

Great photography collection. Great place to see some of the old Morocco in print. It was a little more than the standard museums at 40 dirham. The pictures are well presented and also for sale. I think they did a great job of showing the Morocco of yester year.

Worth the visit!. Great exploration of Morrocan history and culture through magnificent photos. Each floor takes you through mesmerizing photos from 19th century. Documentary on top floor worth a sit down. Staff is amazing too!

A peaceful place in the middle of a hectic city. A beautiful art gallery tucked away from the busy crowds of the markets. It can be tricky to find, but is worth it. When I visited, I had the whole place to myself, it's a gorgeous building filled with wonderful photography and I believe you're given a ticket that lets you get in for free for the rest of your trip (well I was). There is also a lovely cafe on the roof terrace which gives you some fantastic views of the mountains surrounding Marrakech

Beautiful photos! Loved the rooftop!. Great collection of photos from the early days of photography in Morocco. Well displayed in a riad style courtyard building. Allow time for tea and snacks at the cafe on the rooftop, particularly if its a sunny day. Watch out for the touts on the street in this neighbourhood trying to push the excursions to the tannery... a good way for you to lose some money!

Interesting and beautiful place to visit. It was really interesting to see the history of Marocco through the lens. Beautiful pictures and the gallery itself is wonderful and clean. Definitely go up to the terrace for a coffee and amazing view of Marrakech.

An interesting insight into Morocco's past through photography. The Maison de la Photographie was worth the search: floor after floor of photographs of Morocco and Moroccans provided a great way to learn more about the history and culture. The terrace cafe is a lovely place to relax at the end of the visit, and I was grateful not to have to pay to use the toilet, as is the case at virtually every other attraction I visited.

If you are a photographer you have to go here. If you are a photographer or you are interested in b&w-photography you have to go here. Excellent pictures shot in the earlies 1900 (some of the coloured with a special technique) and afterwards a stay on the roof terrace with a excellent view over the roofs of the Medina...
Well worth a visit. The museum provides a fascinating view of life in Morocco for over a century. The café on the roof is worth a visit. It is not licenced, though.

An Englishman Abroad. We walked and walked, got helped by a local who must have been the best actor in the World (cost 200 Dhirams) but finally made it to a true gem - well curated, fab photos and had we done some better planning would have been easy to find! well worth the effort

Well-curated, eye-opening photographs. This photography museum may look small at first, but it needs at least two hours to go through as almost every photograph cries out for a closer look. Most pictures are from the late 19th century to the mid 20th century, and introduce us to a period when the French colonisers were only just moving in and influencing the people and culture. The pre-colonial Morocco is thus very much on display. What is interesting is that where some pictures show much has changed since then, others show how little has changed. There is a nice little terrace on the roof where a light lunch can be ordered. Among the top 3 attractions of Marrakech.
Wow - a must s. great place to have coffee or light snacks / refreshments. However the photographs are stunning - don't miss this place

Fascinating collection, very pleasant experience. There are lot of photos from 19 th and 20 th century, Morroco. You can see pictures of berber, arab and jewish people, either photos of desert and city. You can also see a documentary movie and buy cheap postcards (0,5 E). Visit fee is 3 E.

Interesting look back in time. We accidentally stumbled across the Maison de la Photographie whilst in Marrakech and it was one of our highlights of the city. There are collections of photographs from the past which give a really interesting insight in to the past of the city. Not much has changed by the looks of things! It is better set out for English speaking tourists than most of the City's attractions.
An afternoon trip. We walked here from the Jardin MarjorelleAmazing photographs and a beautiful restoration of a building in the old city. Views from the cafe terrace were lovely.

Fantastic collection of photographs. When in Marakesh this end of the medina is a minimum hustle relaxing place to visit and there is an excellent restaurant next door. Not to be missed! You can see half and return free with the same ticket after having a meal. The collection features beautiful historic black and whites and more modern and contemporary work as well. Buy your postcards and photos there, not anywhere else, because copies around town are inferior and you pay the same. We actually went twice to show my sister in law who also had trouble leaving. Taking that lunch break was the charm. The staff there is multi lingual and really friendly.

A must. for getting a sense of Morocco as it was 150 years ago and in the more recent past. The quality mom the photos is stunning and most are blown up like posters. Yet, there are not too many so you do not feel overwhelmed.

Another Interesting place. Was advised by our hotel owner to visit. Very interesting place too see. Fantastic photos, well worth a visit, call into the roof top terrace cafe, decent coffee fantastic views of the city.

GOOD PHOTOS, BUT SOME WEAKNESSES. This museum is certainly worth a visit, but it's not perfect. The mages are not arranged as clearly as you might wish and the English translations (which we did not need but which we read) were often poor to appalling. In one instance, 'carte' (French for 'map') was translated as 'card'. Other places in Marrakesh get this right: why not the Photography Museum?

Lovely little museum in middle of Medina. We heard about the Maison de la Photographie from our hostel but we stumbled upon it while getting lost in the Medina. It has a great little collection of pictures of Morrocco. It has a great terrace with an incredible view of the Medina and the mountains in the background.

little treasure. Located in a really characteristic building, this exposition offers a great excursion into Marrakech older days. Photographs are really interesting. Brief explanations available in french and english.
Marrakech's history packed in photos history. Nice building with with a super presentation of great photos. You can see some of the first colored photos (chromatography).

Worth a Visit . It's a small museum, with a good collection, that explains very well the fascination that many artists and photographers had for Morocco.It's well exposed and the cafe above it's a good spot to have a snack in the middle of the day.

Interesting museum, well worth a visit.. Interesting pictures from early 20 century. Helpful staff. Good rooftop cafe. We were given a voucher for another museum which was a restored 16th century family house which was also a very interesting place to visit. Also you can revisit the museum free.

Worth the visit. Reading some views we almost did not go to this museum and so happy we changed our mind. The photos are beautiful and it was interesting to see the Marrakech of before. The expo is very well organised and would have loved to watch the movie projection but visiting with an infant has its (very rare :) disadvantages. There's a terrace on the roof we're planning to try for brunch. The tickets we're told can be reused for the visit which makes it worth the 40 dirhams we paid each.

Great images but poor curatorial quality. The images are amazing as is the view from the roof top. Sadly I along with my group felt that the images were let down a little by a very light touch to the curatorial aspects. More context to the images would have easily resolved this.

a treasure chest. when you are truly interested in photography. Its collection, different exhibition, quality of prints and further information offer a journey back to the beginning of photography, a journey through a wide range of ethnological evidence over the course of time - in point of photography as well in its different tribes and cities.The stuff working there is well informed, cordially helpful and kind. On the roof top one finds a beautiful view over the madina, but much more a delicious menu and refreshments. It s a special place - a pitty to miss!
lovely view. nice place to eat out and look at the surrounding area, the roof Terrance over looking most building.

Lovely little gallery and amazing lunch on stunning roof terrace. Really enjoyed the photos, especially the large black and white ones on the ground floor. It was a peaceful, bright airy space. Not a huge exhibition space but very pleasant. Our lunch at the sunny roof terrace cafe was one of the best we had in Morocco. A three course meal for 90 dirhams (€9) including a gorgeous chicken tagine with olives. Even taking account of the 40 dirhams entrance it was still fantastic value. Loved it.

Worth going to see just what souks were like. Stunning photographs which give a very good feel for what Morocco was like at the turn of the 19C. Souks that ooze atmosphere in images that could easily be abstract works of art and amazing images of people - both studio and street scenes.This was photography before the point and shoot approach and it shows.Very nice roof top café (with a steep spiral staircase) and a panoramic view to the south east. Charming staff.

Photographs and roof top cafe!. We visited the museum, which is OK, some good black and white photographs of Marrakech. Went to the roof top terrace for a coffee, good coffee, good value, pleasant spot.We did not eat, but they offer a very good value 'Plat du jour'.
A pleasant surpise. Great cafe on roof with amazing panoramic views of whole townExhibition good with multi language translationsAnd best toilet I visited in 3days!

Nice museum with great roof terrace. Nice little museum with photo's of Marrakesh and other Morrocan cities. All photo's can be bought as well. Great roof terrace, where you can eat something or drink a mint tea.

Nice photos but very small. Nice little museum but compared to the entry price for others 40dirham was a little higher than I think it should have been. We were in and out in less than 15 minutes. Some very nice photos but we saw the same amount just after when we stopped at cafe atay. Enjoyed it but not sure I'd tell others to go...
Photography museum. Very interesting photography of Morocco and surrounding areas. Most of it black and white. Some quite old. Lots of stairs. Small cafe on the roof.
Worth going just to visit roof top cafe. Interesting photos amazing how little things have changed in some ways. High light is the roof top cafe and the views
small cozy interesting nice. nice riad full with old photos from Maroc, you can pick one more - historic - level to your learning of this country

Quiet small museum. Great old photos of Morocco....of about 100-150 years ago. Authentic experience in the medina. Needs about an hour to savor the collection which fills 3 floors of an old house. Small admission fee.

Great little photographic gallery with lots of images of Morocco over the last 100 years. Nice gallery in the Medina with lots of pictures taken over the last 100 years. We visited on a wet day so the roof garden was less of a thing, but otherwise a great experience and some insight into how much or little Marrakech has changed

Small but Impressive. This is a small collection, but the images are thoughtfully displayed within the three floor museum. The building itself is delightful. Light and bright and full of charm. Don't forget to visit the terrace for a view of Marrakech and a truly delicious chicken with lemon tangine.

Go!. What a find, close to Ben Youssef and so a great place to stop and relax. The museum is interesting and housed in a beautiful building (worth the entrance fee alone).The icing on the cake is the wonderful terrace where you can eat lovely homecooked food while overlooking the stunning view of the Atlas Mts and medina (it's shaded too). The staff were lovely too. Set lunch menu is 90dh (about 6 quid for 3 courses) and starts at13:30. Highly recommended.
For photography lovers. A cosy museum with a wonderful roof terrace to have a mint tea or eat something. Great exhibitions and film screenings. Located in the Medina.

Go for the excellent photos, stay for the rooftop terrace lunch. The photography at Maison de la Photographie is stunning and very well done. Being friendly to the folks at the front desk isn't tough as they welcome you right away. Additional conversation (for us, in French) encouraged them to tag along with us for a bit and point out some history and artistic style in some of the photos.The rooftop terrace restaurant was full, but after a few moments we got a table and had a delicious lunch. It's one of the best rooftop terrace lunch spots we found in Marrakech. To be honest, the restaurant itself is worth a trip to the Maison de la Photographie, and then of course you get the bonus of the excellent art downstairs.The postcards with photos in the gift shop make for great gifts for friends, and much better than the kitschy postcards you can find on the street.

interesting photos and good lunch too!. The floors of contemporary and archival photographs give an amazing insight into life in north Africa, past and present. The roof top cafe has great views and the food is relatively inexpensive.
Old photos. if you like photography or old images of Morroco well worth a visit. Nice views from the roof terrace also
Must visit. This is a must place to visit when in marrakech. Some very cool original photos. Of various people and places throughout morrocan history.
Photographic Heaven. Well worth the climb, mint tea served at the top, more steps haha, everywhere we go there seems to be high steps
Worth a visit. Really interesting museum, worth a visit, some amazing photos and history of those that took them. Recommend it

Mesmerising. This maison is one that you will revisit in your head long after you have visited I think. The delightful and often intriguing pictures conjure up some characters and as they are pictures it gives you time to study their faces and demeanour without feeling embarrased at staring for so long. There are a couple of films from the 50's running on a loop about well meaning anthropologists trying to identify the 'real' berbers and venturing into these foreign and strange lands. They was themselves as explorers of a lost world which was worth the admission price on its own. It is dated but indicates that this area and its people have always fascinated western and northern europeans and .... still do. Had a coffee on the top floor but it was crowded and uncomfortable whereas the maison and its artefacts were mesmerising.
Nice few hours. A nice place to spend a few hours. Close to my very nice riad. A decent way to spend a few hours if you are nearby. An insight into moroccan life.

worth a visit!. interesting selection of great photography, which allows getting an impression of every day life in the arab countries, the same with the movie shown. And at the end: enjoy a coffee or a snack and the very nice roof-top-terrace!

Worth a visit. There are some really beautiful photographs here well worth seeing. We ended up purchasing a large one of Place Jemaa-el-Fna from the 1920's as we were staying there. Definitely head upstairs after viewing the galleries and have a relaxed lunch at the rooftop cafe before heading back out to the craziness of Marrakech.

Evocotive pictures of old times.. Wonderful exhibition of old photographs tell ing the story of Morrocco. We didn't leave ourselves quite enough time as it was tricky to find. The visit was well worth the efffort to fo find though and had we been earlier would have spent more time.

Add to your understanding of Morocco. The photos contained will greatly add to your understanding of Morocco. Of particular interest is a film ofthe first meeting of government officials with a particular Berber group just after independence.

not so many but great impressions from earlier Marrakech. it is worth to visit this nice small museum. i´ve been there a few times and in enjoy it everytime again. with a wonderful terasse on the roof top to have a relaxed coffee .

Fascinating Museum. If you're into photography (in its black and white and early colour form) and historic sights and people of Morroco, this is a must see. Displayed over three floors of a riad, a series of fascinating photos taken by the pioneers of the art of photography.

GREAT. WE enjoyed our visit here: Patrick the owner/curator gave us a wonderful overview of the museum and a little bit of it's history. The images were a strong and haunting background to life in Morocco. Note that most of the images are available for sale in a variety of sizes.

A glimpse into the people of Morocco. It is well worth the effort to find this gem of a gallery. The photographs of the different tribes and peoples of Morocco are beautifully displayed over 3 floors. It is possible to purchase prints, cards and postcards as a lovely memory of your travels. In addition there is a café on the top floor with views over the rooftops of the souks.

Interesting photographs capturing old Marrakech displayed in a Riad. Ticket allowed return visits. Interesting display of old photographs mainly black and white and some early colour over last 100 years focus mainly on people. Nicely displayed in a Riad over three floor (stair access). Able to purchase prints and cards. Nice cafe on roof terrace with good views.

Really worth a visit. We thoroughly enjoyed a wander round this wonderful display of original photographs dating from around 1890 to 1945. The expressions on the faces of the local people featured are inspiring. During the visit you will slowly climb stairs to the next level and at the top you will find a small wrought iron spiral staircase. This leads to the terrace where you can have a hot or cold beverage and enjoy magnificent views across the roofs of Marrakech to the High Atlas Mountains in the distance.
Brilliant. The owner has spent his life collecting amazing photos from Morocco and Marrakech. It is a joy to be there, and some great stuff to take back home

Well worth a look round, and great for photographers. Wonderful quiet venue to admire the old photographs of the 20s-60's. Enlarged images bring the history to life, and many of the scenes depicted can be found in 'real life' just outside the walls. Good for a rainy afternoon hour, and the postcards are good value.

Interesting photos and amazing views from the rooftop. A lovely way to spend a couple of hours, fantastic photos (and a short film) depicting life in Marrakech and the Atlas mountains. Amazing to see how little it's changed. The rooftop terrace has the best views and serves a small but perfectly formed menu of traditional Moroccan food.

Smaller but more interesting than we thought it'd be. The museum is actually a riad. It is fascinating. As a complete philistine, I hadn't realised colour photography dated back to the early 1900s and was completely wowed by the quality of the pictures... The cafe is lovely too.
Great Museum. Super interesting museum of photography, with great insights into the history of Marrakech, as well as it's people.Great views from the roof terrace, too.

Berber history. The video of Berber villages in the 1950s and the tajine chicken with lemon in the rooftop restaurants are strong reasons for visiting the museum, even if beautiful black and white photographs is not your thing.

Well worth a visit. Another local attraction which is well worth seeking out and reasonably good value for the 40DH entry fee. Lots of interesting photos of old, set in a nice Riad like place,There is a small cafe on top (with great panoramic views of the city) where we opted for just coffee and mint tea, although they do also serve a limited lunch menu which looked reasonably priced.

Fantastic photography of early Morocco. A visit here is a great way to get an insight into the history of Morocco. Spread over a number of different floors are stunning photos of all aspects of the history of Morocco - early landscape photos, historical photos of different groups in the population, and a glimpse at the early cameras that were used to capture the photos. It is a fabulous way to get an insight into the history of both Marrakech and Morocco generally.
small and cute. the museum is sweet and small but don't expect too much. the people who work there are lovely and they have a nice roof terrace cafe
Most beautiful photomuseum I have ever seen.. In the beautiful backstreets of the medina you'll find this little museum that will tell you all about the history of this beautiful country.

Have a look if your closeby. I'll preface my review by saying that I'm not a huge photography buff. The museum is located close to the Ben Youssef Madrassa, so it's worth a look if you have time. There's also a lovely café on the rooftop.

Great views from terrace. To be honest we were drawn here by other reviewers commenting on the view from the terrace of the cafe. The photo exhibition was ok, but really the only reason to go here is for the terrace. Unfortunately we were here the day of the Eid ul-Adha and the air was full of smoke from barbecuing sheep!
Beautiful Riad. Housed in a beautiful Riad where you view some of the earliest photos ever taken in Morocco. Well worth a visit.

Even if you are not a photographer.......... You don't have to be a photographer to enjoy spending some time here. Really interesting and well laid out with cards in English and French explaining what you are seeing. Amazing views from rooftop terrace café serving great mint tea and food.
Very interesting. We were a group of Photographers on a Photo Safari in Morocco, so this was a must see. Lovely images dating back to 1880. A good range of prints on sale also.

Enjoyable few hours with food on roof terrace. The museum boasts some amazing pictures of life in Marrakech over 100 years ago as well as portraits that can tell a thousand stories. The design of the museum is very visitor friendly as it is impossible to miss a single picture. For 40 dirhams you can view pictures that really get you thinking and can return for free with the same ticket at any day of your stay. There is a roof top restaurant to enjoy Moroccan cuisine and views of the Atlas mountains, mosques and the city of course.
Absolutely beautiful building with some incredible photographs. A beautiful little museum over several floors. Some incredible photographs and an amazing roof terrace.

Polite and friendly. Bit of a strange review, didn't actually visit this place as such as we were lost trying to find somewhere. So asked for directions and they were lovely, very helpful and polite and even gave us a map and showed us where we needed to go. Thankyou.

Well-curated, beautiful venue. The permanent and rotating exhibits here were stunning. Some helped me see that many sites I was experiencing in 2015 haven't changed that much in the last 100 years. Great space, terraced roof, gift shop with beautiful images, and friendly+knowledgeable staff.

Ignore the Hype. A few excellent pictures surrounded by not many of any note photographically except perhaps for their content.
OK food on the roof.

Interesting historical photographs of Morocco!. The collection on display was interesting, although I prefer older photographs to modern ones (from the times when there wasn't as much influence in a way of photographing Morocco, read: before it became touristy). The museum has a nice cafe on the top with an amazing view over the Atlas. If you purchase a ticket, it gives you a return access to the cafe and to the museum itself (within a week I think).
Good. This was a very good restaurant where i got to eat delicious food and also with that i got very much impressive services. I loved my time spent here. Got good memories.

Well worth the visit. Let's get the rooftop lunch out of the way first - yes, it in itself is an attraction and reason enough to visit. Done.It's interesting to see the past in the exhibits, although in some instances it may not appear to be a greatly distant past. This is a small museum in a beautiful old house and with its size, it's nice to be able to see 100% of the exhibits in a museum.Put it on your list.

Interesting presentation. We visited the Maison while on a walking tour. The photos are over a few floors and are a great exhibit of people over the decades. There is a rooftop that has a rooftop view and tables and chairs that can be used if you buy a drink. There is a film recording the Berber way of life.

Very nice to see how things evolved. Interesting photos of how life was before ww2, something you have to imagine strolling through the medina alleys, sometimes still catching a glimpse in the souks. Also impressive heads and faces of all kind. Some screens show documentaries of Berber country life or interviews with anthropologists. A place to contemplate on what you encountered in the overcrowded hustle of the medina. PS: they also sell copies of their famous photos.

Worth a visit for the roof top restaurant alone!. I wasn't particularly over whelmed by the photography exhibition. Some interesting pictures of times gone by but a lot of repetition. The small restaurant on the roof is ideal though for lunch so would recommend it. Great views and delicious and well priced food.

Charming Riad, stunning photos. This may have been my favorite stop in our three days in Marrakech. The museum is small, but the Riad is beautiful and simple and the photos are stunning. The video being played in the second floor is surprisingly informative. Be sure to pop in when you're in the area.

Beautiful space, great images, friendly staff, great food. This was a lovely trip out, through the souks. Great images, gentle atmosphere and lovely food on the terrace. fell in love with the place and welcome change from the hurly burley(:
A nice place to visit. Great artworks and very authentic place you should visit during your stay at Marrakech. We loved the photos.

Fascinating photographic history of Morocco. The museum has some amazing photographs from the late 1800's to early 1900's and offers an insight into the history of Morocco. Also there is a great view from the rooftop terrace which offers good photo opportunities.
Worth a look. Interesting exhibit with a nice little roof top terrace restaurant. Worth the journey getting lost in the winding streets to find it.

Must do. Lovely exhibition and good restaurant.
Find this lovely gem with its fabulous collection of photos of Marrakech and Morocco, from days gone by.
Their restaurant serves good food with a great view over the Medina.
Meet Marrakech, old and new. Photos from early 20th century about Marrakech, Morocoo, life in desert and more.. It also has a nice terrace where you can watch Marrakech's roofs and drink your tea.

Charming stop in Marrakech away from the crowds.. Charming museum set inside a converted read with a cafe on the rooftop, which offers an amazing view. A short walk from the medina. Interesting selection of photographs displayed throughout the various floors of the museum.

Limited Appeal. Ok if this kind of thing is your cup of tea, but even then, I think anyone would struggleto spend more than half an hour looking at what ostensibly is a colleciton of 40 or 50 framed photographs.There are a few more stored in map cabinet drawers but overall, not much to see really.It's great that the time has been taken to collate this personal collection, but it's purely for the scholars or those specifcally interested in tribal/Morrocan photographic subjects.My advice, pay your Dh10 walk around in 15-20 minutes and then carry on your way to the Ben Youssef Madrasa - literally round the corner.

we loved it!. this is a nice break from walking around the medina. it is located within the medina in a converted riad. the photography exhibit was every bit as good as the ones we have in our home city of New York

Some Gripping Images. Spent an hour here viewing the photographs. Some of the portraits told stories in their eyes and expresions. They were quite remarkable especially when the era in which some were taken was considered.It was interesting to compare old images of Marrakech with the current scene. Other than motor scooters and european dress little seems to have changed.A trip to the roof for some food or drink gives a good view over the roof tops of Marrakech.It's worth navigating your way through the back streets to find this place but beware of unsolicited directions which are conflicting and often wrong. I found asking store owners was more useful than listening to uncalled for advice.
Interesting way to learn about Moroccan culture. Moe interesting than a conventional historical account of a nation - the images tell stories of the culture of the nation of old.

Secret jewel. A little hidden in the Medina you ll find a beautiful Riad presenting a remarkable selection of pictures from the past of Marrakesh and Morocco. An amazing view over the Medina you enjoy also from the rooftop's snack restaurant/bar. It jumped into my TOP 5s to do in Marrakesh.

Amazing gallery. This was one of the best places we visited on our trip. The staff were excellent - very welcoming and informative. The photographs were amazing - overall a fantastic way to spend a few hours.

pretty intersting especially if into historic photos. Lovely terrace on top which for me beat the photos which were fairly interesting. Around 4-5 pounds to get in which is not exactly expensive although by Marrakech standards is not cheap

Worth a visit. Even if you are not heavily into photography this is a nice place to visit with some fxntastic photos old and new housed in a lovely building
Go up to the terrace cafe for sustenance and a great view

Window to te Past. Great collection of old photographs documenting what life was like in Morocco before modernization. Focus is on Berber culture. Well worth checking out. Not big so you can see it all in 30-45 minutes.

Interesting collection. Slightly difficult to find (ignore "helpful" passers by telling you it's closed, they're almost certainly trying to funnel you into the tannery scan), but had an interesting collection, with photos from the nineteenth century to the present.

Really really very nice and worth your visit,. An amazing collection of Moroccan photo's from 1870 to 1950. Patrick, the owner, is a Frenchmen passionate about photography, and has a story to tell about each and every picture. Printed from the antique original glass-negatives, we were stunned by their quality. The museum is housed in an old typical residence, and houses three floors of display. Don't forget to visit the terrace on the top floor and enjoy a mint tea or other beverage and the nice view over the city.Many of the (excellent re-printed) photos are for sale, and we couldn't help ourselves and arrived home with a stunning 1880 photo of the port of Tangiers. Our most precious souvenir from Morocco.It takes a 10-min walk from the Medina square and is easy to find.

Small but interesting exhibition.. Run by friendly English speakers, it's laid out in two floors, showing some interesting photographs. There is a small screening area upstairs playing a fascinating old black and white French documentary of an excursion into some of the lesser known tribal areas of Morrocco.It also has a cafe on the third floor.You can buy some very good mounted prints or postcards in their shop at the entrance.

To Know Morocco Through Good Old Photos. Inside the medina, about 7 minutes walk from Musee de Marrakech. Once inside the maison, a different feel from the rest of other architectures in the medina. Enjoy the vintage photos showing old Morocco. Particularly like its terrace cafe with good view, where good tajine to be served. Not expensive menu. Personally I like this place, good to spend two or three hours.

Worth a visit. Nice place, with an average collection of photos from morroco and marrakech.
The house desserves a visit, but keep your expectations low.
A great project though!

Wonderful portraits. If, like me, you are interested in portraits, these are wonderful examples of Moroccan people. I wish I could be as good as these photographers. The roof terrace has snack bar with views over the medina.

Well presented collection of fine photographs. Well worth a visit , wide range if historically important images . One of the hosts speaks perfect English which was a bonus for me to be able to discuss the technical side of the works. Also the roof top cafe is good value and a welcome break
so so. I'm not a photographer or know much about it. good to see the amazing work in there but i would not feel like i missed out on seeing anything if i hadnt been.

Worth going if it's not out of your way. It's a nice museum that now has an interesting movie running (from the 70s) about Berber life ... it's still relevant today. It only takes a short time to get through the museum. Worth going if its not out of your way. The rooftop is a great view! Very tiny though... and hot.
Very interesting. Great photographic history of Morocco with lovely cafe on the rooftop terrace. Very much worth a visit.
well worth a visit. Some really striking portraits and interesting cityscapes. A lovely shady terrace cafe with views across Marrakech.
Great view but very expensive. great view over the roofs of marrakech, but very expensive! (40 MAD against 10 MAD at other sights). Nice stuff.
Great collection. Great shots, cool souvenirs at an affordable price and a cafe with a great view on the rooftop. Very nice relaxed spot for a moment away from the hussle of the medina!

Good if you like old photographs. Not easy to find.Its housed in a three(?) storey riad down an alley. Its near the Ben Yousseff Medersa & Musee de Marakech. Beware of the local youths nearby who try to point you in the wrong direction or tell you that it's closed.Just make sure you know where you are going and look out for the signs.V reasonably priced also staff friendly. Many photographs stretching back to 1870 of Marrakech & beyond. Plus a short video of old Morocco. Roof terrace at the top serves drinks, snacks etc.Toilet on the ground floor Again v reasonably priced for Marrakech.You can buy many of the prints in the Maison in the shop on the ground floor. Stunning views from on the top terrace of Marrakech plus surrounding Atlas Mountains. Can be a bit boring if you are not into old photos but if you like spending an afternoon perusing through photos of old Marrakech this will float your boat.

A little glimpse into the past. A small but interesting gallery with photographs of old Marrakech and other parts of Morocco, many dating back to the 1930s. Some are of the souks you'll have just walked through to get there - just 80 odd years earlier. It's relatively centrally located and you can swing by the Medersa Ben Youssef on the way, so well worth the visit. Don't let local people tell you it's closed though, especially on a Sunday - they only want to redirect you to the tanneries which are close by.

Great Collection. Spend a couple of hours at the Maison de la Photographie and you won't be disappointed. Set out over three floors the photographs take you through the history of the region in beautiful black and white portraits. There's a well-stocked gift shop on the ground floor and a cool cafe on the rooftop terrace.
Worth a visit . Small museum inside a lovely building with inner courtyard showing beautiful photographs depicting Moroccan people, scenery and traditions.

A way into the past.. A visit to Maison de la Photographie is an opportunity to look into the past of Morocco and Marrakech. Some of the prints will amaze and impress. Many photos, copies or very similar are available and make fine souvenirs
very interesting, great cafe. I enjoyed the building, the photographic displays and the cafe on the roof. One can also buy prints of the pictures on display.
Great piece of history. Wonderful pictures to be seen. You get a real view into Moroccan life over the years. Rooftop cafe has nice views of the city skyline, if you don't mind a satellite or two!
A 'must' if you like photography. Well worth walking through the souks to get here - a lovely exhibition of old Berber pictures which really show a stunning Morocco.

Excellent photography and lovely food. The photos gave an excellent insight to older Marrakech - many photos of the 1920's.Bought some lovely books of photographs in the bookshop and had a lovely lunch on the roof terrace.Well worth a visit!

Snapshot of yesterday - and today!. I love photography, anthropology and history and this museum combines all three to create an enduring snapshot of Morocco's history from the 1880s to late 1950s. Especially fascinating are the movie and photos from the High Atlas and Todra Gorge which show landscapes and people who look virtually the same now as they did when the photos were taken.

The best money spent for visiting something in Marrakech. Just to let you know that you have plenty of interesting and beautiful things to visit and to money on in Marrakech, but this small place, this museum is absolutelly amazing! I enjoyed each minute spent here, in a very calm, fresh and full of history place!Each photo tells you so many things, that you can spend hours just trying to imagine every story hidden behind each image.A must visit museum!

Very educational & beautiful!. My husband and I enjoyed our visit here: Patrick the owner/curator gave us a wonderful overview of the museum and a little bit of it's history. The images were a strong and haunting background to life in Morocco. Note that most of the images are available for sale in a variety of sizes. We enjoyed a calm and welcome break on the rooftop cafe; simply lovely and refreshing before re-entering the adventures in the medina. We also learned that you can schedule some interesting tours through the museum--something for next time!
Great little place. Lovely little place, we found this by chance when slightly lost in the souks, lots of images to see with an amazing roof terrace with a view over the centre of marakesh

Strong story in each picture. The museum is rather small, but the quality of the exposition is amazing. You will see strong story in each picture, in each face - it is easy to imagine how the life in Morocco was flowing a centrury ago. The icing on the cake is the rooftop terrace with perhaps the most beautiful view on whole medina.

Great exhibition and lovely rooftop terrace. This is a gem in the hectic medina. Beautiful photos and building. The rooftop terrace offers great views of the city without all the hustling and bustling of the souks and street sellers. Do be careful of the 'faux guides' around the area, especially children - some will offer you directions/say wherever you're headed is closed, just ignore them.

a great way to see the history of the last century of morocco.. this was probably my favorite spot to visit while in marrakesh. I have to say that the palais's are rather boring. however, if you love photography and are interested in moroccan history, this is the place to go. there are several floors of professional photography by various photographers who explored the country, each floor representing a different era. from the late 1800's to the 1960's. there are views of city life (many different cities) and desert life. plus, make sure you go all the way up and take your own photo from their rooftop of the whole city.

Interesting photographs, fab rooftop cafe. We headed here for the food at the rooftop cafe (great value, delicious, totally amazing views) but the building and photographs were actually really interesting too. It's super easy to find but as always in Marrakesh you must ignore the people telling you that "it's closed now, opens in 2 hours, let me take you somewhere to sit down and wait" etc etc etc. Original reason for going was the food and it's fab, cheap and we had a choice of two tagines when we were there (chicken or veggie). Surprisingly, it was easily one of the best meals we had in the city.

Mildly interesting. Not completely my thing, but not expensive and worth checking out if you're in the area. Watch out for locals telling you 'it's closed' to try and lead you to the 'leather festival'!
Learnt a lot. Fantastic photographs, extremely interesting riad. With a nice cafe on the roof, with great hibiscus tea
Great art. Really artistic paintings and very authentic moroccon atmosphere.Worth a visit but seems like local artists but again do like the way they are presented.

lovely. This little place has a fascinating collection of people pictures from around 1880 through 1960, from a place where people do not like their picture taken. We bought a lot of our postcards here, they were prints of the photographs. If you come from the direction of Souk Bijoux, beware every single person will tell you it's closed, it's gone, it moved, that's the wrong way, there's nothing but the mosque and you're forbidden to go there, etc. etc. Do not listen, just keep on toward and then past the Youssef medersa, watch for the signs posted on the walls.

Lovely experience!. Very pretty house, the photos are very expressive and show Morocco's history in the 19th and 20th centuries in an artistic way. I loved the visit through each floor, it's so smooth. In the terrace, the panoramic view over the medina is beautiful. The tajine there is delicious, the service is excellent too. Really worth it.

Fabulous photos!. My husband being a professional photographer, we definitely had the Maison on our list of 'must see.' It is a multi-level, classic moroccan-designed building in the Medina with amazing photos. If you are a fan of historic photos of the people and country ~ both in colour and black and white, you must go. The tiny gift shop sells very good, somewhat inexpensive reproductions of many of the prints in the maison.

one of the best memories of Morocco. the prints there are just a piece of art not a reproduction , especially for the designers. there are some people that are really Moroccan by nature even thay have different nationalities.patrick is a good example of a natural love to the country.
Great place. Great pictures of the Moroccan history.They have a small restaurant on the last floor with a great view.I highly recommend

great museum. for those of you who don't want to spend a whole day in a museum, head over here and spend an hour in this cozy calm riad full of photography of marocco and travel thru time.at the end of it, stay inside and sit on the terrace for a drink and enjoy the view. The house also offers small tours to the atlas mountains which are reasonably priced and seem to be for small groups of people. would definitely recommend.

Good!. Hard to find but once you do its lovely. Loads of really interesting photos to throw you back to Marrakech's past. Loads of photos to explore and lovely staff. The price was not too bad at 40 dh each but we got a little bit bored after about an hour.

Lovely!. Spent a lovely morning here seeing the wonderful photography spanning many years to show Morrocco's history.We were welcomed by a lovely man who I believe is the founder/creator of the Museum whose enthusiasm for his art shone through.
Great old photos!. Pretty place, friendly staff, great collection of interesting photos. Too bad it's so small that they can't show more of it.
Very Interesting. Interesting photographs found it by accident well worth a visit. If you want something a little different to visit this is the place.

Nice view, 'cheap' drinks, interesting for photography lovers. We visited this place at the end of our lonely planet medina walk. High expectations after reading the description and the recommendation of the owner of the Riad where we stayed. Unfortunately the exposition was not so special to us (maybe this is different for photography professionals).After seeing the photos we went for a drink on the rooftop terrace, which has a lovely view over the medina. Drinks are reasonably priced (12 Dirham for a soda), but it took a bit long to order and get the drinks. So if you are not so into photography, 40 Dirham might be a bit expensive for a nice view and 'cheap' drinks.
Worth a visit.. Really enjoyed this place and take the time to watch some of the dicumentary made in the 1950's. Some of the photos are outstanding. Leave at least 1 hour to enjoy.
Nice, small, local gallery.. Nice, small, local gallery. Interesting. Informative. Lovely owners. Worth checking out while you are in the Medina.

Fantastic photos. Excellent photography exhibition set over three floors. Offers interesting insights into the history of Marrakech and surrounding area. The pictures were beautiful and there is a lovely little roof terrace where you can have lunch. Plus the gift shop sells good quality prints which make nice souvenirs of your visit.
Maison de la photographie. amazing photography over 3 floors with wonderful ambience, no lift! amazing views of marrakech from the roof top cafe.

Wonderful photos and great view from terrace. A real gem. The museum is arranged over three floors with photographs from 1870(!) to 1950s. It's really like stepping back in time and we loved the video of the tribes dancing in 1957. The rooftop terrace with sweeping views really does finish this off to be a wonderful little place. Highly recommended.

ok. Dear friends don't expect nothing exceptional.
It Is just a nice exhibition of photos. Better, photos are very attractive, the way the exhibition is arrange is terrible.
You'll pass the story of Morocco through people and through photos. Amazing images. Quiet expensive.

Nice spot for a rooftop lunch. Set in a beautiful building there are many stunning photos to take in. The rooftop is a good place to have lunch, with a view of the Atlas Mountains. My only recommendation would be to have more translations of information into English.
Too expensive- rip off. 40Dhiram for one room of old photos? Like the Marrakech museum, give this one a miss. Overrated and underwhelming.
Diverse photgraphs and relaxing setting. A wonderful exhibition - particular highlights was the video of the Berber villages filmed in 1957 and the roof terrace was great too!

Photography plus architecture. Beautiful black and white photgraphs
Go early for lunch as roof top was too busy when we arrived
Worth going just to see the building

Such a cool place . Very interesting photos of 1920/ 30 s marrakech and especially a great cafe upstairs on.the roof terrace which was by far our fav place to eat ! Gorgeous set menu really nice surroundings and the staff is so kind . You pay 40 dh for the entrance but can.come back all week if you like . Loved it .

Very interesting, and good food too. Liked this museum very much and wish we'd had more time to explore it (our fault to not allow enough time). Restaurant on the rooftop was delicious, and great views.

Incredible photos!. I really enjoyed this place, If you have any interest in history or photography then go and see, some of the photos are over 100 years old and depicting some magical stuff that really transported us back in time to what this place must have been like.Ps. Dont accept directions..plan ahead and if in doubt, wing it. Your safe in marrakech, just relax and enjoy it.
Worth going if you don't have a lot else going on.. Thought it was OK. I am not huge into photography, so would not say this is an expert's vantage point.

Interesting to see their vieuw!. Interesting place to see, we came their by good luck, but anyway a visit worth! We got good explanation by Arab texts, very special photos of the modern Morrocoan woman. The entrance was only 10 dh.

A pleasantly surprising package. I have to say that I was quite sceptical when my wife suggested visiting this location.The scepticism was exacerbated when we struggled to find it in the maze of alleyways in which it is located.This is not helped by the fact that local youth apparently remove or switch directional signs in the medina in order to 'guide' unwitting tourist their their own 'premises'.This practice is very frustrating and annoying and you should be very wary of accepting an 'assistance' from such people as if you do you are unlikely to ever find your intended destination. (if in doubt ask the shop keepers themselves, not the kids on the street).The Museum itself is relatively small being effective a converted family house with a very pleasant, well lit courtyard which is lined with amazing black and white photographs going back several generations.The photographs are well presented in a loosely chronological order and provide an interesting insight into the peoples of this area going back almost 100 years ago.Copies of most of these photographs available to purchase at reasonable prices and whilst we were there we had the benefit of the owner providing us with a great deal of back ground into some of these photographs which was most informative.I would recommend visiting this place, especially if you are a keen photographer and you have the patience and fortitude to locate it despite the 'assistance' of the local youth.

A Small museum, nothing so special. I could not understand why this museum gains that much high rates from Tripadvisor. Maybe the reason is that Marrakech do not have any good museum, so people gives the higher ranks for relatively good museums. After my visit in Marrakech, I understand that it is a city that you have to spend more time in streets and with people, not in a museum. Anyway, I went to this museum also because of its high rate in Tripadvisor. It has a small collection which you can see in an hour. The entrance fee is 40mrd, a little bit expensive for Morocco. However the building itself is interesting to see. The terrace do not have any special scenery, you can find the same view from a terrace of another houses in Marrakech.

Tourist visit . This private museum has black and white photos of Morocco and Marrakech in the 50s, and the employees there are very nice and educated. And I also highly recommend you eat the roof for lunch and it has a 360 degree view of Medina
Informative and relaxing. I found this museum extremely interesting: best thing is that the entrance ticket is reusable. There is a pleasant cafe/restaurant on top.

Maybe I just don't get it.... There are maybe 80 pictures on the walls over three small floors. After about 15-20 minutes we were finished. Not sure of the appeal - and considering the price of other attractions in Marrakech it's pricey at 40.

Beautiful photos but small place. It's very well presented and lots of great photos. But I was a little disappointed that it was rather small and not that many photos. Nevertheless, it's worth a visit. Visit both Ben Youssef Madrasa and Museum of Marrakech, when visiting Maison de la Photographie. They are close to each other.

amazing photography. Amazing photos! I ended up buying three books to take with me so I can keep looking at them. The room with the first colour photos or what we tend to do nowadays on instagram was amazing.
Excellent. some beautiful images and curated in a very engaging way. The rooftop terrace was a welcome relief and allowed us to spend more time there!

Great dispaly of time and history of Marrakesh growth and cultural change.. This photographic display capture and documents the evolution of Marrakesh and its people from a small trading town into the city it is today. Some aspects of life have not changed in centuries and the film on the Berber culture is a look into a different time and different world. Well worth the visit.

Tranquil gallery with good views from roof terrace. We got completely lost trying to find this place but eventually made it and escaped the hustle of the streets. The photography was interesting although not Amazing, get we had a lovely time winding up the floors to the terrace on the food. And here we sat, drinking tea and watching dusk fall. It was worth it for this alone.

An Oasis of Culture. It was quite a struggle to find this place, through the intricate alleyways of the medina and young boys giving us the wrong directions. But once we found it, it was such a revelation! The museum manager greeted us at the door and gave us a brief synopsis of the history and contents of the museum. The photography on display is simply spectacular and powerful, offering a great insight into the history of the area. There is a very nice rooftop cafe as well in case you want to rest and reflect. A very good range of post cards prints are available for sale, all stunning and reasonably priced. A place not to be missed.

Very interesting place with a fabulous cafe. This museum is super with fantastic images of old Morroco. There was a flim about the berbers on the day we went and it was very interesting. A beautiful building with a great wee cafe on the roof. They have the highest viewpoint in Marrakech. We had a lovely tagine. The call to prayer is superb up there as you can hear all the mosques from this vantage point.
Lovely building with a great collection of photos. . You can go here to admire the building or go to see some great photographs which include a history of Marrakech. A favorite visit of mine.
tourist must see. unusal museum to visit, would not have thought this would be in central marrakech, great pictures ti view, and there is a roof terrace with excellent views of the city

Marrakech history in photos. You can see a history of Marrakech here in the black and white photos they have and it is so lovely to see this and to get the amazing view from the rooftop of the medina. This is a great place to visit.

Worth a visit. Maison de la Photographie was right around the corner from our Riad and we came across it on the last day. A nice way to spend an hour for the small admission fee. I do believe you can re enter as many times as you want if you keep hold of your ticket too. Might be a bit more difficult to find if you were coming from the souks/square though!We had a little talk from an English man, who I think set up the museum (if my memory is correct!) on arrival. It was nice to hear a bit about how it came to be.After reading the other reviews I'm a bit gutted we didn't make it up to the rooftop restaurant!
a gem. Of all the more touristy things we did, this was my favourite. Fantastic selection of photographs in a beautiful courtyard building.
Really Great Exhibits, Good Food. I stumbled upon this gem by happenstance and was really delighted with the quality of work, the atmosphere and the food in their rooftop restaurant.

It is really amazing. I love photography and they have a great collection of photos. It can be quit expensive but is money well spend, and you can go there more times without paying, just keep the ticket.
