They also have a nice terrace with a small restaurant, where you can enjoy your Moroccan meal.

C'EST MAGNIFIQUE!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!. Not easy to find, but do not give up, keep asking directions as when you reach your destination it is so worth it. These collections of photos are superb, and watch the doco on early Amazigh culture filmed in 1956, so informative about this amazing culture. The collections are housed in a beautifuuly restored riad, the staff at reception were very friendly & calming. Try the rooftop cafe, refreshing fruit juices & panoramic views of Marrakech. If you are into photography & exotic images of bygone days this is such a treat. Throughly enjoyed it!!
Worth a Visit. good way to spend a hour some great photos on show in a lovely Riad with a great roof terrace serving food and drink

One of the most memorable things we did in Marrakech. Definitely the best museum I've been to in Morocco. I still think about the images 8 months later. Next time I have to purchase a print. They are stunning and special. A must see

Nice place. Very interesting place to spend a few hours. Very close to my riad Dar Nour El Houda so it would have been silly not to visit. I enjoyed the insight into Moroccan past and present through photography.

Some beautiful images. This was a worthwhile outing, the photographs give an interesting insight into the history of the region. Don't be afraid of the stairs and go have a drink on the roof, the view is worth it.

NIce photographs / extremely beautiful 360 degrees panoramic terrasse!. Wonderful museum with photographs of the people of marrakech from 19th to 21st century, not only the photos are nice, but the building as well. For me, the rooftop terrasse was the most wonderful part of the museum. This is because of the impeccable view over marrakech, a very relaxed atmosphere. Moreover, I can highly recommend to ask the museum for trips, we booked a trip with the french owner to a berber village outskirts marrakech. Not touristic at all, we got a personal guide, taxi from / to the berber village & a wonderful meal from an old lady in the village. The guide Khalid gave us a tour for around 3 hours (not for people in a weaker phisical condition). costs: 30 euros a person including taxi. HIGHLY RECCOMMENDABLE TRIP!

Well worth the hunt through the narrow streets to find.. Exhibition photography in Marrakech needs support and the people who run this place are doing an outstanding job. When I visited for the first time in May 2015, they offered a finely curated selection of B&W prints displaying the city from a time before tourism. You'll see a Marrakech which you can barely glimpse now. The staff are friendly, knowledgeable and attentive. If you are interested in photography, history, or just tired of watching performing monkeys in El Fna, take the time to find this museum.

A glimpse into the past... A beautiful exhibition of photos from the turn of the century. A real insight into how life was back then and some very moving portraits. Don't forget to go up to the terrace for a refreshing drink and great views of the medina

Lovely Museum with a Wonderful Terrace. Had a lovely visit in June 2015. Have to mention that the rooftop terrace served the most beautiful and best value lunch we had during our visit to Marrakech - 3 courses for just 100dr - the chicken and lemon ravine was superb and the views magnificent. Would recommend to anyone visiting Marrakech

Great place to visit. This museum is set in a Riad near the Souks so we got a taxi ride there. 40d entry but that ticket can be used all week which is good to know because there is a lovely terrace cafe. The guide told us to view the photographs in chronological order. They were amazing but not that much English description but some more English on the walls. It's worth a visit to see how Marrakech has changed and it was interesting to learn the photographical history. Cheap drinks with an amazing view of the atlas mountains.

Great place to visit, awesome rooftop. Great place to discover a little bit of the morrocan history. They change their exibition every 6 months. 40dh to entrance (but your ticket can be used as many times as you like on different days)! Try the rooftop, great for drinks and very good prices (with a good view of the medina).
Fascinating. Loved the darkened room with autochrome images from the early 1900's. Also has a rooftop Cafe. Has prints

A bit of a quest to reach this lovely gem of a musueum. Check for opening hours and days as it seems to be a bit varied and unreliable.. Suggest you have concierge call ahead for you. I took taxi to place first time and it wasn't open even though on line it said it was.. Besides that complaint this is a very good collection and if your interests are in history,the romance of how "it once was" then this a good couple of hours worth of delicious viewing.

Recommend the roof terrace. Whilst the museum itself was lovely, can really recommend the roof terrace. It's great for a quick drink and the views of the city are beautiful, it helpful to get your bearings!

Surprisingly engaging. The back alleys of the medina souks are great for finding deals on spices and assorted knick-knacks. Not the kind of place you'd expect to find a first-rate photography museum. So, I was naturally rather surprised by how engaging I found the Maison de la Photographie. Marrakech is already a rather exotic city with plenty of history and its fair share of mystique. Looking back at the city across the decades through striking images of its former residents and visitors adds a new dimension of satisfying complexity to your visit. Indeed it is the images of people, rather than places, that are most captivating. It's worth your time to visit and when you are done don't miss the rooftop cafe where you'll be treating to a rare view over the rooftops of Marrakech with the stunning Atlas mountains as a backdrop.

Fascinating. This was agreat place to visit at the end of our stay. It is alovely building, a little hard to find but worth the effort. Fabulous pictures very well displayed. And a lovely restaurant on the roof with a great view.
Worth your time.. If you are interested in 1) history 2) photography 3) a respite from the hot streets then this is worth your time. When you are done, rest with some cool tea on the roof.

Great way to envision Moroccan life in last couple centuries. We really enjoyed this small museum that's not too far from the Ben Youssef medersa. Lovely photos of Berbers and some Moroccan landmarks such as the Koutoubia in previous centuries. You get an idea of how the people clothed traditionally (up until the 1980s it seems from the picture books I have seen) and there are a few documentaries playing on a loop. It's easy spend 2-3 hours here because they also have a small terrace cafe serving teas, coffee and Moroccan sweets and we've heard the director is friendly and encourages interaction.Look out for the photo of the young Moroccan "hussy" with her legs sprawled, obviously enjoying the attention of the male (client?) seated next to her. That photo came as a surprise to us after all the "normal" Berber photos!

A stunning display for enthusiasts of history, photogrpahy and Morocco. This beautiful gallery is tastefully filled with works by various photographers spanning the late 1800s to the last century. I loved the photography and the glass negatives displayed as well as the various books shown in glass cabinets. The color documentary was fascinating. If you love history, Morocco, art, photography or all of the above this is a must-see!

Lovely. This was a lovely museum, slightly away from the hustle and bustle of the main square. The photography is really striking and gives a great insight into the history of Morocco and it's people. The museum also has a great roof terrace, which is perfect for cooling down and having a tea.

Beautiful photogrpahs and terrace cafe. What a lovely place. Visited in May 2015 and enjoyed my lunch on the panoramic terrace = very reasonable prices - after enjoying all the beautfiful black and white images of Morrocan and Berber life below. The house itself is a stunning example of Morrocan design.

Historic Photos of Morroccan Life. There are very nice photos in the museum, but I believe entrance tickets are a bit overpriced since you can see similar photos on the web. Besides, there is a cafe-restaurant at the terrace which also overpriced.

Beautiful historic photographs in the perfect house for them. It was lovely to see these photographs from a bygone era that imbues the viewer with a pang that s/he sadly missed out on by not being around Maroc at the time. The venue housing these beauties was also a delight, as was the film taken a few decades ago of a trip by a group of foreigners exploring an area of the Atlas mountains. The entry fee is MAD40, and there are a selection of postcards and prints available to purchase. Plan to spend an hour or more if you check out the cafe on the rooftop.

Escape from Medina. As a break of your Medina walk, this is a great location to calm down. Watch the photos while you climb up to the roof terrace to enjoy some nibbles, food or drinks. The view from the terrace is also great.

Beautiful pictures. This museum shows everyday life and people in Morocco, in pictures sometimes over a century old. Beautiful and interesting. The museum is not so large, you can appreciate everything in about an hour. Don't forget to take lunch or drink on the relaxed terrace on the roof!
Nice photos. Great roof terrace! Good photographs! Small place, not sure what price was as it was included in our tour.
I love old photos. Really loved all the old photos and the quiet cool if the riad. Lovely rooftop where you can get a cool drink and yum food and look out over the rooftops.

Favourite spot in Morocco. This was amazing. There are stunning photos that really show Morocco and it's people. Also there is a really nice and chill roof cafe to hang out when you are done. I could have spent all day there really. It is small but worth it. It is also so close to everything it is worth popping in and hang out.

Views of Morocco in the past. Close to other museums. The photographs give an insight to Marrakech and Morocco in past days. With a small cafe on the rooftop and views across the Medina very relaxing. Don't be put off by the local boys telling you the museum is closed and trying to drag you to The Tanneries.

Lovely gallery. Really lovely collection of black and white photographs displayed in beautiful setting. The roof terrace cafe offers a great and keenly priced selection of Moroccan dishes. A must see in Marrakech!

Favourite Place in Marrakech. This museum is fantastic. I lovely little space including photos from the last 150 years in Marrakech. The photos are impressive and show the early years in photograpy. You can see what has changed in Marrakech over the years, but more strikingly how much has not changed. One of the best parts of the place though is the roof cafe with some of the best views across Marrakech and the Atlas Mountains towering over it.
Nice restaurant on the top - limited space though.. I can take or leave the photos but they were interesting enough to look at. The roof terrace and the restaurant were very nice here.
Well worth seeing. Very cool collection of photographs of Moroccan people and history. Cool respite from the city. Beautiful rooftop lounge
Fascinating exhibition.. Seeing these early black and white photos and films was like being invited into a romantic world of the Berber tribes.
Museum of Photography. Loved this museum which was really difficult to find! Particularly interested in the photos of life in Morocco in years gone past. Lovely little terrace too.

Amazing...favorite place I visited in Marrakech!. I'm an amateur photographer and an anthropologist, so I loved seeing all these historic photographs and videos of the different cultures, cities, and landscapes of Morocco. The building itself, a former family home, is also beautiful, as is the rooftop terrace cafe, which has great views. I purchased a print here of the Marrakech square and it's my favorite souvenir...I would've happily purchased more if I'd had the money and could've taken them all back on the plane home.

Interesting, worth a quick look. A good range of black and white photos showing Maroccan and regional culture over the years. Not a big gallery so can easily be done within an hour and worth the quick look.

Beautiful Refuge – Must-See. One of the highlights of my stay in Marrakesh – the photos are all stunning and the building itself is a little getaway from the hustle of the city. Whatever you do, don't forget to head up to the rooftop for stunning views of the city and a tea.

A step back in time through the lens of a camera. This museum has inspired me to take more and more photos. The photographs on exhibit capture a Morocco of the past, of newly explored lands, interesting characters and a nomadic culture that is struggling to remain current. From a photographer's point of you, it shows how photography has changed over the years, not only the equipment and processing, but the subjects as well. Historians will love the scenes captured from as far back as the 1870s. Architects will love the traditional building itself. Everyone will love the view from the roof.Entry costs 40Dh and is worth it not only for the incredible photography, but also the view from the rooftop café. Sit back with a mint tea and take in all of Marrakech as it surrounds you with all its colours, sounds and smells.

Understated but top attraction . You don't have to be into photography to enjoy this. There are just some really good photos and some interesting history of Marrakech. Neither of which I am particularly interested in bit found this place fascinating. Was surprised that it is number 4 top attraction but can see why now. We bought a photo too which is a reminder of our time away.

Portraits and Marocco's Past. Atmospheric and historical scenes and portraits in a lovely cool setting. Good information about early photographers who came to Morocco to record a little visited place. Rooftop café available and near Ben Youssef Madras and Marrakech Museum.

Interesting with a beautiful roof terrace.. It was very interesting to compare 100 year old pictures of marrakech to the same sights that we had walked and travelled. My partner studied photography at uni so obviously found it interesting but from an amateur point of view it was also a good place to visit. Really nice sun terrace with great views.

interesting and informative. Well presented museum, interesting to see these great photos of the history of morocco ... couple of photos taken in 1920 's .... could have been taken last week! Had coffee on the terrace ... great views

Top museum in Marrakech. Enjoyed this the best of all the sites/museums in Marrakech. Suggest you have a look around then come here so that you can compare how things have changed in the city since about 1880. Lots of different exhibitions, well curated with English translations available. Some really memorable black and white pics, regularly changed to showcase the whole collection over time. Friendly staff and some unique exhibits. Especially loved the Berber documentary from the 1950s, I stayed on after the credits to watch it again and got a different film! Think there are 3 x 20 mins in total taking you on a different walk each time, and showing different tribes' dress and customs. We didn't have time to do a full day trip out to the Berber area and this really helped to fill in some gaps. Fascinating. Cafe ok but very limited menu.
Gallery of Photography. Definitely a must when in Marrakech, beautiful building with a fantastic exhibition of photos spanning a 100 years. A wide range of prints to purchase.

first trip to Marrakech. Difficult to find.Very interesting history and photographs.recommended by our Road manager as having one of the highest terraces in Marrakech and with a rooftop cafe.well worth the meandering around Medina to find it (it was our second attempt)

some impressive images. small selection with some truly impressive pieces, but not perfectly arranged and professionally enough documented ... Given the selection the museum has to make a move forward to re-position itself within the competitive environment, especially in light of upcoming new openings in Marrakech

Worth tracking down - Some truly impressive images!. A bit tricky to find, not accessible by taxi. A nice cool building spread over a number of floors, clean wash room and great coffee with splendid views over the souks. Great historical photography and a couple of quite iconic pictures along with significant social history dripping out od some of the older images. Probably not much more than an hour or 90 minutes to have a worthwhile visit. Yet another great venue in this eclectic, vibrant and colourful city.
Nice pictures. Nice photographs and nice views from the roof, where you can have lunch or a snack before continueing visiting the city.

Great place to visit. This is a great place to visit for a number of reasons. Firstly the walk there takes you past many interesting places. The actual gallery was really interesting with lots of information provided in many languages with the photos. Fortunately, this was one of the few places I visited in Marrakech that was not crawling with people. It was a great escape. The view from the rooft terrace was beautiful..
BEAUTIFUL. If you enjoy photographic art, then do NOT miss this place. Wonderful building and excellent hanging of beautiful pictures, especially the portraits of past times.
Don't miss it!. Impressive museum, with great photographs from the 1920-1930s. Great rooftop with WIFI to have a mint tea after the visit.

WOW!. It is such a shame that this awesome little place isn't in any of the rough guides!... It was en route from the Marrakech museum to the tanneries and is a must if you are into art and culture; white washed walls, linen and the scent of jasmine surround the wonderful photos on display and don't forget to go right to the top and sit on the roof terrace; there was music playing in the street below and it was by far a highlight of my 'Marrakech cultural experience'!!

Beautiful Photography Gallery - Amazing views. Beautiful small gallery tucked away in the Medina. Incredible Photography and gorgeous interior. The roof terrace was amazing too with incredible views over the medina

Unknown Marocco. The house is in a quieter district of the Medina. A great collection of photography of the 19th century when hardly any foreigners travelled to Morocco. All the works are beautiful presented. The roof top terrace has a stunning view over Marrakesh and good food and drinks
Pretty Pictures. Nice pictures but the museum was much smaller than I originally expected. I did enjoy the modern photos and I thought it was a nice break from the hot outdoors.

Maison de la photographie. difficoult to find, but nice to see.
it is interesting the film you can see inside and the B/W photos of Morocco in the past

Quaint museum. Lovely museum with some fantastic b&w pictures of different eras. Shows you how the famous landmarks looked in yester years.
Tad confusing but Google maps can be used for navigating.
Lovely views from the terrace.
Interesting photos and fabulous views from the roof terrace. Interesting photos with some excellent portraits. Lovely setting and the vies from the rooftop terrace are some of the best in Marrakesh
Stunning photos. Very interesting museum of photographs on early Morocco and its people. Location is a little difficult to find but locals are very eager to help.
Great B & W Photography of 1930's Morocco. Wonderful museum of 1930's b & w photography and most photos are available to buy in print form. Allow an hour, great views from roof top cafe.
peaceful place. Lovely snap shot view of history of Marrakesh people and region - Berber history - a bit difficult to find but worth it! Lovely cafe on terrace roof with fabulous views over the city

nice rooftop cafe. liked the limited range of pictures, but finding it is a challenge so we took a hair raising tuk tuk ride through the souk to get there. roof top café is great, we had to navigate back with a map and gps compass as google earth is useless in the souk but I later found 'here' gps on android did a better job of getting us back through.

Gorgeous . Stunning place with great photography of Morocco displayed beautifully. Must see for photography lovers or anyone interested in the imagery of the past. Loved the darkened room with autochrome images from the early 1900's. Also has a rooftop Cafe. Has prints for sale at great prices! Check it out!

Fascinating spot. The history of photography and some of the shots here really made me pause and consider. I think it cost around 40DH entry, and it doesn't take long to see what there is to see. But the views upstairs are lovely and the cafe was packed. I would recommend if you're into photography, otherwise it's probably not worth it. I enjoyed it.

Recommended in my guidebook and although small, worth a visit with some interesting and thought provoking photographs.. This was recommended in my guidebook and well worth a visit. The door seems tucked away and although there is a board with photographs outside, as with other reviewers, we didn't find it easily and walked straight past until a very helpful man with a stall on the other side of the road called after me and pointed it out (obviously used to people hunting for it!)We were fortunate enough to visit whilst there was an exhibition of unusual photographs by the excellent Eve Arnold, and amongst many others, some very thought provoking photos (of people in Hungary) by Andre Kertesz, but both of these are finishing at the end of April, but I’m sure will be replaced by something equally as fascinating. The building itself was interesting too, with typical Moroccan brickwork and tiles, and worth sitting on the rooftop terrace for a drink and a cool off from the hot afternoon temperature.

quaint. a good insight into the history of morocco told through beautiful photographs.
the little cafe on the roof is gorgeous.

Worth a visit for a view from the terrace - but only for a drink. We were recommended this place by our Riad owner & he also recommended having lunch. Unfortunately we took his advice & ended up uncomfortable & frustrated. The food is fine if overpriced at 100DH for the set 3 courses. The 3 course menu is fixed with a choice of 2 salads for starter, bread, our main was tagine of lemon chicken ( no rice or couscous) & a delicious maison yogurt for dessert. The problem is the tiny 12" stools at little tables barely 20" high & the painfully slow service, it took the best part of 2 hours from ordering to leaving & that was with me taking my own dishes back to kitchen & a queue of waiting customers. We left quite stressed as we had things to do as I'm sure most tourists do.I would recommend a late morning drink to take in the view before you back starts aching. The Hibiscus tea is a tasty & refreshing alternative to mint tea.

don't visit Marrakech without visiting this. wonderful, irreplaceable exhibition beautiful space, very good restaurant. I visited on the first time for lunch, but the people were so charming and the quality of the exhibits os god, that as econd visit was essential

Little gem. This is in the heart of the Medina and can be difficult to find even with the best map! If you have an interest for early photography in black and white, include this place as it is worth a visit. There are some lovely portraits of people in their costumes of the day. Upstairs there is a video about people and their way of life. This is very much about Morocco as a land of multiple culture .
Nice Museum. In this small museum the staff were very nice, lots of beautiful, and very interesting photos. Nice place for escape from the hot city. The terrace is perfect place for a mint tea.

Cool interiors and facinating photo's. A facinating collection of photo's of Morrocco's past, in a beautifully restored building. The exhibits have additional information laminated sheets in a variety of languages. There is a small roof top bistro, and a selection of postcards/posters etc in the shop. An interesting 1 to 2 hour visit, and a welcome retreat from the heat.
well curated collection in a charming environment. this was a great way to spend an hour. The photos are all interesting, and the terrace a great place for a late afternoon drink at sensible prices.

Favourite museum in Marrakech. A small museum in the medina (a bit tricky to find - we were escorted by local kids!) which tells the story, through mainly 1920s and 1930s photographs, of the ways of life, music, costume and traditions of the various tribes of morocco. Suggest you visit after you've been to the museum of Marrakech because you see the artefacts in the photos. There a some stunning photos in this exhibition. Well worth a visit. Nice terrace for tea too.
Disappointing. we had high expectations prior to our visit and left feeling disappointed, a little pricey for whats there. However the view from the rooftop café was fabulous

Amazing a must see in marrakech. Situated in a Riad this stunning collection of photographs is well worth the visit . The photographers have created some beautiful and in some cases atmospheric images of Morocco in the early years of the camera ! Has to be my favourite place to see in Marrakech - even had a small roof top cafe .

Interesting. I visited for an afternoon, the exhibition was interesting but fairly small.
The cafe / roof terrace was really nice!

An intriguing glimpse of the past. The traditional Riad building was a wonderful foil for these stunning and informative photos. We also loved the old documentary footage-what an amazing proud and stunning people. Be sure to use the cafe, delicious food and the most amazing view of the Atlas Mountains.

A View of the Past. The array of black and white photography is striking, especially in a city of colour such as Marrakech. The exhibitions are relatively small which means you can take your time viewing and the cafe on the rooftop is very pleasant - we had another delicious tagine and mint tea here and found it to be relatively inexpensive for the shade and view out over the rooftops it provides.

Marrakesh in pictures. This is a small, wonderfully curated museum. The photographs provide a real insight into Moroccan life and show how little some things have changed for some Morroccans. The museum is housed in a lovely building and should be on your top 10 things to see in Marrakech. Don't miss it. The cafe serves excellent food but be prepared to wait - it's worth it!

photography museum. Interesting museum. There is a cafe on the terrace but we had to wait ages to be served so gave up. The way of life is slow and we were happy with this but they could have been more aware of customers so missed out

A Beautiful Time Machine. Whoops! I referred to this breathtaking institution as 'Musée', rather than 'Maison' in my hotel review... A visit here was highly recommended by a Moroccan friend of mine and it truly is a gem of a collection, sequestered away in the heart of the souks. Don't allow any itinerant businessman to steer you away from its path, encouraging you to look at Berber leathers, stay the course and enjoy the amazing photos, spanning generations and every hue of Moroccan from the early days of photography. The traditional tiled and white-walled courtyard and galleries provide a perfectly sympathetic backdrop for the works. You can also take in some videography, which gives background for the exhibition and the is a rooftop café, with wifi, that parallels the 360 city views from the top of Café de France. Saïd and Muhammad were knowledgeable and super-personable curators. Well worth the visit. I, personally, felt caught between being moved to tears by the beauty of the photos and wanting to set up camp and live in the midst of it all ;)

Beautiful photos located near the Ben Yousef Madrasa. This museum is located right around the corner from the Ben Yousef Madrasa. I enjoyed the museum despite having a limited knowledge of photography. There's also a rooftop restaurant with an amazing view!

Definitely visit - Average museum - excellent food in the cafe but poor service. This place was highly recommended to us by friends who had been and it was not dissappointing. Although I feel there could have been more to the museum rather than the cursory descriptions of the pictures, it was quite insightful and there were many good photos worth seeing although it was a little disappointing later in our holiday when we realised that all the photos we saw in other restaurants were apparently prints purchased from this museum.On the roof is the cafe which makes this place worth visiting. A great little cafe which is so good it is unfortunately crippled by its popularity that can leave you waiting a long time to get any service or food.The waiter is apologetic but it can be a little bit frustrating, with such a small menu, they just need a second waiter.Worth the visit and highly recommended.
Wonderful Museum. If you like photography, I recommend a visit to this museum. It is well curated with beautiful photography of Marrakesh from the late 1800s to the 1940s. The images are striking.

Another haven and wonderful insight . We visited here at the same time as the Ben Yousef Mederasa as it's quite close. It costs 40 dirhams each but well worth it. It offers such an insight into Marrakech and other cities around Morocco. It also has a small rooftop terrasse with great views. We didn't eat there but the food looked really good.

Fabulous photos of Berber life 80+ years ago. Loved the museum, but I love photos in general. It's located in a beautiful little building in the middle of the Medina. Great views from the cafe on the top floor. Food on the pricey side and not that great. So many other more interesting food choices in the Medina.

Little gem with a great terrace. There are some amazing photos here as well as a unique antique documentary about the Berber peoples living in the Atlas mountain range. The best however is a nice terrace where you can enjoy nice juices and beverages while watching a beautiful sunset over Marrakech. They offer food too but we didn't really sample much of that.The personnel are really nice too.
Morocco as it was.. More a series of historical images than any remarkable photography. Cool location though a bit tough to find and the rooftop café worth a visit.

for die hard photography buffs only!. A bit dull unless you are really keen to see the collection of mostly aged b/w photos of times gone by, which is of course interestingto some.Having said that, worth a peer in, if only for a cool drink on the roof top cafe shack, for views over the medina.
worth a visit. Such a lovely spot with a fabulous little cafe on the roof. You will be transported to old Morocco through these evocative photos that show a life both familiar and vanished.

Beautiful museum inside the souk:). It was my last day in Marrakech and decided to go to this place.it is situated in a very secluded beautiful souk.There is arrows to go but the best to do is ask for directions to the sellers.They are very helpful.Its worth looking for.The receptionists are nice and trying to explained what's the museum is about.All the Berber people and Moroccan people picture were so original.You can even see the signatures.At the top there's a cafe where u can have lunch or tea.The view is so lovely and food is good and affordable..Definitely recommend to come here and know the history of people of Morrocco.
A sanctuary for rest!. La Maison de la Photographie is a sanctuary for rest located around the Marrakech souk. Be sure to make time for the terrace cafe! The views are appealing!
Intimate, beautiful museum. This museum is a gem, with 19th and 20th century pics of Morocco, mostly by French photographers. The roof-top terrace offers a great view of Marrakesh.

Interesting and eye-opening. This was a great distraction for an hour, the photography was displayed sensitively and in a well organised way. There was a surprising number of photographs representing the earliest photography in Morocco. There was a lovely rooftop terrace and cafe too.

Worth the quick walk from Ben Youssef. The museum has a very nice collection of old photographs which shows you how the medina and Marrakech in general looked a century ago. Be aware of the people in the streets towards the place that will want to take you to the tanneries. They will assure you that the Museum is closed, and offer to take you to the tanneries instead. This of course is not true. Just say thanks and continue on your way.
recommended to us. Very interesting - seeing old and new pictures. Did find it difficult to find, at first - but then thats half the fun - getting lost!

Go for the roof terrace. If you are interested in photography and scenes of Morocco then definitely come here. If not, it's worth having a drink of the roof terrace just for the view. They have prints of the photos for sale for about US$25.

Small place with nice photos. small museum worth to visit, amazing pictures.
Amazing terrace with great views of Atlas Mountains. Liked the contents and the terrace.

Brilliant, must do!. It is a well known spot to visit in Marrakech for a reason. The photos are amazing and the building is beautiful! The staff also take the time to show you things so that you get a bit of the history of Marrakech too

Beautiful and interesting. This collection of photographies show Morocco's history in a simple and beautiful way. It's a little hard to find, being squashed into the labyrinths of Marrakech's souks. But it's worth finding, a great choice of both cities and people. Slightly inaccessible for the non-french speakers, but still more then worth it.
worth a visit. This is a must have attraction to go to in Marrakesh just to see the view over Marrakesh and the view of the atlas mountains with snow on in the distance

Beautiful photographs.. We really enjoyed viewing the photographs, my husband is a keen amateur photographer so enjoyed it even more!The photos are really interesting and each tells its own story, we were lucky it was not overly busy when we were there (I think everyone was on the roof terrace) this is one place that we felt we actually learnt a lot more about the history of Morocco through the pictures on display, a true work of art.
Stunning Gallery. I loved the tranquility and the well educated handsome young men who will give you a tour of the excellent gallery
great location. good captions and interesting unusual photos - well worth going; it is located at the moment inside an ancient palace now in ruins - very cool
Great captures. It was great to see captures from the turn of the century. You can can really get a feel of Tangier during that time period. A must see if you love photography.

Nice little gallery. Nice selection of interesting Moroccan photos taken over the years.
Small roof top cafe with a bit of shade and lovely views.

A little hard to find but worth persevering - gorgeous photographs. It's so wonderful seeing the old photographs of Marrakech and Morocco - it really gives you a sense of the culture and allows you to appreciate how little some areas have changed over time!
A gorgeous little museum with a nice gift shop where you can buy prints and postcards as souvenirs.

Fascinating. Not a huge museum but full of fascinating photos showing more than a century of Marrakech and wider Morocco. Excellent view of the whole Medina from the roof terrace. Good shop selling mounted copies of many of the exhibits. Highly recommended.
very interesting and relaxing. A very well put togther collection of photos, all well-explained. The building is charming and there are excellent views from the roof terrace.
Worth a look. Not too large to see,small insight into the designers life and works,ok if you like that thing...I wasn't too interested to be honest but pictures are ok

Marrakesh Photography 1870 to 1950 Museum. An excellent collection housed in an elegant Riad. The photographs are a wonderfully vivid testimony to a culture which still exists in Morocco, though is increasingly compromised by modernity. We spent much longer there than we'd planned - there is a small, but good cafe on the roof overlooking the Medina. I wished I'd bought more postcards as I sent most of mine out. If in Marrakesh, this is not to be missed.

Lovely little oasis of peace. Small house with 3 floors of photos. The great thing is the roof terrace. Lovely view over Marrakech. Good food and most importantly, really peaceful. A much required refuge from the chaos of the city.

An oasis in the heart of the souks. Quite hard to find but worth a visit. Beautiful original black and white photographs of people and places that you can associate with today. A very relaxing experience in pleasant surroundings.

Small but fascinating museum. This museum is so we hat tucked away but worth the effort to find it. Great photography from late 19th century and an interesting video from one of the photographers who was there in the 1940s, a good selection of prints for sale. We had a delicious lunch in the roof top cafe ( aubergine salad and Moroccan salad.) There are several artisanal type shops on the same street worth browsing - a metal lantern shop where they made the lanterns in the back shop, a leather shop and a store selling traditional woven cotton and linen scarves. If you continue down the lane (turn right out the door of the museum) you will eventually come to a small local market selling fruit, bunches of lavender and a good selection of dates. A very worthwhile outing.
great place for photography, and wonderful rooftop cafe!. don't miss this place although it's a bit hidden away. Views from rooftop are almost as good as inside
For Photos lovers. If you love old photography of north africa don't miss this great little museum. The collection goes from 19th Century to the 21st Century.

Lovely place for lunch. The Maison de la Photographie is worth a visit, especially for its lovely roof-top cafe. It has a nice collection of photos which the average person may spend around 30 minutes looking at. The main attraction in my view is definitely its roof-top cafe where you can have cold drinks and lunch. It offers lovely views of the city.

great place. the photos were superb, they have a very nice collection of historical photographs of beginning of XX century in a very nice house. The place is nicely restored and kept. lunch on the terrace superlative and good price. Staff was friendly. don't miss it

For History and Photography Enthusiast. There are a lot to be learned of a country from its written history - but more so from a photographic gallery. This gallery/museum in the heart of the medina in Marrakech may be small but its display is large enough to satisfy a curiousity to Morocco's history in visually stunning photographs in black and white. There is a small cafe on the terrace but the main draw is the view of the rest of Marrakech and the surrounding Atlas mountains.A visit here is worth your interest in history and photography.
Good lunch. Very beautiful building and interesting photography.If you have time, have lunch on the terrace, I loved it!

Place you must see. The Maison de la Photograhie is a wonderful museum, a quiet oasis in a very busy street. Beautiful and interesting historical pictures in a nice atmosphere. Visit the nice rooftop café (with Wifi!).

A great visual insight into Morrocco. The exhibition allows you to look into the eyes (and felt like their souls) of the Moroccan people without any intrusion. Insightful photos displaying costume, transport, most importantly people. The cafe is up a tight spiral staircase so not too accessible for some. Difficult to choose a favourite but could happily return which your ticket allows.
Worth a visit. A wonderful exhibition of old photographs. Lovely quality display and plenty of multi lingual explanation

Interesting and elegant.. Fantastic photographs from the past in a really elegant setting.This Riad has been restored sympathetically and with great sensitivity.It was a pleasure being there.I would definitely re-visit when back in Morocco.

A must must see!. We only discovered this museum on our last day in Marrakech and it made me want to stay longer!! The photography is absolutely wonderful - some images still stick in my mind - but the whole setting is superb, and the views from the roof cafe just incredible! Possibly late afternoon as the flat-roofed scape is bathed in a glorious, warm glow while you sip mint tea and contemplate this incredibly exotic (to the likes of me) world.

Fascinating view of Morocco's history - and check out the rooftop cafe too. As people have commented, this is hard to find as the signs on the streets nearby fizzle out as you get near, but it's worth hunting down. Fascinating historical portraits of Moroccan tribesmen and women, 19th and 20th century pictures of towns and cities and documentary film. Set in a beautiful building, the rooftop cafe also offers a small menu but it's delicious food, with vegetarian choices too.

Some pictures well worth seeing. It isn't too expensive to go round this fascinating little museum (40 MAD) and it won't take you too long. The exhibition focuses on pioneers of photography in Morocco and some of the pictures are amazing. It was very interesting for example to see how the sedan Tombs looked pre restoration and to see how in some ways Marrakech hadn't changed a huge amount (vastly in others of course!). There is a small roof top cafe serving guess what.....Moroccan salad, chicken tagging etc, but it all looked good!
Make the effort. A little hard to find, but worth it. Fascinating photographic history of the region, with the opportunity to buy copy prints. Like many Moroccan museums very cheap to visit.

Small and Hard to Find - But Worth the Effort. Like the title says. This small jewel of a museum is tucked away like most everything in Marrakesh, but if you enjoy looking at old photographs and truly want a glimpse of Moroccan culture going back more than a century - make the effort. One can easily spend and enjoyable hour looking at the photographs and then have lunch at the museum's rooftop cafe.
Not what we expected.. Just an old building with Photographs of famous people who had been to Morocco.Nothing much else to say really.

Well worth a visit. A must for anyone interested in photography and/or Marrakech. A lot of effort has clearly been expended in the layout of this fine gallery, which includes a terrace café to quench your thirst after viewing the wonderful photographs.

Great gallery. I had read the reviews and visited the gallery. Definitely a wise choice. The show is excellent and the restaurant upstairs amazing. The only reason I didn't give five stars was because I would have liked to have seen some contemporary work!
A Joy. A moving and breathtaking collection. Not a large exhibition space so not an overtaxing visit. Hence can be grouped with other activities. Do not miss it...

Good way to spend an hour. We enjoyed the historical aspect to the photos, although many were of Tangier. It was good to see a traditional house complete with beautifully tiled floors.The roof terrace is a good place for a quiet drink with a great view over the rooftops.Western style toilet was a bonus.
amazing photo's. very nice little gem in the souks...a must do with a beautiful view of Marrakech on the terrace ,drinks are cheap

A Pictorial Jewel. When you have exhausted the Medina and its souks head for the Museum de la Photographie. Keep trying until you find it. Definitely worth the effort to see some fabulous black and white photos of real Arabian life.
Excellent. This museum in a traditional house (which in itself is worth visiting), is a fabulous visit whether you are a photographer or love history. Well worth a visit

Somewhat Disappointing. Having read about this place and being a very keen photographer I was keen to visit this place whilst staying in Marrakech. However, my exception were dashed and I came away somewhat disappointed. I think a lot more could be done to make this a most excellent visitor attraction.

Great photos and excellent food. The collection of black and white photos was really interesting and they were well laid out. A new museum is apparently being constructed so many more items will eventually be on display. The rooftop restaurant was small with excellent and quite reasonably priced food. The service was superb.

Fabulous fotoextravaganza. This exhibition is glorious, rich and textured and inspiring. The photographic portraiture is wonderful and evokes a bygone era of exploration. Lots to see, excellent film clips and photos to buy if you are so inclined.

A Gem in the Medina. We were taken here by the owner of our riad on the first night we arrived, this is a high vantage point to see the city and the sunset. The exhibitions here are worth a good look and it is a great place to go for lunch. Your ticket allows you to return as often as you wish. We had lunch here before our flight home and bought a print with our remaining currency to remind us of our holiday.

A must do in Marrakesch. This exhibition is a must do - take an hour to wander and absorb, there are photographs from 1880, which means you are looking at people possibly alive in the 18 century - the exhibition is beautifully presented with the black and white photographs foregrounded by the the white walls - it also brings home the effort Europeans must have taken to physically get to morocco in the 19 century - a very moving experience - try to watch the cine films showing on the third floor - amaze balls - to quote the bard - simply brilliant - food smelt wonderful too !
wonderful old photos. so interesting to see how the medina and people looked long ago-and very informative video from years gone by

A must see museum. An interesting place to visit with some fascinating photographs of Morocco through the ages plus a video of the Berbers from the 1950s. All housed in a traditional riad with a courtyard.

Fascinating photos. This is a great little museum showing some amazing photos taken over the past 100 years. The roof top terrace / cafe has great views of the city, although like many places it doesn't serve alcohol. The only small negative is that most of the descriptions are in French & Moroccan but that didn't spoil the visit - the photos are great
Well worth a visit. Such a marvellous gallery. With a roof top cafe to boot. Essential if you are in the Old Town. Extremely well thought display of mainly sepia toned images.
Wonderful museum. Beautiful exhibit of Moroccan photographs in a beautiful house. There is a great view of the city and the High Atlas from the roof.

Fascinating exhibit. An extensive collection of photographs of Morocco, covering a long time period. If you're at all interested in photography and/or the cultural history of Morocco, don't miss this wonderful collection.

Fabulous exhibition lovingly curated. The exhibition is a fantastic with photographs from the 1880s to the 1940s. It is lovingly curated in a serene setting and the black and white photographs were offset beautifully against the white walls. We did not eat there but amazing smells wafted from the kitchen.

Alternative perspective, nice pit stop if you are in the area! . My husband was engrossed in the history and soaked up the minimal information available that was alongside some of the more prominent photos! I was less enthralled, but I appreciated the beauty and skill of the portraits. I found the lightbox fascinating, as it brought the photos in that section to life. The rooftop terrace was fab, and it was where we caught the first glimpse of the high level atlas! The whole place feels calm and intimate, I would recommend it.
If you like photographs you will love this. What a beautiful place. Same owner as the Musee Douriria de Mouassine. Enjoy the peace, cool and photographs. Lovely. Good value. Lovely staff.

Disappointing. Given this was one of "the sights to see" i didn't feel enriched and it was soon difficult to find - give it a miss and take the time you save just taking your own photos of this fascinating city

spend 3 hrs here. This is a great museum, gallery and cafe! While I visited all the usual museum suspects highly rated on TripAdvisor, this was my favorite by far. It was local yet it had a much wider scope. Wonderful place.

not to be missed while in Marrakech. This charming museum has fascinating photographs (some of which you'll see on postcards around town) and a relaxing rooftop cafe with a good view of the Atlas Mountains. It's just a few steps from the beautiful Medersa Ben-Youssef so can easily be combined with a visit there. It's a tranquil place that is a welcome respite from the pressures of the frenetic souks.
Nice little museum. Very nice black and white photoes from Marrakech, a nice roof top terrace with a cafe and also a little shop

A fantastic attraction with lovely rooftop food thrown in!. I was pleasantly surprised by this oasis of calm away from the hustle and bustle of the streets. Some stunning photography ensured a mood of peace & tranquillity with the added bonus of some lovely food at the rooftop garden. Also if you keep your admission ticket you can get in again for free... bonus!!!

A surprising treat. I cannot recommend this location enough. It provides a wonderful insight into life in Marrakech and wider Morrocco over the years in a beautiful building. The staff were helpful giving an introductory talk and available with additional information. It has a lovely terrace for a cold or hot drink and should not be missed. A ral gem in this wonderful city.

Very pleasant. A small museum in a nice building, not stunning but definitely refreshing, original and interesting. Just go there if you happen to walk in front of it, and don't forget to climb on the roof terrace when finishing as the view from there is wonderful.

Worth seeing!. This gallery of historical photos of Marrakech and other cities in Morocco,is well organised and a peaceful haven in the madness if the Souks.The information on the photographers and photos is well documented and clearly labelled. There is small terrace cafe on the roof, with great views over the Medina
A fabulous exhibition. An absolutely wonderful collection of photographs of Morocco. Well worth a visit - a highlight for me.

Off the beaten track. A real gem and well worth getting lost a few times In the souks and alleyways of the medina before finding it!The gallery is located in a renovated house built in the typical style around a courtyard. Three floors of photographs of Moroccan life from the late 19th to mid 20th century along with some small exhibits showing photographic developments from that period.Great little cafe on the roof offering views across the medina rooftops to the High Atlas to the south (we had a clear day). Feb 2015, entrance fee was 40Dh (under £3) each but that gave unlimited access and we went back just for a peaceful lunch.

Great photos - and an even better view. Wonderful airy riad with fascinating photos of Berber and other Moroccan life in the early 20th century. The view of Marrakech and the Atlas mountains from the roof terrace is a dream
A Must See Exhibition. A very well presented display of historical photographs giving an insight to Moroccan life in days gone by. Not much appears to have changed !!

Difficult to Find but Worth the Trouble. Like many attractions in Marrakech some clear directional signage would be helpful. When we eventually found it we had been about to give up as it was raining but the content of the exhibit and the premises were worth the hunt. The photographs are fascinating and the brilliance of the early technology is very humbling. It would have been lovely to have had coffee on the roof terrace but the weather was against us.

Beautiful old photos in a small house with lovely rooftop view. This museum was magical in its evocation of old Morocco. Outstanding photos, beautifully mounted. High roof so great view - can gets drinks there.I would have liked a little more biography of the photographers

A 'must visit' in Marrakech. The historic Morocco photographs are a genuine insight. While there, do go up to the cafe on the top floor for some of the best roof-level sights of the city with the snow-capped mountains in the distance.
What a gem. A wonderful collection of photos in a beautiful setting. Well presented. Helpful and friendly staff. Nice cafe on the roof. Definitely worth the visit
Oasis in the Madness. Beautiful building housing amazing photographs with a rooftop cafe..stunning views of the Atlas mountains....go!

Interesting collecting highlighting the atmosphere of Marrakesh.. If you like photographs this is for you. Very nicely laid out showing many scenes and people of the region..a pleasant hour or so can be spent here then after there is a rooftop cafe with spectacular views of the Atlas mountains.
Great for photographers. Well worth a visit if you are into photography. Really enjoyed the visit. Easy to find on foot just follow the signs.

Nice to tick off. Lovely & peaceful with a great roof terrace for relaxing.
Very nice to walk around and view the different photos, and very cheap entry.
Worth a visit but not a must do
Nice museum, great little cafe. Interesting old photos and their history. Excellent value little (so get there early) rooftop cafe with views of the Atlas mountains
Evocative collection. Wonderful photos well displayed with a restaurant on the roof overlooking the Ben Yussef mosque and the Atlas Mountains.

Small exhibition, manageable in 2 hours.... I enjoyed looking at the historic portraits and an interesting short film about the principal photographer... It seemed to focus on images from Tangiers which was surprising... Also images of Berber culture which was fascinating... There was a lovely inexpensive cafe upstairs with great views of the medina...

worth a trip. if you can find it (ask in souk) about 100m from marrakesh Museum..... well laid out, old photos last century; nice rooftop cafe
on 3 floors and cafe accessible only by spiral staircase.
Great rooftop café. Some amazing photographs in the gallery but the café on the roof is the hidden gem for a tea or coffee...

Lovely Photographic Museum. We really enjoyed this museum. Very well done, perfect setting. Really gives you a feel for how Marrakech used to look. The bones of the old city are still the same so it is easy to see where the pictures are from. Mostly black and white, beautiful work, mounted perfectly. Nice rooftop cafe and right across the street from an elementary school. I enjoyed hearing the kids sing and seeing them get out of school.

Wonderful Small Gallery of Moroccan Photographs. This small museum is worth a visit. It is a wonderful old building with an equally wonderful collection of Moroccan photographs displayed on clean white walls. A small roof terrace serves coffee, tea, soft-drinks and snacks and has a great roof top view. The small admission price allows multiple visits. A bit tricky to find but well worth the effort.
Glimpes from the past. Beautiful photos of Marrakech from days gone by. The variety was huge and available for purchase. Great stop

beautiful small museum. We went hiking in the Atlas mountains through many of the Berber villages. Got this museum recommended by a swedish couple who visited it to compare the now and then of the life in the Atlas mountains. Was totally worth it and you can visit it over and over again once you bought the ticket.

Nice cafe on roof terrace. The views from the roof terrace cafe are great. Check your change at the cafe as they will short change you if you can.There is a clean lavatory.The museum is a pleasant place to visit but I did not find the photographs that interesting.Keep you ticket and come back to use the cafe another day.Amazing sunset view from the roof.

Small, calm space. Not convinced that we were dropped off at the nearest point by our taxi driver, but after walking though the souks, we did eventually find Maison de la Photographie, not sure I could tell you how we found it, or if we could find it again, but, what I can tell you, is, that it is worth seeking out. Really loved this place.It is set in a traditional Raid, it's small, but perfect, set over three floors, with a little roof top café, where we stopped for a mint tea.It open's at 9:30am,we got there at 10am, and it was starting to get busy at 10:30am. I think it cost 40 Dirhams each to get in.Beautiful black & white photos set over the three floors, showing some really interesting images of Morocco. Staff were helpful, polite, and informative. and you can buy prints and post cards of the photos if you want to. Great place, would highly recommend a visit.
A small personal museum. A nice visit - views from the rooftop terrace of the atlas mountains were a highlight ! Interesting to read the influence of Scottish photographers !

Went twice!. A fascinating tour of Moroccan culture with some beautiful and arresting images. Another bonus is the lovely café on the roof terrace with far-reaching views and delicious home-cooked tagines and couscous where you can lunch very well for not much!

Photography and Culture. A cross section evoking early 20th century Morocco. Clearly displayed in a handsome building.(Be aware that some kids will tell you, "It's closed," and try to direct you somewhere else)

Art, Photography, Culture housed in an amazing building. If you like photography this place is a must see stop point. Good for the social anthropologists and photographers alike. Interesting portraits and pictures mainly in black and white offer a historical snapshot of the changing face of Marrakesh over the last hundred years. The exhibition is housed in a stunning building over a number of floors with roof terrace - not good if anyone in your party has difficulty climbing stairs.

Very interesting. This is a great place to visit for an hour or so. Entrance is 40Dh (about £2.80) and there is a fabulous roof terrace café with great views over the whole city with the Atlas mountains as a backdrop.

Most Interesting. This museum is fascinating in that not only does it contain lovely old photos of Morocco and its people but also equipment and photos dating back to the almost the beginning of photography.

The highlight of our trip....!. Marrakesh is a great place to visit and the Maison de la photographie would enhance any visit with a truly amazing collection of photographs from 1880's to 1930's of Berber people, Gnaua musicians, nomads, the souks, the square etc. It really helps to put in context the history and culture of the region. It is all housed in the most delightful riad with a roof top restaurant that serves lovely, reasonably priced food. For me it was the highlight of our trip!
Photography. Interesting collection of historic photographs of Morocco and its people. Great view from the rooftop cafe. A must for photographers.
Superb and a great terrace. A really tasteful and beautifully designed exhibition of wonderful photographs. Topped off with a lovely terrace offering drinks or meals. Not to be missed

Not to be Missed. This was one of our favourite places in Marrakech. The photography exhibition was interesting and it has the bonus of the best views over Marrakech to the High Atlas mountains from its roof terrace - absolutely breathtaking.

Extremely interesting. Set over three floors the exhibition was fantastic, showing photographers from back in the 1800's. We spent about an hour and a half looking around and once we were finished we enjoyed a drink in the sun on the roof terrace.

Great little find . Hidden away amongst the northern medina's souks and alleyways is a wonderfully boutique gallery, which in essence is similar to a small Riad in size, over 3 floors and a terrace. Various pictures taken from 1890--1960 with brief descriptions make for a gently r chanting experience as you quietly meander around its well tiles floors.A great reflection of old Morocco.

Nice exhibition and amazing view. We had a few issues finding it but once we arrived the exhibition was worth it. a multi-level space is full of images from Moroccos photographic history. The photos are well labelled and there are interesting notes on the history and photographers involved. The cafe at the top of the building is tiny but with a great view of the city and mountains. We had a reasonable mint tea and coffee up there and although we didnt eat the food looked nice enough.

Great Exhibit. This is a very interesting exhibition, lots of photos of old Marrakesh and Morocco in general. A super film is run on the top floor. Fab views of the Atlas mountains from the top terrace. Nice clean toilet!
Superb Pictures, stunning view from roof. Very interesting collection, well worth the visit. Nice rooftop terrace to get reasonably priced drinks and snacks all with a stunning view.

The best way to learn about indigenous people of Morocco. As the Marrakech Museum does not tell a lot of story of the Moroccan people history, this photography museum feeds our thirst. Really, the showcase of beautiful photos from the 1930s-1940s is the best way to tell us the story of Morrocan indigenous people. The maison de la photographie also has no doubt the best terrace in the town, great view of the town's skyline and Atlas mountain. Get some mint tea there!
Photos of old Marrakech & Morocco. A lovely collection of photos housed in a traditional riad, with a small cafe on the rooftop. We viewed the sunset after looking round the collection.
A hidden treasure. Wonderfully presented, and oasis of peace in a bustling city and the best toilets in Marrakech.Don't forget to have a coffee on the roof and take in a view of the Mountains

Lovely photographs. Loved looking at the old photographs but the best bit was the great food we ate on the terrace and the magnificent view of the city with the Atlas Mountains in the background. Will never forget that view as long as I live.Could have stayed all day and watched.
Fabulous. Hard to find, but everywhere in Marrakech is hard to find. Don't let friendly locals show you, it will cost you

Definitely worth a visit. great pictures from the 1870s to the 1950s! They offer a unique view on Morocco at the time. Some pictures are absolutely breathtaking and the rooftop café is great (and has free wi-fi, a rare enough commodity in Marrakech). Like in a lot of museums in Marrakech, the exhibition is a bit short and your visit may only last longer than 30/45 minutes if you look at every photograph with minutia.

A little gem. Fantastic. Wonderful photographs. Great rooftop terrace and food. The collection is a really important view of the development of the country stretching from the late 19 C and should help to guide future development of the country.

Go for the view. Lovely photographs, but the best bit is the roof terrace with a panoramic view over the rooftops of Marrakech to the Atlas Mountains. There is a little café there where you can get a drink or lunch. Food was good, and the view is stunning.

Great Pictorial History. A great photographic history of Morocco set in a well restored Riad. Definately worth the visit. The photos tell their own stories. There is also a great view from the roof of Marrakech.

Worth the time.. After reading about it here I thought I'd be in for a much better experience than it really was. Anyway, it's worth it, but no big deal if you miss it. The terrace is cool and you can have something to drink up there.

Brilliant - went twice. Highly recommend it. Gave a real insight into the life in Marrakech in the past.. Well displayed and peaceful environment. Lovely roof top cafe and reasonably priced. We visited twice as you could visit as often as you liked with just the one ticket.
photograph museum. fascinating a real look back in time with amazing pictures and a roof top terrace for something to eat and drink with a view over the city

Unexpected pleasure. This small museum, tucked away in the Medina of Marrakech, offers a wonderful photographic insight into the country as a whole, as well as having some of the best city views and food on the roof of the terrace/cafe. It's good value too, as you can return as many times as you like with one ticket - worth it for the food alone.
Worth a visit. Lovely and fascinating old photos, housed in a delightful setting. An interesting historical insight into Morocco. Good little café on the roof. Clean loo, which helps!
Great photos from this wonderful country.. Nice exhibition of photos from period 1870-1930. We bought a few pictures at decent prices. Helpfull staff.Nice cafe on rooftop with great view!

Great historical photographs. If you're at all interested in either images of Northern Africa from the past or photography in general, go. It's a great place, with a small terrace cafe out of the noise of the street.
Highly recommended!. Fascinating voyage from 1870 to 1950. Rich and detailed pictures that tell the story of the North African people.
Historic and arts. A must visit to witness the history of Morocco. After checking out the arts, go to the rooftop for panoramic view of the streets while sipping tea.
A glimpse of history. A fascinating historical record of Marrakech and the area. Beautiful photographs and interesting documentaries.

Best terrace view of Marrakesh. This is a special little photography museum housing a terrace where food and drinks are served. The staff are extremely polite and helpful. This is my second visit as i find it to be a calming spot to escape the manic mayhem in the alleys of the souks and surroundings.There is a small fee to enter the museum - worth paying as the photographs are beautiful and informative. This time the main purpose of visiting was for lunch. There was a fixed menu and quite a wait for tables. However, my friend and I asked for small adjustments to the meal, which were delivered and the chicken tagine with preserved lemons was very tasty. You can get a large panoramic view of the city from this terrace and it is shaded in many parts, should you need to escape the heat. I feel it is reliably satisfying and will always pay a visit when in the city.
Interesting collection. Beautiful building with some wonderful photographs. Lovely restaurants nearby as well. The prints to buy are good quality and reasonably priced.

Well worth a visit. This museum was recommended for a visit by a resident of Marrakech. We were not disappointed! The building is beautiful and the range of photographs from across North Africa was impressive. There's lots of information to hand and the staff were very helpful. The view from the rooftop is stunning!!

Great black & white photography in this Museum.. This was the second time we visited this museum and again enjoyed it very much. As a photographer I especially enjoy all the black and white photography from the early days in the photography. On the rooftop of this museum you can have a drink (tea/coffee) and watch the people below in the busy alleyways or you can count all the satellite dishes you can see from here!
Brilliant. really enjoyed the visit to this museum, informative, comfortable and well worth a trip to the top of the building.

A "Must See" in Marrakech. This exhibition is so fascinating - seeing photos of the city from over a century ago was amazing - there are some very haunting pictures and to see the changes was quite unreal - we had just walked along some of the routes in the pictures and they have changed so much! highly recommended

Amazing works of art. I finally found it! A amazing collection of unique photographs over one hundred years of age. I enjoyed spending the morning reading about the photographers and admiring their art work. Worth a visit if you have a soft spot for photography.
Amazing oasis. An interesting view of Moroccan history through photography, we'll worth a visit and be sure to go to the roof terrace the views are incredible!
Perfectly hidden from sight. Although we had maps and found the street, there was no sign at the alley to the riad, so after 15 minutes of searching we gave up.

Really interesting. Loved the films that one could watch from Daniel Chicaults trip back in 1957. Very good indeed. Photos also good and some stunning. Once you have purchased a ticket 40 dirhams you can revisit whenever you like.

Expensive. How can anything in Marrakesh be expensive i hear you ask. 40 Dh entrance per person is too high in my opinion for what is available to see. Similar size to a small riad we walked round in about 15 minutes. The film was in french. I personally wouldn't recommend unless you are interested in photography however the view frim the upstairs terrace is spectacular with a really good view over all the rooftops and of the Atlas mountains. I suspect this is why it rates so high.
Early photography exhibition. Brilliant photos taken in 1880-1920, including autochromes. Good café terrace. Excellent panoramic views of the city.

Our favourite place in Marrakech. There's always something different to look at, the layout of exhibits is great, the rooftop terrace has great views and a visit to Marrakech without having the chicken tagine here is unthinkable!There's also a little shop selling good quality, set price hand woven scarves opposite!
Must eat lunch here. Fist this place to arrive 1230 and the food will be fresh. They make one thing everyday and each day's it's different! Amazing veiws
Art Respite. Beautiful small museum which focuses on the early days of photography in Morocco. A must if you like photography! The building is lovely too.

nice to see that not much has changed since 1932. Good glimpse into the past, nice terrace although the cafe is not the best lunch deal anymore. Since the Lonely planet quoted a chicken lemon tagine for 50MAD, they now only have a veggie tagine for 50 - good size though. The menu of the day was 100MAD, nice view. 40MAD entrance seemed a bit high for the amount of photos displayed, the doc about the berbers in the high atlas was interesting but only in french.
Interesting, small museum. Nice museum to visit for 1 to 2 hours. Have a drink on the roof terrace afterwards, very sunny and great views!

Crowded and overhyped. The gallery and cafe were highly recommended by one of our guidebooks, so we decided to visit on our last afternoon in Marrakech. Unfortunately so did everyone else! You must pay admission just to go to the rooftop cafe. It was extremely crowded and the wait was at least an hour, so we left. I can't therefore comment on the food but the entire experience felt like a tourist trap. The photos were interesting but there were really too many people there to enjoy it. I would avoid it unless you are really into historic photographs, and maybe go first thing in the morning. This place seems to have become too popular for its own good.

Owner is just as lovely as the photographs. Had the pleasure of visiting this museum. The photographs are beautiful and well worth the nominal charge. But even more lovely is one of the owners, Patrick. He was a joy to talk to and told us about some of the other projects he's working on (like a charity and a school!) The rooftop cafe also offers beautiful views.

Small and unique. Loved this little white-washed museum with just 2 floors of black and white photos taken of Morocco/Marrakech's pas by some notable photographers. A lot of wonderful portraits of men and woman - Berbers, Touregs etc, mainly from last century but looking as if those people are still around. On the roof terrace, there is a little cafe with an excellent menu du jour which was fantastic value and really good. In 2016 this museum will be in a larger, purpose-built building. Hope it's still as charming.
Great visit. Beautiful photography and a lovely rooftop terrace to finish the visit. interesting documentary as well.
interesting. good collection of photographs, inexpensive to enter, building itself was interesting, great rooftop cafe with wonderful views.
Great old photograps. Well kept photo museum with pictures from marrakesh but also from fez and rabat. Great seeing the dresscodes from the past.

Impressionen. Its definitely worth to go see! Great photos with impressive messages fascinate the visitor, taken by real artists long before Photoshop. Don't miss the wonderful view from the terasse on the roof.
Very small. It's really small, with only a few photographs and most not even of Morocco. It's worth visiting if you are already inside the palace

Excellent look into the past. I really enjoyed this place. The photographs are well organized, a lot of information is provided, and the images are really beautiful. I highly recommend this as a stop in Marrakech, especially as it's so close to other great attractions.

nice but not mandatory. very closed to the Medersa and the museum therefore if you have time it's Worth a visit. there is a nice restaurant/bar on the terrace but the kitchen is not running all day long, if you want to have lunch there do not arrive too late
Beautiful Terrace. Love the photos and artists, the photos reviews are well written and interesting.At the top there is a nice caffe' with a lovely view
loved it.. We thoroughly enjoyed the Maison de la Photographie exhibit...not only the pictures, but the space was lovely too..
A must for Photography enthusiasts. Enjoy a morning at the photography museum followed by lunch at a nearby restaurant. Wind your way through the kasbah. Shopping gems await you.

Excellent, thoroughly enjoyable.. If you love photography then you will enjoy this place. Clean, white painted walls in old house on multi-level, displaying beautiful vintage prints. Good variety of work on show, with prints and postcards for sale. This isn't touristy modern colour digital photography, this is 19th century and early 20th century vintage photography. The cafe terrace on the roof is the highest in the medina, with slow service, but who is in a rush anyway? Great place, thoroughly worth the visit if you know and like your photography.
A fascinating insight. A lovely look at the history of Morocco through the lens, magical and captivating. Well worth the visit and some nice postcards to pick up too.

Interesting stop on your walking tour. Three storey house with an exhibition of (prints of) fine old photographs of Morocco and Marrakech, some of which are also for sale. Roof top cafe but don't overdo the coffee, there's only one WC.

fascinating small museum. The photographs were stunning, beautifully laid out in a lovely setting and well described in multiple languages. The terrace up top has really remarkable views, too. Well worth a visit.
Lovely hidden away gem. Lovely photos of the area dating back to late 1800s. Nice terrace for lunch. Is hidden away a wee bit but not that hard to find.

Go here! Best views of the city and great artwork. We went here for a quick visit asked stayed for 3 hours!The building itself is beautiful and the art inside is really well considered.We then ventured on to the roof and found the most amazing space to view the city. A fantastic hidden gem and worthy of all the great reviews

Beautiful photos with a beautiful Marrakech's view. It is really worth seeing for the sunset and azzan- call prayer. From the tarrace you can see the whole city and drink 'berber whisky'- there's cafe. Pirces are very good. For entrance you have to pay 40dh but it is woth- photos are marvellous- you can admire really good photographs from Morocco from 1920 and even previous one. You can buy them (not original of course) and you can left you email for sending you the "photo of the month".

Roof terrace view impressive. The party I was with talked this up, but I was less impressed. The photos were interesting (pre 1900 and showed how little things had changed) but the exhibition is pretty small. Some of the prints are repeated and the English version of the written guides were haphazardly positioned. Definitely worth a coffee on the roof if it's a clear day as you can see the mountains.
Worth a visit and a drink on the terrace!. Very good at explaining the history of Morocco which is not always the case in other museums, Must see!
For those who love photography. Excellent place to get an insight about Morocco life in the past century through a set of excellent photos. And the restaurant at the rooftop is also very good.

Dusk visit. Not a must if you spend in town less than two days, but this is definitely a pleasant place to visit.The collection of pictures is wide and pleasant even to the unexpert eye. The museum did a great job at telling a piece of the history of the country through a consistent sequence.Recommmended to pop up when the sun goes down so that you can admire dusk from the rooftop terrace

Intimate Gallery. A ;little gem run by lovely people. Some beautiful photographs taken over a hundred years ago. Some great shots that you can also purchase. Won't take long to look around as it's quite intimate - but worth it.

Interesting photos and great terrace. A nice place to visit. The pictures are interesting although I think most people were on the terrace having drinks and food. The terrace has good views of the city and distant atlas mountains.

Definitely a place to visit if you are interested in Art/Photography. Visited as both my Wife and I have an interest in Photography.Very nice museum with some great photography. Some of the information material is purely in French, however it is repeated in other areas of each room in English so you do not miss out.Ticket allows you unlimited re-entry and we'd recommend trying to make it to their roof cafe and enjoying a mint tea at sunset. It was amazing!
Very Interesting. This is a sort of hidden gem. If you are interested in culture you should definitely seek it out - well worth the trip!
Photography... restaurant good!. I am not a photography expert and the exposition didn't touch me so much :(However, the Tajine in the restaurant is the best I have eaten in my trip.
Amazing view!. Small museum. All photos in black and white. Gives a historic perspetive of Morroco. The view from the roof top terrace is amazing

ok photos - amazing roof cafe. After reading the reviews I was expecting a lot more to be honest or maybe the photos weren't to my taste - anyway the house is worth a look and the roof top cafe is NOT TO BE MISSED! Although they stop serving foor a 3pm so remember that!
Really enjoyed this museum. Beautiful photos and glimpse into the past. We enjoyed both the museum and the small exhibit at El Badi Palace.
Great rooftop view. Great old photos and the roof top terrace had the best panoramic view of the city and mountains we found all week.
First visit. Excellent - chance to see photographs of Morocco from times gone by and also the cafe on the roof has great view over Marrakech.

Fantastic museum with a wonderful outdoor cafe. This was a highlight of my trip to Marrakech.The museum houses some fantastic photography that's both a delight to look at and a means of better understanding Marrakech's rich history.
