It's split across several floors of a lovely traditional building with a courtyard and lots of wonderful geometric tiles.As others have mentioned, the terrace cafe is great ? reasonably priced and with a panoramic view of 'the red city'. We held into our tickets in order to visit the terrace again. Recommended!

Fascinating look at old Morocco. Three floors of photography from 1900 - 1940 or so. The building itself is beautiful and the collection of photographs is wonderful. Would definitely recommend this stop.
Great venue and photographs. This was very interesting, great historic pictures and we had the best tagine of the whole trip on the roof terrace here - it's well worth a visit

Excellent collection. Definitely worth a visit. Great photos from the 20th century of Morocco and its people. The photographs are also for sale. The roof terrace seemed very nice with free Wifi. With the ticket you can come back for several days after, so worth to go on the first day.
Great Museum. Very special collection of pictures of old Morocco (1870- ), and great roof terrace! Great hospitality.

Not just the pictures. It was an interesting show of pictures from different periodes. Discovering Moroc now and then. Really beautyfull pictures to see there. The building is peacefull as well.Also nice is the terrace on the roof top with good and tasty good. Spending some hours listening and watching Morrocan life from the hight.

Mint tea on the terrace. Interesting place and lovely spot to watch the sun go down. Can be a bit hard to find. Plenty of local lads hang about and offer to 'show you'. They expect a dirham or two for their trouble though.

Nice Finding in Marrakesh Medina. A wonderful find inside the medina! Nice, quiet and not crowded, this museum is located inside the medina, quite away from the main square.It has a beautiful collection of photographs depicting 19th and early 20th century Morocco.Although may not be among the main attractions of the city, this museum is one of those sole surprises of the trip.It didn't take a long time and is excellent to visit in the afternoon, ending the tour with some tea and pastries at the museum terrace cafe.Definitely a must see.

Must visit. . Again another must see individual place in this area, close to Patrick's rug museum. Beautiful photos and film through the last century. Definitely eat up on the roof terrace. The lemon chicken tagine was out of this world!! No others have come close. Great views too.

A beautiful building displaying historic and atmospheric photographs!. This small museum of black and white photographs is laid out over several levels and includes a small cafe up on the roof terrace.it was very peaceful after the bustle of the street, once you bought your tickets to go in you could go in again for free. The view from the terrace at sunset was beautiful. This would not be suitable for people with mobility problems although the downstairs would be accessible.

An interesting experience. We found our visit to the museum fascinating and a great experience. The museum had great architecture that completed the experience, along with the black and white pictures.

Great photo exhibition and lovely rooftop terrace. If you like photography this is a must see in Marrakech! Lovely photo exhibition with pictures of Morocco from 1880 - 1960. Enjoy a mint tea on the rooftop terrace with a great view afterwards.Entry is 40 Dirham, mint tea is 12 Dirham. Totally worth it!

Found by accident - loved it.. We were doing what we like best and just wandering around the backstreets taking in the sights when we happened upon this museum. Although a keen photographer I have generally found photography museums far too pretentious and tiresome..... this was different. The staff were incredibly friendly and polite. The museum is housed in a typical Riad.Some of the photographs on display were truly haunting - some photo's taken in the Souqs in 1912 (?) were so evocative, the age and techniques used helping to the historic feel of the images.As well as the actual photographs the museum is worth visiting for the roof cafe - nice views across to the Atlas mountains, nice snacks and food.All in all a very pleasant hour or so spent here.....

Love Photography. Wish we had longer to browse round this beautiful artful photographic history of old Marrakech ... Upstairs and more stairs takes you up to the panoramic views of a busy, amazing city with the snow capped Atlas mountains in the distance. WOW free WiFi and cafe..

Time out from the Souks. A great way to take some time off from the hectic bustle of the streets and souks. The photographs are a vivid reminder of the rich cultural heritage of northern Africa and the house itself is a lovely piece of architecture.

A little gem. We loved this small photography museum in an authentic neighborhood within the Marrakech medina. The old photos were classic Morocco and the short videos were entertaining. We had tea on the rooftop terrace, then continued our day with a walk in the souks.

Lovely. Lovely photography on show in a beautiful house. It is very well displayed and offers postcards of the photography that you can buy. On the top floor there is a restaurant with wonderful views and the food is great too!
Loved it!. the photography is superb, the staff are welcoming and the roof terrace is even better. It was well worth the trek accross town.

A must for those who like photos. I just loved all the old photos with all the old techniques. We even bought a photo of a beautiful tribal girl and now we hope to win the Photo of the Month. A beautiful museum.

Wonderful building and an interesting photographic exhibition. It's an interesting exhibition of old photos of Morocco from the beginning when the first photographers have visited it. The old centre of Marrakesh have not changed much since than if comparing to these photos . I loved the building and there are also old french documentaries to watch which is interesting. Roof terrace is lovely, beautiful view. It is easy to go back to jemma el fna just by following red signs for it attached to the buildings. We had more troubles finding it, at the end a young boy took as there.
History and style. A beautiful, relaxed space in which to see Morocco through the lenses of those who've gone before you. The rooftop cafe was lovely too.
Worth a visit. Eventually found this place and we loved the exhibition, its got some great photos to view, worth getting drenched for!
Fascinating. Beautiful art that shows what Morocco was like. In many cases it still looks much the same. Well worth a visit and there are photos to buy as well.

Nice place. Quiet. Nice cafe with views on roof. This is the 2nd time I have been here and the positives are that it is quiet with very interesting images with a nice cafe on the roof with nice views of the satellite dishes on the rooves around.The display had not changed much if at all from my previous visit in 2012 but definitely worth a visit for first time visitors.

A must see- the photos will stick with me for a long time. I loved it and so did our whole group. The photos themselves are spectacular never mind the subject and when they were taken. I highly recommend it.

Maison de la Photographie. We enjoyed the small museum very much. The exhibition shows wonderful black & white photographs. The small café with its terrace is worth a try; stunning view over the rooftops of Marrakech.

Musee de Photographie. Great place to while away a few hours and get a better insite into the region. Tucked away in the backstreets of the medina, but we worth seeking out. Very tranquil place amongst the madness!

Great food, good photo's. intended to only go to the restaurant, but had to pay to get in. Photo exhibition was well worth the miserly rate to get in, although not extensive. Food in the restaurant very good.

Lovely little museum, Beautiful artwork. We stumbled upon this lovely little museum while avoiding a rainstorm. While small - it has much better signage than most museums in Marrakech. Well curated and found in a great little riad.

A must for photograph lovers. After reading reviews of this museum we tracked this gem down. Easy to find than expected, the day before we had ventured to the museum and it had been a conundrum! However, head direct to the souks that say berber market and museum, and like the previous reviewer mentioned - head straight. ..after museum and the merdesa follow the windy alley..you walk past restaurant fondouk and the museum is just there. Excellent exhibition, your ticket is valid throughout your stay...useful if you want to come back yet again for views from the roof terrace. ...Fantastic images within the gallery, very informative with English translation. A must.
Brilliant in history, art and location. This is a must see together with Musee Boucharouite. Both are brilliant for history, art and location and restful places to just be.

Great exhibition, beautiful cafe. Really interesting photographic exhibition with historical photos of Morroccan culture. At 40 dirhams for entry (the equivalent of about £3.00) at the time of writing, it is great value for money. Do not go without having something in the rooftop cafe- they had a 100 dirham 3 course lunch, but I just had some soup and the aubergine salad, which were great. The waiter was very attentive and friendly. Do not miss this little gem in the Medina!
Photograph exhibition. A lovely museum of photograph memories of old Marrakech - enjoy. Also had a lovely afternoon tea on the roof.

Family visit as part of a week's holiday in Marrakech. 7 of our family group of 10 (no teenagers) visited this lovely museum in the pouring rain. 3 got side tracked en route via the tanneries, having been assured that the museum was closed! Amazing photos, well presented, plus beautiful film footage from 1957 in the Atlas mountains. Charming staff. We bought lots of postcards.

A highlight of Marrakech. I loved this photographic gallery. Set over three floors of a restored riad amongst the crumbling fondouks of the medina, surrounding yourself with the black and white (and some coloured) images here provides a pleasant escape from the noisy medina outside. The photographs transport you back to the life, traditions, scenes and ambiance of times when these photographs were taken - 19th century some them! Explanations of the exhibits and life stories of the featured photographers are in English. Definitely gives you a glimpse of how Morocco has changed (and hasn't changed) in the last century or more.For 40 dhm entry fee it's excellent value. The terrace is a must visit too to see the medina and souk from the rooftops. It also has a small menu to relax and refresh with. Wifi available but didn't work for me.I combined this gallery with the walk through the souk/medina to Ali Ben Youssef Madrasa. I found it easily enough by following the advice of my local friend. Which was: Go to Jamaa el Fna (main square), find the lane that enters the souk directly opposite Cafe de France, follow this lane (by following the pedestrian traffic) inside the souk (largely undercover) all the way to the end - where you'll find the open air. Once in the open air take a left - this path/road will pass the Marrakech Museum (Muzee) and then the Madrasa (if in doubt ask the locals for these landmarks). After the madrasa entry follow the path right and follow this through the medina. Keep left from there - there are a couple of signs pointing the way. Follow the pedestrian traffic if in doubt!

Fascinating. Fascinating. Well worth a visit with lovely photos. With only backpacks we just bought postcards but there were bigger prints available. Watch out for men approaching pretending it is closed in order to guide you elsewhere. It is not far from the tanneries.
Lovely little museum tucked away. Lovely museum with old black-and-white photography. Roof top has a great view over Marrakech and a simple cafe and restaurant with a few snacks. Highly recommended.

Impressive photo collection - gorgeous homemade food. The collection of photos is impressive, the building is very nice, the view from the terrace stunning, the food gorgeous and the staff very corteous. A must when in Marrakech!

another world. the museum displays photos taken by great photographers. you are transferred to another, former world and get good insights. it has a nice teracce where you can get some drinks and snacks and enjoy the view

Worth finding. We had a bit of trouble finding the Maison - but then Marrakech is like that and there is always someone to help you - for a small tip of course. The Maison has stunning photographs and the roof top café is a great place for lunch or a drink.

Magnificant pictures. After having visited the tanneries, we found an oasis of peace here in this museum and enjoyed the beautiful pictures! At first we got an explanation of the personell,which was very useful.
Worth a visit. Great glimpse of Moroccan Hx in a lovely riad - the photographs are amazing. Wee worth taking the time to visit even though we found it a little difficult to find.
a true gem. A beautiful place in the heart of the Medina, with photographs of great interest and a fantastic roof terrace to drink and eat with the view of the whole Marrakech.
Worth finding. Lunch on the terrasse,with a rooftop view of the medina was wonderful. The kindness of the chef to a stray cat was heartwarming.

Excellent Collection, Well Displayed. A large collection of all the most important photographers of Morocco from the dawn of photography onward. They rotate the display and provide very good descriptions in several languages - big cards in each room you can carry around as you look at the pictures. Movies of Berbers also from the beginning of moving pictures. In a lovely old building that is well-restored.
Really good. A very interesting attraction and with a very enthusiastic owner. On the top terrace you can find a cafe/restaurant with some excellent food.

Fascinating Photographic History. Fascinating photographic history at this little museum, but the piece de resistance was the cafe on the room. Highly recommend going there for lunch and having a tagging. Delicious! Views are spectacular.

Superb bite of history. Third trip to Marrakech and finally got here with my group. We all loved this quaint place and everyone agreed that it should stay on the itinerary in the future even if it means dropping bigger tourist attractions. Beautiful photographs all superbly displayed in this lovely riad. Gives a great sense of Moroccan history and is inspiring for both amateur and professional photographers.

Great little museum!. It's a wonderful chance to visit a renovated riad and see some excellent photos of days gone by in Morocco and other N African countries. Lovely and cool and clean inside, with knowledgeable, welcoming staff and a surprisingly nice little café up top. Tricky to find, but have fortitude - it's well worth the trek through the maze of the medina to get there :-)

Excellent Little Gallery. Fairly small gallery of photography, concentrating mainly on 19th century photography in Morocco. There are some very early photographs indeed. It is a fascinating insight into Morocco more than 100 years ago and also surprising to see how little the medina in Marrakesh has changed in that time.

Fab photo museum. Collections of old photos of Morocco in a lovely 3 story rid , well worth finding in the narrow streets along from the Ben Youssef Madras, also worth visiting.Very friendly reception staff, plenty of information and exhibits, plus a great roof top terrace with cafe for mint tea or coffee. You can also peer over the walls into the tannery area to see hides curing in the open air! A well spent 40 dirhams. Its free for under 12 s and opens every day from 9.30a.m. to 7p.m.

Lovely little museum.. Many would probably not think of visiting this museum as it's not showy or very big, but they'd be wrong. It has some of the loveliest exhibits I've seen in a long time. The property is charming in it's own right with a super little tea room on the roof with some of the best views in Marrakech. The young men that man the desk downstairs are obviously photographers themselves and speak excellent english. Upstairs are early (1950's) reels of film of the Berbers in their amazing desert cities. Watch them, it's worth it. Really interesting. Take time and go.

OK could do with some proper signposting.. Nice exhibition of classical photos from the 1900's onwards. Tricky to find leading to much hassle from guys telling it was closed and offering to take us to the Tanneries instead, rther ruined the experience. Nice cup of mint tea on the roof terrace
One of the best places to visit in Marrakesh. Great house, good displays of wonderful pictures from so long ago. We bought two large prints to take home and frame. You must go there.

A photographic heaven and haven!. This charming converted townhouse in the old Medina has a great collection of photos of Morocco from the late 19th century to the 1950s - not too many, though, just enough to savour on each of its three floors. Then on the roof terrace you can sit eating a chicken tagine while taking in the most spectacular views of the Atlas mountains. But the best thing about this place without doubt is the staff - they are the most enthusiastic and friendliest and refreshing of people.

Difficult to find but worth the effort!. If you love a window to a lost world that as a sixty plus you can almost still remember or just want to connect with the soul of country then you'll spending a wet day looking into the eyes of individuals who are so like 21st century man or woman but would have found today's world totally baffling. Best coffee I had the whole time I was in Marrakech!

Worth Visiting. Very interesting and beautiful photos/large prints that you'll see being sold all over Marrakech as (knock-off?) postcards. Despite this, the museum is definitely still worth visiting. Pretty remarkable to think how many of the photos exhibited could be taken today. They also have a nice roof terrace/cafe with a view over the medina that's worth visiting.

Picture Perfect. A beautiful space, quite and peaceful to look at the exhibition that is on. Venture up to the terrace and sip tea overlooking the roof tops of the Medina. The guys that are running the gallery are really helpful and will point you in the direction of other hidden treasures

Great historical perspective . Fantastic walk through history of people and scenes of Marrakech. Wonderful B&W photos. Very friendly staff and a quick tour is a good respite from the heat and crowded markets. We enjoyed this little museum.

Favorite sight in Marrakesh!. Of all place we visited in Marrakesh, this was my favorite one. Fantastic collection and a haven of peace in the busy medina. Make sure you make it to the fantastic rooftop!

Nice collection of Marrocan Photographs. Photography museum showing maroccan scenes from international photographers, mostly europeans. stunning images, nicely presented. Nice little riad beautifully restored ... postcard and picture selection ... Nice little cafe on top, we couldn't test - all seats were taken, usually a good sign ...

Out-of-the-way gem with beautiful terrace. I didn't attempt to make it out to the Maison de la Photographie until my fifth visit, and it should be said that it's very difficult to find on foot. There is a little signage as you get closer but it's rather misleading. The place itself was great compensation, though. The photographs were beautiful and fascinating, giving an excellent sense of the history of the city and region. The building is cool, clean and peaceful, offering a very pleasant and quite unique gallery experience. Then, the famous roof terrace. The view and setting are stunning, perfect for a break and a bit of people-watching, and prices are reasonable. However, we came in the early afternoon and it was very difficult to find anyone to take an order from us or to pay - service did seem rather disorganised and not particularly friendly. It should also be said that whilst still not expensive to a European traveller, even one travelling on a shoestring, entry to the Maison de la Photographie cost more than visiting all of the other local sights put together.
Roof top cafe is a must. The museum itself is lovely. Some beautiful photos of Marrakech through the ages, but the roof top cafe is a must. Pricey but a great view accross the city.
amazing. Great work on show. As well as being housed in a great building with amazing tiled floors.lovely terrace and mint tea.friendly helpful staff

Photos are great but the Chicken Tagine is out of this world. Obviously the photos are interesting and beautiful as everyone states. But the reason I'm writing this is because the cafe on the rooftop turns out an absolutely absurd Chicken Tagine. I went there for lunch 2 days in a row because I was in disbelief something could be that flavorful. I'm not kidding. I marched into the little kitchen, uninvited I might add, to try and figure out how they made it because I was involuntarily groaning while eating it. I went to get it the next day to make sure I hadn't just been caught up in the moment and it was even better the second time I got it. I cannot overstate how f@#king good this dish is. Sorry to cuss but I am not sure any other word can convey it properly. Thank me afterwards.
Interesting old photos of 1920 Marroco. The expo is quite small - but still interesting. It is fascinating to see that apart from the mopeds and tourists, little has changed over the last 100 years!

Interesting museum/gallery. It's worth visiting this museum, photos are interesting and show how Moroccan culture, people and cities looked in the past. It's a peaceful place to escape crowds and a hard sale. There is a rooftop terrace where you can enjoy a view over Marrakech and have a drink. We also purchased a print, which was pretty affordable.

Oasis of calm. Lovely photo exhibition of images of Morocco. Well laid out and some descriptions in English. Lovely quiet roof terrace cafe serving limited menu of very good value food and drinks. They do not advertise the cafe very well and we had to specifically ask to see the lunch menu as our riad owner had recommended it to us. 3 courses was about 100 dms each which was good value.

Worth a visit. This is a great way to spend an hour or so in Marrakech. The photos are beautiful and the museum is set up really nicely. We stopped in late in the afternoon one day while waiting for a nearby restaurant to open and were informed that we would be able to come back another day as the tickets allow for re-entry - a nice touch. Not sure how busy it gets at other times but we arrived at 6ish and there were barely any other people there. The roof terrace gives great views out over Marrakech too.

Definitely Worth A visit.. Yes , it is a little tricky to find but it has some lovely old black and white photos ..housed in a lovely house with a cafe roof terrace serving nice food with a fab view. All for 40 Dhirams...£4!!! Come on...why moan...and you can go back as often as you like on the same ticket. Definitely go take a look... enjoy a few tranquil hours and chill.

Well worth a trip - tricky to find though.. Wonderful place full of amazing photographs. Well worth going but be warned it's not the easiest place to track down. Took is 2 attempts and had to resort to a taxi in the end! Lovely cafe too and bathrooms which are impeccably clean. Next door there's a lovely Riad where we had lunch - home cooked by the family.

It's Conceivable.... that, had I not been so angry at my girlfriend at the time, I might have enjoyed the museum more than I did, but I doubt it. The price of admission was steep for what was displayed. There were few photographs in the collection that really held my attention for longer than five or ten seconds, which made our visit quite short, probably shorter than half an hour. It is true that the view of the city from the rooftop cafe is quite lovely, though the cafe, unfortunately, is as overpriced as the museum is. There are much better ways to spend time, much better places to see in Marrakech. Don't waste time here.
Well worth a visit. Interesting old photographs displayed in lovely house. Cool and calm. I particularly liked the portraits.

Fascinating pictures,good roof top cafe. Really interesting historical pictures of marrakesh, combined with a delightful roof top terrace serving good local food at a very reasonable price.nice clean little place where you can easily pass an hour or so.

Expensive for what it is.. After all the rave reviews I was underwhelmed. The photos were interesting but we were done in 15 minutes and the terrace was tiny and over crowded. Not somewhere I would revisit.
Great photos. Some great photos, some dating from around 1910 but most mid century. Very well displayed. There were a couple of lovely haunting shots in the main hall.
Interesting. Nice collection of mostly black and white photographs from MoroccoNice roof top cafe for a mint tea.

Amazing Collection of Photographs. Fairly easy to find from the Ben Youssef (ask for directions, though). Brilliant assemblage of historical photos of people and places. It's amazing to see how much things have changed - and ,yet, stayed the same in the last 150 years. Worth the 10dh...

Nice Little Diversion. A little hard to find within the souk but well worth the effort.
Beautiful old house with photos from 1800s to the 1950s with a roof terrace for a drink afterwards.
Well worth a visit.

well worth a visit. one of the most interesting cultural spots in marrakech, definitely worth seeing. loved the little cafe at the roof top terrace. the museum has the amazing collection of vintage photographs, would visit again when in marrakech

Beautiful surroundings, great photos. This place is photogenic as a building let alone the beautiful and historic photos on show. At 40 dirhams (£3) it's a snip and a must for anyone interested vin photography and/or history
Well worth a visit. This photographic exhibition was really interesting, with images of historial Morroco, set in a lovely Riad style building.

High interest. Very interesting and informative re history of local photography and European influence and participation. they would sell more photos were they not unnecessarily expensive. P'cards good.

Lovely Museum. We were taken here by a tour guide for a visit, entry fee was 50dh per person and you can keep the tickets and go back another time! Great value for money we thought! The museum is bright and full of light which makes the photographs easy to see and showcased beautifully. The museum tells a story of the history of the city and its well worth a visit to see it through the art of photography. If you buy any prints they wrap them so you can take them home without damaging them.

Secret Surprise. I loved visiting this little hidden gem! It was quiet and peaceful the day I went, and as I looked at each photo, it was like being drawn into the past... and yet, just outside the door in the bustling medina, some of the aspects of life in the photos are still absolutely present! It's like experiencing a time warp, just walking in and out the door! I don't think this exhibit is for everyone, though: it's for people who are observant and also thoughtful about the realities of life in Morocco today, and who are therefore open to what these very special photographs have to teach us, certainly about the past and the present, but maybe about the future also.
Kodak Kasbah. Wonderful selection of photos ancient & modern, showing Morocco in its many guises & colours, along with the indigenous people
Memorable. The photos are awesome & the food on the roof terrace is excellent. Always worth a visit to spend a couple of hours.

Had a good feel. It was on our tourist map but not in our guide book.It was a little difficult to find, but after constantly getting lost we were used to it!The building has been lovingly restored, and the young chap who gave us our ticket took pains to explain all about the building and the collection of photographs, he is understandably proud.We really enjoyed it and though it well worth a visit.

Closed despite being advertised as open!. Ring ahead of your visit because when we arrived at the palace on our first visit the palace was closed for a public holiday and when we returned a few days later the palace was open but the museum didn't open despite hosting and advertising its featured exhibition.
Worth a visit. Hard to find but worth it Doesn't take too long to go round as small so don't plan more than 1 hr to actually be in there
Well worth a visit. A place to escape and enjoy the photographs from days gone by. You can buy prints from the shop and also enjoy the views from the roof top terrace
facinating restoration. A great insight into how local people are interested in preserving the pasts social history. I enjoyed being guided around the restored home in the Jewish quarter.
Nice old pictures. Very goof collection of old pictures from Marrakesch and other places in Marokko. Recommended! !!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!

Really nice small attraction with great terrace. For anyone interested in the cultural history of this part of the world, this is a must-see. In addition to a range of excellent photographs, professionally presented, capturing the history of photography in Morocco, there is a very interesting video from the mid-1950s covering the Berber tribes in the high Atlas. And the views from the terrace are breathtaking: right across the city. Lunch is from 13.00, so before that it's drinks only.
A highlight of Marakech. Great photo exibits and lunch on rooftop terrace. The staff was very helpful and informative. I will return here again,
good collection. nice collection, more of a show room than a museum. i think its over priced. has free WIFI on the roof

Great museum and great lunch spot. We had a wonderful visit to the museum. While it is on the small side, the photos of the souks in the 1930s were beautiful. We even bought a print to take home. We had a fantastic lunch on the rooftop of the museum. A great spot to rest and get out of the craziness of the medina.
Would definitely recommend. Beautiful photos and a tasty chicken tagine on a roof top terrace - what more do you need? But don't believe the kids who try to lead you astray on your way there :)
beautiful photos. worth a stop! great old photos of morocco in a restored riad. lovely! and a nice little cafe on the roof terrace.

Pretty good!. It doesn't look like the biggest or most promising place from the outside, but there are lots of really interesting photos inside. They give you a good picture of the history of Marrakech, and Morocco as a whole, over the past century. There's also a very nice cafe up on the roof!

Beautiful place. Very serene and beautiful museum. The staff were very polite and informative. The price of entry was extremely cheap. The exhibition was very rich and informative – historical photographs of Morocco providing a fascinating look at the culture. The interiors were lovely and the overall presentation was very good. The photographs had extensive English annotations. This would suit enthusiasts of history or art, although would be enjoyable for anyone looking to discover this country in a different light.It was a little difficult to find, although once you get close there are a few signs pointing the direction.There is also a very nice small rooftop cafe, we did not eat but had a reasonably priced drink.

We really enjoyed it. A lovely oasis in the vast tourist warren of the medina. Need to take a cab, as one could never find it alone. Cab drops you off about 1 block away in a very "authentic" local part of the medina. Fruits and veggie market, an old tannery just like the huge one in Fez, but this one takes you walking all around up close and personal --like don't wear good shoes! Amazingly gritty and up close. Museum was well designed in an old riad with lots of natural light. Photos were a lovely collection of history. We marveled at how so little has changed since 1800s when many were taken. Still veiled women, donkey carts, men in tunics and slippers selling tagine pots. Young men at front desk were knowledgeable and helpful. Highly recommended

Zen in Marrakesh. A delightful riad with a superberb and well chosen collection of photographs organized by eras and photographers (1870–1950). If you are lucky the curator will give you a private tour. It is a haven of peace and calm away, but not far, from the soucks and the bustle of the surrounding streets. From the rooftop café, there is a 360 º view of the Medina.

Special Gallery - Don't Miss. This is a beautifully simple gallery tucked in the medina. The director has a clear passion and has created a delightful experience that puts all the focus on the photographs. It's a great collection that unlocks some of the history of the Berber people and culture. Plan your visit around lunch as there is a sweet cafe on the roof for a light bite or beverage. Nominal fee.
Fabulous lunch spot. Great history in the pictures and the terrace area and lunch was really good. You got value for money.
interesting. pretty cool place, real nice photographs. It was pretty quiet and chilled when we went which was nice.
A great collection.. A beautiful gallery, with a great collection and an excellent cafe on the room. The director is very helpful and enthusiastic. It takes a little finding but is well worth it.
A lovely history of Morocco. Stories told through photographs are what most remember and take back. The are indelible. Old, new -- all telling and fitting.

Interesting comparison of Moroccan life. Worth a visit as they are an interesting series of photographs in to the culture of the place. One thing that struck us was we were advised to not just look at the photos as a whole, but study the backgrounds in the photos, and indeed they still look like they could have been taken today.

Lovely and amazing insight into the culture of Morocco. The best bit was the film about the Berber villages in the mountains which was filmed in 1957 and was one of the first contact from the West with the Berber tribes.

Interesting. Nice clean place with a roof top cafe that doesn't really sell very much. Lovely photographs and prints that can be purchased. Beware of guides offering to take you from your taxi to the gallery down some winding streets . They offered to take us with no mention of money and once there asked for a lot of money which we refused and they wouldnt leave us alone. Eventually we walked away into the gallery leaving them standing outside. These guides are usually in cahoots with the taxi driver so be very careful. You can find your own way as there are street signs and other tourists heading the same way, just follow them

Very nice place for a visit and lunch !. A very interesting place with photographic works of quality, a nice dive in the past and the history of Marrakech, the small restaurant upstairs with views of the medina is a must ! Reservation recomanded

Excellent visual history. Despite good directions, we were lost in the medina for a while before finding the Maison de la Photographie. However, it was definitely worth the find. One gains a sense of the beauty of the culture and social history of Morocco here.

Gorgeous photos from the relatively recent past. Photos of Marrakech (and nearby) are featured in this small museum. In addition to pictures of the city itself, you will also see compelling portraits of the people of Morocco. Amazing stuff and a must for any fan of art photography.
Charming place. Great atmosphere and superb project.Beatiful collection of ancient photos.Come for lunch and spend a magical moment on the rooftop

Glimpse into Morocco in days gone by. Lovely small museum of black and white photographs with prints to buy too. Very helpful staff, a cafe on the roof with good views over the souks, and a place to watch the first film documentary made about the country in 1957.A little treat, and respite from the crazy streets.
Normal. Nice pics and roof terrace but nothing amazing. We had to pay 6euros and the room was relatively small

stunning. love this place. as soon as we walked in the a young man gave us a great welcome and spoke about the museum and how the photographs keep changing to refresh each experience you take at this brilliant museum. the photographs are inspiring and amazing and brings a countries history alive. you must visit this museum if you are ever in marrakech.

Recommend visiting first. I would definitely not miss this photography exhibition as it provides a window into the Morocco of the past. The photos of people and everyday scenes help take you back in time when you wander the alleys.
The food at the cafe on the roof is also a nice escape from the hustle and bustle.

Great place, beautiful photos. A wonderful find, great to spend an hour in and have a relaxing mint tea. The views from the terrace are spectacular - a real bonus. Only downside is that it is really quite difficult to find - though not surprising given its Marrakech! Allow an extra 30 minutes for wandering through the souks :)
worth the trip. beautiful collection of b&w photos from old morocco - stunning shots to give a view into what it used to be
amazing collection. amazing place that give you a small view into the past of the country, a full immersion in another era

Great museum, amazing views. This museum has a great collection of photos, dating as far back as the late 19th century. Located in a quiet and cool riad, it's definitely worth the stop. Once you've soaked in the past of the city, climb upstairs to the breezy terrace for a drink. It's location offers an unmissable 360 view of Marrakesh, and seeing the city from above it always a treat. While you're there, try the orange and cucumber juice. Truly refreshing!

Go for lunch, stay for the museum!. If you are in the area of the Marrakech museum and Ben Youssef, I highly recommend a diversion to the Maison de la photographie for lunch. There is a roof terrace on the third floor with a beautiful view of the city, and very reasonable prices - only ~50MAD for a pizza and ~90 MAD for a set menu (three courses) the day we went, but I get the impression this changes every day. The museum was also great, with a lovely collection of photos and good detail in French (though only occasional English translations available of the detailed placards) with both English and French labels on all photos.A word of caution - while walking there from the Marrakech museum my boyfriend and I were hassled numerous times. This is the same route to the tanneries and a lot of boys wanted to give us a tour there or tried to tell us we were going the wrong way. We were not and thankfully didn't listen to them. Trust your map or GPS and ignore those trying to help. It really is a simple path on the same road as the Marrakech museum (just maybe 5 minutes further including the sharp right at the corner past the Ben Youssef).

Photographic History of Morocco. This is a small but great photographic museum in the middle of the medina in Marrakech. I love the old pictures that gave me a different perspective and insight into the history of Morocco in general and Marrakech in particular. Located in a restored riad, the storied building is beautiful in itself. There is an amazing view from the rooftop terrace/cafe of Marrakech and the Atlas mountains in the distance. It was a satisfying hour and a half for a history and photography enthusiast.
Worth a visit. this gallery is delightful. The photographs and videos give a sense of history of the place. There is also a delightful rooftop cafe, and nearby are 2 other museums to visit.
great. interesting insight via photography of old Marrakech, the rooftop also gives a exceptional view over the rooftops of marrakech

beautiful collection. I love the orientalist period of course i know Edward Said, but i like the aesthetic around this european fantasma.We found a lot of interesting pictures from the early past century.It is Worth visiting.
Worth the stop if you have time. Worth the stop if you have time and also in an interesting part of the Medina. I loved the old Moroccan photos. They were all so mystical and magical feeling.

A lovely little spot!. I am surprised by some of the reviews here that seem dismissive of the size of the museum, and even a couple that say things along the lines of "it's ok if you like old photos". It's a museum of Moroccan photography! It displays historical photographs!The building is a renovated riad, not a purpose-built museum so it is not huge, but for the size of the building there are a lot of photographs, well- displayed on all three floors. The majority are stunning black and white images captured during the early part of the twentieth century, with some as recent as the 1940s. There are panels that give general information about some of the photographers in both English and French and each photograph has a title and date, which leaves the viewer free to observe and interpret the image (because it is an art exhibition!).The top floor has a little roof terrace with stunning views across to the Atlas Mountains and the kitchen (not a formal cafe) serves great coffee, freshly squeezed orange juice and a 'dish of the day' - we had the chicken tagine and an Aubergine salad, which was excellent. Pricing for the food is very inexpensive.Not a good option for anyone with limited mobility dur to the stairs.There is a shop on the ground floor where you can purchase prints and postcards of some of the photographs in the exhibition and they will post overseas for you. A great little place, and no more tricky to locate than anywhere else in the Medina.

worth a visit. A nice restored road in the medina. Shows photographs from 19th and early 20th century Morroco - Berber girls dancing, marrying. Faces of slaves, Jews, Tuaregs, warriors. Tastefully presented, nice restaurant on the top with a view over the kasbah. Near one of the main mosques. Inexpensive. Definitely worth a visit.
Interesting pics but very small. It is in the Palace...great pics but very small space and very little explanation to describe the photos...but definitely go in if you are in the palace anyway

Interesting. I think my husband enjoyed this little museum more than I did, but the photos were interesting and there was a nice cafe on the roof terrace. It was a bit more difficult to find than I would have thought ... I think that may have been true for most everything in the medina.
Fantastic view. Have lunch at the roof-top after seeing the exiting pictures in the gallery!But the view from the reataurant on the top is worth a visit.
good collection. good museum, with old photographs of Morocco, for those who enjoy photography and history worth it..

Beautiful piece of history. We loved it, most amazing pictures from 19th century in Tangier. Worth visiting and getting lost in the eyes of people on the pictures and actually seeing that places like medinas have not changed much. Mesmerising

OK if you like old B&W photos of Moroccan locals. The museum is bit tricky to get to, having to brave the outlying souks, and is a bit limited. It does have a handy cafe for lunch, though. All the photos seem to be stills taken of native Moroccans, sporting tradional dress. OK if that's your interest, but otherwise not rivetting.

lovely, tranquil spot with a great roof terrace for lunch. We really enjoyed the images of old Marrakech. However be careful not to follow 'friendly'' directions from people on teh street back to the main square. We did follow these tips, ended up in a lonely street and were robbed...so you've been warned!

Great little stop. This is a nice little gallery of large old photographs of Marrakech and the medina. Definitely worth your time to explore, and we enjoyed a soft drink on the roof terrasse afterward.

Well worth a visit. We were lucky enough to meet the owner of this small but interesting museum. We recommend a visit as you can enjoy photographs and films of Morocco, both old and recent. Lunch on the roof was fun, friendly and delicious.
Superb. Superb photographic museum with roof top terrace and bar. Free wifi and your entry ticket is valid for a whole week sop you can pop back when you want. Clean toilets. recommended.

Great little museum with fantastic restaurant. Do not listen to anyone in the medina - they will tell you it's closed and try to send you to the tanneries.
The restaurant on the top of the building has a fantasic view and delicious food as long as you're up for tagine.

Definitely Worth a Visit. An interesting collection of photographs around a cute little house. Also a cheap rooftop terrace café that offers pretty good views over the city. Always worth mentioning that they have a good toilet too!Entry is 40 dirhams (less than £3) but once you've got your ticket you can return as many times as you like, though once will probably be enough.

OK (with reservations). Couldn't work out the percentage but a lot of the images here are printed from scans of original (presumably smaller) photographs. At least one is copied from a book. Not that there's anything wrong with that but it's something to be aware of. As other reviewers have said the restaurant is good. Lovely food and good views. The downside is it is difficult to find and you will probably have a taxi driver get near then deliver you into the hands of a young lad who will insist on walking you there. A taxi from the square will be about 15MAD the 'guide' will probably try and sting for about 200MAD. Don't pay that. You might have to pay 100MAD.The entrance fee at present is 40MAD. (£2.84)
Old Fashioned but Worth a Look. Easily found, this small museum is full of really interesting and well-taken photographs. Fascinating stuff and has a cafe and shop (this is a little expensive)
Small but perfectly formed. This was a lovely selection of photography with useful labels and guides. Small, and only a short walk from the main square

I loved it!. If you are passionate for Photography (in special, old Photography) that's the place to visit!During my visit to Marrakech I've been there more than twice and I really enjoy it. The Museum is located in the old part of the city - in the middle of the labyrinthic alleys of the Souk - which can make you walk in circles for a while until you find it. The place is cool, in a renovated old maison, three floors and at their terrace you can enjoy having a coffee (or a tea) with one of the most beautiful views of this part of the town.Also, you can purchase copies of the original pictures displayed in the Museum.I definitely recommend it!
Worth the trek to the north medina. If you like your black and white photography, this is worth the walk out the top of the souk. Lovely cafe on the roof and clean loos too.
Worth a visit. Well laid out museum of photography. Café service was poor as staff inattentive but well worth a trip to the gallery

Great Museum for Photo lovers!. This really is a wonderful museum in marrakech, but you have to be a photo enthusiast to really enjoy it. Me and my husband are not, so we really found it quite dull. But this is our taste and I am sure photographers would love it though. The restaurant on the rooftop is amazing. Good food and amazing views,

More than worthwhile a visit. Both being enthusiastic photographers, this was thought to be a "must do" for us. Rightly so. But not just for photo nuts: a very interesting series of photographs, well curated. There's also a very pleasant cafe situated on the roof for a spot of relaxation and refreshment.

really interesting place to visit and lovely roof top cafe. some beautiful and very well presented old photos. definitely worth a visit. The roof top cafe has a wonderful view too, and the food looked very yummy (we just had a snack!)

Wonderful Place To Visit. This lovely , privately owned, photography museum was recently voted 'Best Museum In North Africa' and it's easy to see why. The smiling , friendly staff give all visitors a warm welcome. The museum is situated in an old Riad in the Marrakech medina. The owner, a delightful Frenchman, Patric, has created a cool and inviting space. The photos are wonderful collection of Morocco and it's people from times gone by. This attraction is not only a delight for photography buffs but for anyone who appreciates beautiful photos. Do make sure that you allow yourself time to visit the delightful cafe on the roof top terrace to enjoy a refreshing glass of mint tea, orange juice or lunch. The terrace also has one of the best roof top views over Marrakech

Worth a visit. I enjoyed seeing this photographic collection of old Morocco. Some interesting historical pieces and the upper terrace is perfect for a light lunch. Visit the museum not far away, it makes the walk worthwhile.

Okay.... This is quite far away from the usual tourist path and it's quite hard to find since all the signs in the souk usually lead you to the wrong way. The interior has a beautiful Moroccan design. Although I am not an expert of photography, would still recommend coming here to see the beautiful interior.

Excellent. It look a little longer to find this museum than we thought (but doesn't everything?), but it was a lovely little cool interesting place. The photos really tell the story of the people of this fascinating country and considering how old the photos are (1880's to 1940's) you can see how little had changed. There is a sweet little roof top cafe serving the usual 3-course tagine meal of the day and pizza and it was yum. ?4 entrance fee each, don't know how but we spent 3 hours in the musem including lunch and it was a very enjoyable break from the wandering and shopping. Note: would be good if they put signposts on both walls at the beginning of the street and not just one, so look up and at both sides when trying to find it.

quiet and cool. a visit is a must for the history and photo lover to experience this area from a pictorial aspect. brilliant wee cafe upstairs and rooftop views. in the souks and easy enough to find if you follow the signs and painted directions on walls

Excellent lunch and terrace. The museum itself is a nice break from the overstimulating surroundings. Photos were nice, but the best part for me was the rooftop terrace and the lunch they serve. The terrace looks out over the city and had a lovely breeze. They offer drinks and also a set lunch for about 80 dirhams - the tagine was the best we had in marrakech. Also you can return to the terrace any other day as long as you keep your ticket stub.

A must do.. We are regular visitors to Marrakech and always return here. The exhibits are changed regularly and so there is always something new to see. It is fascinating and very informative one of the most impressive things to see.

Small, Pleasant, though not spectacular. If you know your photographic history, then perhaps you would get more out of this, but for us there was nothing especially captivating. The staff are certainly helpful and if you suffered the walk through the tanneries, it's a very welcome escape. Our visit was marred by a hellish morning trying to find the place which took 3 hours even with a taxi so it made it hard to apreciate what we were loking at. I would say that to get the most out of the exhibition you need to find the start of the story and try and follow it through, otherwise it's not very cohesive if you just wander. The prints dont seem to be of great quality either, with just a few exceptions, even taking age of the originals in to consideration. It's good value though at 40dh per person - a bit less than 4 euro, and the terrace is a little higher than most so gives a better view - though still mainly of satellite dishes and rooftops full of junk. Prints, start from around 250dh, for 20x30cm - the larger images are much more impressive if you choose carefully, but obviously much more expensive. Post cards are better value at 5dh, though as we later found - they are not exclusive and can be purchased cheaper elsewhere. Food is average for marrakech, but reasonably priced though dont expect much choice, there was a selection of 2 when we went.I dont want to be too hard, as overall it was a nice visit I think which would have been better had it been easier to get to, just dont expect too much.

NEED TO SEE THIS!. First of all it is a lovely townhouse , with a fine display of early portrets of people and of Marrakech. Its main gem are the 1950's films of hikes into the high Atlas : life in the Mountain Kasbahs as it used to be still. You can see the hard way of life for young and old and the authentic dress.

A Gem of Marrakech. A hidden gem, lovely place to visit, wish I had of had more time to appreciate the depth of the collection. It is well worth the visit even if you only have enough time to walk through the building to admire the architecture.
Excellent Photograph Museum. This museum has many historic photographs by numerous photographers that tell an interesting story about the history of Morocco and Marakesh
very enjoyable. It was good value for money, well worth a visit. The staff are very helpful and welcoming. The photographs on display were brilliant.
Great terrace and interesting museum. Quite a small museum spread over three floors but some really interesting photos. There's a shaded rooftop terrace and cafe with some great views

Worth a visit.. After visiting the tanneries, itself being a unique if not smelly experience, we came across this museum of beautiful examples of early photography of Marrakech and Morocco. It is worth the fee to see these prints(most of the originals however are kept in France. To me it was very important to read the information posted on the walls as they gave a great insight into the history of the images. Also interesting to see the quality difference between the changes in photographic media. One image even has a reflection of the camera used to take the image(see if you can find it).After have a cool drink or snack on the rooftop terrace.
Lovely Museum. This museum was one of my favorite places in Marrakech. The photographs were stunning and a must-see, and the terrace of the museum was incredible.
Smalller than expected. Kind staff, nice pictures but overall not as expected from the other reviews. Spent about 35 minutes in the museum.
Not to be missed. . beautifully displayed photos . Work of love.Lovely collection in an old riad, it should not be missed

Secret gem. Look for this near the Madrassa in the centre of Marrakech's Medina. Try and leave enough time to view the unique colour films of life in the Atlas Mountains in the 1950s - and for a light snack on the lovely rooftop terrace. Great view.
Great value. Welcome break in calm surrounds. We escaped many offers for a tour of the Tanneries . So glad we did! Loved the Tagine and salad.

A must visit attraction. The Maison de la Photographie has got to be one of the best places to visit whilst in Marrakech. There are some interesting photos of Marrakech and its people of days gone by and and the whole place is calm and quiet. I particularly enjoyed the rooftop café with some great views over the rooftops of the city and an outline of the Atlas Mountains. The access to this café would not be suitable for the elderly or infirm as it requires climbing a spiral staircase.
Excellent!. My 1st impression is that the gallery itself is small. Although the collection claims possession of several thousand photographs

Worth a visit while in Marrakech. This little museum is a worthy and quick stop and distraction from the bustle of the rest of the souks of Marrakech. Visit for 20-30 minutes and see several exhibits of Moroccan photographs--both old and recent--and then hang out on the roof terrace with a cold drink.

Rooftop cafe and views offer a wonderful reprieve from the hustle and bustle of Marrakech. Go right to the rooftop for some coffee, great views and tranquility from the busy streets of Marrakech. It's interesting to see the sea of satellite dishes on the rooftop of Marrakech. The cafe offers free internet access, however, it wasn't working when we were there. I would suggest going during sun down. The staff are very friendly. Oh and the photographs are amazing.

A bit overrated. I think this is designed for people who loves photography. The overall exposition is good to watch and appreciate but do not expect too much (I mean, its not a huge gallery). We liked a lot the terrace and the prices for drinks are quite ok. I recommend this place as a refreshment place for very reasonable cost in the centre of Marrakech. The sight at the terrace is pretty good as well.

Excellent!. If you enjoy photography, you will love this place. Very interesting photos, and a lovely roof deck to enjoy some tea. they also have wifi. My only suggestion would be to ditch the stools as I would have hung out there longer (and spent more money on food/more tea on the terrace) but the tiny stools were killing my back (and I am a small person). Definitely worth a trip and right around the corner from the Koranic school.
Very good place. Very good place with a fantastic terrace for the lunch, the view is terrific. But the price for the entrance of 40 dirhams each is a little bit expensive for such a small place.

Fascinating and beautiful!. A beautiful and interesting collection of photographs, run by lovely staff and with a fantastic, quiet roof terrace to stop for a bite to eat and some tea with a great view of the city

Brilliant old photos - worth finding. This was excellent - make sure you can find it amongst the souks. Cheap entry with super photos. Many portraits dating back to 1880 or earlier - the quality will astound you. Far better than can be taken with modern digital cameras. Nice staff and there is a super rooftop cafe.Not to be missed. If we go to Marrakech again I will not hesitate to revisit.

Excellent choice of old pictures. Far the best collection of old pictures of Morrocco. A really fantastic private housse with rare pictures made in remote places. Staff is very helpfull and very involve.

A lovely gem tucked away in the medina. While we had some difficulty locating the place, I'm so glad that we managed, finally and fortuitously, to find ourselves at the doorstep of this museum. Stepping out of the afternoon heat into the cool serenity of the museum, we were warmly welcomed by a friendly local by the name of Nizàr. Receiving an introduction of the museum by him, we wandered about its beautiful interiors, admiring the interesting old photographs that revealed the historical and cultural aspects of Morocco of a time past. The view from the rooftop terrace was gorgeous as well, offering an unobstructed view of the medina. I'd definitely recommend anyone heading to Marrakesh to give this lovely museum a visit!
quick visit and well-worth looking at photos. Looks like lovely cafe on the roof. Nice views. Not crowed and cool inside. Staff is helpful with lots of information
Small and nice place to learn the history of Berberis. İt is easy to find close to Ben Medrasa Youssef, see lots of photo about their history from 16th century.

Nice photos. Interesting place with wonderful photographs, and nice to get out of the streets for a while. Don't expect too much though. Half an hour will give you plenty of time to see everything. The terrace is great and is a good place to take a break.

Better than a museum. The Maison de la Photographie is a must-visit while you're in Marrakech. The photos tell of a history that's hard to see in modernizing Morocco. The photographs are simply stunning. Plus, there's a related museum up in the Ourika valley that is also worth a visit - the Ecomusee Berbere.
Very fine printing throughout. Was busy when we arrived, beware the long lenses they can bruise in confined spaces! the quality of the prints for sale was very good which makes a nice change.

Not a huge collection of photos but nice and the cafe is great!. There are not a huge number of photographs in the collection at the Maison de la Photographie but the ones they have a lovely - showing Marrakech and Morocco from about the 1800s to the 1930's, landscape pictures and portraits of local people. It probably took us about 30 minuets to look at everything, but it does only cost 40 dirham to get in. It is a lovely peaceful environment also amid the hassle of the medina The thing we enjoyed most about the Maison de la Photographie was the roof top cafe with views of the medina. The food was good (the chicken pastilla was a little dry but my husband's chicken tajine with lemon was lovely) and they do a set meal with a Moroccan salad to start, a tajine and a yogurt for desert for 80 Dirham. The hibiscus tea was great too. It was a very peaceful place to take a break from the Medina.
Photographic experience. Really recommend the visit to see 100 years (approx) documented. Nice, calm. Good roof top terrace for drinks/light meals.

Great pics, great views. Fab little place. Lovely black and white photographs from the 20's to the present day. Interesting. The cafe on the roof terrace was lovely and great value for a simple lunch.
Great place for lunch on a rooftop terrace. Lovely photos, not lots there but it's nice to be away from the hustle and bustle and a great place for lunch on the rooftop terrace
Special Look at Morocco. Great small gem of a place with beautiful, old photographs of Morocco. A wonderful place to visit to gain more insight into the history of the country.
Hidden gem. If you love photography, and want a glimpse into old Morocco, this museum satisfies both cravings. You can buy prints of the photographs - wonderful souvenirs!
Delightful photographic museum. An excellent initiative to save and display photographic records of Morocco. And there's a lovely cafe on the roof terrace.
the best part: the relax onthe terrace. nice photographic show, great terrace where to relax, drink and eat. easy to walk to from the main square

Nice but far from amazing. It is a pleasant museum and well curated. However at least half of the images are recent prints off of the original glass negatives - nothing wrong with that per se - can see some amazing details - but lacks the patina and also a chance to see how the photographer brought out the original image (development and printing is more an art than a science). I would recommend to buy the ticket that allows you to visit 2 other museums nearby. For all 3 museums I would allow 2 hours, for this venue itself probably 40 minutes. The cafe on the terrace offers nice views but is about twice the price of similar venues. The print copies they sell in the lobby are very well done and an excellent value.
Unexpected surprise. It's more than an exhibition. It's a trip across ages about Moroccan culture. Great place to relax and great photos to "dream" of past centuries. BRAVO !!!

A great place with some very special images. If you like photography this place is fantastic full of great photos of Morocco in a very nice building, don t miss the roof terrace and little cafe upstair

Maison de la Photographie. Visit this museum! This is a great place for history buffs and lovers of photography in Marrakech. The roof top terrace affords amazing views, have a mint tea and relax after viewing intriguing old photographs of Morocco and the Berber people. Very cool.

Lovely little place to get some peace and tranquility. Visited this Museum after being told that this was a must see in the City, was quite hard to find ( like most places in Marrakesh ) but once we did find it we were warmly greeted by a french man ( probably the owner ) sitting at the front desk who gave us a breif explanation of the museum and what to expect. Photos in the gallery are very interesting, only issue is that the room that held the video would be to have this translated into English... The cafe was a little dissapointing as we sat on the top of the terrace where this was located and waited for about 15 minutes to be served.... no one turned up! however this musuem is definately worth a visit at 40dhs a head!
Would have loved to have visited. We walked to visit this and found it closed until 1st May 2014 which was too late for us. No hint on the webpage that it was closed. Poor indeed.

Excellent. Really interesting place with a great cafe on the top.Wonderful views of Marrakesh. Hard to get to though. Could be slightly better signposted, but that is all part of the adventure! Would recommend!
Interesting, but limited collection. Nice building and set up of photos. Nice photos. Pity there was more of historical background such as French colonial impact.

Very interesting and showing excellent examples of 19th century Morocco with opportunities to buy good copies. Variety of photographs - many different portraits as well as interesting town and country scenes . Good examples of original printing techniques.However, although housed in a beautiful old riad-style house, this means the whole exhibition is spread over several floors with step steps and no lift - a great limitation for those with mobility difficulties.

Low key but interesting!. A group of six of us visited this museum and all really enjoyed it. Fascinating photographs with enough information, well displayed in a lovely old building. Very interesting video (original film) of life in rural Morocco in the 1950s. The cafe on the roof was really good too - the best freshly squeezed lemon we had in Morocco and very good orange! The post cards and photos for sale in the entrance were excellent.

Interesting glimpses of an earlier Morocco. Not a huge museum, but well laid out and with great photographic prints of Moroccans from the 19th Century. A haven of calm in a beautiful building. Well worth seeing.
Great pictures. It is a nice museum, with a beautiful view from the terrace. The documentary 9in french) is worth watching.
great rooftop cafe. really great gallery, well worth a visit and with fantastic view and food from the shady and tranquil rooftop cafe.
A must see!. A haven from the souk hustle, with gorgeous old photographs starting from the 1880's. The roof top cafe is perfect for a cold drink or lunch.

Really good gallery with a cool cafe. The exhibition that was showing when we were there was really interesting with some fantastic and fascinating pictures. The gallery itself is a nice building and it has a cool café on the roof from which you can look over the city and enjoy a mint tea and pastries.

A lovely little museum/gallery - if you can find it. This is a great diversion for an hour or two and gives an insight into Marrakech past. It's fascinating to see how much (and in some respects how little) has changed. You can even buy prints from the shop.
loved it. Great escape from the chaos outside. Gives you a good insight into life in Morocco in the past. Amazing photographs and a nice terrace for great views of the city.

Great photography and an an excellent rooftop terrace cafe.. Calm, cool and fascinating, plus a breathtaking view of the city from the cafe roof terrace. Take your own camera
.
Recommended. I thought the photographic museum was fab. V interesting and amazing pictures, particularly the ones of Morocco from over 100 years ago.

4euros to get in & great views of the city from the roof terrace.. Situated in a beautiful house, with photos telling the story of Marrakech's history over the yeas. Coffee shop hidden on roof terrace which offers cheap refreshments & fantastic views of the city.
Easter Visit. Well laid out galleries and the restaurant on the terrace looks good (although was full for lunch when we visited)

Wonderful surprise. This was a wonderful museum, the photographs showed Moroccan life in the early 20th century. It was not overwhelming and it was a wonderful surprise. We bought a reprint of one of the photos we liked. A great memory.
Worth a visit. Interesting selection of photographs of Morocco through the ages. Definitely worth going up to the roof terrace for a wonderful view over the city.

not worth going out of your way for. This attraction could use an infusion of more recent photographic works. This would enhance the excellent photos of the past and give a much needed perspective, to the traveler, of what little change has taken on also of what great changes have been made to this most amazing city and land.

Absolutely worth a visit. A few reviews state it's a bit out of the way and hard to find, but it's not far at all from the Medresa Ben Youssef which is another popular place to visit.The museum is small, but well laid out in a beautiful building. The rooftop terrace has lovely views and is a quiet place for a sit-down.Unfortunately for the wallet, you can buy prints of the pictures which makes for a very nice souvenir.

Old Marrakech on film. It's a little out of the way and the signposting is poor, but a visit to this gallery is a must during your stay in Marrakech. It features a remarkable collection of photos, and film documentaries, on Marrakech and other Moroccan cities as well as rural areas such as the Atlas Mountains. Dating from the late 19th century to the mid-20th century, the pictures are truly evocative. One look at them and you'll see there's a lot about modern Marrakech that remains unchanged from a century ago. The gallery has a rooftop cafe terrace with great views of the city and prints of the photos can be purchased.
Absolutely amazing!. Great place, with beautiful pictures of life in Morocco as it used to be, an absolute must-see in Marrakech!
interesting. Nice selection of old photographs. Cafe on roof top terrace worth a visit for the menu of the day 60 md

a wonderful way to see what Marrakech was like 30-50 years ago. easy to find, great cafe on the roof terrace and lovely photographs of the local places and people. A nice place to cool down from a few hours in the souks
Small museum with nice roof top restaurant. Restaurant serves one meny. Nice relaxing area . Museum has some interesting old photographs and is set in a nice building.

Lovely spot. We enjoyed this little gallery very much. The grainy black and white photos were artistic and captured a feeling of a bygone age. The little terrace on the roof was quiet, delightful, not overly expensive and a real welcome reprieve in a hectic city.
Interesting. We enjoyed this exhibition, however felt the 'pop up' display in Badi Palace was just as interesting to see... Make an effort!The roof terrace looked a wonderful place for lunch.

Well worth a visit. We were lucky to be staying just around the corner from this delightful gallery, as I would imagine it is difficult to find. Lots of wonderful photos of old Marrakech and great views of the medina and Atlas mountains from the rooftop café.
Smaller than expected. A lovely exhibition, complete with cafe and toilets, just a little smaller than we thought it would be! Worth finding if you have half an hour to kill

Beautiful. The riad this is set in is serene and beautiful and walking around viewing the amazing photographs was fascinating. There were less phots than I had expected as I read that the museum has 5000 photos but it has been very cleverly curated. One of the highlights was sitting on the very peaceful 4th floor roof terrace which has stunning views over the whole of the city. We also purchased some very reasonable and good quality prints of the photos from the little shop in the entrance. Well worth a visit.
Beautiful. A wonderful expo of fascinating 19th century photos and a roof where you should definitely have lunch - fantastic!!!

Nice photographic exhibition and good. Nice photographic exhibition (for those who are interested) and a good place to take a break on the rooftop restaurant in the sun enjoying the view. We had nice coffee and mint tee :)
Best views!. Interesting photos, lovely building, but the best thing is the rooftop cafe! Amazing view across Marrakech to the mountains,.

Flying visit . This was on our way back to the riad at lunchtime so we stopped by. The motivation was more the view from the roof and lunch to be honest so the 40 Dirham entrance might have dissuaded us. We did have a very pleasant lunch though and the views across the city to the high atlas are stunning. Shame we didn't have more time for the photos I'm sure that would have been worth it
Ok place to visit .. An unusual setting for a photographic display but worth a visit.A small cost to enter and your ticket will allow free subsequent visits.
Lovely Staff. Great location.... not expecting a photographic gallery in this location and they guys that work there were so nice
Great historic photos. Panoramic view not as good as revues. Quite difficult to find, especially with local's trying to con you to go to tannery

Hidden museum. This museum is not too far from the main square but quite a mission to find! We ended up having to ask for help from a local who of course expected a tip, but it was worth it. The museum itself is almost a very large house containing lots of historical photographs of Marrakech throughout the years. Possibly the best thing about the museum was the rooftop café. From there you can see a really good view of the city skyline with lots of mosque minarets jutting up all over the place, and in the background the majestic Atlas Mountains
Lovely Roof Restaurant. Menu limited but worth it for the view - book if you can. You can see the Atlas Mountains in full. Photos are very interesting and you can buy prints to take home.
a must. calm, distiguished, wonderful old photos, a very nice little restaurant on the roof, an oasis in a very busy town

Great getaway from the bustle. If you need an hour or 2 away from the markets and mopeds, take a breather here. It's only a few Dirhams to get in, and the photography is fantastic! It's a great look back at the history of the city (not that Marrakech in the photos from the 1800s looks much different to how it does today!) But the best part is the cafe on the top floor. We had lunch on the balcony, 90dhms (about £9) for 3 courses, consisting of a salad, an incredible chicken tagine and a strawberry-topped yoghurt (the menu presumably changes, but i'm sure you can be guaranteed a tagine). Eating with that view of the Atlas mountains (on a good day) is a delight. Take advantage of the view from that balcony to get some photos of your own.

Well worth the visit. This lovely traditional building is home to a fine collection of old photos relating the history of Marrakesh and its surroundings. If you happen to be there at lunchtime, try the roof restaurant where home-cooked and delicious food is served.

Beautiful light in a riad kept in white tones.. If you are interested in old pictures of Morocco or you want to feel the beauty and calm of this house kept in white colours, this is definately worth a visit.Nice upper terrace with a nice vieuw on the Marrakech roofs.My wife’s friend back home, told us that we should book their day trip to the Ourika Valley, because here they offer a more authentic, more eco walk through the valley, without the tourist traps at the waterfalls. And so it turned out. So lucky we did.

Wonderful photos. Well worth the walk to the museum, some great photos of Morroco's past, and a fabulous spot for views on the roof terrace, we were lucky enough to see the Atlas Mountains on a very clear day.

Inspiring insight into Marrakech a hundred years ago. A small but very interesting museum with fascinating photos (most from around 1900-1930) of Morocco in days gone by. Well laid out and the roof top cafe is a pleasant place for a drink - they were not serving food when we visited at lunchtime.

Inspirational!. As a photographer, I enjoyed this small, but inspirational gallery. It was quite cheap to enter and they sell food and drink on the top floor. The gallery was full of great photography from the late 1800's to the mid 1900's. The photographs were both aesthetically and emotionally impressive.If you're interested in art/photography or want a short break from the madness of Marrakech, this is a nice stop.

fascinating- don't miss it!. Aziz at Riad L'Orangerie recommended that we go here, and we were not disappointed- a great way to get a feel for the cultural history of Morocco - if you like photography, this museum will take your breath away!

An unmissable portal into the Morocco of the 1890s. Contray to TripAdvisor's map, this is not in Fes but in the heart of the Marrakech Medina, just up from Ali Ben Youssef Madrasa.There are three floors of wonderful photography from around Morocco from the 1890s which give you a sense of just how little the old town has changed (except for the damn motorbikes!).There is a terrace with a lovely view across the souks and alleyways and you can have a snack while looking over the Atlas mountains.There is a also a shop selling prints of the photos should you want to take Marrakech home with you.

Worth a short visit. Super little museum. A simple display of some great old photographs of Morocco dating back to late 1800's spread over a few floors of a traditional Riad. Little cafe on the roof has good view over the roof tops, although the menu very limited. Nice clean loo and good collection of postcards of the photo's on display as well as larger copies on sale. If you do go, look for the herbalist on the way out (towards the school nearby) ~ the best we found in the city, expansive, beautifully laid out. We were served by a charming man, happy to let us browse & explain what things were.
Interesting photos. Extremely nice proprietor. Lovely collection of old photos, and can purchase photos as well. Great rooftop view of the city.

Calm amongst the "madness". After 4 hours of the Medina, we began trying to locate this museum. Not an easy task at all. We eventually found it and after paying our 40 Dirhams were entertained by the black and white images of Morocco/Marrakech. This was very interesting. The ticket does allow free revisits to this museum.The museum is naturally a cool place, after the warmth, hustle and bustle of the souks. The roof top café, provides what looked like good, cheap food and drink. The mint team was very refreshing.The best part of the café is the 360 degree panoramic views of Marrakech and its surroundings, especially over the Atlas mountains.Well worth a visit..After the difficulty of finding the museum, we began to find signs directing you to it....so they do exist....
Nice small museum. Lovely photos. Great rooftop terrace with 360 views of the rooftops. Only drawback is it was Hard to find!
Very nice place. Loved this little museum. Very interesting pictures of old Marroco in a nice little building. Even a small roof terrasse
Lovely photos and great terrace. Lovely photos. Great rooftop terrace with 360 views of the rooftops. Only drawback is it was Hard to find!

Somewhat tricky to find. This museum has a nice but small collection of older photographs from throughout Morocco. A number of the photographers featured are foreign. They sell nice prints of the photographs which were also available elsewhere as (cheap) postcards so I assume that these are iconic photos. There is also a cafe on the terrace. We stopped up there but left when no one appeared to take our order.
