Fabulous photos!. A lovely calm house with beautiful old photography, so interesting to see old Marrakech. The view from the roof terrace across the whole city is stunning, well worth the entrance fee of 40 dirhams!

Great rooftop for lunch. While the museum is definitely worth a trip, showing photographs of Marrakech and Morocco in chronological order with the earliest dating back to 1875, the tiny rooftop restaurant overlooking the city is a great recommendation for lunch. Offering only one menu (on our particular day: A choice of Moroccan soup or aubergine salad to start with, followed by chicken tagine, with a dessert of natural yoghurt and fresh strawberries) for only MAD80 (approx. 8€), this is the best we've eaten in Marrakech in terms of value for money. The free wifi is a plus.

Excellent exhibition. This gallery is like an oasis of beatiful art close to the tanneries. The exhibition gave us an opportunity to learn more of the way of living in this country. The rooftop cafe is a splendid closing of the walking through the gallery.
great collection. A really great collection of old prints and chromes well worth a visit Not the easiest place to find but the place warrants a visit
Very interesting. Well worth a visit and a good rooftop café - good soup , tea and aubergine salad . An oasis of calm close to centre of medina .
Have a look at the city over the years.. The city doesnt appear to have changed that much and a very nice view of the sunset from the balcony.

Nice stop.. The Maison de la Photographie is a nice stop while you're in the Medina. The photography is interesting (considering the age of most of it...) and the layout and stained glass windows are nice. The real bonus is the cafe on the roof. It's got a great view over the city and some pretty good food, too.Perfect place to relax with a tea and write a few postcards home...
Facinating. Really enjoyable if you like old photographs. Even if you don't, it has a great roof cafe. The entrance ticket can be used repeatedly
Nothing special, nice cafe. Was not that impressed, photo's were OK but nothing special and i was slightly disappointed. Cafe was on the roof and has a good atmosphere.

lovely museum. lovely museum giving a historical persepctive of photography and life in this area of north Africa. Beaufiful 360 degree views of the city acroos rooftops and to the Atlas mountains from the cafe upstairs
Nice photos and a great roof terrace. Interesting photos exhibition in a lovely old building. We had lunch on the roof terrace, food was nice and not too expensive. Lovely spot with great views

Nice Location & Food!!. Found amongst the hustle and bustle of the souk, we really enjoyed this small museum. The rooftop cafe is excellent and you can get great shots. You can use your ticket again as well if you want to return....
Beautiful setting. Very atmospheric setting and exhibition with a good rooftop cafe. A good view over the whole city and well worth seeking out.

Great photos and a lovely cafe on the roof. Really interesting selection of photos of old Morocco. At the end of the visit just go up to the roof terrace for a simple fresh lunch and great views over the city.

a change of pace in Marrakech. visited this place in the afternoon - had a lovely collection of photos, calming and quite atmosphere and we loved the great terrace upstairs for lunch. The best chicken tagine we had all trip, with a nice view too.

Inspiring photos and video about Berber life. Fascinating small museum and a wonderful place for a lunch on
the terrace, with a spectacular view and delicious food.
Lovely place. Very interesting and lovely roof terrace restaurant unexpensive. Amazing view and good food. We liked the pictures.
Great collection and great food on the terrace. Fantastic views of old Morocco in the exhibits and fantastic view of the medina from the rooftop restaurant.
interesting. very interesting and beautiful pictures , unfortunately quite expensive to buy copies , tip very good free wifi in the house !

delightful museum. This small sophisticated photographic museum is full of wonderful atmospheric pictures, well framed and historically and aesthetically interesting. The curator is well informed and this place should be supported. Lovely rooftop cafe is a bonus

Beautiful Museum. Fascinating to see the history of Marrakech in photos as far back as the late 1800's. So much has changed and so little at the same time. Quick Tip: If anyone tells you it is closed don't believe them. For whatever reason, a lot of locals will claim things are closed to try to get you back to the main square. Just smile and keep moving.
Glimpse into history. Wonderful little place. Quiet and serene little place with some amazing photos. Added bonus of the rooftop cafe with delicious food and a picturesque view
Great little museum in the heart of the souks.. Lovely mint tea on the balcony. The atmosphere when all the local mosques do their call to prayer around 12.50 is incredible.
A great place. If you can find it - go there! Don't miss the terrace up on the roof. Great photographs and helpful, pleasant staff.

What a view. The museum is small, but we liked it, contains old photos from Marrakech and Morocco.Nice to see how life changed.At the top you will find a roof terrace with restaurant and bar. Nothing extraordinary but cosy.We didn't luch, but the lunches served beside looked great. We went for tea and drinks, no remarks at all.+ point: clean spacious toilet, roof top view on the Atlas mountains and the city, free entry afterwards with the same ticket!.
Go. Very interesting photos on three floors with a wonderful roof terrace and café. It is worth making the effort to find it!
Museum of Photography. Some really good old black & white photos - worth a visit. The building is worth the visit as well as the pictures.
fascinating. Not too many people about, but lots of good information. Excellent cafe with limited but good men and stunning views
Excellent photos and nice coffee bar. Excellent, once we found it, some amazing photos and nice coffee bar on top level. Staff very helpful.

The best place to have lunch. Beautiful pictures and a great view with friendly people and the best tajine we had in Marrocco. the place is rather small so it is good to look at the pictures and have lunch afterwards
My birthday trip round the Medina. I was taken to this place on a walk around the Medina...what fascinating photographs and lovely building.
Beautiful hidden gem. If you can find this beautiful place in Marrakech it is def worth a visits. Beautiful. So cool to se the old pics hanging on the wall

Visually intriguing. The museum of photography is in the midst of the Medina, close to the Ben Youssef Mosque and Madrassa, beautiful images in monochrome, thoughtfully presented and curated, giving an insight into life in the Medina of Marrakech, Fez and other cities in Morocco, the documentary of Berber life filmed by the french director is raw and all in french, but the images are visually intriguing and introduced us to the hard life led in the Atlas by these original indigenous inhabitants of North Africa, before the Arab settled, bringing their culture and religion to this beautiful land. The cafe terrace is relaxed, and peaceful until the call to prayer blasts out. great value and nice people!

worth a visit, especially for 360 degree view on balcony. The museum is worth the money although the balcony is worth the entrance fee alone. The views are amazing the best in Marrakesh. You can sit down and relax in the shade with a drink or a 2 course meal

Interesting photos, nice patio in the medina. Multi level house in the medina converted in museum displaying photos and movies of Morocco dating since 1870. Possibility of buying copies of some of the photographs displayed. Worth the stop. 40 Dhs. Located between Place du Moukef and Médersa - if needed, ask a guide or kid in the medina to take you over in the medina street maze. Restaurant on rooftop with nice 360 views on the medina.

A different museum!. Totally worth the visit to this small museum! If you like photography and are interested in seeing images of Marrakech and Morocco in general through time, do not miss this visit! It does't take too long to visit and it's absolutely worth it! If you make at sunset (it closes at 7 pm) make sure to watch the sunset from the little cafeteria they have on the roof top! amazing views of the city!

A quiet oasis in the madness of the souks. well worth a visit a quiet tranquil spot within the souk. Lots of interesting photographs dating back to early 1900's and before of ancient morrocco and the berber population- have lunch on the terrace whilst you are there!

Go and see the Maison de la Photographie in Marrakech. This museum is in a beautiful building and contains fascinating material very well-displayed. It's easy to find (well-signed), staff were very friendly and the cafe on the roof terrace is a great place from which to look over Marrakech and beyond to the High Atlas mountains.

Amazing "Maison". I love this museum, the photos are stunning and evocative. The staff is very helpful and friendly.The rooftop terrace offered a superb 360° view of the city; with snacks and refreshments.This is a very interesting place in the Medina.
Lovely - rooftop cafe great too.. Wonderful collection of photographs of Morocco in a beautiful riad. We enjoyed the rooftop cafe as well. So tranquil.

Beautiful exhibition, great place for tea stop!. We stumbled upon the gallery whilst it was pooring with rain, having got completely lost. It was a gem to find - great exhibition & good place to buy some nice prints. Ticket costs 40dirham but you can re-visit during your stay in Marrakech so we went back on a sunnier day to have tea / food on the terrace - great view from here - good for photography!

Lovely place to visit. We really liked the building, and also the interesting photographs and the nice rooftop terrace. The photographs and also the fil,M that was shown give a quite different view on Marrakesh history.we really like it and its a very busy in this traditional building

Romantic imagery.. Although in essence a high end shop displaying its goods in the guise of a collection(with entrance fee)As a gallery, set in a most pleasant riad, it was a pleasurable experience with roof terrace refreshments to purchase and great views of the medina.

Great find!. I don't know much about photography, but I loved seeing the photos they had here in such a beautiful building. A big advantage was the roof terrace - we sipped (cheap) mint tea and watched the sun go down on our last night in Marrakech - a great way to finish the holiday. Tickets also valid more than one day - so great if you fancy a revisit.

Great Views!. One of the best views over Marrakech, with the Atlas in the back. Good for a relaxing afternoon snack, very friendly service - the photos (mostly historic in b/w) alone are worth the visit. The tickets are good for multiple visits!
An artistic oasis in the chaos. Incredible photo gallery. Very friendly and knowledgeable english speaking staff. Great terrace for food and tea with very good prices. A must see in Marrakech!

Little cozy museum. Nice cozy oasis inside medina. Probably, it's worth to keep it till the very end of your visit to Marrakech, as you can see how places you might have visited looked like ~100 of years ago (Ali Ben Youssef Madrasa, Jemaa el Fna, Souks).The only drawback is that it's located not so far away from the tanneries, so expect more pushy guys trying to persuade you to go to there instead.

Wonderful. For anyone interested in photography or indeed the history of Morocco this is a wonderful place. But not only do you have some great photographs, they are housed in a pretty building which has a cafe on the roof with knock-out views of the city and the mountains beyond.

Great experience, well worth a visit. We recently spent a few hours here and thoroughly enjoyed it and would recommend it - extremely informative about Morocco and has the most wonderful photographs. The two young guys who seemed to be managing it were really nice and helpful - a pleasure to chat with. We went on to the terrace to order tea and something to eat but no one came to serve us which surprised us. The lack of street names on the streets in the Medina is a very real problem, it makes having a map completely pointless and means you will get lost which in turn makes you a target for young men trying to guide you and hustle you for money. This is obviously so common place that it makes you think the Authorities are content with this practice which is a real shame as it, in my view, reflects very poorly on Moroccan people and culture and does a real dis service as the people are mainly kind and helpful. Come on Government, it does not take much effort to get street signs in place!!

Nice museum in great house with good excursions. The museum is really worth the 40 MAD entrance, even though you are not interested in photography. It's situated in a nice old building and the roof teracce is one of the highest in the medina. There they offer nice and affordable food (set menu 80mad) and it's perfect for taking photos.We also did an excursion they offer to Ourika valley by local transport in taxi collectiv and a personal guide in the berber villages (incl. lunch at his house with his family). The whole day package is 300mad and it's really great and worth the money!
Best attraction. Beautiful photographs and films in a very tranquil setting. Knowledgeable guides. A cup of mint tea on the terrace is a must especially at sunset!

Fascinating Collection. The photos date from1880s and are the earliest images taken of Berber people. Beautifully displayed. We ended our visit up on the roof terrace. Great view and a simple but tasty lunch.

Interesting photos great terrace. The photos dont take long to look at and the real reason to go is for the terrace. Fantastic views and food at great prices. You get picturesque views of the atlas mountains on this restful little terrace and a menu du jour at 80 dh. The tajine was wonderful. Be sure to try the hibiscus tea.
History of photography in Morocco. Fascinating view of Europeans coming to Morocco and taking photos but rarely of the inside of homes. Also 1950s footage of a visit to Saharan tribes

Nice place to visit, and to eat there!. The title sums our visit. It's a nice place to visit, like an oasis in the middle of the desert. Also, you can enjoy a delightful meal on the roof. Don't miss it!

Something different. This property can be seen along side the Ben Youssef Medersa and is arguably as interesting as it has an art exhibition as well as the photographic exhibits.The lady running the cafe here however did not have the right attitude towards her customers.
Interesting photos even more interesting day trips to the villages. We enjoyed our visit and also booked a day in the villages with a local guide through the museum which was most interesting.

Learn a lot about Morocco!. This museum is full of photos, mainly from the 20's, of Morocco as it,used to be and the Berber people who make up a large percent of the population. Great photos & portraits.

A house with THE view!. Treat yourself with this! The view was amazing! The montage of the exhabitions were both sobre and stunning at the same time. Don't miss this. Both Julian4years and Liam20 had as much pleasure as maman44.

Very well worth a visit. The photographs are sensational and depict the history of Morocco better than any history or guide book can ever do. I loved the 1950's television french documentary. Given that we were not impressed by any of the other museums in Marrakech, I would not miss this one. Although the terrace features well in other reviews, I would not recommend eating there unless you have loads of time to kill. Service is slow!
Amazing place. Magic place. Please, take your time and drink a tea or coffee at the terrace at sunset. Unique experience !
Interesting & fantastic lunch. Enjoyed the history of Berbers through photographs. The lunch a set 3 course meal was inexpensive and probably the nicest meal we had all week

Great museum. Excellent roof cafe!. We love photography so we visited the museum on the first day of our 3 week trip to Marrakech and found out that our ticket allowed us reentry for our entire 3 week stay! We went back several times to enjoy the images and visit the roof cafe! Great view of Marrakech from the rooftop!

If just for the terrace ..... Fantastic B&W photos from 1880s onwards. Beautiful composition and they could have been taken last week. Thoroughly enjoyed this museum. Best facilities in town. But the icing on the cake is the tranquil, terrace. Fantastic views. Good lunch - try the hibiscus tea!

Nice get away from buzzing streets of Medina. Beautiful building, very interesting collection of photographs, fluent in English and very polite staff. Really refreshing experience after buzzing Medina streets..

Great pics and rooftop cafe. Lovely atmosphere and friendly staff. Some good written information in English (not always available in the city) and superb, historic photos with a neat film on the history of the Berber people. Excellent terrace cafe which serves an incredible three course meal for 80d (about £7.50 when we were there). No choice but well worth it.
With seeing. Gives you an idea of the country's history. Wonderfully evocative. Also, they have a good cafe on the top floor with great views and a 3 course lunch menu for 80 dirhams.

Great rooftop!. Charming house, very difficult to find tough. The locals certainly don't help you much, but it's worth the effort.
The rooftop has a very beautiful view of the city.
The photos were quite impressive, specially because of the date they were taken.

Bridging past and present brilliantly. Marrakech has gripped the foreign imagination for over a century, as this super little museum in an old fondouk or serai clearly reveals. Here you can wallow in the 'exotic' past of which more than a flavour persists in Marrakech: photos of sun-barred, robed and turbaned Berbers in the souks; of men leading queues of camels across Saharan sands; of a staring boy, backed by the Red City's red walls and a frieze of snow-covered Atlas peaks beyond; of musicians, crowds, interiors, atmospheres. Great photographers such as Muller and Belin are well represented, and you can watch Daniel Chicault's poetic film of life in high-Atlas Berber villages, which is helpful in illuminating aspects of the culture now. Nip up to the cafe on the top for a splendid view, the flitting of house buntings and a meal or a drink. Your ticket can be reused: a great excuse for returning, to add more layers of history to your visit.

Interesting photos, fab cafe. A pleasant escape from the busy street life outside. This is a little oasis of calm, looking at photos of old Morocco as you wander through this 4 storey building. On the rooftop is a wonderful little cafe with great views of the city.

great historical photographs & a rooftop cafe w/ 360 degree views. A must visit when in Marrakech - their collection of photographs is stellar and gives you peak into what Marrakech looked like back in the day. Even if you don't want to sit down for a drink or bite - check out the rooftop cafe. The giftshop stocks copies of most of the photos - wish I would have picked some up.

Hidden gem. Very hard to find, but for us, the best visit in Marrakech. A collection of old photos of real historical worth and so clear. Lovely rooftop café too: cheap and great views. Find it. Persevere.

Must see. I was visiting Marrakesh with a good friend when an acquaintance of his took us there . I fell in love with the place within seconds !The photographs are out of this world and gave a window into Morocco's past like I had never seen before . You can also watch a couple of great documentaries in a small viewing room upstairs.The building itself is really nice and the roof terrace has a great view of Marrakesh . Make sure you stay for tea or have a meal there . The food is good and on the cheap side . Check it out if you want a quiet place to enjoy Marrakesh , especially of you are with your significant other or a small group of friends .
If you like photography it's worth the trip :-). So many photos that could have been taken today but are 80,90 years old! Great view of the sunset from the cafe on the roof.

Not so interesting. We were a little underwhelmed by the photo collection although the building itself was quite nice. Perhaps it's unfair to complain as entry is free but I wouldn't recommend a visit.
Top place!. Super rooftop café-resto, now getting well-known and costlier than the guide books say. Not all that easy to find, but then where is in Marrakech?
Nice to see. The old photos are great to see...it always amazes me to see the past. It's a smallish museum but worth the visit.

A total must see. First of all this is located in a lovely little riad (not so easy to find though, don't hesitate to ask for help). Second, you will see many older pictures of Morocco, from various photographers (mostly European), also a nice series of 3 movies about the Berber culture in the 1950s. Lastly, a tea on the rooftop is a must, especially at dawn...

Worth a visit. I enjoyed browsing the photos, but am no expert in this area. The building itself is very charming and the roof terrace is nice for a sit down with a view but were unlucky with service here, possibly due to the fact that the staff are downstairs in a tiny cupboardlike space and they need to carry everything up a cramped spiral staircase. It made little difference to us, we enjoyed sitting down to enjoy the scenery.

Interesting exhibition. A nice and interesting selection of ancient photographs that give a very good insight how the life in morocco and the medina used to be. Great view from the terrasse. Well worth a visit for the images and to get away from the overcrowded souks for a few minutes. The "photographs" from the exhibition that are for sale in the shop turned out to be just simple ink jet prints not even on photographic paper and definitely not worth the price of 250 dh. Better go for postcards if you want to buy something to take home.

Photos slightly underwhelming, but beautiful roof terrace. For the price, relative to other attractions in the city, the actual exhibit of photos on show are interesting but a bit small in number. However, the roof terrace is a delightful place to have a drink or a bite to eat. There is a cheap lunch menu and they serve nice mint tea, and you get some pretty views of the Medina.

Too romandic/voyeristic/Morocco through western eyes. I loved the building more than the collection. The collection was based on westerners' view of Moroccans many decades ago. I would have liked to see the work of contemporary Moroccan photographers/artists and see what issues concern them in their daily life - rather than the current display of a westerner's romanticized view of Morocco. The building itself is worth the visit, as I loved the tiled floors and the verandahs.
Nice museum. We were not that interested, maybe you are :) It had some very nice pictures, but Marrakesh has so much other things to offer.

Well worth a visit. Stunning collecting of old photographs in a beautiful building. Time your visit so that you can stay for a delicious lunch on the roof terrace - it has great views of the medina and Atlas mountains beyond. You can also buy prints of the photographs but these are not cheap.

Svårt att finna men värt att leta efter. Easiest to find from Ben Yossef.It is lovely to look at the black and white photographs while you just have been passing through the colourful souk .
They hade a roof terrace with good food. A fixed meny <100 MAD.

Excellent photographs and well worth a visit. Beautiful photographs with excellent composition. Takes you through pictures from the earliest days of photography and evokes a different era with amazing pictures of people. Beautiful views from the roof terrace cafe.

great exhibition. we loved the atmosphere and the photos. howevery, the entry fee (40 Dh) is not cheap...compared to other sights in Marrakech (Palais Bahia, El Badi etc). but it is worth a visit! go to the terrace as well - you will enjoy an incredible view over the medina of marrakech.

Well located in the souks. The Maison de la photographie is situated on the street that goes to the tanning district.
The price is cheap, and you can go as many times as you desire with one ticket (you can come back several days)
The roof top is nice with a nice view.
Charming house. Some very interesting old photos in a lovely old house. The rooftoop terrace cafe is great! Worth spending about an hour or two here.

Great Look into the Past. The exhibitions are very interesting. There are many pics from the late nineteenth century early twentieth and you can see the difference between past and present. I would recommend you come in the end of your stay in Marrakech so that you can have a sense of where things are and how they look today.The museum's building is also nice and it has a beautiful rooftop.

Calm amongst the chaos. Hard to find but well worth it once you get there.40 DIR entry but you could go back again for that as long as you kept your ticket.Amazing photography chronicling Morocco and Marrakech up to 1950 with some amazing prints created from original glass plates.Three floors of gallery with a stunning roof terrace serving hot and cold drink. Well worth coming back 30 mins before sunset as gives you an amazing view over Marrakech.

Charming house and interesting collection. It's a beautiful house, hidden a little behind the Medersa ben Youcef and Marrakech museum. Take the time to walk there, it's worth it. Surprising colored pictures from 1870s, amazing portraits from the 30s. Beautiful house. And a superb terrace. A must see.

What's all the fuss?. How on earth is this the 3rd best thing to do in Marrakesh? It's a nice old house that's been lovingly restored. A lot of the photos are nice enough, but it's all pretty sterile with slightly blurry photos all round the walls everywhere. Some are, of course, amazing given their age and location but, really, the 3rd best attraction in Marrakech?! I wonder whether it's more the contrast of the endless hassling in the surrounding streets compared to calm serenity in the museum and the nice cafe on top with the fantastic view of Marrakech? The entrance price is now 40 dirhams rather than 30 as was mentioned. I guess the plus side is that we were told we could use our tickets and come back another day and also that kids under 12 were freeIf old, blurry photos are your thing then this is for you. I can't imagine this museum being other than marginal interest in any other city anywhere else to be honest though

Quite Stunning. Not to be confused with the new Museum of Photography this gem is tucked away close to the Madrassa bin Yousef and is well worth a visit. The evocative photos map out the history of the Berber since 1898 and many are exquisite in their composition and sensitivity. The exhibition is planned out chronologically and with great care to ensure a fluid connectivity while giving each photo the space it deserves.If you have admired those black and white postcards you find in the souks, those images and many more can be found in a much larger format here.

Fab-u-lous. If you love photography, this is a must on your visit to marrakech.It's a small but perfectly formed gallery with a beautiful and provocative collection of photographs.Don't miss this hidden gem
Excellent. Great photo museum. Also do not miss going on the first class tour to a Berber village organised by this museum and led by the charmant genial and articulate Khalid.
Recommend. Interesting place to visit is you appreciate art and photography.If you are visiting Madrrassa Bin Yousuf, the it's worth popping.

Wonderful evocative pictures. Somehow the pictures reinforce the great power and longevity of the Berber history... the faces and dress you see in the photos from 1898 are no different to those in teh street you have just left. The thing that most struck me, however, was how on earth they managed to take pictures of the souks in 1929, when in 2013 my superduper all singing and dancing phone just took a picture of a dark hole!Well worth a visit and once you have finished, make the effort up all those stairs to the terrace for a SPLENDID chicken/citron tagine. Three courses, 80 DHr. BARGAIN. Splendiferous view.across Marrakech looking south to the Altas mountains. One of the best lunches on my trip.
Worth visiting. The museum is a nice change from the hectic market. The photos are very good and present some interesting historical perspective. Good addition to any Marrakech visit.

Interresting.. The best museum I visit in Marrakech. If you look for history that the place you should visit. Beautiful picture of Marrakech old's time, it helps to imagine what was looking Marrakech century ago. The team is helpful and kind, you can heaven have coffe or sandwich on the roof top.Nice view.

Wonderful. This place and its photos are magic. It makes for a welcome change to the hussle and bussle on the street, and you feel as though you are transported to another time in Morrocco. If you love photography or history this is for you. It is not a big exhibition but it is excellent. Great views from the roof top terrace. Definately add this to your to do list.

Amazing exhibition and great roof terrace. Fantastic place to visit and only 30 Dirham (less than 3 quid). If you are interested in photography, history of Marrakesh, portraiture, or architecture you will love it. Set over 3 floors in a delightful building, with an amazing roof terrace serving delicious mint tea, with top views across the city. You are also able to purchase many prints of the photos that feature in the exhibition. Really glad that I visited.

Nice. Nice photographs all well-arranged and taken. Was nice to see photographs from decades back especially of the Berber’sThe price at 40 MAD was quite steep for Moroccan standard but I enjoyed the visit none the less.

Just ok.. As someone who loves photography I was disapointed by the Maison de la Photographie. Yes it's a nice space and the images are great. However, it is overpriced when compared with the rest of Marrakech and you feel like the main point is to get you to visit the roof terrace cafe!One positive thing is that your ticket is valid for multiple visits so go and enjoy the sunset from perhaps the best terrace in Marrakech.

Evolution of photography in Morocco. It has been our only "museum" type visit in Marrakesh. We really liked it. The building is very nice, the view from the terrace is amazing. They display various photography techniques, that evolved over the years and they show different scenes from the country many decades back. I thought that the buildings in Marrakesh were falling apart because of there age, na, they looked exactly like that a century ago. Very interesting if you're a photography enthusiast. Don't expect any one to guide you through the visit, unfortunately.
History of Morocco through Photographs. Brilliant collection of historical photo's with some brilliant scenery & people. All in a beautiful Riad with a roof top terrace for lunch or coffee.

Amazing art with a beautiful view. The photos displayed in the museum are topped only by the incredible view from the terrace at sunset. The photographs were historically significant but also full of texture and beauty. Of all of the museums and monuments visited this was by far my favorite. I would highly recommend a visit to the museum and tea on the terrace.

An unexpected delight. This humble building opens into a lovely re-purposed courtyard. In my experience the natural light provided a lovely way to view the exhibit. In this case, the photographs by Lewis Muller, mostly sepia toned, are artful and historical and unposed. All these aspects made these photographs important. He captured the true appearance of the people in their time. The pained or joyful eyes, the somber landscapes, the urgency and drama of the cloud filled skies. These are indescribable in truth. Upstairs is a small film showing which is excellent and on the top floor is a sweet spot to see Marrakech and to take a break with food and beverage.

Well worth a visit. We went as it was rated #1 on tripadvisor. It was hard to find and they could really do with some more signs to help hapless tourists! That said we were very glad that we made the effort, the photos were really good and we enjoyed the old films about the Berber villages which was good preparation for when we went off into the mountains later on. We also took advantage of the 80MAD menu du jour in the rooftop terrace and it was a great meal and really good value for money. The views from the terrace were also some of the best we saw. So if you have time do go, but if you are pressed fro time then I would rate the Madrasa as a higher priority must see than this.

Nicely pitched, interesting museum. We enjoyed the photos and the calm ambiance of this museum. A glimpse through the photos of Morocco before we all arrived. We had a pleasant snack and a 'pause' on the roof terrace.

Good collection. Interesting exhibition of portraits and historical pictures. If you like photography and black&white images, you must visit Maison de la Photographie. You can buy prints from almost all pictures exhibited. Bit difficult to find but worth the walk.

Lovely old pictures of Morocco. Had a very nice visit, looking over all the old photographs of Morocco. There's also a little café on the roof with a beautiful view. It's a little difficult to find, like most places, but there are a few signs showing the way.
Great building. Interesting exhibitions but they could have been anywhere in the world. If you have a limited time in Marrakesh this would not be one of my priorities.

Trip to the Atlas Mountains and the desert. As first time visitors to Morocco, my sister and I were treated to an amazing experience with Morocco Countryside tours Company. From beginning to end, we were made to feel that we were traveling with friends who really cared about us and wanted to make sure that we enjoyed every moment. Our trip was planned for us with great detail to ensure that we were able to go from Marrakesh through the Atlas Mountains to the Desert and back by Said. We were priviledged to have Addi as our Driver/guide. he was very professional and did everything to ensure that we were happy from the get-go. Although Mother Nature  challenged us on the first day with every type of of weather from snow, hail and a lot of rain, we both felt safe with Addi driving. And He gave us so much historical information about the Berbers and their way of life and was eagar to answer all of our questions. He also did his best to teach us some Berber words which he must have repeated a thousand times. By the end of the trip, we had learned and laughed so much and we were excited that we were on our way through the mountains to the desert with Addi. We enjoyed every minute - especially our Camel ride that included an overnight stay in the desert at a camp. Addi also helped by taking pictures for us to make sure we had plenty of memories to take home to Australia. We met other travelers at camp who also enjoyed the Berber Music entertainment given by our Berber hosts making us feel more at home. I want to thank everyone at Morocco Countryside Tours for making our Moroccan experience one of the best trips ever! I want to thank Said for his expertise in planning the perfect tour and Addi for getting us everywhere safe and sound and making us feel like we were longtime friends as soon as we sat in the SUV by entertaining us, laughing with us and making sure that we were comfortable and happy throughout this trip. Most important, as two women traveling alone in a foreign country, we never feared for our safety which is the most important aspect of any trip. If you are looking for a great and authentic experience in this wonderful country, then Morocco Countryside Tours is the only way to go.

Don't Miss this Opportunity. Visited this stunning Photo Museum based on Trip Advisor reviews. It contains an exceptional collection of photos from the late 1800's and early 1900's. Do not miss viewing the video. That is exceptional as well. Highly recommended from a museum lover.
Nice visit. Interesting glimpse into the history of Marrakech. Worth a visit if you're in Marrakech for a few days, but I wouldn't necessarily go out of my way to go there if time is limited.

Relaxing oasis in a desert of madness. I'm not sure whether this place deserves to be the number 1 attraction in Marrakech on TripAdvisor (which it is at the time of writing), but it is a very calm, quiet museum of photos with a nice rooftop terrace. Definitely worth a visit.

must visit. this place was lovely the photos are amazing dating back to 1880.the staff are very friendly.it makes for a very peaceful afternoon it even has a rooftop terrace with a little restaurant.all in all a very interesting place to visit

A glimpse into the past. A small and nice museum with a beautiful collection of historic photographs. Mostly black and white, these photographs of people, places and landscapes give a good impression of Morocco's recent history - and it is a pleasant place where you can drink and eat on a lovely roof terrace.
Nice view nice food nice pictures. I enjoy the photography selection and the location. Pleasing surroundings on a fresh area. We enjoy nice lunch on the roof while enjoying the view.
A fascinating glimpse of Morocco's past. The best place in Marrakesh to get a real insight into how life was here 100 years ago. The photos are stunning, and don't miss the film on the top floor.

Worth looking for !. We found this really difficult to find but worth persevering! The building is beautiful and the roof terrace gives fabulous views, the food looked delicious & v tempting but it was very busy.The film of the Berber village in the 50's was fascinating but my french not good enough to follow it. An English synopsis/audio would have been great. The photo's were interesting and well presented, there was plenty of space to stand & look.
Oasis in hectic medina. The photographs here are stunning. The space is lovely and a welcomed reprieve from the hectic medina. Head to the rooftop for tea and tangines.

A real find. The museum is very well laid out.We found it very interesting and atmospheric and would definitely recommend it.Downside- it is hard to find and not necessarily marked on the map- head for Ben Yussef school and it's nearby. It is open 7 days a week (see website).Ignore any locals who stop you in the street and tell you it's closed to lure you elsewhere.Persevere!

Interesting collection and a great roof terrace!. The friendly and courteous staff offered us information about the museum in English as we entered, and pointed out that we could come and go if we kept our tickets.A lot of loving detective work appears to have gone on to draw this collection of mainly very early photographs together, and they're a fascinating record of what has and hasn't changed in Moroccan life.A looped video on one of the upper floors shows colour footage shot in a Berber village in 1957 and although the commentary is in French it's pretty easy to grasp what is being shown. It was an interesting reference point when we got to visit a contemporary Berber village a few days later.The museum building itself is a traditional house around an open central courtyard, which keeps it cool and makes it a pleasant place to stroll around. The roof terrace, (supposed to be the highest in Marrakech), has a cafe offering tea and food. The service was glacially slow and we gave up on getting refreshments in the end, but the view out across the city was fantastic and worth the price of admission in itself (40dh).We wanted to come back to look at more of the collection, and spend more time on the roof but there were too many other things to do in Marrakech. We'd definitely go back next time.

Fantastic small museum, well worth a visit. This is an excellent little museum - it is a small building packed with old photos of Morocco and Marrakech in particular. It really is fantastic seeing these old photos of the people and places - and seeing how in some ways they have changed so little.We knew about the museum but only found it by accident as we were lost one day - its tricky to find but well worth searching out.
Interesting!. Worth a visit, if only to realise that the only thing that has changed in 150 years is the presence of mobile phones and scooters!
Underwhelming. Lots of black and white photos of people. I didn't really learn anything about Maroccan history. The video is in French.

Calm and beautifull heaven and ohh that lunch!. The Photographie is stunningly beautifull and make it seem that besides the scooters not much has changed in Marrakech. The menu off the day has made me return 3 times all ready with paying the entrance fee just once!

Morocco Through the Lens. Photography isn't really the thing you go for in Morocco, yet this place gives you a very interesting sight on Moroccan culture. Terrasse is nice, but do not expect for a great view,all you can see are roofs of surrounding buildings.Admission fee is 40 dirhams and your ticket is valid for multiple visits.Don't forget to buy the post cards at the entrance, the nicest ones you could get in Marrakech.

A wonderful view. While Maison de la Photographie may be a bit hard to find, it is definitely worth the effort. The museum is full of wonderful photos showing the history of Morrocco and the staff were charming.The crowning jewel though is the rooftop restaurant. The food is a 3 course set menu and delicious, if you get lucky ensure you have the lemon chicken tagine. At just D80, £8, it is cheap and very filling and while you are eating you get one of the best panoramic views of the city.The entrance fee is D40, £4, but this allows you to come and go as many times as you like during your stay so make sure you keep the ticket as it is well worth going again.

A Little Gem!. Tucked away in a back street, the Maison de la Photograpie is a lovely little gallery of old photos. I was particularly delighted to see some photos there by George Washington Wilson.A definite must see.

Lovely collection of B&W prints depicting Moroccan culture. This is worth a visit, although a little difficult to find but persevere as its worth it to see the many well presented images in a converted traditional riad.

best museum in Marrakech!. It's a beautiful house full of interesting pictures about the history of Morocco. The best of all: the terrace!!!
Take a cup of tea while you are enjoying the 360º of views!
The service is excellent and they also organize one-day trips to the mountains!

Not just for photography lovers. Our Riad suggested we go here as a first stop on our single full day in Marrakech. We were not disappointed. You don't need to understand or like photography to enjoy the photos. The view is one of the best in Marrakech and you can enjoy a VERY reasonably priced lunch. We had the "Maison Pizza" after too many days straight of Tagine and were not disappointed. A little hard to find, but getting there is half the fun.

A treasure of a museum... .. not only for shutter bugs. The place, the selection of pictures, the descriptions, the atmosphere in mid of the medina makes this place a must for Marrakech visitors. I´ve been travelling a lot and have seen many museums. This one is one of nicest I´ve ever been.

La Maison de la Photographie, c'est bon.. Nice building with a great terrace and view. Photo's are diverse and interesting and span a realtively long period of time. Good place to spent a bit of time and the price of entry allows you multiple entries to the terrace and it's rather decent view.

Best thing we did in Marrakech. A beautiful little building housing some wonderful photographs. I would highly recommend a visit. There is also a wonderful terrace which has amazin views across the Medina. And you can buy prints of some of the photos which will be a great memory for us.

a gem of a small museum. While this museum was not so easy to find, it was well worth the effort!The photographs were beautiful and very educational about life and the people of Morocco predominantly in the years between the late 1890's and the first 3-4 decades of the 20th century.For people also interested in the history of photography this is a place to visit!There is a very interesting and lengthy video on various regions of morocco in a room upstairs and a lovely rooftop cafe for lunch or a snack.Lovely prints of most of the photographs on display are available for sale in various sizes.I highly recommend this museum as well worth a very pleasurable and leisurely visit of 1-2 hours.

Nice little museum. The museum is a nice tribute to Morroco's past. The exhibits (pictures and videos) were interesting, although I had expected the visit to last longer and the museum to be bigger based on the descriptions in travel guides. They have a good selection of old prints at the boutique.

Morocco history via photos. This private collection is true gem! Do not miss a visit; it provides a magnificant visual account of Morocco from 1870 - 1950. The curation - installation of the works are superb. Exhibits change every 3 months. There are also videos and a fabulous roof top deck for viewing Marrakech. I look forward to the hanging/enjoying the image I brought home. Patti B.
Oasis. Amazing! Welcoming staff, beautiful photographs, and a wonderful rooftop terrace with delicious tea. An oasis in Marrakesh!
Exquisite Gem. Not to be missed! The curator is an absolute genius and has captured the history of Morocco in collection of photos that is unparalleled.

Interesing photos, not bad value. Like many of the museums in marrakech, there isn't a great deal to be said.
It is fairly small, with some interesting prints, and good views from the terrace.
Entrance fee is fairly cheap (40 dh from memory) so not bad value at all

memory in black and white. Within the walls of Marrakech lies a beautiful house converted into a photography museum, where one can trace the history of Marrakech and Morocco. The costumes in the photos are stuning, and the faces are fascinating. The terrace, where you may have a snack or just a drink, provides a nice panoramic view of the medina and the Atlas mountains.

Interesting museum. We liked the building the interesting photographs and the nice rooftop terrace. The photographs and also the fil,
M that was shown give a quite different view on Marrakesh history.

An ethnographic museum. This collection of pictures gives you a chance not only to look at the past of Morocco, but also to look through the eyes of the colonialists who ruled on Morocco for 100 years. It is a unique collection. A must see!

Brilliant location, excellent view from the terrace. Great photos on show on three floors - about half an hour and you will have seen them all. The real gem is the roof terrace. Great for lunch, very clean, great service. The house is higher than the surrounding ones so the view is really spectacular.

nice terrace for drinks and food. Lovely little gallery. nice terrace for drinks and food. Lovely little gallery in a riad type of building. it's got a nice view from the terrace and is a good sun trap although has shade too
Great place. I liked this place so much, it is another face of Morocco, you shouldnt miss the chance to visit there

Nice place to escape the noise of the souks in Marrakesh.. The staff is very friendly. Your ticket can be used on more than one occasion in During your stay in Marrakesh and costs 40 dhr. Some very interesting black and whit photographs as well as a film about old Marocco. Well worth a visit. The roof terrace is an added bonus.

Hidden away but worth seeking out. We actually found this place more easily than we had thought it has some great black and white photo's of days gone by in Marrakech and a super rooftop terrace cafe with good views...40 dh to go in at time of writing!
Very good. Really enjoyed the photography museum. It was calm with good descriptions of the photos. A good view from the terrace of the city.

Step back in time. A great little museum showing images taken in Morocco from the early days of photography. Worth a visit for photography fans - the portraits and landscapes are stunning - as well as anyone who wants to see what the medina used to look like. It also serves as a peaceful haven from the madness of the medina - stop and get your breath with a mint tea or lunch on the rooftop terrace.
Fabulous!. We loved this place...the photos have a real depth of understanding to our visit to Marrakesh and we loved relaxing with a cold drink at the roof top cafe afterwards.

Lovely service, beautiful photographs, and a great cafe. The exhibition's fascinating, and the staff are more than happy to show you around; they're good-humoured, relaxed, and aren't looking for a tip. Head upstairs afterwards for a limited menu, but a lovely meal with a view of the city.
small but nice. It is a small exhibition, but I loved the photo's that where shown here and the terrace is lovely to take in the views of Marrakech while drinking some tea
Amazing place. They have a nice shop where you can buy prints.Small rooftop cafeNice staffWonderful photosBased in a beatyful Riad
Amazing photos. Spent a couple of hours here - fantastic photographs and artwork. There is also a nice rooftop cafe with great views over the city.
A must see. Very good museum full of excellent photographs picturing the berber culture. And a little cafe on the rooftop is a must if only for a moroccan mint tea.

Great. Go there and support their private gallery and their organization. They are privately collecting old, historic (beautiful) photographs without government support. The rooftop view is worth some time as well, great views.

Find it and love it. I'll admit it was hard to find, but that's what travelling is for, wandering and discovering!My husband and I really enjoyed it here, such a quiet escape from the bustling city of Marrakech. I felt like we walked out with a better understanding of Moroccan life. The owner and the people that work at the Maison de la Photographie are great and really care about what they do.Afterwards we had a delicious lunch and mint tea on the rooftop patio. It was such a lovely way to spend an afternoon in Marrakech.Oh and we bought a beautiful print that's proudly hanging in our home :)
stunning insight into the life and times of Marrakesh. totally worth a visit - a little difficult to find but well worth it. go to the roof bar and look out over the roofs of Marakess. amazing!

very nice place but be careful on your way. this place is amazing for people who loves photography.we got kind of lost walking towards there and locals tried to help us?? but lead us to wrong way on purpose.it was kind of dangerous.just becareful and make sure you know which ways to go because when we went there, there was not much people around to go to this place.

Worth the effort. Great little museum with a delightful cafe on the roof. Yes it's a bit tricky to find and ignore all the touts telling you it's closed to 3pm - it's not! They just want to take you to the nearby tannery. Once located its a great place to step back in time and spend an hour or so admiring the collection

Very difficult to find. A very interesting museum which shows how little has changed in the interim years between the wars and how much of the medina has been allowed to decay. Very welcoming staff but it was difficult to find with no signs to show the way.
Lovely old photographs. Gives insight as to how people dress in the earlier days. Lovely black & white photographs, some almost 3D in appearance.

Phantastic. It is a hidden treasure! If u appreciate photografie and are interestet in Morocco this is the place to go! Not to crowded very welcoming staff who are not shy to explain about the place... Nice terasse on the top of the building where u can eat- quite expensive though.

Insight into [mainly] 20th century photography on Morocco. Small museum with an interesting photography (and film) collection on Morocco from late19th century until the 50's, giving one an insight into culture, traditions, urban planning, etc., throughout times. We had a brief introduction to the collection by one of its amicable owners, which was very useful. Especially interesting for photography buffs. The rooftop café has a good (nearly birdseye) view of Marrakesh.

Eyes of the past look down on you..... A little bit hard to find, for the alleys in the shouks keep twisting and turning the opposite direction of ones' desire, but at the end the stunning Maison is found and reveals its secrets.The house itself is another beautiful example of a hidden treasure, another surprise that one doesn't expect when passing by, tastefully restored by the enthousiastic owner.The foto's exposed are of incredible beauty, historically seen of great value, very tastefully framed: one wishes to have large empty walls at home to fill with some of these fine examples of early photography.....Really fell in love with 2 foto's in peticular, maybe one day the very sweet owner who greeted us upon arrival and gave us a small private tour, decides to open a webshop, so we can obtain those foto's after all ..... or we will return to just admire them as- and where they are now.One advice: take your time, don't rush, and do take a break at the lovely rooftop terrace with its stunning view over this highly interesting city: you won't regret!

Lovely place. Had trouble to find it as it is in the middle of the medina. Very nice exhibition of some early black and white photography. Terasse upstairs invites to stay a little longer. The stuff is very friendly and helpful.

Not bad but not great. It had some interesting photographs, but mainly from a certain period 50 or so years ago. There was nothing modern and the prints were very expensive to purchase. I guess with the internet these days good photographs are easy to access. The history was interesting and you were able to compare parts of Morocco with how they look today

Loved it!. I absolutly loved this museum...It's in an old riad and shows different pictures from the 20s-40s of Morocco...Really gives you a peek in older Moroccan times. The place itself is beautiful and has a really nice terrace with a great view of Marrakech. You can even see the mountains in the background while enjoying a mint tea. The guy working at the museum was really nice and gave us an introduction. It's like a little oasis in an otherwise crazy city.

The best attraction of Morocco!. Like every other hotel/restaurant/attraction in Marrakech, the Maison de la Photographie is so unassuming. Yet, once you enter its the most beautiful little museum ever! The riad stunningly presents the most beautiful first photographs of Morocco, captured by a French man, who traveled from the Loire Valley to North Africa on his bicycle. All the photos have captions in Arabic, French and English, so you can understand the context. The first colour footage of Morocco is absolutely fascinating, even though I couldn't understand the French commentator! Also, I definitely recommend the gorgeous hibiscus tea on the terrace afterwards! The terrace has one of the most stunning views of the whole of the medina.
Well worth a visit. This is a great gallery...The staff are very sweet and helpful...food was excellent on the terrace with awesome views. It has a sophisticated atmosphere. GO!
Surprisingly good. Some great old photos in a beautiful setting. Worth a quick view and great to add in after seeing Ali Ben Youssef Madrasa.

Interesting photos and great rooftop cafe. The price to get in to this exhibition (which can be hard to find so study a map and don't listen to the locals telling you it's the other way!) is about 50 dms (about £3.78) and you can use that ticket to get in again as many times as you like). Really nice way to look at the history and the rooftop cafe is to be recommended- it is crazy cheap and they do lovely food, although there isn't a huge selection. Be careful about going there at really hot points of the day as not all of the tables are in shade so if it is busy you might be out in the boiling hot sun trying to eat!
a real discovery of Marocco history. fantastic overview of maroccain tradition though a lot of fotos of the old french colony descovering the cultural past of this wonderfull country.

"Very good place". The museum is right behind the Medersa Ben Youssef. A wonderful collection of prints through the ages of Moroccan photography history. One of the highest terraces in the medina with views in all the directions, the view may well be worth the money alone.
Nice place. Great place, make sure to give it a visit while in Marrakech :) good restaurant on the roof as well.
Good place for visiting. 3 floors of photos. I have a pleasure to watch how marrocan people live 50-100 years ago. A surprise waits for you in last room of exhibition.
Hidden gem in Marrakech. The place is small but worth checking out - it's also nice to take a break for a drink or some food on the roof - the view is wonderful!

Charming and fascinating place to visit.. This is a small photographic museum over three floors which shows the work of a range of photographers in Morocco over the last 150 years. The pictures are fascinating, the atmosphere is serene atmosphere and there is a lovely rooftop cafe.

Got lost in the beautiful photography. Excellent little place with a fantastic range of images showcasing many different eras in Morocco. The is also a lovely cafe at the top where you can get a nice range of food and drinks all day.

A brief look back in time. The staff were helpful and provided information sheets in both English and French. The images were insightful and offered a glimps at moroccan history. The roof cafe was a nice place to chill and had a good view across the city

Great pics, real social history. Loved the quality of the images and how they reflect the social history of the country.
The catering is a little basic, but you don't come here for the food!
Beware locals trying to divert you to the tanneries by telling you the museum is closed.
Loved it. This was a well curated collection. The photographs were haunting and were housed in a beautiful building. The staff was very friendly and answered any questions we had.

Lovely oasis. A petite collection of photographs of Morroco by a variety of photographers. The location is a little tricky to get to and you will have to politely refuse many offers of guides as you make your way through the souks, but it is well worth a visit. The visual space has been utilised really well with my favourite being the ground floor as the large prints adorn the walls in the small courtyard. Outstanding value as your ticket allows you to go back as many times as you wish whilst in Marrakech. An oasis of calm that takes you on an historical journey of Marrakech. The food from the terrace was simply delicious. Maison de la Photographie was definitely the highlight of my visit to Marrakech.

Small but lovely. Not a large museum but the photographs inside make the entrance fee well worth it. There is also a cafe on the terrace to have a coffee or tea and enjoy a view of the medina. When I was there in July, it was much too hot to sit on the terrace in the middle of the day but I imagine it's a wonderful spot come September.
Beautiful retro feel. Old photos Exotic views: great location in the Medina wonderful roof for drinks A true little gem that no one should miss

Good place to visit... This is really nice place to visit all pictures black and white from Marakesh and Marocco and takes you back in time. And people will spend time with you. I will recommend this place to be.

Maison de la Photographie 1870-1950, Marrakesh. Definitely go: an intriguing collection of historic photography of Morocco housed on several floors of a beautifully renovated riad with a small roof terrace restaurant. It’s open long hours and worth the visit. Opened in 2009, this gallery, showing the owner’s collection of historic photography of Morocco, 1870-1950, is a rich addition to sites in Marrakesh of art, architecture and cultural history. The collector/owner, who lived previously in the Himalayas, shows and sells prints from his collection of travel, documentary photography by travellers, anthropologists and others, primarily outsiders looking in on an exotic culture through an Orientalist lens. Yet these images give us a tangible sense of lives and actions, personalities, landscapes – wind, weather, dust and skin. It’s a Morocco distant and gone, but it’s also the Morocco that continues in the arid landscapes of the mountains of the moon, the pastoral stretches where Shilha boys still graze their sheep as their grandfathers did.
Pretty cool. Nice pictures very educational, lot of history and information about Morocco. People were very knowledgeable and nice . We go a great lunch with a 360 o view of the medina.

Well worth a visit. We enjoyed looking at the carefully chosen photographs here and really found a lot of emotion in some of them. Would highly recommend a visit. In a delightful neighbourhood even though a bit tricky to find-it is well signed.
kept going back!. Inspiring museun, great photos, even stayed to watch part of a film from 1957, and great little cafe with best views in the Medina

A gem. If you only do three things in Marrakech, make sure this is one of them (the other two being the madrassa Ben-Youssef and the Jemma-el-Fna).La Maison hosts impressive vintage photography of Marrakech and the Atlas Mountains which should please photography enthusiasts and non-enthusiasts alike - the photographs are very much people-centered, and most are truly excellent, impressive, even breathtaking.As if that was not enough, it has a fantastic rooftop cafe with truly excellent views to the Atlas mountains, which also serves delicious food.My only minor complaint is that the - fascinating - colour film made by a french anthropologist of the Atlas mountains and its tribes does not have english or any other subtitles. Make sure you go - the museum receives no public subsidy, so it depends entirely on paying visitors.

:-). Very nice to give you a vibe of Moroccan life.. Great pictures!You can also buy both pictures for decorating and postcards- very beautiful :-)I bought a copy of an old map of morocco and I love it :-)

Great insight into life as a Moroccan. The exhibits are always changing but consistently show the changing face of Morocco over the last 150 years. Great value for money (the ticket gets you unlimited access for the length of your stay). Be sure to have a drink or lunch on the terrace roof - great view and great food!

Evocative photographs and a very good panorama from the terrace. The collection is broad enough in subject matter but doesn't take too long to work your way around. The main focus is early 20th century photos showing life in the Medinas of Morocco, allowing you to compare Marrakech to the other cities. The terrace offers reasonable but unexciting food. The main draw must be the view from the top, which offered the most open panorama I found in the city.

linger on the top floor. One of the few things that I regularly enjoy in Marrakech. It's often not very crowded and very relaxing on the roof, where drinks are served. They've done a great job- a shame they don;t produce any books and don't rotate the exhibitions enough...

Beautiful. This is certainly worth the visit. The museum is interesting and very informative. The small fee for a ticket allowed you re-entry which was worth while as the food in the terrace was lovely.
A little sanctuary in the city. We went to look at the museum and though the building was lovely, the photographs did not really do it for me and overall I was not too enraptured by the place
Cool. Great photography in a really cool space with fantastic views form the roof terrace. The ticket allows for repeat visits.

Some great photos in a stunning building. We came here for lunch as well as to see the photos. It turned out we were a bit early for food but we waited with cool drinks on the lovely roof terrace and enjoyed the amazing views. The food was tasty and reasonably priced. Afterwards we walked around the museum - our favourite photos were of the souks in the 1930s because of the stunning diffused light. Possibly the best thing of all was the building, which we ended up photographing from every angle. We were glad we came.
Gem in heart of Medina. Fabulous collection of photos of old Marrakech and Morocco. A must see and dont miss lunch on the terrace - delicous and great value and amazing views.

Nice roof terrace. Liked the roof terrace. Photos nice but perhaps not worth 50 dirhams a heads to look at! Having said that the 10 Dirham mint tea was lovely and the shots from the terrace are the best we got all trip.

Worth the rating. We went there based on the good reviews we read on trip advisor. They were right on. The wealth of historical pictures of marrakech that were on display, were reason enough to go there. There were also amazing portraits and shots of other parts of Morocco. When walking around Marrakech you get the sense that while some things have changed due to the inevitable invasion of the modern world, there's a spirit to this place that hasn't changed in a millennia. The form of the old city is still there. It's just the technology that moves around in it that has changed. You walk around feeling that the long past of their ancient civilization is actually not that far back in time. Seeing these pictures from the early nineteen hundreds and later, show you that it wasn't that long ago and they are a wonder to look at. If we weren't traveling with two kids in tow at the time I could have easily spent a day looking.

Jnane Tamsna s remarkable old photos collection made us eager to discover this. It is a wonderful place, very informativ. Gives an excellent idea of Morocco a century agoAn affordabl choise of old photos to buyA charming roof terrace for a snack A great spot
Good for photographers ofcourse. Small place but well presented.. intersting photo histories, a good video of historic Morocco footage, all in French though, as it was by a French traveller. No subs.

Black and white!!. Beautifully laid out.....photos from across mainly the 19th and 20th centuries....not all of Morocco, Tunisa gets a look in...definitely worth a visit... If you go to the top up the spiral staircase you will also get great views of the city...

Lovely week at marrakech. This is a good place to visit, to see how was Morocco in the old days. It does not focus only in Marrakech so the experience is good.Also when you buy the ticket you can return how many times you want to revisit. :)

Rooftop respite. The owner is very kind. I stopped in twoyears ago and bought a few postcards and he let me wander up to the rooftop terrace for free. This time I stopped by with my 18-year-old son and offered to pay two admissions and he only charged us for one (40 direm). The old photographs are interesting to look at and the rooftop terrace is a wonderfully peaceful place to have a drink (Nonalcoholic of course)

Cool photos but I expected more. I'm not sure how this place is so top rated. Yes, it's neat to see photos from Morocco's past, but the museum is actually fairly small and my wife and I didn't think it was worth it..

Beautiful Collection. Beautiful collection of Moroccan history, the owner kindly gave us a short introduction when we arrived which was nice. The cafe on the terrace also had nice views and was a quite spot to have a drink before immersing ourselves back into the bustling streets of the medina.

don't listen if someone tells you it's closed. Touts in the medina may tell you that the madrassa and the Maison de la Photographie are closed, trying to get you to come with them to the tanneries instead. Don't listen to them--keep searching for the Maison, which is not far from the madrassa and is well worth the walk. Beautiful photos, a very worthwhile mission, and friendly and helpful staff.
Worth an hour or so. A walk around the Maison de la Photographie is well worth the time. You can get a glimpse of the past of Marrakesh.

andor says: "not to be missed...experience the past from the photographers eyes. Enjoy many beautiful black and white pictures, video in a gorgeous setting. Enjoy the terraza restaurant on top. Your ticket will allow to return if you want to. Great place
Worth hunting out. Liked everything about this place from the evocative old photographs to the roof terrace where you can take in the views- with a breeze!
Beautiful Gardens. What a lovely place to come and relax in a busy city. Not too expensive and a beautiful garden (mostly shaded) to sit in for as long as you like.

Fascinating insights. A wonderful collection of photographs that are satisfying both as a visual experience and as a historical record. So good to see These images in context, rather than in a museum in Europe. The museum gives an introduction to the collection as you arrive, which is very helpful. Lunch in the rooftop terrace is a real treat.The museum also has an association with the Berber Ecomuseum museum in the Ourika valley. A fantastic day out.

Worth the search!. It is well worth seeking out this photographic exhibition - it gives an insight into the history and culture of Morocco in an interesting way. Buying some of the black and white souvenir photos is a nice momento. They do run a film but it has no English subtitles so that is an improvement that would be helpful!

Wow! Must see in Marrakech!. This amazing museum shows the history of Morocco (since 19th Century) through original pictures. The owner/founder has a passion for photography which he is more than happy to share with you. The building is typically Maroccan touch. And the view is amazing!!!

fascinating photos in great atmosphere, great staff. We spent a very pleasant hour or so here. We really appreciated the historical explanations of the photos and found this to be an interesting way into the history of European colonialism and orientalism more generally. A kind of antidote to the neo-colonialist tourist experience that is Marrakech much of the time.
Beautiful space. Very enjoyable, non touristy glimpse of Moroccan history and culture. Quiet, peaceful and cool way to spend an hour or so. Adorable little cafe on the rooftop.

Interesting little gem. Well worth a visit to see the view from the roof terrace cafe. However it's not just about the roof terrace. To see Marrakech through the eyes of some amazing photographers is truly a treat and you get to see the souks in a totally different light. Highly recommended.

If you love photography.... A nice collection of old Morocco...photos. Its great to get a glimpse of the past. In the end go up to the terrace where you can enjoy a nice cup of tea with a lovely view in front of you.

Outstanding collection of photographs. An amazing place with beautiful photographs. You really get a sense of the importance of this city and what it was like 100 years ago. Keep your admission ticket...as long as you have proof of admission you can re-visit the museum again, anytime you like. There is a rooftop terrace where you can buy sodas, coffee, tea, and snacks. The view from up there is spectacular! Be aware: in an attempt to mislead you, you will be confronted in the streets by young people who will tell you the museum is closed. Smile, shake your head, and continue on. They are paid by the leather tanners to direct you to their shops, in the hopes that you'll purchase goods from them.

Interesting Moroccan History. Why this place is not on the tourist maps who knows. Found it eventually with the help of a young local for 20 dirham. Small amount of photos over 3 floors but very interesting. Great little cafe on the terrace serving a limited set menu but great tea. Enjoyable and peaceful.
Somewhere cooling to go. Didn't find this particularly exciting but enabled us to get out of the heat. Didn't think it was worth the hike though

a magical , informative place thanks to Patrick the founder and owner, do have lunch on the terrace with fabulous views. a delight to discover,, wonderful photographs quite unique,, haunting and unforgettable do visit well worth the journey..
great Balcony views and amazing pictures. Balcony views of city-best we seen Possibly could have more English explainations of pictures,but thats being picky.

a sense of history and a great meal. We had read about this museum on Trip Advisor before going to Marrakech and weren't disappointed. Fascinating photos of Marrakech and other places in Morocco. It is always interesting to be reminded that what we are seeing didn't always look like it does now. The meal on the terrace was one of the best we had in Marrakech. Looking out at the High Atlas and hearing the call to prayer from the many mosques made for a magical moment.
What a wonderful way to see history. The pictures and images were of amazing quality. Both floors we were just amazed by the quality and beautiful pictures. Great time

Interesting but not worth going out of your way for.. Interesting opportunity to see some pictures and marvel at how Morocco has changed over the years however this wasn't particularly well presented and there was no particular attempt to engage the visitors.
Food on the terrace was good and the views were fantastic!
Truly amazing photographs.. The wonderful photos and ambience of the Maison visually informs of the history of Morocco. I can find no fault or anything I disliked about the Maison de la Photographie.

A bit hard to find, but well worth it. After trying to be redirected to the tanneries or 'big square' we found some signs and followed them to the Maison de la Photographie. Beautiful gem of a museum. Fantastic photos of turn of the century morocco. All photos available for purchase - they didn't have what I wanted in the right size so had it printed up and brought to our riad. Would highly recommend.
Don't miss it!. Beautiful photos and a great place to have a quick bite to eat and enjoy the 360 view of Marrakech. You can keep your entrance card to comeback whenever you want!

A trip back in Time. Having been way laid in true Marrakech style by a ' friendly' local taking us on a detour to the Tannery, we arrived into the calm of the Maison de la Photographie.What a delight an oasis, a wonderful collection of historic photographs of anthropologically important record of life in Morocco.

amazing view. The top roof of this museum is a must to attend! You will not have a view like that over the city, and it is very relaxing to chill there with a cup of tea after all the madness in the town :)

Lovely Little Museum. What a gorgeous photography musuem in the Medina. I highly recommend it to anyone traveling to Marrakech. Be sure to visit the terrace for some beautiful views. I only wish the museum was larger, because the photographs were fascinating!
Lovely Gallery. Totally worth the visit, loved the prints and post-cards as an memorable souvenir! Nice break from the hectic souks and markets and nice cafe on the terrace that overlooks the city!

A real must. We visit this museum every time we are in Marrakech. The exhibits change and are always fascinating. The old photos are so evocative that we never tire of seeing them and there are great reproductions that you can buy.
Little gem nestled in the Medina. Great visit and break from the pandemonium of the souk. Lovely roof top cafe for lunch and tea. Photos were fascinating.

Lovely photographs and terrace. When we went we were told that our tickets were valid for as many return visits as we liked during our holiday, which was a nice touch. Make sure to have a cup of mint tea on the rooftop terrace.

Great look into history. An excellent collection of photos and history of Morrocco. This Riad not only the highest terrace in Marrakesh (which serves light refreshments overlooking the atlas mountains!) BUT also gives a varied and unique view of Morrocan history through photography. A very low admission fee gives you access to a good couple of hours of bliss (away from the busy Marrakesh streets) and the staff are very knowledgeable & approachable (especially Siad who introduces the collection passionately to each and every visitor!). There are a number of prints for purchase which would make an excellent memento of your time in this beautiful city.

Interesting collection, several side perks. Great collection to get some historical context on Morocco. There are several portraits in particular which I loved. You don't have to be a photography hound to appreciate it. Beyond usual Arabic and French, English is present everywhere. I even saw at least one laminated info card in Spanish.Several side perks also make this museum worthwhile:- Ticket is good for multiple entries. It's already a deal at 40 dirhams, so, yeah.- Free Wi-Fi! Password is listed upstairs on the terrace. Speaking of which...- The terrace. Nice cafe, lovely view I'm assuming you can't get anywhere else without access to a minaret.- The building itself is quite appealing inside.- It's very close to the Ben Youssef Madrasa and Musee de Marrakech, so easy to combine.

Nice museum with beatiful terrace. To be honest I was so tired after walking through souks in the medina and some shopping that I couldn't really concentrate on the excibition. So no opinion about the photos. But place looks really nice. Tickets are 4 Euros. Some movie about Morocco on the third floor. The best thing is the beatiful terrace and the tasty food:) For 8 Euros you can have full lunch, which is not extremely cheap but ok for Marrakesh. Great view over the city and very relaxing atmosphere. Definately worth going there.

Surprisingly great!!. Interesting photos - very well done. My son and I loved the film even though it was in French and I could not understand it - we could follow that the gentleman was traveling through Morocco. LOVED the upstairs terrace with view over the medina. The staff was very very nice. We booked the tour through them to the Berber Museum the next day. That was a lovely adventure and a great value.

do not understand the fuss. maybe I just dont get it - maybe I'm not cultured enough, but being the no.1 rated attraction in marrakech on tripadvisor, we felt it was a must-do. we were quite underwhelmed to be honest. it was a pretty riad, no prettier than others we'd seen including the one we stayed at - Riad Djebel. It takes all of 20 minutes in total to look round. Theres no real organisation or themes to the photos. The guy on the front desk was sweet and cheerfully told us we could come back again with the same ticket.for me it all felt a bit 'emperors new clothes'. there really are other more enjoyable things to do in wonderful marrakech.
Terrific Creative Space in the Medina. Really worth taking the time to take in the atmosphere of this place - an incredible look at the Morocco of old
