Did not enter, price is absolutely to much. We did not enter this attraction, the price for a ticket is as much as the main atractions in paris and barcelona. Almost all the atractions in Marrakech are expensive.

Not large, but worth a visit.. A small photography collection of Moroccan works. Definitely take the time to enjoy the terrace! The video they show is very interesting and the reprints are worth a purchase if your personal photography isn't the best :)

Great photographs, delicious lunch. Not only were the photographs an in-depth look at the people and culture of Morocco (Tangier especially) and its diversity, but the lunch was both delicious and cheap (~50 dirhams/entree) and came with courteous service. I highly recommend the karkade (hibiscus) drink and the tagine chicken and would go back again for any lunch. The views of the roofs and minarets of the medina from the roof terrace cafe are definitely a big bonus.
If you are at all interested in photography.... Not only a stunning gallery, but the shots taken from the roof were amongst my best tourist shots of the whole trip...
Personal approach. Patrick welcomes every visitor here with a personal introduction and a welcoming smile. Good collection!

Take time out to visit the Maison de la Photographie!. This small museum, tucked away near the Ben Youssef Medersa, is really worth visiting. Its only been open a few years, and the photographs displayed are regularly changed, but they give a fascinating glimpse into Morroccon life in the 1920s and 1940s. Some photographs date back to the 1880s. They are beautifully displayed in a cool, light riad which is an oasis of calm and tranquility - also a lovely roofterrace cafe which serves great coffees and mint tea and has fantastic views over the medina. An unexpected gem.

Lovely small museum with an excellent roof top. The museum shows lovely black and white photographies of Marrakesh and Morocco around the beginning of the 20th century, gving a good impression of the live back then. The lovely renovated riad displays the photos on 3 stories (takes about 20-40 minutes), but the best part is the roof top terrace with excellent views over the city, where some beverages and snacks can be consumed in the cafe. The tickets is for multiple entries, so coming back for a tea of enjoying the sunset is a plus!

Fascinating and worthwhile. This is a wonderful collection with a great story, and if the man who runs it is there when you visit you're in for a fascinating conversation. Defintely worth seeking out!

Wonderful destination. A welcome break from the souks and the busy city of Marrakech. It is located in a nice mansion and filled with beautiful old photgraphs. The museum is not that large but has a nice cafe terrace with great views of Marrakech. The staff is very friendly and speak multiple languages and will give you a quick little tour of the museum.

Sensational display of old photos which are available for purchase.. The range of photos was great and French owner was able to explain reproduction process. Reproductions were very reasonably priced and packaging for homeward travel very good

Beautiful old Funduk restored to a nice museum with a view. Great persons working there, my small group got a very personal introduction to the place... Lovely restoration and beautiful pictures and fantastic that a one-time go means you can come back during your stay!

Charming place :). Nice museum and it has beautiful photos. If you like photography then don't miss this place. After visiting museum go to the terrace and enjoy the view while drinking mint tea and eating moroccan pastries. It is just perfect :)

Interesting. As a photographer who works with film/paper in black and white I was most appreciative of the exhibit of vintage photographs. Some of them are visually beautiful and artistically very interesting. It was also very interesting to see the people and Marrakech of long ago. In some ways so different and in others not so different from today. I hope the museum finds other vintage photography to add to this already wonderful collection.

A real inspiration!. We somehow managed to find this place by ourself (not easy in a town where there are no street names or numbers!) and once we got there we were really pleased. The building itself is really pretty and it hosts, scattered on several floors, a variety of vintage black and white pictures, some absolutely amazing. They sell original reproduction of all the pictures in different formats so you can take a memory home! After the visit make sure you have lunch or a snack on the terrace while you enjoy the view: we had one of the best chicken tajine of the all vacation for a ridiculous price (I think we spent less then 20 € euros for two people). The ticket is valid for more than one day so you can come back if you wish!

Great little museum with a view. I am a photographer, so this museum was always on our list, but the experience was made 100 times better by discovering they have a roof terrace cafe, with panoramic views across the city and fabulous food! An absolute MUST visit!
Interesting. Amazing to see all the historic photos, would like to have seen pictures on display, lovely terrace cafe ,
photo. good to see, nice building, very historic photos, nice coffeeshop at the roof with phantastic view on medina

Relaxing break after the chaos of the Souks. This is a very pleasant little museum. Nothing particularly sensational to see, but some interesting photos illustrating the history of Morocco over the last 150 years. Quiet and peaceful after the turmoil of the souks and a lovely rooftop café with good views of the city.

Exhibition so-so, food decent. The photo exhibition is ok, small and not outstanding (but the thought counts, and there are not many other interesting art-initiatives to support). Restaurant on roof was good (although serious problems with delivery of two pastillas) and not least -reasonably priced .
Magic house. It is a must see ! You will learn about the history of Moroccan photography in a lovely setting. The only thing I thought it was a shame, that one could not buy some books.
Nice!. Nice place to spend a few hours if you love Photography, are enchanted by Morocco and fancy some down town in Marrakech. Shame the cafe had run out of veggie food by the time we arrived.

Fine photography added view of the city. Old photos of what has changed and what has stayed the same. A great window on the history of the place, and a fine counterpoint to step into away from the thrum of the souks.
Go and See. This is a good exhibition with plenty to see and a great spot for lunch upstairs. It is also conveniently located next to an interesting part of the souk.
Basketmakers visit.. Charming owner and such an interesting visit. We bought three photographs and are delighted with them.

Classy little gallery with a great tea place. Its well worth visiting this museum early on in your stay to get a true picture of the old Morocco. Like most marrakech houses, the museum is built around a cool central courtyard. there is also a great little luchspot at the top of the museum where you can view the city laid out around you. Don't miss the little room displaying some highly unusual colour films of the people of the High Atlas mountains - made in the 1950s. Its well worth scheduling extra time for these - an extra hour. many people miss these but they were the highlight of my visit. On my trip I also visited the museum's outpost about an hour;s easy drive out of town - also worth checking out.
Simple museum in Marrakech. Has a great roof terrace, lovely photographs of Marrakech in antiquity. Nice little place to while away an hour or two.

Day trip to Ourika valley organized by Museum. Use a chance to visit Ourika valley organised by Photography Museum - very meaningful insight into Berber life, also good for solo, small group travelers (no minimum number of participants). Thank You Maison de la Photographie for giving us a chance to learn and discover!
Lovely museum. An oasis in the middle of the hectic Medina. Lovely house, wonderful photographs and spectacular views from the terrace. Well worth spending a couple of hours here.

Amazing photos of historic Morocco. Well presented little house exhibition, amazing to see what photographers could accomplish all those years ago without the gadgets of today. Nice little roof terrace cafe with amazing views of the entire city. Prints and postcards on sale.

Something a little different. The entry fee you pay to this museum allows you to return during your stay, which is exactly what I did. On the first visit I enjoyed a drink on the terrace, on the second it was lunch. There is a small blackboard menu and on the day I ate, I had a chicken tagine and it was delicious.The images are beautifully presented and the videos are well worth watching, so make sure you have time, or take advantage of return visit.This is a photography museum and it has done an excellent job of presenting old images, but, I think new works are just as important as history is in the making. It would have been nice to see some new artistic photographic images of the Moroccan peoples in addition to the old ones.

Definitely worth a visit. The photos range from 1920's yet actually nothing much has changed apart from the cars and scooters in the streets. Its also good as you pay 40DH but can use the ticket again and again.
Definitely Worth a Visit!. Compact museum with wonderful photographs dating back to the 1800s. Great Moroccan prints available to buy and take away.

Charming museum. Small museum that doesn't overpower you. Photos from 1880s to mostly 1920s of Moroccan native groups like the Berbers and city scenes such as the Souks. You can come back any time with your ticket. The cafe, although basic, has got to be the best value in the whole city, catering for tourists, in terms of quality and price. Wifi, too!

Superb building of archived picture history. Perfect for a short cultural glimpse of Morocco, notably the images shot in Tangier.
Glass plates, auto tones and silver images are gradually working their way back to this archive.
Nice and welcoming staff - informed. The roof terrace a must. One of the higher terraces in Marrakech.

Excellent for lunch. Definitely worth a visit. A welcome, calming interlude to the bustle of Marrakech. Spend some time perusing the photos in a pleasant environment. Some of the photos are fabulous, my favourites being the large portraits.Then head for the roof terrace for an excellent lunch. The chicken and lemon tagine was superb with an enormous piece of chicken. If you are not that hungry - share!
well done. Private museum with an exhibition on 3 levels. A bit small but some of the pictures are absolutely beautiful. Thanks
Defo worth a visit. Great place, great restaurant, beautiful views in the middle of the medina. We really enjoyed our visit.

Not the number 1 attraction for us. Nice architecture, few photographs, although what they display are interesting, but expensive entrance fee. However, if you want a stunning view from the rooftop cafe this is the place.
Quiet and interesting. Many interesting photos. Worth the money. Visit the café on the roof, and use the ticket to visit it again!

Well organised and interesting. This small gallery is just around the corner from the museum and is well worth a visit - the building has been sympathetically restored and the photographs are wonderful.There is a small cafe on the roof terrace with excellent views over the city. The food we had was the best we've eaten in Morocco (so far), the service friendly and efficient and the bill realistic. Sadly it's not open for dinner.
Great couple of hours!. This is so worth it - fascinating photographs and a quiet roof terrace perfect for a coke and taking the weight off - don't miss it
Seeing Life As It Was. If you have seen and enjoyed the Musee Albert Kahn in Paris, you will love this photographic collection. A step back in time.

Worth the visit. Quite difficult to find as,although we had a street map, the streets dont often have names on them! However, as we made the mistake of standing in the street looking at a map and scratching our heads we attracted the attention of a local who "happened to be going that way". We followed him for 20 minutes and ended up at the tanneries. We made our feelings clear and he took us to the museum - another 10 minutes. Naturally he wanted paying so we gave him 20 dirahms (about £1.60 with the advice that had he taken us straight to the museum he would have got 100.Anyway, we got there and it is a cool sanctuary of Berber culture history in pictures. Most of the work is from the 1920's and 30's with some interesting earlier work from the late 1800's. The top floor cafe is very good and served us the best tagine we had in Marrakech. With water, mint tea, bread and cous cous the cost was around £8. The views are expansive but quite dull as buildings in Marrakech are pretty much the same height, but there is a good view of El Koutoubia Mosque Entry fee to the museum was 40 dirhams (just over £3). It would be good to see some more modern works say from the 1950's to 70's when there were a lot of photo journalists working in North Africa but overall the difficulty of finding the place was worth it.As a matter of interest when we came out we walked about 50 yards and saw an area we had already passed many times before bumping in to the helpful local.

Cultural Gem. After traveling though many parts of Morocco it was wonderful to see the beautiful photos of the Morrocan people at this museum. I was amazed at the quality of photos that were taken over the last century. Though this museum is a bit difficult to find, I would highly recommend it.

A interesting museum with a great café on the roof.. To get lunch on the roof is a real treat and a great experience. The food is very good and very reasonably priced. Staff are extremely friendly. The only problem you will have is deciding what to have as it all looks so good. Light lunch for 2 came to only £8.
A must-see. Amazing photos and fabulous lunch on the roof terrace. Near to the Medersa Ben Youssef so easy to combine the two.

Excellent trip to the Photography museum. We really enjoyed our trip here. The building was lovely and the photographs were well displayed, with interesting commentary. The rooftop terrace cafe provides unparalleled views over Marrakech and the mountains.
A really interesting visit, with a big plus that you can return for free if you retain your ticket.
Highly recommended.
Intersting. Gives an insight into the history and culture of Morooco, entrance fee a bit too much for what you get to see, but a worthwhile visit.
well worth a visit. Lovely little museum. The photos of Berber life were especially evocative. The terrace cafe has excellent food and one of the best views of Marrakech to be had.

An oasis of culture. This beautiful and interesting little museum is one of the highlights of Marrakech - don't miss it, it's worth every dirham! The ticket seller is an extremely friendly chap and a mine of information on everything in Marrakech. Very nice that you can come back as many times as you want with same ticket!

A glimpse into history. A beautiful old house is home to this super collection of historic photographs of Morocco.From a photographic perspective the images and their stories are fascinating. The real interest for most folk I think is that they show a little glimpse of old Morocco and how people lived, dressed,worked and played. There is also an excellent colour movie film which shows the history of tribal farmers. At the top of the building you can eat and get a drink as well as take in the view across Marrakech. The loo is very clean.Definately worth a visit.

Great little escape from the busy medina. Although the museum is quite small, there are some beautiful pictures on display that are really interesting. We loved to see the pictures that showed Marrakech in the 1920s a lot of streets havent changed a bit!The building itself is beautiful and quiet, its a perfect escape from the busy city! We also bought 2 prints of pictures so if you're looking for some interesting souvenirs take a look here.The only thing i would fault is the roof terrace; although it looks lovely the service was appalling - after a 30 mins wait without even being seen by a waiter, let alone having a drink order taken, we (amongst with a lot of other people) left.All in all go there to see the beautiful pictures, and visit the lovely Cafe Arabe nearby for lunch or drinks afterwards.
Lunch on terrace. Lovely way to lose a few hours, browsing at some historical and more recent photographs as well as a simple lunch on their roof terrace. Nice menu and very relaxed.

Through the looking glass. Tucked into one of the smaller alleyways behind the souks, this small museum in a converted riyad has a collection of 19th and early 20th century black and white photographs that show life as it was. I found the pictures of Jewish and Berber women in traditional garb to be of particular interest, as these populations have largely disappeared.The rooftop terrace cafe has a decent panoramic view of the city.
Well worth a visit. Fascinating. Apart from the sheer beauty of the images, the photographs gave us a great history of the region.
Go to the terrace cafe. The terrace café on the roof top is well worth a visit- inexpensive tagine /cous cous and mint tea. with a fabulous view of the city.
A historic overview of moroccan photography. Very well distributed and categorized. Great portraits of Morocco's past. Very nice art exhibit if you seriously enjoy photography.
Tricky to find but worth finding. Great place to see historical images of Marrakesh. Roof top garden a relaxing space. This is not a free venue, 40 DM's
Have lunch here. Great view and the best tagine I had on my trip!Very international feel on the roof terrace and a very good exhibition too.

Fascinating pictorial insight onto past times. A must see unique photographic history of Morrocco and Marrakesh. The pictures are changed on a regular basis from a vast collection.Not that big number of pictures, but you can spend many minutes studying the pictures and marvelling at the detail and in many ways how little has changed.Nice roof terrace serving a simple lunch.

Wonderful photographs. A quiet haven in bustling Marrakech filled with sensationally good old photographs, beautifully displayed in rooms around the courtyard. I learned a lot both about Morocco during the middle decades of the twentieth century and also about the photography processes and effects of that period. Some of the photographs have haunted me ever since, both beautiful light effects and extraordinarily characterful faces.The cafe on the rooftop is a bonus. Delicious simple local food is served at lunchtime for an amazingly modest charge. No alcohol.

Free entry & good to see. No charge for entering and it was quite nice ambling around and looking at the photos which gave a snapshot of Moroccan life through the years. You can have some food / tea here as well. You can buy photos from the store on your way out.

Worth the vist. Anyone interested in photography should head to the Maison. Some great shots from late 1800s and early 1900s. Has a good roof terrace, great views, especially at sunset, and the food is good at reasonable prices. An oasis of calm just North of the Souks.Staff are really friendly. I wanted a particular print, they didn't have it in, but arranged to get it printed to pick up the next day.

Unique exhibition, lovely rooftop restaurant. We visited the Maison de la Photographie quite shortly after it had opened when it was still a bit of a hidden gem. It was very worthwhile for us as photography enthusiasts, but it also showed quite a unique angle on Moroccan life. Really interesting! Being a Riad it is also not overwhelming and the exhibits are nicely spaced throughout the building so visitors aren't on top of each other. The staff is really friendly and welcoming too, and there is a lovely restaurant on the rooftop terrace which I recommend for its views and its dish-of-the-day style menu of simple but delicious local cuisine.
Wonderful way to pass a morning!. Amazing photos of how the country used to be in the 1920 - 40s. Tranquil space inside with roof café!
interesting visit. Worth visiting this place on the way the "Tanneurs" area. Interesting explanation from the guide. You can enjoy a nice view from the roofterrasse.
Museum and Coffee Shop. The museum is a bit difficult to find, but held a nice assortment of photography. THere is a cute rooftop cafe where you can rest and enjoy a nice view of the city.
Berber treasures. Loved this museum. Well worth the visit. The portraits of people from the 1920s and 1930s are mezmerizing
Fascinating. The photographs were amazing well worth the visit. It was very near to our Riad. We learned a lot about the history of Morocco from the maps and photos.

Beautiful photographs, no restaurant service!. Cool rooms full of some very atmospheric old photographs, evoking the history of this bustling country, it's traditions, and it's inhabitants. Many things appeared not to have changed very much especially the conditions inside the Souks. The children were in much more traditional dress than the trainers, and football strip which they seem to prefer to wear today. We sat for a while watching fascinating old films depicting life 70 years ago in Berber mountain villages, and then went up to the roof terrace for some much needed food. What a disappointment! After 20 minutes of waiting looking at the dirty dishes on our table, with other tables just sitting waiting as well, we left without even being asked why we were leaving! The views were certainly good across the city, but over stretched or no staff at all do not make for a good dining experience! Although our 40 dirhams ticket allows us to return as many times as we wish, I am not sure that I would want to following our experience in the rooftop restaurant.
excelent. wonderful place a lot of thing to discover i really love it it was like a dream,will visit it again.....

Hidden Gem, beautiful place!. I was so glad we went to visit this place. A wonderful gallery with beautiful photographs inside a great building. It's easy to find (it is sign posted) and the rooftop restaurant has views to die for and great service. The food was incredible and so cheap!
Riad Sacr. Photos are true to real life! The Riad Sacr is worth visiting and Fatima folds the towels into animals each day.
Maison de la Photographie. You don't have to be interested in photography to enjoy the photos in this gallery. Roof top cafe is an added bonus.
Great rooftop view. If you don't mind spending 40mdh for entrance fee the place has a great rooftop cafe with excellent view over the roofs of marrakesh

Boring. Having followed the trip advisor rating we put it as a priority. I couldn't see what all the fuss was about; a load of old lack and white photos of Marrakech and its people not looking to different to now. The view of the snowy mountains from the rooftop restaurant made it slightly more worthwhile but that was the only redeeming point for me. A waste of money otherwise.

Very interesting photographs of early Morocco and stunning views of the Medina from the rooftop. Located close to Ben Yousuf Madressa, the museum offers a wonderful collection of early Moroccan photographs. Entrance is 40 dirhams and you can use your ticket to gain access more than once. Its a must for all photographers. Will take under about 45 mins to go through the 3 levels and stunning views of the Medina and Atlas mountain range awaits you at the rooftop terrace. The restaurant on the rooftop offers a great spot for lunch and the food was excellent. 80 dirhams for a 3 course set menu.
Have lunch on the roof1. Great small gallery with historic Morrocan photography. The best is the roof though.....have lunch there and look at the mountains and rooftops......it is tremendous.

Lovely gallery with a stunning view. This small gallery is a labour of love. We really enjoyed looking at the photographs and the view from the roof terrace is stunning. Postcards and prints are available to purchase. Definitely worth a look.

Good lunch stop. Small gallery but with some interesting photographs. Friendly staff and under 16's are free (otherwise it would have felt quite expensive for such a small collection). We went because the owners of our Riad recommended the roof top terrace. We ended up having lunch there which was very nice and offered quite views of the Medina and Atlas Mountains
Good original images. Small area, you will like the historical images if you are there, but you'll not be missing out if you can't make it. Friendly staff there.

A gem in the midst of Chaos. An oasis of past life, very interesting and a great expedition to a Berber Village arranged by them. Really imformative and a good price, with the money going to local People

Fascinating photos and great roof terrace for lunch!. The photos was very interesting, showing Morocco since the early 1900s. But the best bit was the panoramic roof terrace, views right over marrakech over to the Atlas mountains.
Im not sure why this was rated no1 at the time. The view from the cafe at the top is nice as was the little cafe we stopped by for a rest. But im not sure why this attraction is so highly rated.

A must go if you like anything remotely related to humanity. Nice photos that you simply can't miss if you want a nice intimate rapport with Morocco. The nice thing is they sell posters and photos developed from original films so that you can take with you a piece of Morocco

Nice photos, but way too expensive. The photos were very nice, not doubt about that, but for an entrance fee of 40 dirham (If I remember correctly) I expect more information in English and more photos as well.

Great for lunch. This is a quirky little museum. You can buy a ticket which allows you to return any time. Definitely interesting to see the history of Marrakech. Perfect for lunch with a stunning roof top restaurant that serves great local cuisine for a fair price.

Nice getaway from the Medina hustle. We came here based on the nice reviews in order to get away from the Medina hustle for a little bit. Although it certainly must have been a hidden gem before, it may not be so anymore. The rooftop terrasse has a nice view over the city and is worthwhile going to, especially to have an inexpensive nice tajine lunch. Service is very slow though. We did not find the photo exhibition particularly interesting. However, all staff is very friendly and helpful. The place is difficult to find indeed, but we managed to do so by ourselves.

Photographers, do not miss!. A trip into the history of photography. There are very few places in the World where a photographer can experience the development of this art form as here at the Maison de La Photographie.
Tricky to find, but worth the effort. The photos in this small museum are wonderful, you can purchase prints. The cafe on the rooftop has great views too, and the loo is really clean!

Incredible. We visited the Maison de Photographie at the suggestion of Mandy at Dar Hanane. This small museum was opened just three years ago and features some great vintage photos of Morocco. If you have spent some time in other parts of Morocco or the medina in Marrakech, you will marvel at how little has changed. They have some lovely prints of the photographs for sale-250 dhs.

Beautiful place, but small. As an amateur photographer I was expecting more. But the museum is very nice, well maintained and has very nice pictures showing the history of Morocco. If you like photography don't miss. And take a quick look on the view from the top of the museum.

Peaceful, interesting, informative. Nice lunch with a view.. Visited with my boyfriend in March 2013. The best museum we visited in Marrakech. Well laid out out, and with information at regular points adding to the beautiful photography on display. Information available in English, which seems quite unusual in Marrakech's museums. Interesting film footage of hill/ mountain villages from the 1950s. Also, a lovely terrace restaurant, with a fabulous view over the city to the Atlas mountains. Lunch was a set menu which included a salad, chicken tagine with couscous, followed by set yogurt with strawberries. Food was good, but not the best tagine we ate. Also a little expensive at 80 MAD per person for the set menu before drinks.
work out where it is first. Great museum of photography capturing Morocco since the end of the 1800s. Friendly, but it was tough to find without the 'help' of self appointed guides

Interesting to visit with a rooftop cafe. We visited the Maison de la Photographie as it was rated no 1 and looked interesting. There was less to see than expected but it is a pleasant place to spend some time and we ate a tasty lunch on the rooftop terrace which was worth visiting in its own right.

Good, but not exceptional. Some interesting pictures and the colour documentary was good, but museum was a little small for the price, compared to other Marrakeshi activities. Worth calling in but I wouldn't call it a highlight.

Overrated. I guess you have to be into photography to enjoy this place. There is no English guide whatsoever as to what your're looking at so basically you're just looking at a bunch of old black and white pictures which is really not worth the price of admission. The rooftop terrace cafe offers a great view though.It is not bad but not very deserving to be the top attraction of Marrakech.

So many great pictures. This place wasn't that hard to find after I visited Ali Ben Youssof Medersa, and I'm glad I did. I'm really enjoy looking at photos and there were many here. Some of them were old, showing how Marrakech used to look like (and other places of course), and gives one an insight in to the city and country's history.You can book a tour with an English speaking guide, who will tell you more detailed about the photos. I like to just look at the pictures and wonder what the story behind is, so I opted to say no to this offer.Also, I highly recommend the cafe at the top. Stunning views and great food, and a nice place to relax and recharge your batteries.

calm and interesting. I really liked this gallery and found the photos fascinating. It is a very pleasant exhibition space and the people working in the gallery were extremely knowledgeable and helpful. I would definitely recommend a visit.
Tranquil and interesting. Leaving behind the bustle of the medina to step into the cool calm of great photos and my favourite terrace so far. Strawberries and mint tea on the roof was fantastic
Hidden gem. Best roofterrace in Marrakech and it serves exquisite Egyptian karkaday tea. Great exhibits too and cheap prints

Great location with roof top cafe and museum of photos. We arrived just before closing but had the opportunity to visit the museum very quickly and arrive on the roof top cafe just as the sun was going down. The staff was very, very kind and we loved the selection of photographs

A must see. Amidst a rainy Marrakech day, Maison de la Photographie was the perfect way to spend a couple hours indoors. Just near Ben Youssef Medersa, for a meagre entry fee, you can explore a beautiful old building filled with original black&white photographs of Morocco spanning 1870 – 1950. Be sure to pick up some postcards or larger replicas. The rooftop terrace can be accessed for lunch on days offering better weather.
Worth the visit. Old photos ranging from about 1840. In many cases it appears that nothing has changed!! Admission is inexpensive, the staff are helpful and you can take pictures!!

Small enjoyable museum. Great small museum with fascinating photos giving glimpses into the history and culture of Marrakesh and region. Helpful staff at entrance, but slow service on the small rooftop cafe.To get to the museum from the Ben Youseff Medersa: if you were coming out of the Medersa entrance, turn right, then take the third street on the left. The photography museum is on that street.
Makes a change. Some great old photos of Marrakesh in atmospheric building. Difficult to find but worth the effort. Your ticket entitles you to return throughout your stay.

Saved by the roof terrace cafe. Based on this being the no 1 attraction in Marrakech this was our first port of call, what a let down! Difficult to find we ended up paying someone to show us the way. Most of the pictures on display we later saw on postcards for sale all over Marrakech. The roof top terrace cafe is its saving grace as it has fabulous views all over the city. Overall though we have no idea why it is the no 1 attraction there are much better things to see and do.

Nice escape!. A really nice, calming place set in an old house. Very beautiful with fantastic views on the sun terrace - great spot for a picture of the city and the atlas mountains in the background. A nice way to spend an hour.

Excellent little Museum!. This was a lovely place to walk around and see the history of Morocco through the eyes of some great photographers. The terrace at the top of the museum gives a great view of Marrakech and the Atlas mountains!

Nice people. Nice lunch on rooftop terrace. Interesting photos of 1880, 1920, 1940s Morocco. Step inside away from the craziness, hassle and hustle of the street into a little oasis, calm and tranquil. Staff were very nice, lunch pretty good, but seemed like great value equivalent to about 7 Euro to feed two.

Great Photos and Roof Terrace Food. The photos are a great record of the way Morocco has evolved but the terrace was my favourite part. They offer a set tagine menu which one can eat while overlooking the medina with the Atlas Mountains in the background and the lunchtime call to prayer drifting in across the city.

Ensure you go here!!. Get a cab here - ask for the Musee du Marrakech if they don't know if the maison de la photorgaphie as it's just around the corner. You will probably still need to get a local to guide you for a few £1's though as it's in the souks.Inside are some amazing photos of Marrakech back in the 1930's and the guide will give you a great explanation as to how Marrakech came to be.Also, and one of the best bits, is the roof terrace. We took some amazing photo's up there and had a nice cold drink, perfect.
Oasis of calm. Atmospheric selection of old photographsNot disabled friendly with steps everywhere. But helpful and friendly staff.Nice loo
Beautiful architecture. Lovely place to stop for coffee on the roof terrace. The photos are a wonderful peek into the history and culture that have shaped the country.
Worth a visit!. Beautiful! The building is lovely and the photographs are fascinating. A stunning collection and a wonderful way to spend an hour or so in Marrakech...
A pleasant experience and good value food.. I would recommend this place. A good place to relax and eat. There are many interesting photos of Morrocco.

A very special museum in M'Kech. After the bustle and noise of the souks, the extraordinary collection of vintage and modern photos in a quiet, peaceful setting is not to be missed. there is even a small terrace cafe with views of the rooftops and Atlas mountains.

Worth it!. The photos are interesting and the museum is a little hard to find, however I would strongly recommend having a quick tea/snack/lunch at the cafe on the roof. The food was very good and the prices were very reasonable.

Interesting place to visit. Once found, a little gem of a small museum showing really interesting photos of old Marrakech & Morocco. Don't miss watching the TV film of an adventurer going into the Atlas Mountsins. It's in French but worth seeing. If you are hungry definitely recommend eating on the roof top cafe where we had three courses for only € 8. A great Plat de Jour !!!!

Fascinating. It took us quite a while to find the Maison de la Photographie as it is very tucked away. However, it was well worth the search. Looking at the photographs is like stepping back in time; they are absolutely mesmerising. There is a lovely café on the roof which has lovely views over Marrakech. It seems that they just do one meal of the day; however, it was excellent and fantastic value. So if you are visiting the gallery it is well worth stopping for lunch or a mint tea.

Hidden gem. Take a cab it will drop you 50m from the entrance, no chance of beening persuaded to go wrong way. The photos are fascinating showing the real history of Morocco and photographic trend of the time. The real gem is the rooftop terrace far above the hustle of the souls below you can lose yourself in the warmth of the sun the view of Marakesh. Once you have soaked up the rooftop view you suddenly see in the distance the clouds and the shape that is the Atlas mountains. If that is not enough to satisfy your soul then try the dish of the day followed by hibiscus tea, delightful and the staff are very friendly and welcoming too.
a great insight into the past. superb photographs from ages past using basic camera technology making our little point and shoot cameras pathetic by comparison

Has to be the first place to visit in Marrakech. A wonderful archive of photography located in a beautifully restored building with a 360 degree view of Marrakech and Atlas Mountains beyond. This collection of photography represents an insight into traditonal Moroccan life and a history of photography that is fast disappearing. You have to go!
interesting. there's not a lot to do in Marrakech, so this should be on your list. We bought a photograph, not expensive

Not to be missed. We loved this museum. Pay once & you can return again for free.
Great photographs and a terrace with views over the roof tops of Marrakech and the Atlas Mountains. Although showing a three course menu fir lunch you can just have the starter for a light lunch. Hard to find inMarrakech
Not great. There were about 100 pictures from between 1870 en 1950. Overrated and not that special. Maybe you really have to appreciate art to like it.

Great view from terrace, good quality for value food, nice exhibition. If you visit this, try to eat on the terrace (go early as food finishes around 2pm). They have one menu, it's far better value and quality than many touristy places in Marrakech (180 for full menu with drinks for 2). Nice lunch with a great view. Exhibition is ok, a few nice photographs.

Such a friendly place with great views over the city. Well worth the visit but hard to find. The photos were beautiful and the people who worked there encouraged us to go upstairs and check out the sunset. The gallery was the high point culturally of our trip and i will definately re visit it.
A Treasure. Make the effort to find this place because it is well worth it. The photos are wonderful. And there is a rooftop terrace with great views over the old city as well as a good value meal.
Well worth a visit. Fascinating collection of photos in a lovely building, with a wonderful panorama from the roof cafe.

A place to escspe the hurly burly. If you set your camera to monochrome you could take pictures just like these but probably better. Most shots are of market scenes and local people and the essence of these hasn't really changed. Roof top cafe with a view of1000s of satelite dishes and old TV aeriels. Oversold attraction.
Hidden gem. Wonderful, cool gallery with fabulous photos giving a real sense of history and a great roof terrace

Fantastic. A beautiful little museum containing some great photos of Marrakech and Morocco from times long past. The museum is housed in a very pretty riad and has a roof top café which is well worth stopping at too. Once you’ve paid for admission, keep hold of your ticket as you can use it to regain entry again at no extra fee, either to take another look around the gallery or to visit the café. The owner was very friendly, spoke English and was happy to give a brief explanation of some of the prints on show. If you’re interested in photography or the history of history of Marrakesh, I’d definitely recommend a visit.
cute. It is very nice but small so it can feel cramped. Maybe because we went toward the end of our visit, but i had no interest compared to the busy and exciting streets just outside.

A oasis of calm with a tasty bonus.. . A quiet, spacious exhibition of old Morocco, & it's people - hardly changed to some extent. Various kinds of prints on display in cool white rooms off a beautiful courtyard, with info in French and (mostly well translated) English. Very nicely presented. 40dh entry relatively expensive (compared with 10 for some of the palaces), but you can return as much as you like with the ticket, & I believe it gives admission to another museum in the Ourika valley.We were attracted as much by a tip off about the rooftop restaurant as by the photographs, & weren't disappointed. The 80dh menu du jour at lunchtime comprised a tasty aubergine salad, a generous chicken/lemon tagine with couscous, & fresh strawberries. Really good value, friendly staff, & excellent views to the south of the Medina: a great photo spot, appropriately enough.

Perfect little place. If you like photography, visit. If you like history, visit. If you like Morocco, visit.Great exhibition. A warm welcome. Pay once and return as many times as you like.Go up to the roof too and have lunch. The set menu we had yesterday was delicious.

Oasis. The pictures are a delight in black and white. Marrakesh has really changed only a little as those fascinating photos showed. A small roof terrace served a well priced set lunch. We arrived near the time for the calls of prayer and it was quite an experience to be surounded by the sound.Interesting place

Well worth finding. A great collection of old photographs of Marrakech, housed in a pleasant building with several rooms on three floors. Well laid out. Could do with a bigger place as only a small proportion of the collection is on show. Don't miss the rooftop cafe with good views across the city.

what a delight very interesting.. this is a lovely building housing a wonderfull exhibition of photos of old morrocco, plenty to see and very helpfull staff to give youextra information.lovely roof terrace at the top for refreshmentand the view

A gem. This was an amazing find, a great way to leave the hustle and bustle of the souks behind yet still immerse yourself into true Morroccan culture. The staff were very good. The photographs are amazing, you can visit multiple times on one ticket and even an amateur will appreciate the photo opportunities on the terrace. The terrace gave the best unobstructed 360view of Marrakesh that I found. On your own or with the whole family this would be enjoyed by all.

A great little find!. Having an interest in photography, this was high on my list of things to do in Marrakech. Although not large the museum has some wonderful photographs of people and the souks. We spent about an hour wandering round the museum and seeing how Marrakech and Morocco in general has changed, or not changed! There is some great footage of the Berbers taken in the 50s which we sat and watched and although it was in French and we couldn't understand it, it was still really interesting. I would definitely recommend a visit.

Wonderful museum. Really interesting photographs of Moracco. Amazing portraits of people from the area as well as great photos the Medina and other parts of Moracco. Beautiful terrace to enjoy a coffee with a great view of the city. The building itself is wonderfully ornate. A must see!

So great, I couldn't leave without a few prints!. This was one of the highlights for me in Morocco. I did a lot of travelling across the country, but wanted some older photos that illustrate the culture, history and Morocco's people. The ground floor has some stunning portraits. There is a second and third floor, and a terrace on top. It was great to see such amazing photos - many of them range from the late 1800's through to the 1940s. My prints are going to cost a fortune to frame back home - but they'll last me my life time and I'll have no regrets on the purchase.

Nice short museum with awesome cafe. The photos in this museum let you take a step back in time to days past. It was a nice collection. The highlight of the trip is the rooftop terrace with an amazing menu del jour.

A real must-visit place near the Medersa. This is an excellent museum. The staff were very welcomg and gave a quick introduction to the exhibits - amazing photographs of local places and people mostly. Fascinating to see how little some parts of Marrakech had changed since the 1920s!When you are finished you can get great views over the city from the roof terrace/cafe. The ticket allows multiple visits so you can come back for a sunset view if you want.
a peaceful haven in the midst of the bustling medina. well worth the visitbeautiful old photographs in a really tranquil settinglovely rooftop terrace cafe clean toilet.

Absolutely worth a visit. The photos are extraordinary and some quite haunting. The whole exhibition gives you an even better sense of Marrakech's and Morocco's history. They also have a great little roof cafe.

Calm and very pretty. The building was very pretty and light. The terrace is a lovely place to sit and drink tea.The exhibition was interesting and I liked looking at a bit of culture instead of all the tourist tat. You could see a big part of Marrakech from the roof terrace, and it was there that I also first spotted the Atlas mountains. They looked like a mirage above the dusty sitty.

Great photography and history. Thoroughly recommend spending sometime here at the Photography Musuem. Really enjoyed our visit taking in the photoo's from Marrakech, and also Morrocco.Great cafe at the top of the building to take in the vista of Marrakech and the Atlas Mountains.

wonderful museum. This is a great place to visit at Marrakech. The exhibit displaying photographs mainly from the 1950s is wonderful. It's a peaceful place and you can wonder around endlessly. They have a nice cafe on the roof and keep your ticket for muliple entries.

Nice Spot. This small musem is worth your time. There were some really nice photos, including some classics that I did not realize were Moroccan. We really enjoyed the rooftop cafe above the Maison de la Photographie. The view was great and beautiful weather while we were there (Jan). The tea was wonderful and the lemon chicken tagine with cous cous was excellent and enough for two. It doesn't take much time to look through the museum, but it is near the Museum of Marrakech and the Ali Ben Youssef Medersa, so altogether and including a leisurely lunch it makes a nice day excursion.

Beautiful place. Although it took us over an hour to find the place it was well worth it! It is an oasis in the madness of the Souks. Ignore any of the local lads outside saying it is closed! This is a great place to eat! The food was fantastic and the views from the roof terrace are worth the walk.
Elegant and ivocative. Go there to see a beautiful house, see some historic and evocative pictures and enjoy an excellent linch on the rooftop terrace with an excellent 360 view of the Medina
Hidden photography musem. Very recomended and hidden place for photography lovers and to see the history of the city. A highly recommended roof top terrace view fo the city

Definitely worth a visit. Gorgeous, quiet building full of a wonderful collection of photography, absolutely worth making time in your itinerary for. The roof terrace is a perfect spot for lunch or tea as well, and if you don't have time on the day the ticket remains valid for a re-visit another day.

Don't miss this. Wonderful photos, you can buy prints, and fascinating videos. Pleasant terrace for lunch or snacks and drinks, friendly owner and staff. You can revisit on the same ticket during your stay in Marrakech.

Fantastic comparing current locations and old photos. My daughter is studing photography so we really enjoyed our visit. It was wonderful to compare current loctions with older photos. The view from the roof is amazing.

Great for both history and photography buffs. This place is a great stop if you love photography and/or history. A fantastic to collection of historic photographs in a lovely riad setting. You not only get a visual sense of the old Morocco and Marrakech but also learn a little of the photographers themselves and the techniques they used. It also shows that things haven't changed all that much in Jmaa El Fna!A nice break from the hustle and bustle. The rooftop restaurant looks inviting but unfortunately it was a blustery, wet day when we visited.

Look into Morocco's past. I'd heard if the gallery from some people in my hostel. It's got a fantastic collection of images from 1870-1950 of Morocco, exquisite black and white images of varying sizes and styles (portraits, landscapes, etc). And once you've explored the various collections, you can buy copies anywhere from postcards to full size and/or take in the views of the city from the rooftop cafe.Thing to bear in mind is, like everywhere in Marrakech, it can be hard to find and there will be "helpful" citizens who'll offer to show you the way. Best to do is head to the bigger sites nearby on your map, and ask shop keepers and museum staff for directions - they'll guide you the right way.Make sure you don't miss this beautiful gem! And get a postcard.

Museum of Photography. Great place. Unfortunately, the scans they use to convert their negs. into reproductions for sale are of low resolution, so the repros. themselves are not of the greatest quality, otherwise I would have bought a pile. A must see! One warning: if you ask for directions from anyone on the street, particularly when in the souk streets, you will be told by child or adult alike that the Museum is closed today. Don't believe them. It's a ruse to get you to one of their friend's stores, usually far away in the tanneries. DON'T GO, under any circumstance. You'll have to pay them once after you arrive and pay again to get you out of there through the maze.

Some nice images but rooftop cafe the best. The museum is very nice and is a beautiful example of a classic Riad ( not changed into a hotel) but the rooftop terrace is the best part they seem to do lovely lunches but a cold drink while taking in the view and taking your own pictures isn't to be missed!

Beautiful photos capture a bygone era. A small museum that has some trully stunning images - of Marrakesh, Tangiers and Berber villages. But it's the people's faces yiu remember - the old, the young, the beautiful. Worth spending an hour savouring photos of a time gone by, but still recognisable today.

Beautiful building. We loved visiting the photography museum. Even if you don't like the pictures (which we did) - it's a lovely building with a central courtyard overlooked by terraces. Beautiful tiling and a roof terrace where you can enjoy a drink overlooking the streets and roof tops below. Once you buy the ticket (30DH) you can visit as many times as you like too.

Best view in Marrakesh. View a wonderful collection of Photographs depicting history of Marrakesh on the on the way up to the roof terrace for almost 360 degree view of the City. A Great place to visit for Lunch or a Mint Tea while taking in The Atlas mountains in the sunshine.

Great museum. This place is very cheap (10 DH) and it gives a great impression of the historical development of Medina. I would definitely recommend it for anyone visiting Medina even if you are not interested in photography as such.

Don't miss it (if you can find it!). The museum is just the right size - not too big but perfect for displaying its fascinating collection. As Aberdonians, we were amazed that the very first thing we saw was a collection of the work of George Washington Wilson who is very well known in Aberdeen (and beyond!). Also a quaint roof-top cafe with excellent views of the city and Atlas Mountains.
Pretty Nice. What a great place to visit....Beautiful pictures , nice collection and lunch on the roof was great. Thank you Nelly for this address

worth seeing. Small but well worth a visit. The photographs are great and the young morocan lad gave us some very interesting information. There is also a small roof terrace where you can have a coffee and a snack.

Great pictures, stunning view, amazing food.. The photographic exhibition was very nice. Stunning pictures from earlier days in Marrakech. But one should not forget visiting the cafe at the roof. In the shade of a straw roof, you can enjoy one of the best views in the city, with endless rooftops and the majestic Atlas mountains in the background. The food was some of the best I had in Marrakech. Perfectly cooked and in non-enormous portions. The rooftop is worth the visit alone.
Worth searching out. Something a bit different - lots of beautiful old photographs of Morocco - a nice way to spend some time.

Great view on a sunny day. It is a great view at the top, we planned for lunch there, but I don't recommend you to have your lunch there, it better to just have a drink and enjoy the great view of Marrakech. I'm not that in to art, but their gallery is worth the entrance fee just as the view is!

worth it for the terrace view. It has a good photo collection but it's worth it mainly for the great terrace view! Pity the cafe service on the terrace is weak.The surrounding area isn't very friendly but you do have a very nice restaurant nearby (Le Fondouk).
Go. Great place, stunning photographs which need a little more context to be fully understood, and a fantastic roof terrace. Go.
Beautiful photographs great place for lunch. this is a beautiful setting for phostos from marrakesh in the early 20'2=40's . They have a cafe on the roof that has a stunning view and a great tangine.
well worth a visit. A great collection and managed by young people who care about their heritage. An impressive collection of early photographs.

Small, lovely museum. Brilliant cafe roof terrace!. Good value museum, small but interesting. It's well worth putting aside enough time aside to have a drink or some food on the roof terrace - we went on two separate days; the view is one of the best in the the Medina.

Worth hunting out for a taste of Morocco of old. A gem of a museum, showing evocative photos and films from Morocco. Some of the architecture and scenes will be very familiar from walking through the souks to reach it. Don't be put off if your told the museum is closed and that you should visit the tanneries instead. We had to ask directions a couple of times and it was open contrary to what we'd be told!
Photographic Museum. It was an interesting place to visit - lots of photographs past and present. Set in a little alley/street close to the Merdsa Ben Youssef.
Wonderful small museum. Great range of photographs of Morocco from the birth of photography. We really enjoyed our visit. Very good roof terrace with spectacular views for drink of mint tea.
Super. Great place, friendly staff and good food on the terrace. The photo collection is a great reminder of the grand historie of Morrocco.

Worth a look. Nice atmosphere and photographs gave a sense of the city in an early time - which we didn't really get from the Museum which we had visited earlier - albeit it a beautiful building.A cold drink on the roof after enjoying the photos is very pleasant
Fascinating. Many different photographers and style, representative of the history of Morocco, lovely building with coffee and magnificient view on the top.
Great views. Had one of the best lunches of our trip on the upstairs balcony overlooking the mountains. We also bought some fantastic photos downstairs.

Lovely for lunch. If you're lost in the Medinas of Marrakech there is no lovelier place than this to stop for a coffee and to take in the city. The view is incredible from the rooftop terrace. It's tiny... so not for big groups. The exhibition space is pretty too... but it's the view that's really the draw.

Well worth a look. Small but interesting, 40 dirhams entrance fee, but worth it. You will get an introduction when you enter, there are lots of lovely photos from 1880 on, an interesting video (in French) about Berber life, and a terrace cafe with panoramic views.

Nice cafe, bland photos. The photos lack some variety, as they are all monochrome and from 1910-1920, and more or less similar. The rooftop terrace has a great view and he best chicken tagine we tried (50dh).

Lost in Marrakech. A small museum but some fantastic pictures.
We had a lovely lunch on the roof Terrace.
You can use your ticket over again

Must do!. Nice to see all the different photos of all ancient Marrakech.
Something different than all the other stuff you visit.
Very nice overview on the Medina from on top of the building
TIP: if you buy a ticket you have access for several days and you can also have breakfast there.

Essential Museum of Photography 1880 to 1940's. Suburb collection of early photographs cyclically displayed. Prints of the images are sold to support the Museum which is in a lovely Riad with a small roof cafe. The docents are very knowedgeable and helpful and can direct you to other worthy museums. Small charge, ticket is also good for the Berber Museum in a Berber village near the city which was the best Museum of Berber culture we found. Don't miss this museum.
Recommended. Nice pictutes give insight in the past. Beautiful building. Spectaculair view and good dood on The terrace.

solid but small collection. Many of the photos are really compelling - true art, not just travel photos of beautiful Morocco. Most are from the first half of the 20th century and taken by Frenchmen during the occupation. My only complaint is that it is not bigger. The (shaded) roof top cafe has a nice view of the city rooftops and the Atlas mountains and serves a good 3-course lunch for about 12 euro.
Keep your ticket. for free re-entry. Rooftop has great food! Great place to wander about for a while. So beautiful photographs.

Friendly photographic museum. High quality museum with good vintage photos from Marrakech and Morocco. I really recommend it. It is small but easy to find if you have a good map (and as always in Marrakech, do not trust the young kids telling directions). The view of Marrakech from the roof-top terrace is the best I found during 10 days (visit it during sunset). The staff is very friendly and you can also buy prints. You can reuse the tickets and come back several times.

Beautiful collection. Do take time to read about this place before you visit - and perhaps after a few trip around the medina - because it gives you a context to the superb collection of photos. It is located in a old restored foundouk - a beautiful building. The terrace is lovely with a great view of the medina - but the lunch may not be worth it especially if you have already had your fill of tangines. A nice pot of mint tea is a nice alternative to contemplate the view from the terrace. The prints of photographs on sale are not very expensive - a pretty good and cheaper alternative are prints available in Gueliz including some of the shops near the majorelle gardens

Fantastic Exibition & Terrasse. I felt in love with Maison de Photographie: the exibition of local artists is wonderful, the house with its light atrium also. Entrance to the terrasse is inclouded, you can have traditional tea in the sun for 10Dh. Priceless is the view over Marrakech, the Medina and the close Mountains covered with snow. All is silent on top of the souks.Pay Entrance once and you can come as often as you want. During 1 week in marrakech in January 13 I used this chance three times.

Fantastic lunch and great views! Great exhibits too.. We decided to come here for our last lunch destination in Marrakech. We got very lost coming here but so glad we finally made it. The lunch is served on the terrace and the views are beautiful. You get a wonderful of the Atlas mountains and the medina. Lunch was 80dhs for a 3-course meal and it was absolutely delicious. So much better than the touristy place our local guide took us the day before. Amazing view, delicious lunch, gorgeous day, you can't get any better than that. The photo exhibitions were also moving and it really shows the history and changes of the country. I would definitely recommend to people of all ages and it's worth the trip!

A Serene Sea of Tranquility with a great view. Hard to find,,, and look out for the scammers on the way !, but once inside it a great old building, great photos of what Marrakech was before it lost its soul ! the views from the terrace on the top over the medina to the atlas mountains, and the tranquility is worth the 40DH entrance fee alone !

Very Good Review of the History of Marrakech Through Photos. We looked for this maison or museum, which has a very complete review of the histiry of Marrakech and its peoples through photos. Don't miss the roof top terrace restaurant, they make, serve the best chicken tagines in Marrakech
A window on old Morrocco. Fabulous place, wonderful images of the old cities and Berber tribesmen. The roof terrace is a delightful place to eat.

don't miss the roof terrace. The museum is very interesting but I find the best part if its roof terrace - with magnificent view of the medina. We watched spectacular sunset on the terrace. It was so quiet and beautiful yet breathtaking.

Best museum in Marrakech. This is an excellent museum, both from a photographic and historical point of view, and do not miss the café on the roof which has the best view of the medina with the Atlas mountains in the background
Ok place. Well, not sure why it's rated so highly to be honest. Stumbled upon it. Went in. Good photos. Nice tea on the terrace, but I wouldn't seek it out if time limited.

Marrakech o Marrakech!. Beautiful and interesting display of archive photos. The terrace on top was a welcome place to view Marrakech rooftops whilst sipping on a cola and having a bite of Morrocan cuisine. A definite highlight in the medina.
Nice place. A good place to visit, very intresting pictures and the staff was very helpful and friendly.hey heve a fantastic terasse on the top roof where yuo can get a nice cup of the or dinner.
A gem in the Medina. We loved this place. The exhibitions were well thought out and the rooftop terrace has the most amazing views. The lunchtime menu was delicious.
Wonerful. Photos are terriffic insights to early marrakech, it was well laid out and the terrace cafe was a great way to end the trip

Photomuseum. A very interesting museum to learn about the history of the region. Amazing old photos. You have to visit the restaurant/café at the top of the house. I had the best lemon chicken tagine there. And really sweet staff.

Extremely interesting and unique. This exhibition is well worth the hunt! The staff were very well informed and clearly enjoyed their job and appreciated the photographs as much as the tourists. It gave a unique insight into Morocco.
Small museum with interesting pictures of Morocco. This museum shows old pictures of Morocco. Pictures of Marrakech, The Berbers and The villages in The Atlas mountain.
Lovely museum. We enjoyed our visit - it's a small museum but their collection of Morocco and Africa is worth the price of admission. Will take maybe an hour to get through - it's fairly small.
Incredible museum!. Well worth a visit- stunning photos that are carefully set out and a great roof terrace for lunch with delicious food.

Stunning little museum. I always find old photographs strangely moving, and this museum has some beautiful early photographs of Moroccan cities, including Marrakech, and portraits of Berber and Touareg people. It provides a fascinating historical perspective, and also an insight into the history of photographic development. The rooftop cafe has stunning views and a very reasonably priced lunch. The place is run by charming enthusiasts, put in on your itinerary without fail!

Hidden gem for a delicious lunch with a view. Enjoyed a delicious chicken tajine with preserved lemon and olives on the roof top terrace. It was a great place to relax with a cold drink takknv in the view after the hustle and bustle of the Medina. Thanks Hassan for taking us there.
Very pleasant. Lovely building, very good collection of photos, exceptionally gentle staff, and the roof-top terrace is a great place to watch the sunset.
Interesting phoography. Some of the old photos were as good as todays modern ones! There was a small cafe on the terrace with panoramic views of the city.
A beautiful vantage point, relaxing and fun. Great views, relaxing and peaceful. Good photos and a cool cafe on the roof with great views. Sunset and the call for prayer at dusk are brill here.
well worth seeing. It was really nice to see photos from 19th century before Morocco become Mecca of bohemian travelers. Well worth a visit.
Well worth a visit. A terrific gallery of early photographic portraits and scenery, you can purchase copies. All you have to do is find it...
Absolutely Fantastic Exhibition. "Brilliant Photography" from a bygone era. A "must see" while you are in Marrkech, especially if you are interested in photography. Amazing experience, thank you.
Nice Stop. Wonderful photography in a wonderful setting. Great books and postcards. Nice view from cafe on roof.

Interesting Museum of Old Pics. I really enjoyed seeing the pictures of Marrakech and the High Atlas from the 1920s. And there were a number of really compelling photographic portraits of Moroccan peoples. Good for history buffs as well as fans of great photography.

Really interesting, and the best lunch in town!. The owner of the riad we were staying in recommended this place. It was so interesting and there arer some beautiful photos of old Morocco. They were running some old travel films from the '50s, and these were actually fascinating. Time it right and you can head up to the roof for lunch - delicious! All the staff were charming too.
Lovely!. What a brilliant gallery! And the roof terrace is a chance to take in the view over a cup of mint tea. Do this if just for the roof terrace as it is truly lovely

Photos with a view. A nice collection of vintage shots of Morocco - sadly showing how shockingly little things have changed in the past 50-80 years, in some cases. Lovely cafe on the roof with delicious tagines and a great panoramic view of the city. Only downside is that the museum's space is so limited, and thus only able to display a tiny fraction of the 5,000+ photos in its archives. But worth a look nonetheless (it's also conveniently located, close to the souks and madrassa).

overrated. Don't waster your time visiting this maison. 20 photos and a rooftop where you can buy snacks. that's all they have to offer. It is teasteful, but just not worth the visit with the admission fee.
Excellent!. A great young team have set up this wonderful gallery in Marrakech, full of interesting photos - a great addition to the Marrakech scene
An interesting insight to Moroccos past.. A great little gallery with many old photos showing the Morocco of old. Really interesting to see how things were and compare.
Special museum. Nice little private museum with an excellent 1 menu restaurant on the roof, not far from the sooks. Tickets are reusable during 4 days.
Nice place good views. but you have to pay 40DH to get in... Worth it thou. There is a cafe on the terrace if you fancy a drink.

Nice cultural oasis in Medina. Visited Maison de la Photographie based on top reviews on Trip Advisor. It was a nice pictorial history of the Morroco area and the people. It was also wonderful to be able to think and read without being pestered for "help" or to look at trinkets. The only downside - it took 45 minutes walking around it to find it. It is difficult to find, and you will get incredibly annoyed with all the street "helpers" trying to ferry you away to the tanneries, or being continually told "the market is this way, I'll show you". We were also told it was closed for cleaning. Once we did find it, it was a calming breath of easement. We met Patrick who was extremely nice. Entry fee was inexpensive, and we got a short introduction from Mohammed who spoke English and was pleasant but knowledgeable. Go to the rooftop cafe, a stunning view - also something to behold when all the mosques start blasting the call to prayer. It's like one bullfrog croaking, then the others come to life.
Nice photo's and great view at the terasse. After looking at the photo's and movie, you can have a drink or eat at the roof terasse, with nice view.
Very good situated in a traditional building with a restaurant.. Historical photographs of Morroco and well presented. A video was also provided showing historical events etc.

A Step Back in Time. A delightful small exhibition of photos of Morocco from 1870 until 1950. Well presented and a fascinating view of how little the country has changed in many respects.It is also worth having a mint tea on the Terrasse as it gives you one of the best viewing points in Marrakech, being higher than most other buildings.

Don't miss. Impressive collection of excellent photos (the pictures on display change regularly as there are too many to display all at once. Enthusiastic staff are happy to explain the background nad provide further details. Nice roof terrace for a mint tea too.
Wonderful photographic museum. Fascinating pictures, you could easily spend hours here and happily buy a print or two to take with you..

worth getting lost for 4 hours in the medina!. great staff who speaks English! very polite and positive although I lost my temper when we finally stepped in the museum! we had the opportunity to meet Mr Patrick and I must say this is one of the most interesting people I have ever met! DEFINITELY RECOMMEND!!!

A look at old Marrakech. This is a great little museum, and they have done a wonderful job curating their collection of old negatives and selecting prints to give an impression of Marrakech in the old days. Looking at the photos is a good way to remind ourselves that in the days before EasyJet and the Internet, Morocco was a truly exotic destination, and that the special nature of the place was captured in the faces and the clothing of the people who lived there.
Worth a visit. Low entrance fee well worth it to see historical photos of Morocco. Small cafe on the terrace is a nice place to enjoy a tea or coffee. copies of photos may be purchased.

Lovely cafe. Seems like the price has gone up recently as it now costs 40 dirhams to get in, although this does allow you multiple reentry (or so I was told). The photos are interesting and worth a browse, but the best bit is the cafe on the roof. Respite from the madness below, a nice breeze and wonderful views across the city and out to the Atlas mountains below. Worth a visit. Not sure it warrants its number one position in the charts though!

Charming. A small but beautiful collection - with a nice introduction from the owner on arrival. The riad itself is lovely. Visit when you're in the area of the Ali Ben Youssef Medersa and the Musee de Marrakech (and don't be stopped by claims it's closed from men who want to re-route you to the tanneries). Great views over the medina from the roof terrace, where we ate a tasty lunch.

Great place, once we eventually found it!. I have to say, that finding a place in Marrakech is a bit of an adventure in itself. Seems the locals are not too familiar with the Maison de la Photographie and it's certainly not on the tourist route. Really enjoyed the exhibition, the film about life in the Atlas mountains and our personal introduction to the museum. Very pleased we persisted in finding this! Totally worth it. Great view in the cafe, a quiet haven from the streets below.
A jewel. So sad the Moroccans cannot afford visiting the little jewel. Tea on the roof is a must, gorgeous view of Marrakech
Great lunch venue. Despite the entrance fee this is a really good spot for lunch on the terrace. We three girls shared a main and couple of side dishes with drinks for about 120Dh
Good impression of Marrakech and ancient Morocco. Worth visiting with good assortment of pictures of well known French and other photographers.Well worth the 10 Dirham( 1 Euro)

Great pictures of Morrocco in a unique location. This a "must see" place should you be travelling to Marrakech. Close to Medresa ben Yousef, however not always easy to spot, in the labyrinth like streets of Medina. The pictures are from early 20th century to nowadays. Especially early 3D pictures printed on glass are very interesting. Ask staff for help. They will show you.

back to Marrakech history through photography. I visit this museum of photography. I spend 1 hour and took the chance to relax and drink hot mint tea on the terrace and enjoy the upper view of the city. The exhibitions are very nice and you can get to know Marrakech city many years ago, observing black and white pictures of the old city. Very interesting.
Great photo collection. Makes you want to hit the streets and start snapping away yourself. Decent food on the roof as well.
Interesting but not special. As stated, interesting to get a view in the life in Morroco, but not for the artistic value of the photos.
excellent museum. a greqt place to visit just behind the musee de marrakech lovely roof top terrace and cafe very interesting old collection of photos

Very interesting. Beautiful pictures & wonderful rooftop terrace to enjoy mint tea and a meal. If you love photography, this is a good place for you to go. Also, if i'm not mistaken, my ticket to enter (which was i think 60 dirhams) allowed me to return as often as i wanted over the course of a few days.

Well worth a visit. The photographs on display here are, by turns, both interesting and beautiful. When we visited it was very quiet which gave a good opportunity to linger over the displays and enjoy the atmosphere.
Go on up to the roof terrace too, to enjoy a glass of tea and the amazing views.

Most expensive museum in Marrakech. This museum is very difficult to find on the far side of the souks. Once in, it's airy and the exhibit is interesting. But it's small. After touring several museums, I was shocked at the price tag.
Wonderful sunset. Interesting gallery, helpful friendly staff, relaxed cafe on roof with fabulous views of Marrakech and Atlas Mountains

very good outing. great not crowded informative old photos collection
allows a little shopping \easy access and not far from the beautiful Medersa

interesting photo museum. i love photography so visiting this place was very interesting. great views of marrakech from it upper terrace. around a typical moroccan riad you can enjoy different exhibits with old photos of marrakech and of other cities in morocco.

Certainly worth a visite. The maison de la photographie is a lovely place to visit. The collection of pictures are a great introduction to Morocco. They have a cafe on the rooftop which is very worth going to for both the view and the food.

tranquil and great surroundings. Loved the old photos, which showed than not much has changed. The house is lovely, and the roof terrace a delightful way to end the trip. We only had drinks, but the food looked good.
Photos. Well run museum with some interesting photos of old Marrakech and friendly knowledgable staff. They can also arrange tours at reasonable prices.
A Great Visit. An Oasis in the Medina. Beautiful photographs and a great sense of Moroccan history. Lovely rooftop terrace for an afternoon drink.

Small but beautifully formed. This little museum is a definite must if you visit Marrakesh, the staff are excellent and show you round and the little coffee shop on the roof gives you a fantastic view over the muddle of rooftops of Marrakesh

Relaxing and interesting. Really good exhibiton and very informative guide to introduce you to the collection. The photographs are of excellent quality and the buiding has a lovely feel about it. A roof top provides good place for lunch.

Our most enjoyable Marrakesh visit. The photographs are great and the view from the terrace to the Atlas mountains on a clear day is outstanding. We even enjoyed the hour long videos from the 1950's. The only place we went that I didn't feel we were being oversold.
Be sure you stay for lunch. The museum itself is quite nice, but keep going up to the roof top and enjoy a lovely lunch and great views of the city

Real gem!. La Maison de la Photographie is a tiny great photographs museum that celebrates Moroccan culture and people. The guys running it are very friendly and helpful.Photography lovers: it is well worth visiting! Even if, like us, you get to it from the wrong side of the Medina and have to go through smelly carcasses and starving horses :(The museum also has a roof terrace that serves great lunches with an amazing view of the whole city. Highly recommend it!

A tranquil oasis in the madness of marrakech. The rooftop bar looked fab, the guys running the exhibition are very very friendly, the images are fantastic, dating back 140 years, wished i could have stayed longer

a gem worth digging out. When we visited La Maison de la Photographie, the owner manager was there and was very happy to give us a short introduction to the collection. The photographs are fabulous and are displayed in a beautifully restored old riad. It is such a pleasure to come across a tourist attraction that has been developed out of love for a country and for its culture like this place. It's really near the madrasa and the Musee de Marrakech as well as a street of old Fundouk (caravanseraie), so you could easily spend a good half or whole day exploring this neighbourhood. Just load the map on your smartphone (or have one in your pocket) and ignore the young jobless who try to direct you in the opposite direction (towards 'the Square', or so they'll have you believe).

We Loved It. We found it a bit hard to find, but that's pretty much Marrakech, right? The introduction to the collection by the "curator" or manager was fascinating and helpful. Yes, the collection is of a modest size but interesting and well worth seeing, particularly for those with an interest in the old Marrakech or photography. Beautiful reprints of vintage photos make wonderful gifts and souvenirs.

Nice little museum with great rooftop café. Nice little museum with great rooftop café. It's relatively cheap (ticket can be reused during your stay), quick to see and cast light on both Marrocan history, it's people - and of course photograhy.
The view. The roof top is AMAZING. A must do.First have a look at the photos, then go snack and refresh on the roof top and admire the view.

A jewel. This was a high point of our visit. A beutiful location full of intriguing prints and exceptionally courteous staff. Had the old-world feel that much of tourist Marrakesh lacks. And a fantastic rooftop terrace. Go towards sundown and have a hibiscus tea. Mmmm

Well worth a visit. The Maison de la Photographie houses an excellent collection of old photographs featuring scenes of daily life and people in Morocco in days gone by. The collection is well laid out in a tranquil, restored riad which has a lovely roof top terrace with a small cafe and is a good place to photograph Marrakesh. It's located not far from the Medersa Ben Youssef and is well worth seeking out. The staff are very knowledgeable.
