Must see for any photographers & great food as well. This is an attraction that any visitor to Marrakech should make some time to visit but especially if you have an interest in photography. They have a great selection of images from a variety of antique mediums and everything is very well displayed.To top things off, the roof-top terrace serves excellent food at starving student prices, in fact my wife and I both agreed it was the best meal we had and we'd previously dined at the very much up-market restaurant nearby.

Very interesting. The photography museum is a nice place to escape the hustle and bustle of Marrakech for a while. They show old pictures of Marrakech and Marocco and it's possible to buy excellent reprints from old negatives.The rooftop is nice for a view over the north of the Marrakech medina.

If you love Morocco and Photography then this is for you !. A few minutes walk from the Museum & Medersa....and just past Le Foundouk Restaurant, you will come across this unique, partly renovated building housing photographs and equipment covering life in Morocco from 1870 through 1950. You will receive a warm welcome and a short talk by one of the young men there. As well as the many Photographs on display there is a small area where videos of Moroccan life are shown. You can buy Prints of the Photographs on display and there is a seating area on the rooftop Terrace where you can buy light refreshments and look out over the rooftops of Marrakech and Atlas mountains in the distance. When you buy your ticket (40Dhs) you can use it again on a return visit, if you wish. No photography of the exhibits are allowed, although you can take photographs of the building and rooms.

Nice and relaxing place. A must if you like photography. In a partially renovated riad, close to the Ben Youssef Medersa, you are presented with magnificent photographic prints of the end of the XIX century and the first half of the XX century, plus some (DVD) motion pictures from the late fifties, all Moroccan in subject.A stunningly detailed héliogravure of a Marrakech souk by Flandrin in the thirties stands out in the first floor. A stereoscopic image of a water seller in Djemaa el Fna awaits the curious in a cabinet in the ground floor. The upper terrace offers a view of the surrounding medina, up to the Atlas if the weather is clear.When looking for the museum avoid the spontaneous guides who direct you to the tanners.

Indiana Jones couldn't assemble a better collection. The photography in this collection is a rare look into the Morocco of old, bringing to mind scenes from Raiders of the Lost Ark, minus the assassins of course. It's truly amazing to look at early color photographs of Tangier and Marrakech, at times when little (if any) outside sources had access to the wonders of Morocco's main cities.It's a fascinating glimpse into the country's history, but it also reinforces just how little some things have changed. Djemaa el-Fna is instantly recognizable from a century past, and even the Medina bears a striking similarity to its modern incarnation, albeit with slightly more advanced goods up for sale.The staff is young and multi-lingual, and they're eager to answer questions about the collection.
Nothing really striking. Relatively small collection of passed photographers. Some nice portraits though. The rooftop bar has a nice view.

Wonderful collection. The Maison de la Photographie houses a wonderful collection of old photos of scenes of daily life and people in Morocco in days gone by. The collection is well laid out in a tranquil, restored riad which also has a lovely roof top terrace with a small cafe. It's located not far from the Medersa Ben Youssef and is well worth seeking out. The staff are lovely and very knowledgeable.

Photographic History. Here in a typical Riad are gallaries of of old prints depicting old Morroco and Marrakesh, and Berber Tribesmen, not hours of studying is required but well worth a visit, good view from the roof terrace where is is also a small cafe
interesting. little museum with old pictures and movies. Lovely terrace with a great view. A mint tea is a real pleasure here !
My Favourite. Even if you are not a photographer, you really can't miss this incredible place. Very friendly people as well.I highly recommend it.

Very interesting if you can find it. This is north of the Souk, not far from the Museum of Marrakech, and it's worth it if you can find it. It has black and white photos dating mostly from the 1920s to the 1050s, of tribal peoples and of Marrakech. It is well laid out and well explained
Marrakech's past. Great insight into old Marrakech through photo collection. Amazing views over the medina from the top

culture in the midst of chaos. take your time...sit and soak up the amazing decor and artifacts. Marvel at the buildings interior architecture and adornments and pass critical comments on the art works. Cool and tranquil retreat from the outside hustle and bustle that is Marrakech.

Great old photographs of Marrakech and Morocco. Several people told us this was closed to get us to not go. I guess they wanted us to stay and shop with them. We went straight to the top for tea and a view off the terrace. We made our way down looking at vintage photographs of Marrakech and Morocco. It was a great stop.

A window into the past. I arranged for a group of photographers to visit here to explore the pictures and have lunch on the terrace after a morning of shooting in the medina. The old photos were enchanting and inspirational...Lunch was pretty good too!

Lunch on top of the Medina. This is a well worth visit.
Not just for the photographs and memorabilia equipment but the terrace rvafe was a great find.
they do 1 fixed menu a day, when its gone its gone. about £6 a head with stunning views out over the rooftops of the Medina.
Old time pics. Worth visiting if you have an interest in portraits of a historical nature. It is a little out of the way and requires some walking to get there.

Love this place.... It is such a welcome break from the madness outside and the collection of photography is really interesting.Upon paying the entrance (40 dirham per person but reusable) we were give a 10 minute tour of the ground floor and the exhibits of show, which really set the seen. From there you wind up through the riad which houses collections from different photographers. Once your done they have possibly the best roof terrace in Marrakech with the most stunning views of the atlas mountains. Take a seat, relax and order a tagine for about 40 dirham! It was the best tagine I had whilst in Marakech and was great place to chill for a while and soak up the views. Highly recommended but to ensure you get a seat on he terrace you may want to arrive slightly after the traditional lunch hours as we did as i imagine it would be bus around lunchtime.

Maison de Photographie, Marrakesh. This museum, located within the medina, houses a collection of remarkable photographs dating from early in the nineteenth century to the 1930s. The images are beautiful and illustrate many aspects of life in Morocco. They are amazing both aesthetically and technically. The films from 1957 are also a joy to watch. I really enjoyed our visit to this museum. A wonderful gem. We spent a long time here - 3 hours - but we did enjoy a drink in the small cafe up on the roof.
wonderful. Loved all the photos and the ambience. Loved Marrakech and viewing the various photographs. Truly wonderful

A small gem of a museum in the Medina. The museum has an interesting collection of old photographs of Morocco, including many of the Medina in Marrakech and the nearby Atlas mountains. It is housed in a lovely old Riad with a superb roof terrace with 360 degree panoramic views across the Medina. The tiny kitchen upstairs serves a simple but delicious and very cheap 'menu du jour' and light drinks while you take in the view.

Fantastic. Being a keen photographer, what is there not to like about this place! Even if you're not a photographer, its still a fascinating place with its collection of old photographs of Morocco. The guys in the gallery are super friendly and informative, and the rooftop restaurant was my favourite in Marrakech. Good food and a cracking view. A couple of my best pics were taken from there.

Nice place. Thanks to man from museum we got wonderful background to interesting reflections about history of Morocco. He told us about wonderful pictures and stories related with. Thanks.After visiting museum, go to the roof. Stunning views like from Riads. And tasty food. You can plan lunch there during your cityviews.

Nothing has changed. This place is easy to find as it is a ten minute walk down from the Ben Youseff school. It has a good display of photos of Morocco between 1870 and 1950. It is obvious nothing much has changed, except the clothing, as there is no evidence of jeans, t-shirts and western clothes. The display is well set out over three floors. There isn't a great number of photos, but what they do have is interesting. The documentary playing on the second floor is particularly interesting as it shows village life in the 1950s or round about that time. There is a view from the rooftop looking out over Marrekesh (roofs and satellite dishes).

gem in the medina. we liked everything.. from staff trained to explain the exhibitions to European women.. (respect and multi-lingual) , to the quality of the photos on show, to the Terrace cafe - about £10 for the Plat du jour.

Fabulous view into the history of Morocco. Wonderful collection of photographs, displayed in a very sympathetic way. You get a real sense of the history of Morocco. It is a lovely building and the roof terrace is a nice relaxing place for a drink or lunch.

Nice place, great rooftop terrace. Very cheap entrance fee, lots of great black and white photography to view. A nice break from being out in the heat to just chill and look around this place. Great terrace for lovely hibiscus tea!

Great for seeing the exhibition. The photography exhibition is far better than the Medersa or the Museum as a sightseeing opportunity. Really well presented and interesting. We were going to eat lunch on the roof but it looked like service would be slow and there were no storks in nests to be seen as promised by Lonely Planet so we relocated to the lovely Cafe Arabe instead.
Great photograph museum. Well worth a visit : Patrick runs a very interestig small museum in a lovely house : great place and informative with a mega terrace for viewing the whole city

Must visit. We really enjoyed our visit, especially having a guide from the place (free of charge, after buying tickets of course) explain the story of most of the photos. The exhibition is very good, the quality of the prints is excellent, and the story of the place is worth ur time. the place also has a terrace restaurant with a very nice view over the city.

Absolutely fascinating!. The photographs tell not only a fascinating history of the city, the culture and the way of life but also of photography itself. You simply have to go there if you are in Marrakesh, the photographs will astonish you. There is also a lovely rooftop cafe. Entry costs 40 Mad. per person.

Roof top terrace for lunch - go now!. Great place for lunch. Worth the entry fee to get access to the good food at a great price. Whilst you're there check out the photos - the city really has not changed much since 1926 (in a good way!).
fascinating glimpse at former age. Great local guide gives you a 10 minute overview - fascinating photos. Ticket remains valid for your trip and worth the price alone for the rooftop terrace cafe.

Worth a look. My visited with my sister. The main attraction is old photos of Moroccan life which were very intriguing. But a secondary thing is the building itself. It gives you an idea of what a traditional middle class house looks like. I like the central courtyard, but we couldn't have one in Iowa. There is a nice cafe on the roof from what I hear, but we couldn't manage all the steps at our advanced age.

Wonderful little stop in the Medina!. Lovely small museum housing the personal collection of the owner, who speaks passionately and knowledgeably about the early photographic history of Marrakech & Tangier. A charming property, with a lovely little rooftop terrace cafe that serves charming lunches. A perfect stop to break up the usual grind of the Medina!

Brilliant!. This is an exceptional little museum and well worth a visit. The staff are passionate about their exhibition of old photos and are happy to guide you around the gallery. Better still, you can buy full-sized copies of many of the old photos - or postcard sizes are available if you wants something smaller. A great souvenir of Marrakech - and Morocco!

worth the wander. the ticket is perpetual so if you are likely to come back hang onto it! the view of the sunset from the roof cafe is worth the climb but be aware that once the sun sets you will need your bearings to find your way out of the small streets of the area. exhibits excelent and constantly changing, likely to become a well loved institution.

Well worth visiting for great vistas and lunch. The photo's are interesting, but actually the real find is the cafe on the top floor, with great views of the whole city. The curried chicken tangine was great.
A must see. A great Musee to see photographic works by Morocaan people, dating back many years. A little tricky to find. But well worth it.

Perfect roof terrace!. Worth every penny even if only for its roof terrace which we returned to time and time again during our visit. Your ticket gets you unlimited entry all week. The photography was a great introduction to Moroccan history.

Oasis from the Madcap. The white cube transferred to Marrakech in the form of a dar with beautiful exhibit of photographs of Morocco including a sub collection of the film industy in the country. Great stop off the madcap ride that is Marrakech for a brief respite of quiet and contemplation.

Interesting exhibition in a lovely building & location. The display here provided a very interesting insight into the photographic history of Marrakech and Morocco, while the owner was very welcoming and genuinely helpful. The cafe on the roof is very reasonably priced too, and a great little refuge from the heat of the streets nearby. Bearing in mind that I'm not particularly interested in photography, this was still a great visit.

Worth the search. Hard to find as the local boys keep removing the signs so they can charge to guide you there, this beautifully restored house is full of a collection of photographs of Morocco from 1870-1960 ish. Portraits of locals, views and a repeating film of Berber life filmed in 1956, the gallery also has a delightful cafe on the roof. Run by Frenchman Patrick Menack from Brittany it is a testament to how a good visitor attraction can be created.

Very enjoyable Gallery experience. This is a lovely Gallery and the introduction to the photographs was a good touch. The rooftop cafe is great and this was probably my favourite 'tourist attraction' in Marrakech.
Very good initiative. Informed and excellent owner.Old photos give a perfect feel of culture and lifestyles in various areas of Morocco

Excellent. Brilliant museum with a great collection and very knowledgable staff- a must see in Marrakech! You also have to try their terrace which has a panoramic view of the city and excellent tagines!

Well worth seeking out. This museum is not easy to find but is well worth the effort. It's a lovely little building, full of character. The photography on display is stunning and the staff are knowledgeable and helpful. The roof terrace is great for a reasonably priced drink/snack and offers great views over Marrakech. The gift shop offers beautiful photo prints for sale. Highly recommended!

Hidden Gem. The exhibition on when we were there had some wonderful photogrpahs, very throughfully curated and introduced for us. The real beauty though was the small resaurant on the roof. It can only seat 8 or so people at a time, and has a fixed menu, but provided us with a gorgeous tagine and hibiscus tea, sat in the shade looking across the rooftops of the Medina - the perfect retreat from the early afternoon heat, and all for only 7 Euro

Great place to visit, beautiful building and exhibits. We stopped in on Eid-al-Fitr, 2012, in the afternoon, when the city was closed down and the residents cowering from 47 degree heat and bright sunshine. The staff were charming and welcoming, the building was beautiful.Note this: the roof terrace alone is worth the admission - one of the highest in the city, the views are unique.The exhibits were also fascinating, beautiful and inspiring.The descriptions of the exhibits, and the more general interpretation boards, were mostly provided in French and Arabic - some were in English as well, but not all - and more English language translations would have tipped this up to 5*.Thank you all for your hospitality during our visit, we'll definitely return when we visit Marrakech again (insh'Allah!)

Excellent photos. A lovely personalised introduction was given by a member of staff who explained what we will see in each section of the museum. It was a really nice touch that the ticket is valid to return during your stay in Marrakech and brilliant that you can purchase most of the photos in various sizes. Awesome views from the terrace restaurant, good tajine.
Beautiful place. Beautiful photos and building, very welcoming people working there. Very pretty terrace with great view of the city.
Absolute delight. Fantastic photos, amazing building, lovely place to relax away from the hustle and bustle. Good lunch too! Well worth an afternoon

Lovely vintage photos. This small museum shows a fantastic collection of vintage photos taken at the turn of the 19th and 20th centuries in different regions of Morocco. Often taken by some famous photographers, the stills show scenes and portraits of "exotic" Moroccan life.

A really good way of understanding Marrakech. Amazing photographs from as early as 1870. Lovely roof top terrace for a drink or some lunch, too. There is no aircon in the museum, so bring plenty of water. And quiz the guides, they are very helpful and knowledgeable.
Interesting. Old images from Marrakech history, take a look and by some postcard. Nice people, ready to tell you more (for free).
Beautiful photos. Beautiful photography and lovely terrace right in the centre of Marrakech with a beautiful view. Recommend a visit and a cup of Mint Tea on the terrace :D

Lovely museum with a good roof top cafe for great views. Very informative staff and interesting subject matter made this a really enjoyable visit. The rooftop cafe was a great spot to get good views across the city.
Fantastic!. A great photography museum that displays different collections of amazing works done in the beginning of the twentieth century.
Interesting. It's a small musuem but the selection of photos are magnificent and seeing what Morocco was like years ago is really worth it

a peaceful and interesting stop away from rugs, spices and babouches. Every thing
Nice photos to buy
Excellent gifts ideas
little gem of a museum. great little museum with beautiful pictures of marrakech history
Interesting. Nice little museum, beautiful old movies and pictures. Don't miss the terrace for a tea, a fruit juice or simple dishes.
great initiative. Loved it and interesting shopping to do far away from the rugs and fake antiques

Nice place with interesting photos and stories. Nice collection photos with kindest guides, telling you all about historic pictures of (people in) Morocco. Really worth a visit, for a nice rest at the rooftop also
A gem. Beautiful photos, free introduction from the staff. The restaurant on the roof is the best part, lovely view, best homemade tagine we had and very cheap!
Worth a visit. Fascinating library of early Morrocan photographs.
Nice new museum. Great staff, nice pics, well put together museum with cafe

Make the most of the roof-top restaurant. The museum was really interesting, but the best part was the chicken tagine with preserved lemons and olives, on the rooftop terrace, for only 40 dirham. Maybe the best meal we had in Marrakech!

excellent. anyone interested in photography or the old berber culture will find this a very interesting place to spend an afternoon.full of old photographs particularily of the atlas mountains and the old villages and kasbahs.wonderful portraits of berbers in traditional dress.

Interesting photos of old Morocco here.. The house( which is a riad style) includes a big collection of photos of the kingdom of Morocco, there s also a filmed displaying high atlas mt, do up stairs, great view of city of Marrakech.

art and tea. One of our first stops in exploring Marrakech. Love the history of the photography, great photos and a mint tea at the end on the terrace with a great view.
With the same ticket you can come back many times

A step back in time. Very interesting museum of photography with some wonderful black and white images to purchase in card or poster form. Also informative videos about Berber culture shown in the upstairs salon.

Worth the trip alone- Maison de la Photographie. Nearly two centuries worth of carefully gathered large original prints collected and returned to Marrakech from all across the world, along with a good, brief tour, and a delightful little cafe with a first-rate nearly 360-degree roof top view.

Great impressions of Marrakesh in the past & delicious lunch. The Maison de la Photographie is an excellent place to start your visit to Marrakesh. It gives you a nice impression of how life has been here in the past. Said, who works at the Maison, is knowledgeable and gives you a good desciption of the exhibition in French or English. They also sell reprints of beautiful old pictures - a nice souvenir and not too bulky to carry home. You should time your visit in such a way that you can enjoy the freshly prepared and authentic menu on their rooftop. The vistas over Marrakesh from there are breathtaking.

A Good Place To Visit To Gain Some Insight On Morocco. La Maison de la Photographie is a new museum that is building a following of visitors with an extensive collection of original photographs of Morocco from the 1870s until 1950s. The photographs provide an insight into what life was like in Morocco at that time. On the ground floor of the museum is an exhibit showcasing the various types of people who make up Morocco (Muslim, Jewish, Berbers, African). I loved going through this small museum taking in the images of Morocco captured by its photographers.
worth seeing. Interesting photo history of the area. It's very hard to find, so a guide or some help is in order
Excellent Museum. A captvating film by French anthropologist who traveled the Atlas and Berber villages in the beginning of the 60-ies.Further amazing portaits .
Stop for a drink and a browse. Nice roof terrace with reasonably priced food and drinks. An interesting collection of photography to browse for an hour or so. A bit of a challenge to find!
Amazing. Beautiful photographs of Morocco and Marakech and it's people from the past

Interesting Photographic History. A collection of interesting old photos from travellers of the old Marrakech and other areas in Morroco. Apparently, the tickets are valid for the whole year so the cashier said.

Loved the photos. I have many old (to me) photos of Morocco from 40 years ago, so obviously I was interested in ones from much earlier in time. Great knowledgeable staff, pity about the very high price of photo reprints otherwise I might have bought several, but not at 250dh each.

A real Gem. This is a under discovered gen of Marakesh. It is in a delightful Riad style building with wonderful photos or historic Marakesh. The founder and executive director of the museum gave us an introduction and was delightful to talk too. He is a real wealth of knowledge about Marakesh and Morocco and his love of the place that shows through.You can see the exhibit in about 1/2 hour. They also have a small but inviting cafe. and some very nice reproductions for sale at reasonable prices./well worth a visit.

Worth a visit. Nice little museum. Gives a good feeling of Moroccan life throughout the last century through various black and white photographs. Road itself is nice with a great shaded terrace offering great views over the city
This palce is a peice of passion. Whats facsinating is to see how time has stood still though the beautiful black and whit pictures in this small but charming museum. easy to find and copies can be
Highlight of our stay. Lovely exhibition of photographs with a delightful cafe on the roof top terrace, was the highlight of our stay in Marrakech, would definitely recommend a visit.
Excellent staff. A great museum with very well informed staff who were happy to share their knowledge and ensure that we got the most out of our visit

Old photos of Morocco past. Lovely old photographs attractively displayed. The view from the terrace is spectacular so go up there for tea or cold drink--or the set lunch which was a delicious bargain.

A real discovery!. For all who are interested in the history of Morocco and who love old Photography this place is a must-see. The building is wonderful, especially its terrace is great, drink a tea à la Hibiscus on the roof top and enjoy the view over the city.

Interesting collection, wonderful views. An interesting collection of photographs showing life in Marrakesh. Knowledgable and generous staff - offered us water to calm us after we got lost finding the place! Amazing views from the roof terrace of the atlas mountains and marrakesh. Yummy tagine. Useful tip - the ticket you buy allows you entry any number of times throughout your stay in Marrakesh - excellent value!, Also beware locals who keep trying to direct you back to the Souks or Tannery - we were told the museum was closed and the road was prohibited (which it wasnt!) but eventually found another way around! I think the owners are trying to ask trusted locals to look out for 'lost' tourists and direct them correctly!
Wow. What a great treat for anyone interested in photography and a pleasant perk of a roof top cafe....buy all of the postcards they are cheap and beautiful.

Visit the Museum and stay for lunch!. Lovely little museum in an old riad - it was so interesting to see the old photographs of Marrakech and be able to compare to the sights today. Make time for lunch on the terrace - great view of the city and one of the best tagines we had in Morocco!
Pricey. The entry fee and the photos on sale were expensive
Great photos, good prints and post cards. Very interesting photo expose from the beginning of photography - both the usual and the very odd.

sweet. really liked this fairly new addition to marrakech ..very interesting historical photographical archive of morrocco
situated in an old riad near the ben youseef medersa
Some very good b&w photos. A good collection of photos of the city over the past 150 years. Worth a visit.
Nice Time Spent. I liked the old photos very much, it gaves a good flash back to the great Marrakech
Worth a visit. Interesting collection of vintage photos of Morocco. Gorgeous view of the Medina from the terrace.

Nice collection and friendly host. Nice collection of photo's from historical Marrakech, It gives some extra background information about the city and its environment.
The owner is also very friendly and helpfull.
Wonderful photographs. An insight in to the history of the people and the city. Truly wonderful photographs
Nice photos, good terrace. Nice small museum. Interesting to see how Morocco has changed over time
a treasure. highly recommended, old photographs, a passionate owner who loves to connect and help others

Fantastic little place to see great photos of Morocco. not many people knew where it was but it's near the Ben Youssef Medersa. Ask the man at the ticket office here for directions. Entrance was 40 dirhams which I thought well worth it. It's a good place to have lunch on their rooftop cafe - great tagine and not expensive at all if you share as the portion is quite big.Their website is http://www.maisondelaphotographie.ma/

Paradise. What a find! This place is a must - even if you're not that bothered by the photos (they are very good) then please just go up to the roof and have some food & a book read. This place was a highlight of my trip. A must for any visitor. It's not easy to find but is very much worth the maze and getting lost.

Understand more of the culture. A good opportunity to understand more about the city and the country by seeing these photos taking you usually a hundred years back in time. Staff is very friendly and helpful and the roof terrace is a nice place for a refreshment or simple lunch.

photo museum - interesting. Beautiful photos of old Marrakech here. Hard to find, I thought. I recommend taking a taxi. From anywhere in the center 30 dirham would cover the taxi ride. This is also near the "tanneries", which were truly disgusting I found
A must see place. The museum is very interesting and has a beautiful café on the rooftop.

Beautiful riad with an interesting museum. This is a great little museum housed in a stunning riad. Three levels with several rooms and hundreds of photographs of the people and sites that make Marrakesh what it is. It was a little hard to find but that is ok when you're in a city where its better to be lost than to have a hard and fast agenda. I'm sure if I had looked in a guidebook or asked directions it would have been easier but I didn't mind. The pictures of the souks and the medina back in the day were the highlights for me as well as the architecture of the riad itself.
Cultural highlight.. Quiet and cool, historic photos of men and women living in Morocco. Respite from the bustling streets, roof terrace cafe great. Staff very knowledgeable, helpful and genuine.
Worth a visit. Great collection of original b/w photographs of Morocco. Prints can be purchased.

Beautiful photography & roof top scenery. We spent long time trying to find the place, even signs on the walls in the medina did not help. After we gave up on finding it, we more or less bumped into it. Impressive photographs of Morocco, dating back decades ago. Also, this may be one of the few places where you can view busy Marrakech from the roof top terrace. Ideal for a late afternoon drink.
Wonderful setting. A tranquil riad with beautiful and informative photos of early visits by Europeans to Morocco. Fabulous roof terrace. Stayed for lunch, service slow but food great.

Peaceful escape from the souks. Great attraction, well layed out with interesting photographs and exhibitions, including old video footage. Nice rooftop terrace cafe to escape the streets of Marrakech. Good selection of postcards and photos to buy also.

very intersting. A little museum with photgraphs from morrcain people .The latest photos are from 1956. The very friendly staff explains the museum very well. It gives you a very good impression of live in Maroc in the old times. Do not forget to visit the cafe on the roof.Ther is a fantastic view on Marrakech and the Atlas mountains.

historical photographs of Morocco. Many beautiful enlargements of original old photographs taken in morocco from about 1890 to 1960? The collector was there when we visited and radiated enthusiasm and knowledge. A good stop for some more unusual postcards to send home, to buy some posters or prints or just to have tea, looking at the snow covered High Atlas, on one of the highest terraces in the Medina.
Don't miss it!. The photos are exceptional and worth taking the time to browse around.

Fascinating. Hard to find but definitely worth it once you get there - some wonderful photographs and short films from the early days of photography as well as the 1930's and 50's giving a real insight into how life in Morocco used to be. A delightful guide and roof terrace where you can enjoy a drink and lovely views.
A treasure trove of memories. Had a great hour or so looking at all the old prints of Morocco - intended to buy one print as a memento - ended up with six!
Excellent restaurant. Worth visiting for the restaurant alone. 70 dhms for a 3 course meal with a wonderful view.

Get a map, ask enroute and enjoy. This was not easy to find but worth the visit. It is off the north east corner of Jamal el fna. Get close and ask as al it's everyone seems to know where it is.The portraits are beautiful, haunting, surprising and makes any photographer want to dash back out and get some more. Of course, that is practically impossible without either a lot of money and/or a translator.Take your time, watch the film. Buy a coffee or tagine (be prepared to wait) on the roof terrace and maybe buy a photo. They will put the larger pictures in a tube.The best thing we did, and we did quite a lot.

Excellent portrayal of early photography. Very informative, recent history of Morocco in photographs. Worth a visit, and a second, and third.... The rooftop restaurant served simple but exquisite lunch!
Fascinating, peaceful and great views from roof. Go upstairs and have the 3 course lunch for very little money, served by really pleasant guys.
Small site with interesting photos. I was reluctant to go to this site...thinking it probably boring. The displays, however, were well done and presented a picture of both history and current times.
Highly recommended. Very nice selection of pictures and history, also great terrace for a birds eye view of Marrakech!

hard to find. This is located in a very difficult area to find.
The photos are very nice

See Morocco through the eyes and lens of early travellers. Admire the beauty of the people in the portraits and see how much or how little Marrakesh has changed since the 19th century in the exhibition of early photographs.
The building is an architectural gem and the roof terrace cafe has one of the best views over the city for non muslims who cannot access the minarets.

A hidden gem. Having walked through the chaos of the Souqs and the Medina we entered into the Maison de la Photographie and breathed a sigh of relief. This beautiful building is so light, airy and peaceful with stunning works of photographie. We had the roof terrace to ourselves where we could enjoy some mint tea and wonderful views across the city.

Best view Of sunset over Marrakech. Great small museum. Interesting with beautiful photographs of Morrocco and it's people. Staff very friendly and informative. Reproductions of some fab photography for sale. Restaurant on the roof terrace where the food is simple but delicious and great views across the rooftops of Marrakech to the atlas mountains!
little gem. Fantastic gallery/museum. Staff are very knowledgable and passionate about the work. Great tagine on the terrace too ! So please that we found it.
fascinating. a super place which we stumbled on by chance. a very worthwhile place to visit
LITTLE GEM in the middle of the Medina. wonderful to be able to see historical photos of old Marrakech and compare to today. Lovely rooftop cafe to relax and see hte Atlas Mountains

Good place to learn more about Moroccan culture and history. This one year old photography gallery is housed in a nicely restored Foundouk (or caravan) building in the upper end of the Medina. This area is full of old caravan houses where traders at one time stayed the night and their horses also stayed inside as well!It is like a country inn. If you don't have the chance to experience what a Foundouk house is like this small museum is good to go for that reason alone. The pictures are okay but still educational. The rooftop terrace serves a cheap but good 3 course lunch for 70 Dh. Also it is a nice place to get a WC break in Marrakech where clean public WCs are a rarity! Entry cost- 40 Dh

Beautiful photography and a nice rooftop cafe. For us, the Maison was a wonderful oasis of calm just after we'd got lost in the northern end of the Souks. The photography is wonderful, the staff are helpful and the rooftop cafe did a nice three-course 'meal of the day' at a sensible price. The aubergine salad was one of the nicest things we ate in Marrakech. Your admission to the Maison entitles you to free return visits too. Well worth a visit and the views from the roof are great too.

An unexpected gem. I stumbled on this small museum with its interesting collection of historical images. I was made to feel very welcome and was told that having bought my ticket I could come back whenever I wanted during the rest of my holiday. The terrace had a small cafe with great views over the rooftops. I went back to photograph the sunset while enjoying a drink. Well worth a visit if you have an interest in photography or just fancy something a little different.
Lovely surprise. Beautiful house worth seeing just for that, and good collection of photographs. Curator helpful

Views. Fascinating photos of old Morocco and Marrakesh in a beautiful Riad. The most amazing roof terrace with a low key restaurant with one fixed menu and amazing views . WONDERFUL and very reasonable.
Marrakech oasis. Excellent photos of Moroccan people and way of life more than 80 years ago. Quiet and well laid out. Roof terrace brilliant!

A gem of a Collection of Photographs. Lovingly collected photographs from early days of Moroccan photography as well as the first documentary made by a Breton ethnologue in 1957. good collection of Berber artifacts.You get the feeling that someone did this with lots of loveI highly recommend this placeBecause of the visit to this museum, we drove the 40 km to the village of Tafsa in the valley of Ourika to visit the sister museum Econmusee Berbere..
Must visit!!!. To see how was the country 1 century ago. Great pictures, very well documented (unlike many other museums). A wonderful terrace upstairs, they serve delicious teas.

Amazing collection of photos. The owner of the collection is a true enthusiast and very happy to share his knowledge of the history of the photos and photography in general, it is hard not to capture some of his enthusiasm. Really worth a visit!

Fabulous!. Very interesting private display of photographs beautifully arranged and annotated. Photographs going back a hundred years or so some original and some reproduced and resized. We were given a short briefing before looking around at our leisure, explaining about the collection. So interesting to see Moroccan photos from another era. The roof terrace has brilliant views across the city. Definitely recommend Maison de la Photographie for a visit!

Do not miss this!. An excellent collection of photos and history of Morrocco. This Riad not only the highest terrace in Marrakesh (which serves light refreshments overlooking the atlas mountains!) BUT also gives a varied and unique view of Morrocan history through photography. A very low admission fee gives you access to a good couple of hours of bliss (away from the busy Marrakesh streets) and the staff are very knowledgeable & approachable (especially Siad who introduces the collection passionately to each and every visitor!). There are a number of prints for purchase which would make an excellent memento of your time in this beautiful city.

An insight into some of the history of Marrakech. This simple museum of old photographs gives an excellent insight into the history of Morroco. You are greeted and given a background to the museum and the exhibitions on display.
the place to photograph the city. nice collection of black and white pictures and the best best view of the city from the top top floor , even better in the winter

Something a little different worth a visit with some fantastic old photographs. I had read in a guide book that there was a photographic museum within the Medina. It was worth the detour away from the ornamental garden run. The curator was a well informed young man who took obvious pleasure in passing on his knowledge of the images and the photographers themselves. You can purchase print copies of the originals or, postcard sizes if you prefer. It's a pleasant place to while away an hour or so. We came away with a sense of history and having gained a valuable perspective. I would recommend it most definitely.There is a small cafe on the terrace for refreshments with an impressive view across the Medina.

Great look into history. Great museum, fantastic lunch on roof terras (good local food!) and very frendly and helpfull staff. Don't forget to check out th photo's on the first floor (drawers in the cabinet).
Must be visited. Great little museum, friendly service with a nice little roof terrace with friendly prices
Lovely spot. A great break from the souks with a lovely lunch on the rooftop terrace

Informative Visit. Thought provoking collection of historical Marrakesh images tastefully displayed by knowledgeable staff.Not widely known locally and so difficult to find but worth the effort of seeking out.Good place for a value lunch on roof terrace high above the city.

Brilliant Collection. Priceless Rooftop View.. The collection of photographs was fascinating and we were shown some magical artifacts by an attentive and interesting member of staff.The rooftop terrace in this place was beyond imagination. On our last afternoon we sat transfixed with the view. A few hours on this terrace had me head over heals in love with Marrakech. Brilliant

A pleasant find. A wonderful collection of prints through the ages of Moroccan photography history.Would have liked to learn more about the equipment that was used at the times though.The receptionist was a lovely friendly guy who found me wandering around an exhibit and came to explain to me the different exhibitions in the different areas.There's then a lovely little terrace cafe to catch some rays and relax before heading back into the souqs.Amongst other foods, they do a great traditional tagine au poulet citron at a bargain price, and don't forget to tip the waiter who has to walk up and down the tiny spiral staircase to serve you your tagines and mint teas!
Amazing photos. Although the limited collection of photographs were very interesting it was worth visiting just to reach the roof terrace and seeing the whole of Marrakech.

A wonderful glimpse into the past. Hats off to the founder who had the vision to buy up old images of Morocco. The images are impressive, a slice of history and popular culture in the past, and best of all, you can buy from the collection. Well worth a visit, particularly if you are already in the area and visiting the Ben Youssef Medersa.
simply beautiful. the photography exhibitions gave a good context to Marrakech and the rooftop gave the best 360 rooftop view of the mountains. Great postcards too.

good authetic photos. The old Marrakech its people and its life. Worth every penny and a must see when visiting Marrakech. Trip to the roof terrace with its views over the Souk to the atlas mountains is worth the admission alone
Rich archives but poor reprints. Wonderful images to learn more about the morocan history! It is a shame the images for sale are so poorly printed...

Interesting picture of travellers past.... Great place to drop by with an interesting collection of old photo's of Morocco from travellers around the 1900's to 1940's, you can also buy re-prints too at fairly reasonable prices which make for a nice decorative souvenir that can actually be displayed! Great place to have a shopping break from the souks...
Great tajine!. The photographs tell a story of Marrakech and its people in a way that is unique in the city. Great building and a good value cafe.
Interesting. Photographs from earlier days in Morocco, some of them by top-level photographers, and a fantastic view of the city and the Atlas mountains from the top floor terrace cafe.

Worth a visit.. To be honest, we didn't care much for the photography - mostly french 'orientalist' style pictures from colonial times. However, the Maison de la Photographie is worth a visit just to sit on the beautiful roof terrace, eating a tasty lunch during the midday call to prayer. The entry fee allows you to visits as many times as you like within a week.
What a find!. A really interesting museum of photography over 3 floors with delightful monochrome images of Marrakech and very helpful staff.

Peaceful sanctuary from the hustle and bustle. We had a lovely visit. It is a challenge to find! But once you orient yourself by the museum there are signs. The young guy on the front desk is a delight - giving us a full description of each room and background to the collection. The photographs are stunning and informative of how Marrakech and other cities in Morocco looked in days gone by. The riad itself is also lovely, and it has the highest terrace in the city with beautiful views in every direction. The terrace has a cafe with tea and a small selection of meals. It is worth a quick visit even if you are pressed for time.
fascinating. Some great images, very relaxing, nice roof terrace.
very interesting photo history. Found this place by accident, very good photographic history of Marrakech. Nice welcoming and informative staff. Lovely roof terrace for refreshments
Really cool little museum. I loved this museum , the french owner was fantastic, gave us loads of advice about places to go and things to do, things way, way off the beaten track

good collection and excellent location. the collection of old travelers photos is unique and allow your mind to travel to the ancient time of the region. the building is one of the tallest in the area and from its terrace you have a 360 degree view of the medina. thanks to the owner and founder , mr Patrick, for his passion and commitment
Small, interesting photography gallery. Old pictures of people and places in Morocco, very well done, including cinema

Interesting place for photo lovers. A good stop for all photo lovers, you will find a great collection of even Daguerotypes, beautiful arranged. All arranged with quite some love, you can watch movies and just walk around in your pace. Little restaurant on rooftop with the best view over the Medina, it is supposed to be the highest place.

A must see!. Excellent museum to spend a hour or so looking at beautiful photos and rest on the beautiful roof top overlooking the medina by sipping mint tea! I would give a five star but the documentary they show about the Berberes was only in French! It would be nice to have seen some english subtitles!
Interesting. The meusium is housed in what feels like a small house. The vidieo was great to see. To see old photos really gave me a feel for how morocco has changed.
serene and inspiring pause to reflect in the hurlyburly. Really worth looking out, also very good lunch on the roof with lovely view!
Don't miss the terrace views. Calm, well displayed rooms. But the terrace is a must eith views of the Atlas Mountains and the Mefina

Well worth a visit - even if photography isn't your thing.. The photos are stunning, evocative of a bygone era; a slave boy stares out of a large image with a piercing gaze and Djemaa el-Fna hardly appears to have changed over the last century. But the photos have competition - the roof terrace offers a view that's a living work of art - Marrakesh against the snow capped High Atlas. This and the lunch menu (set menu - MAD 65 p.p. - salad, chicken tagine with lemon, and home-made yogurt for dessert) must make this one of the nicest spots in the whole city. The French owner is charming and will give an introductary talk before you begin looking at the photos. Exhibitions change approx. every 3 months. Admission MAD 40 p.p.

Interesting pictures and a relaxing terrace. The photos of people in old Marrakech are all of course black and white, but are interesting to create a picture of life in this town through many years. The building is nice and a quiet spot in this busy town. The roof terrace is great for a 'poulet au citron' and mint tea, and a relaxing hour with view over the Medina.
Excellent. Awesome terrasse on top is a huge plus! Nice pictures and nice people, definitely worth a few hours visit - late afternoon to catch the sunset over Marakesh.

If you like art, good food and amazing views, go!. We went to see the photography but were not expecting to get such a feeling from the images from the late 19th and early 20th centuries. The added extra was the roof terrace that Lonely Planet sold a little short. The views are amazing, with clear views over Marrakech to the snowy mountains. The food was excellent, and such good value at 65Dh for a three-course lunch of high quality. Mint tea at 10Dh, fresh orange juice at 12Dh, and the whole thing was superb. We spent 2hrs there enjoying it all, and although there is an entry fee of only 40Dh, the ticket is good for up to a week so that we can re-visit the terrace and enjoy the images again at no additional cost.
Good enough for St. Laurent!. Lovely gardens to wander; decent bite of food at cafe.

Great photos - and great café. Try to time your visit to see the sunset from the roof terrrace! Beautiful views. The photos were wonderful and showed a Marrakech and a Morocco you don't see as a tourist. Well worth a visit.

Terrific Photo Museum. We checked out this small photo museum on our last day, and had a great time. The museum has hundreds of photos from all over Morocco, taken over the past 100+ years. The man at the desk was very friendly and helpful, and gave us a 10-minute description of the museum before we got started. There's also a roof-top where you can get great views of the city. (You can also have lunch up there, but we didn't.)

Good if you are into photography or social history. A lovely little museum with enthusiastic staff and a collection of images of old morocco, some by queen Victoria's photographer. It also has the highest roof terrace with cafe for excellent views.

A very cool loo back into Morocco history thru photos. For the 40 or so dihram it cost to get in, you are able to come back as many times as you want...according to the guy at the admission desk.The space is really cool with lots of natural light and a great terrace. The photos are amazing, really cool to get a glimpse at life and people back in the day.They have a room with a video playing, showing rituals of dance and chants. Very cool to see.

Awesome experience of bygone days through unique photographs. Probably one of the best museums in Marrakech. The collection includes amazing photographs from all over Marocco. The staff are very professional and friendly. The riad has one of the highest rooftops in Marrakech and hence has a great view over the city. It also has a great cafe whcih offers lunch and drinks. Well worth a visit!.Hightly recommended.
Unmissable if you like photos. Fascinating photos, and the best views of the Marrakech skyline from the rooftop cafe.

Don't miss this !. If you want a flavour of by-gone Marrakesh this is the place to be, though many old photographs are very similar to present day street scenes.The curators speak good English and are happy to discuss the exhibits. There is also a lovely roof terrace with great views.

Visual History. A little pricey at 40 MAD but well worth the cost, the combination of original prints and reproductions of historical scenes from Morocco's past are an amazing sight for the history nut and camera buff
Definitely eat lunch on the rooftop, not bad prices (excellent Hibiscus tea) and the best view of the medina in all the city
Good. I would have said this was good , but there is not an option on here , only very good and average . After reading reviews i was expection so much more , but it was interesting none the less.

This place is a must-do in marrakech. The photos alone are worth the price of admission. Add the film of the berber village in 1920 and you gave a winner. Connect with Patrick if you can. He will give you interesting background tidbits about the exhibited photos.

Great museum, excellent cafe. The Maison de la Photographie is Morocco's first photography museum. It's located near to the Bed Youssef Medressa and the Marrakech Museum, both of which are must sees on anyone's list. And the fact that it has a great rooftop terrace cafe makes it a great place to end your tour of that part of town. The exhibits at the Maison change, but seem focused on early photography by Europeans in Morocco. What we saw was fascinating and/but Orientalist. I'd love to see some exhibitions by Moroccan photographers there in the future, too. However, seeing how life was in the early C20 was very exciting. The staff were very helpful and gave us an careful introduction to the photos, which were beautifully laid out with detailed explanations. I appreciated the fact that this museum had a shop with postcards, books, posters, and more. The cafe has a lunch menu that is reasonably priced and changes daily.
Mesmerizing Photographs. Very simply displayed - the photographs are very powerful. Lovely terrace to have a drink after exploring the museum.
OK not wowed. This was rated as a top attraction in the Lonely Planet - it was fairly interesting but nothing special

stunning black & white historic photos, very friendly & knowledgable staff.. the museum is very nice, the setting great, we had coffee on the roof terrace, the views were spectacular and by far the best coffee in marrakech,A word of warning ! we found it very difficult to find even though we had printed out a map, for us the map printed out without a sign for north and the map looked as though you were going in the wrong direction, in getting a map card from the museum they are slightly different.our map printed out as les tanneurs (the tanneries) at the bottom of the map and they are actually on the east side of the souks, so if you look at the map with them on the right it works out better. with luck ?
well worth a visit. Interesting photos with a great view from the roof terrace

Beautiful. This was a lovely oasis of calm in the frenzy that is the Marrakech medina. A bit tough to find but worth it. Loved the pictures showing the history of various parts of Morocco. And loved that I could take them home with me as postcards. Definitely worth a visit and don't miss the roof top restaurant if only for the view.

Beautiful and informative, a lovely break from the full on Medina!. The only photographic museum in Morocco definitely didn't disappoint. Me and some friends spent a long time browsing the pictures, watching the film from the 1950's and sipping cold drinks on the roof terrace. Fantastic.
a museum. you can see the best pictures taken over the last 100 yearsshort film made in the 50 a must to visit
Very interesting. Interesting look at Marrakech from time gone by from early 20th century
Maison de la Photographie. Small, but photographs from different eras which gave an interesting slant on Moroccan history.
Well worth a visit. Well worth a visit to give an insight into the history of the area.

Well worth a visit for three reasons: photographs, food and views.. Not far from the Medersa Ben Youssef, this small museum of photography also provdes great views of the Medina from it's roof top and the lunchtime food was freshly prepared and very reasonable priced. The curator at the museum gave of his time to explain the history of the photography on display. Well worth a visit to this museum which has only been opened for a couple of years.

Beautiful view from the terrace at sunset. Worth a visit for the view from the terrace, take a break from the sight-seeing and the opportunity to grab some lunch or have a mint tea & of course to look through the fabulous images of Marrakech and to buy a few prints.

Unexpected treat. Loving photography I arrived prepared for a few photos in some nondescript room. Not at all the case. Charming man welcomed us and explained the history and layout of the ancient building. You wind your way upwards passing both black and white as well as colour photos of Marrakech in all its poverty and splendour. Fabulous studies of individual profiles - haunting photographs of eyes projecting the souls of the subjects. Pictures of times gone by. Wonderful. Totally surprised by the expansive views from the roof where a tiny restaurant/tea room awaits. You can lounge on cushions and eat a delectable tajine of lemon chicken followed by lucious pastries and either coffee or tea. We spent an hour here eating, relaxing, enjoying the view before re-entering the fray of Marrakech's medina. Entry cost (60 dhms) allows you unlimited entry during your stay - so you can go back as often as you wish - the roof-top salon alone is worth it.

In-depth view of 19th century Marocco.. After a dissapointing experience with some salesmen in Marrakech we stumble upon Maison de la Photographie. Patrick, the owner was quick to lend us some wise words regarding cultural differences which completely changed our views (and the rest of our holiday) on Marrakech. Later that week I descided to go back and take a look inside the museum. Both Patrick and his assistants are eager to take you on a trip through 19th century Marocco telling you all they know about the intriguing photographs they have. I won't spoil the fun by telling to much, but make sure to stop here and take time to see this. If only for the view from the roof-terrace. And if you go, make sure to ask the owner about the map of Marocco and Spain that you can find in a dark corner of the staircase. This is a very interesting story.
Worth a visit if you are interested in vintage photograhs and history. Located in a beautiful Riad! Worth a visit if you are interested in vintage photograhs!

Gorgeous, calm, and really relaxed. We visited and really enjoyed the experience. The exhibits are phenomenal; the photographs are stunning, really evocative of another era. The building itself is stunning, full of beautiful tiles and typically Moroccan featuers, whilst maintaining a beautifully cool and relaxing atmosphere. This was a welcome relief from the madness of Marrakech after having stayed there for almost a week.In addition, there is a lovely roof-top terrace cafe, with lovely scattered floor cushions and low tables. The other major plus point for the museum is the professional way in which it is run. The owner was incredibly friendly and welcoming, as were the staff; really knowledgeable and enthusiastic about the exhibits, but without the pushiness that seems usual in the rest of the Medina. We felt made completely welcome and were left to enjoy the photographs at our leisure, without being hassled to buy tours or souvenirs.The price is very reasonable, and this was the high point of our holiday.
Nice stop. Great selection of period photos from the romantic era of travel.

Gorgeous photos housed in a beautiful space. This place is a gem. The entrance is more than most museums and sites in Marrakech but it's well worth a visit. The black-and-white photographs are displayed beautifully throughout the riad. They say a photo is worth a thousand words and the photos here certainly are. If you've spent time in the museum you'll certainly find it interesting to see the contrast between the old photographs and the medina today.

Great space / building. Exhibition changes regularly. Really lovely , cool , airy space with amazing photographs. Ticket lasts your whole stay so you can revisit a different day. Amazing views from roof terrace which has a small menu of drinks and snacks.

Best views in the city. The museum is quite hard to find but definitely worthwhile. We were give a tour by the staff and the exhibitions are clarly set out. The real jewel is the roof top cafe which has the most amazing 360 views of the city. Well worth a visit

Best Find in all of Marrakesh. This place is definitely worth a visit. The photography is absolutely stunning and the prints that you can take away are one of a kinds. The staff are amazingly friendly and the building is fascinating. It was a lovely break from the hustle and bustle too.

Absolutley fantastic. Such an amazing place....not only an interesting and beautifully curated exhibition but exceedingly intelligent and interesting staff and a real gem of a roof top terrace.As much as we loved the exhibition the terrace and the staff were the real find - the terrace had amazing views, we lounged on cushions and enjoyed one of the best tagine of our trip. To be honest we could have stayed there all day. We really enjoyed chatting with the staff and then as we were leaving had the pleasure of meeting the owner who was an incredibly interesting and friendly guy with whom we wish we'd had longer to talkto.A real gem and not to be missed.

Best part of our trip. My mum and I were in Marrakech for 2 weeks and we did loads of things, this by far being the best! We actually almost didn't go as we weren't sure if it was really our thing but one day we had had enough of the souks and decided to try to find the museum. It is pretty easy to find, head up the main souks street off the main square - if you get lost, politely greet a shop owner with "Salam Alaikum" and ask which way to Medersa Ben Yousef (an old school), they will be more than happy to point you in the right direction - failing that someone will most likely offer to take you for a very small fee - this is what we did the first time we visited the museum as we were hopelessly lost! Once at Medersa B.Y. the museum is signposted and is about 5 minutes away. Entry is only 40 dh if I remember correctly. Stepping into the museum is a welcome relief from the mopeds and the heat, helped very much by the relaxed and welcoming atmosphere. The owner(s) of the museum are lovely and we were given a tour of the ground floor photographs in english, the photos date back to the 1800's and depict people that had been abducted for slavery, regal looking women, all sorts. There are more pictures on the second floor and then on the third floor is access to the roof which has an amazing view overlooking the city where you can have a cup of tea. We went to the museum twice (didn't take enough money for all the things we wanted to buy the first time!) and were invited back for a cup of tea to watch the sunset and to see the city light up but unfortunately we fell ill and couldn't make it - I imagine it would be the nicest place of all the cafes overlooking the city to see the city change from day to night. We came away with 4 beautiful and highly professional prints and some posters which are also great quality. I hope the people we met at the museum read this review - it truly was the highlight of our trip, thank you!

A very special place in Marrakech. There's too much to be said about the Maison de la Photographie and what a great initiative it is, so I can only suggest you go and experience it yourself as I have done to everyone that has asked me what they definitely should not miss when visiting Marrakech.Not only will you be treated to a wonderfully curated exhibition of beautiful pictures of a bygone era in a wonderful little building, but you'll also be able to enjoy one of the most amazing views of the Marrakech rooftops from its terrace. The traditional food is excellent! Don't miss the chicken and lemon tagine or the berber yoghurt!
Not only for photography enthusiasts. History, tradition and discovery of Morocco (the films on show). A tea on the panoramic terrace in the center of the Medina adds to the pleasure of the visit.

Not to be missed, highly recommended. Ne manquer pas cette musee superbe!This gem of a museum offered hospitality and culture in equal measure.The rooftop terrace offered a superb 360º view of the city and mountains; with refreshments available as well, it was a welcome respite from the local streets where "helpful" guides were more than usually insistent on directing one to the tanneries; there was no limit to how long one could stay and relax. Staff were shorthanded on the day we visited but I believe it's possible to eat there as well; we had cold drinks.For the holiday visitor: highly recommended, a little awkward fo find if you haven't got the hang of the souks but clearly signposted from the Medersa Ben Joussef.The owner/curator was on hand to offer an indepth introduction to the collection which changes periodically; for the serious student of photography or ethnography this is a very important collection of Moroccan photographs, photographic techniques, information on photographic history, source of information for Moroccans on their own history. The collection is put together with passion and dedication, photographs on three floors.It was a cultural highpoint of our visit to the city, far more informative than the local standard.

a must when in Marrakesh. Very interesting insight into the past of Morocco through a collection of wonderfully interesting and well captured photographs. If you enjoy photography this museum is a must visit. Easy to find, well sign posted from Madusa Ben Youseff and very friendly staff who speak excellent English and even information cards in English ( we found most museums in Morocco to only give information in Arabic and French.)

A labor of love. This is a small gem of a museum, recommended by the concierge at our hotel. You can see they don't have the same budget or means as a larger institution, but one senses the love the people who run this place have for photography and the museum's impressive collection. It is located near the Medersa ben Youssef. You can easily see everything in less than an hour. Definitely worth a visit -- you are taken back in time and see how much Marrakech, like all cities, has changed over the years, and how in many ways how it has stayed the same! You should end your visit with a mint tea at the small rooftop terrace -- just magical.

Delightful insight in to Marocco. Treat yourself by allowing an hour or more to visit this tranquil space of photos of Moroccan past. The staff speak english and are delighted to assist you in understanding the galleries. The terrace is one of the highest so great views of marrakesh.

Great hospitality and wonderful photographs. We found the Maison de la Photogtaphie fairly easily as it was just round the corner from our Riad, however it shouldn't be too hard to find from the Medersa Ben Youssef as it is signposted. The entry fee is 40dh and it is well worth it. We must have looked rather hot as Patric, the owner, gave us some water and some delicious fruit (not quite sure what they were!) to cool us down while he introduced the collection to us.The museum is within a typical Riad, with three floors and a roof terrace as well (where you can have lunch). The rooms all have specific photographs, and the to floor has comfy cushions and a video (in French) plays on a flatscreen about the Berber villages and life in the mountains. Most of the literature is in French, however each individual photograph has its description also in English. Even with my awful French, I still enjoyed watching the video of the Berber villages.Overall, this is far more than a museum, its an experience!

Worth the trip. There is no doubt that it is worth the trip to look at all the aamazing photos. After looking at everything there is great roof top patio that gives a great look at the city. You can even eat and have a drink. You will get lost we mapped it out as best we could and got within 100 meters and still had to have kid show the rest of the way, we gave him 20drm when we got there.

Worth the effort to find it. I am a professional photographer who loves to look at all photography, old and new. A poster in a Riad led me to want to find this museum, and I was not disappointed. It took a bit of effort to find, but there were signs at most of the places we might have made a wrong turn. I loved the photos on display, and spent some time looking at everything in the flat files as well. I ordered about 10 to have shipped to me in the States.....I liked them that much! The prints aren't editioned, but they aren't expensive either, and I certainly want to do my part to support this labor of love by Patrick, the charming owner, and Hamid, his partner who handles the printing. The place is a lovely oasis, with only old photos for the time being, but I think the plan is to incorporate more modern things as well. I would definitely recommend any visitor make the trip to the museum.....the journey is an added bonus, as you get off the beaten tourist track.

Bad prints. This museum is indeed lovely. The quality of the prints in the shop is however dissapointing together with the fact that we spotted some of the postcards available by other retailers around the medina for a lower price.

Amazing museum. Got lost looking for the Musee de Marrakech and ended up following the signs here! Best getting lost experience I've had! A very warm welcome and introduction to the displays and the photographs are incredible, so pleased there is something like this to see. Great views from the terrace too. Will be recommending this to everybody I know going to Marrakkech.

A wonderful find, a treasure!. A friend and I stopped in to the Maison to ask directions to the Medersa: the best idea we've had in a long time! The curator was extremely welcoming and helpful. He invited us to view the rooftops of Marrakech from the roof terrace. Oh Lordy, it took my breath away - a view I will treasure forever, a moment in my life I will never forget!!! We were invited to return at sunset, so, we came back the next day with our partners (we had raved about the place). Sunset was breathtakingly wonderful, it easily competes with the Cafe de France as a viewpoint.Combined with the Medersa, the Museum de Marrakech, and the Koubba, this is a memorable package and its right in the middle of the real Marrakech. Pay! Go Today! You won't be dissappointed

Worth a visit.. The Museum is right behind the Medresa ben Yosef, once you step in, you re welcomed by Patric, who give you an insight of displayed 19, 20 Century photographs, there s also a 1957 filmed journeys on the High Altas Mt, the medina view from terrance s OUTSTANDING. food and drink re under requests, would highly recommend going there.Cheers

Diamond in the Rough. The Photography Museum is an oasis from the madness of the souqs. The museum allows a peaceful place to admire photos from the past. And, it's more than just the collection...eat lunch (excellent food) on the rooftop terrace with a bird's eye view of the city.

Great Images and excellent views.. If you are interested in a bit of a visual photographic history of the country then you must see this place. 3 levels to get through to see a great collection of images. No images post the 1950's unfortunately which I would like to see. Maybe elsewhere?Well worth the price paid for entry and the staff are friendly. One of the highest terraces in the medina with views in all directions, the view may well be worth the money alone.

Wonderful museum, incredible views from the roof terrace and good food.. The Maison de Photographie was such a find. Tired of tramping the streets and alleyways we found our way to this haven of peace and interest. We had not expected such a wonderful exhibition. It is simply laid out with no pretensions other than to let the photographic images speak for themselves. And they are eloquent and moving. The staff were friendly, informative and welcoming. We were blown away by the views of the Atlas Mountains from the roof terrace where we had a delcious lunch and ended spending about 2 hours just sitting and enjoying the views, the sun and the relaxed conversation with fellow travellers. It is a truly laxing corner in this busy city. Go and see for yourself!

Amazing!!. What a fantastic place, a real jewel in the bustling alleys of the medina.Patrick and his staff were wonderful, and if you buy an entry ticket you can go back as many times as you like.There are copies of images to buy but my friend and I asked for copies of prints that we like. 24 hours later our prints arrived and we sat in the cool courtyard looking at out prints. Wonderful!The maison also has a wonderful roof terrace where drinks and lunch can be served. The perfect place to end a busy day sightseeing and shopping in the souks.Highly recommended.

Unmissable photographic exhibition, with many images from 19th Century Morocco. Patrick, the proprietor could not have been more welcoming and helpful with advice & tipsfor us as first time visitors to Marrakech while enjoying the wonderful view from the roof terrace.

Ho-Hum Museum with a Nice Terrace. The entrance fee was 40dh, which is quite expensive in Morocco, as most government-run museums and attractions are 10dh. Whatever. I still went in. The young man (perhaps the manager?) in the entrance was very friendly and pleasant. The building is laid out in Moroccan-riad style: Central courtyard with a small fountain, open to the sky with small rooms directly surrounding it. There were movie posters and an old film projector on display there. Pictures were hanging on the walls, neatly lined up and organized. It was OK, but hardly impressive by any stretch of the imagination. There were 3 floors of photos on display.The REAL selling point of this place was the roof terrace. There are traditional cushions for sitting on the floor, carpets and low tables in the sunshine but also shade from the sun, if required. Refreshments can be served on the roof as well. Nice views of the High Atlas Mtns. and the medina too.All told, the entrance fee wasn't really worth it, but the terrace was a relaxing spot to just chill and converse with the fellow travellers who happened to be there at the time. Not a "must-see" stop in Marrakech, but if you happen to trip across it, check it out for a calm and panoramic terrace view away from the crowds.

Great pics and fab view. Really enjoyed seeing the history of the city captured in pics ... A new museum as it has only open for a year or so. Warm and welcoming ... Great collection worth a stop and make sure you have a drink on the roof deck bc some of the best views of town!

Only if you have really run out of things to do.... We spent more time finding this place than we did inside it... and I have a love of photography. The collection is ok, but not presented in a particularly interesting way....on one floor there are just a set of drawers filled with photos. The rooftop terrace was described as a delight, but it was very crowded (the owner would let in for free people who said they just wanted to visit the terrace).

Don't miss this. We just happened to see a flyer for Maison de la Photographie and I'm so glad we did. 3 floors of amazing photos and the owner is incredibly interesting to talk to. Have lunch on the roof top!

Fantastic jewel. This is an amazing place. It is set on 3 floors and has a roof terrace which offers very good, and good value, fixed menu food, offering great views over the Medina. Once you get into the general area where it is located, there are clear signs directing you.The curator met us on arrival and patiently explained the collection, which although rather small is well organized and of high quality. He was clearly very passionate about what the museum had achieved, and with good cause. An exhibition of Berber photographs was the special during our visit. The collection ends at the 1950s - I think this simply reflects the original collector's interests, so do not go expecting modern works reflecting contemporary Marrakech.After working you way up through the floors, do take lunch on the terrace: if you bring your camera (and why wouldn't you?) you will be rewarded.This place is a must for anyone with an interest in photography, and equally rewarding, if you simply want a rest from the frantic Medina.

A moment of calm in the middle of the medina. In the heart of the Medina, a visit to the Maison de la Photographie is like taking a step back into the history of Morocco. The collection of photographs goes right back to the earliest days of photography and contain many very moving images of lifestyles, which have now almost all disappeared. The staff are all very helpful and there is a café on the terrace, which has a wonderful view of the Medina and where you can get a drink or a simple meal. A refreshing change from the better-known museums, which are often rather disappointing.

moving and fascinating. one of the staff at our hotel recommended this museum to us and having an interest in photography, we sought it out....our taxi took us down a dusty back road lined with artisan furniture making shops and when we could go no further, we jumped out, found our way through the edge of the busy souk and entered the maison.....what a contrast....quiet and peaceful and lined with amazing images of the people and places of old Morrocco....evocative and fascinating.....the owner, a Frenchman Patrick spoke to us and after offering us delicious iced tea, he explained that 60% of his visitors are from the UK...he also told us about the sister museum in the Atlas mountains and how to get there but we didn't have time on this trip to make that journey.....but we will next time.....
